abstract: The Seymourites of the Eastern District of Brooklyn held a mass meeting last evening, at the corner of South-seventh and Fourth streets. At 7
lead_paragraph: 1/2 o'clock Washington Hall was titles to repletion, and a respectable crowd in point of numbers assembled around the outside stand, in front of the budding. The usual concomitants of such demonstration -- flags, pyrotechnics and music -- were brought into requisition. These attracted a large assemblage, which may be classed as one-eighth Republican-Union, one-fourth non-committal and the balance Seymourite.

abstract: As an unfaltering supporter of the National Democratic creed, I respectfully announce myself as a National Democratic Union candidate for Congress from the Fourth Congressional District. That creed is founded on the eternal principles of justice, morality, and the Federal Constitution.
lead_paragraph: I shall be glad to receive the suffrages of all who believe, with me, there can be no permanent tranquillity in this country until the Federal Constitution is restored over every inch of our former territorial limits, and who regard the separation of these States,and the consequent overthrow of this Government, a calamity little less disastrous to the human race than the overthrow of the Christian religion.

abstract: There is then a prospect of a mighty vote in city and country next Tuesday. The people are at last finally aroused to the real character of the issue. The brief period of earnest discussion has ventilated the field wonderfully. The dust and the smoke which
lead_paragraph: the Seymourite leaders early contrived to raise has been dispelled, and the real principles and aims of these men now stand out in clear relief. It has been made perfectly evident that these leaders mean to weaken and paralize the arm of the President -- that they seek to distract and divide the loyal sentiment of the North -- that they desire to convince foreign nations that there is not spirit enough left here to oppose intervention -- that they purpose to make all things bend to the one sole consummation of a speedy peace -- that they will give or take any terms, and that the whole practical result of their policy must be the yielding to the rebels of everything they have struggled for, and the making them entire masters of the situation. The demagogues themselves have discovered that it is useless for them to try to hide their real motives longer. They have dropped all their first clap-trap about the more vigorous prosecution of the war, and now do not stick at proclaiming that the sooner it is abandoned the better. The have devoted their later labors particularly to fixing the responsibility of the existence of the war upon the Abolitionists, and to maintaining that the war is only continued to realize the ends of the Abolitionists. There can hardly be a doubt that if the canvass were continued a month longer these leaders would come square up to the Beauregard mark, and not only denounce the war as an Abolition war, but denounce as Abolitionists every officer and soldier engaged in it. That audacity would be but the natural climax of their present outgivings.

abstract: The third contest between these celebrated horses took palce yesterday afternoon, in presence of about 2,000 spectators, including the largest number of the regular sporting men who have attended on any occasion this season, except at the Fillingham and Ethan Allen Trot.
lead_paragraph: Both horses went under saddle, mile heats, best three in five; Rockingham being the favorite at a $100 to $40 previous to the start, which was taken freely by the friends of Butler. The favorite was admirably ridden by young BUDD DOBLE, son of the trainer and driver in the first race; while the General was mounted by DAN MACE.

abstract: A grand mass meeting, called jointly by the Jeffersonian Democratic Convention, the Republican Union Convention, and the People's Union Convention, was held last evening, at the junction of East Broadway and Grand-street, to ratify the nomination of Capt. JOHN DUFFY, as Representative to Congress for the Fifth Congressional District.
lead_paragraph: The immensegathering, in numbers, unanimity, and enthusiasm, evinced a determination on the part of the people that they would support an unconditional Union candidate in opposition to an avowed secessionist, one too, that some of the bannersstyled a "squatter" representative, in allusion to the fact of Mr. WOOD having his residence in the Nineteenth Ward two months since, and taking rooms at the Metropolitan Hotel to qualify him as a candidate in the Fifth District. Delegations arrived from the Seventh, Tenth, Thirteenth and Fourteenth Wards, with transparencies and torches, until the space in front of the platform was densely crowded. The platform itself, (built by Mr. JOHN ORR,) proved to be of stout material, in bearing the great strain upon it.

abstract: CHARLES L. BENEDICT, the able and faithful representative last year of the First Assembly District, Brooklyn, has been most deservedly renominated by the Union War Party. His competitor is THEOPHILUS C. CALLICOT, a new resident of the District, but a member of the Assembly of 1860, and an active participant in the memorable corrupt legislation of that year, for which he was indignantly repudiated the year after by his former constituents. There ought to be no hestitation between such candidates.
lead_paragraph: CHARLES L. BENEDICT, the able and faithful representative last year of the First Assembly District, Brooklyn, has been most deservedly renominated by the Union War Party. abstract: The grandest eulogyever pronounced upon the value of a good name was put, by SHAKESPEARE, into the mouth of Iago, by all odds the most consummate villain he ever drew. The master-artist was simply true to nature. FERNANDO WOOD's glorification in his ratification speech, of the eminent virtues that ought to be combined in one who aspired to represent the people in the National councils, became him well. All such characters, to be fully themselves, must at times appropriate the livery of heaven. But we are happy to hear that, despite all this high corruption, FERNANDO will probably come to grief. The ratification meeting last evening of his competitor, Capt. JOHN DUFFY, the war candidate of the Fifth District, gave excellent promise of it. The Captain has a support, which the Ex-Mayor, with all his chicanery, will find it about impossible to overcome. It really looks as if the man who has so long been a public scandal will now get his quietus. There is not a Congressional nominee in the State whose defeat would be hailed with such unfeigned satisfaction by all good and true people.

abstract: It is not toomuch to say that the presence of Gen. JAMES S. WADSWORTH, at the great meeting night before last, has most powerfully contributed to his success in the canvass. He exhibited a noble eloquence in speech and a majesty of thought that the people generally have not given him credit for. There is, indeed, avividness in his perceptions, and a contagious enthusiasm in the delivery of his sentiments that mark him as belonging to the highest class of popular orators. That he is earnest, able and eloquent, as well as patriotic and self-sacrificing in his devotion to the Union, are facts that will make the people of New-York anxious to have Gen. WADSWORTH for their Governor.

abstract: A grand Union demonstration was held last evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The house was crowded to overflowing, and outside meetings were organized for the benefit of those who were unable to gain admittance to the build- ing. Mr. TREMAIN made one of his most able, argumentative and eloquent appeals in behalf of the Union. Rev. Dr. COX and others also addressed the meeting.
lead_paragraph: The German Union men of New-York made a glorious display of strength last evening at the Cooper Institute. Prof. FRANCIS LIEBER, of Columbia College, presided, assisted by one hundred and seventy Vice-Presidents and eighty Secretaries, comprising some of the most eminent German names in the country. Able addresses were made by Gen. Wadsworth, Prof. Reinhold Solger, [???] Gernsbach, Capt. R.W. Raymond, and Dr. Rudolph Dulon. A series of patriotic resolutions was passed, and the emancipation policy of the President and the Union ticket were indorsed with unbounded enthusiasm. Many ladies were present, and a fine glee club sang, during the evening, patriotic airs composed for the occasion. At least five thousand persons filled the hall,and all seemed animated by one hearty Union sentiment.

abstract: Poor Harper's Ferry has been again the scene of one of those terrible desolations which seem to have become chronie to its existence, What sin it has upon its shoulders it is difficult to imagine, but surely no spot in the United States has been subjected to such perpetual visitations of fire and sword from the days of old JORN BROWN and his insane crusade down to the present time.

abstract: Whatever may be the present position of the main body of the rebel army udner LEE and the opinion at Gen. McCLELLAN'S headquarters still is that it is in the vicinity of Winchester there is no doubt that oar army is steadily pushing forward into Virginia, BURNSIDE was yesterday at
lead_paragraph: Purcellsville. The forces under Gens. FRENCH and SEDGWICK left Harper's Ferry yesterday morning, and crossed the Shenandoah Bridge. SUMNER's corps also moved through the Blue Mountain and Short Hills, to form a junction with BURNSIDE. Nearly all the troops have moved from the London and Maryland Heights, though Gen. GEARY's command is for the present to remain or Bolivar Heights as a guard. A reconnoissance from Harper's Ferry found the enemy in heavy force at Charlestown, and another from Purcellsville discovered them near Paris and Upperville, said to be under LONGSTREET, and Snicker's Gap was strongly defended by them. LEE is positively said to be still at Winchester, and a battle is looked for at any moment.

abstract: JudgeRUSSELL, in his speech at Tammany Hall, said that "if any man says that BEN. WOOD, because he is a candidate of the Democratic Party, is a traitor, he lies." abstract: Prince JOHN VAN BUREN, the blase political chief of SEYMOUR's staff, speaking for one who hopes to be the legal commander of the militia of the great State of NewYork, publicly advises the people to let the rebels go in peace. Thus, to use the
lead_paragraph: phrase of Mr. GLADSTONE, would JEFFERSON DAVIS create a nation. But, that nation once created and acknowledged, what peace would there henceforth be for the remaining United States? The millenium has not yet come, the lion and the lamb do not yet lie down together, as the navies and armies of all civilized nations attest. The hollow voice of a worn-out political comedian, like the heir of Lindenwald, is not likely to exorcise the spirit of war from SEYMOUR's dear Southern friends.

abstract: The second article in the Saturday Evening Courier on Plymouth Church is devoted to a description of and comment upon the peculiar institution known as the "Social Circle," which Mr. BEECHER introduced when he first assumed the pastorate of that Church. The Circle is long since done away with, but the description, as given, will amuse some, offend others, and instruct all.

lead_paragraph: Orders have been received to send the Vanderbilt to sea to-day, if possible. She is nearly ready, and may probably go. Her mission is said to be of a most important character, but its nature it has been deemed advisable not to publish. An armament of twelve 11-inch guns and two rifle Parrots have been put on board. It is notified that henceforward she will be known as the United States steam frigate Vanderbilt.

lead_paragraph: The vast space within the building was crammed -- not only every seat was occupied, but those occupying them had, in many cases, friends of the Government upon their knees -- and every aisle and other passage-way was filled. On the platform there were many of the most respected citizens of Brooklyn. Among them -- formerly and long a prominent clergyman of Brooklyn -- Rev. Dr. Cox was there, Hon. George B. Hall, Ex-Mayor E.A. Lambert, Hon. Jas. Humphrey, Hon. J.S.T. Stranahan, Edward Fish, Henry E. Pierrepont, A.J. Spooner, Esq., John Dikeman, Esq., Walter S. Griffith, George C. Parsons, S. D. Chittenden, John F. McCoy, R. Graves, Cyrus P. Smith, Horace B. Clafflin, Judge Reynolds, John D. Cocks, John E. Cummeyer, John A. Cross, Dennis Strong, John Winslow, Esq., Joseph Ripley, and many others.

abstract: A very important case of burglary and receiving stolen goods has just been developed in the Sixth Ward, and among the parties implicated is the noted "Red Drop" loan, better known as Dr. HUNTER, alias Uriah Levison, of No. 3 Division-street, where he has been located for over thirty years.
lead_paragraph: It appears from the facts, as already developed that about two weeks ago the store of JACOB RAUTH. No. 82 Chatham-street, was burglariously entered through the window, and robbed of diamond jewelry, gold watches, rings, &c., valued at $2,500. Mr. RAUTH duly reported his loss to Capt. DOWLING, of the Sixth Ward Police, who detailed Sergeant JOURDON and Officers GOLPEN and RAKER, to make a thorough investigation of the matter. While thus engaged, the officers were not a little surprised to learn that the burglars had again entered the same store last Sunday night, and stole, plated ware worth $40. After two weeks of vigilant search, both night and day, the officers traced a portion of the stolen goods to JERREHIAN DOOLEY, who keeps a thieving resort at No. 23 Baxter-street, but without molesting him at once, the officers first arrested the burglars, who gave their names as BERNARD DUREY, JOHN CAHUL, DENNIS HALLEN and JOHN WARREN, all boys from 14 to 18 years of age. The prisoners not only confessed to the commission of the burglary, and their manner of doing it, but said they sold the goods to DOOLEY. The latter was then taken into costudy, and in turn, after seventeen hours incarceration in a dark cell, confessed to selling the stolen, demands to Dr. HUNTER. The Doctor then received an official visit from Sergeant JOURDON, and after each hesitation admitted he had the diamonds received from DOOLEY in the safe at his residence. Washington street, Brooklyn. The officers there discovered and seized the precious stones, minus the settings, the latter of which were subsequently found at his place in Division street. For what purpose, except to present beautification, the diamonds were removed from their settings, is best known to Dr. HENRY, but may be readily explained on him. In the doctor's house were found rosewood cases containing 18 gold watches, 17 silver [???], 23 gold vest chains, 16 guard chains, magnificent diamond rings, pins and brooches, estimated to be worth $7,000. Sergeant JOURDON, and the officers engaged with him, are strong in the belief that most, if not all of the diamonds. &c found in HUNTER's , he doubtless tells the truth. It is stated as a fact that on other occasions he has received goods from this name DOOLEY, who is one of the most hideous and suspicious looking men to be found on the Points. After the arrest of HUSSER Thursday night, two officers were placed in his house to prevent any valuables being removed from the safe till it could be legally searched. The officers are still in hot pursuit of the balance of the stolen diamonds with a fair prospect of success. The young burglars and the reputed receiver were committed to prison to await an examination before Justice HERNNAN.

abstract: The Seymourites have held numerous meetings in this City and vicinity during the past month, and in no single instance have they been interrupted by any of the adherents of the Union and WADSWORTH, though the speeches of their orators have abounded in topics and the language of irritation. None of the Seymourite journals have as yet recorded an instance of any attempt to molest their gatherings, on the part of the Union Republican War party; and we all know that the least effort in that direction would have been recorded and immensely magnified by every journal in the interest of the Submissionists. So much for the fair-dealing policy which actuates the Union party. But how stands the case on the other side? On Thursday evening last, small gangs of Seymourites stationed themselves in front of outside stands at the Cooper Institute, and showed their love for "free speech," (which they have made one of their party shibboleths to trap the unwary,) by continual insults and interruptions during the addresses of our orators. Not content with this, their principal organ, the World, informs us that these ardent advocates of unrestricted freedom of debate, cast missiles at the speakers on stand No. 2, and that "while the missiles were being forwarded," (we quote from the World's report,) "several gentlemen obsequiously bowed their heads, and thus escaped injury." On Wednesday evening of last week, at the meeting of Republican Unionists, corner of Forty-seventh-street and Broadway, called to ratify the nomination of Col. MCLEOD MURPHY for Congress, the same class of "patriots" caused such great confusion that the speaking was, for a time, necessarily suspended; and at the meeting on Wednesday last, a squad of police had to be in attendance to prevent similar disgraceful proceedings. The TIMES of yesterday records a like outrage attempted in the Twelfth Ward of Brooklyn. We desire to make no comment on these matters, but merely to ask every honest voter the question, "Which party has, by its acts, proved itself the advocate of free speech?"

abstract: IRVING HALL. -- As, in these balmy days of Indian Summer, it is esteemed a previlege by the ladies to attend a Gottschalk matinee, there can hardly be a doubt that Mr. HARRISON's final entertainment will meet with a sufficient recognition in fashionable circles. We shall merely direct attention to the fact that, in addition to the usual attractions offered by this very liberal management, Miss CARLOTTA PATTI will make her appearance and sing two of her brilliant morceaux, being accompanied by Signor Muzio. The programme is one of the best ever offered in this City, Mr. GOTTSCHALK, Mr. THEODORE THOMAS, Mr. CASTLE and Mr. EBEN having selected their finest pieces for repetition on this occasion. The doors open at 12 o'clock.

abstract: An audience of not much less than 2,000 greeted Mr. TRAIN with enthusiasm. CASSIUS M. CLAY introduced the speaker, with a few words of complimentary acknowledgment of Mr. TRAIN'S energetic Americanism abroad; and his introduction was received with a great shout. Mr. TRAIN announced his subject as "England, Ireland and America." We
lead_paragraph: are but little American. We were more so in 1776 -- in 1812; we are denationalizing ourselves by payingso much attention to English opinion. That is partly because every American who does business in England must praise England, and forget and despise America; and thus all the Americans in England -- Barings, Peabodys, &c. -- have ceased to be Americans.

abstract: GEN. WALBRIDGEIN THE FIELD. -- Gen. WALBRIDGE has taken the field in the First District, as a War Democrat, in opposition to BEN. WOOD. Gen. W. is a great favorite in his district with his own party, and will be likely to carry a large majority of it in his favor, and at the same time unite all the elements of the opposition. He is for war upon the rebellion till it is utterly crushed, and sustains the most vigorous military measures to this end. He is the antipodes of BEN. WOOD in every particular -- in respectability, in patriotism and in his devotion to the public welfare. If he can save the City from the everlasting disgrace of the election of "Love and Secession" WOOD, he will be entitled to a Nation's gratitude. Gen. WALBRIDGE's position in reference to the great questions at issue in the election, is well set forth in his card to the public, in which he shows himself to be an earnest supporter of the honor as well as the perpetuity of the Government and people. We hope to be able next Wednesday morning to chronicle his triumphant election.

abstract: men of the Seventh Assembly District, comprising portions of the Ninth and Fifteenth Wards, have an excellent candidate presented for their suffrages in the person of THOMAS E. STEWART, Esq. Mr. STEWART is a young lawyer of good standing, great energy of character, and strict fidelity to principle. He has never sought or held office, and did not solicit the present nomination, but his numerous friends in the District urged him to accept it, and they should see to it that biselection is placed beyond peradventure. The district has heretofore been a pretty closely contested one, but, from the two candidates now presented, it will not be difficult for loyal men to choose the one who will best represent their sentiments at Albany Let them give Mr. STEWART the majority he deserves.

abstract: SIR JAMES ELPHINSTONE, M.P., and Sir FRANCIS BARING, M.P.. were present at the 108th anniversary of the Beneficial Society, celebrated at Portsmouth. on Oct. 15, and both gentlemen spoke at some length. Sir JAMES, in the course of his speech, made the following allusions to the war in America: "The events of the last month appear to me to bring the period for us to mediate nearer than it ever has been. Both parties have tried their hands at invasion, and have found that, while they are capable of defending their own soil, they are not able to hold possession of each other's territory. It appears that the line of the Potomac is the natural boundary between the two dissentient parties, and I cannot help thinking that the time approaches when the Powers of Europe can be brought together to offer to mediate. Although that mediation may be rejected, and probably rejected with scorn, still it would form a nucleus, which men of moderate opinions in America would be able to fall back upon." Sir F.T. BARING, speaking on the same subject, said: "As far as I can judge from circumstances, there seems to be, I am sorry to say, a stroug feeling in America against this country, and I am afraid the interference of this country would rather damage the cause of mediation than benefit. What may happen some time hence I will not venture to prophesy; but at the present moment I very much question whether any attempt at mediation would be taken in that spirit of friendliness in which it would be offered. I need not say that our object would be that the two unfortunate parties in America should make up as far as may be possible, the quarrel between them, and should become what they will be under any circumstanses. I believe there exists on the part of the Government of this country an earnest desire to contribute, as far as possible, to peace between the contending parties. I believe they are the best judges, know most, and have the best information on the subject. [Hear, hear.] I believe, therefore, that we may fairly rely on their judgment, and leave it to them to interpose if they see there is the slightest possibility of doing so with effect."
lead_paragraph: SIR JAMES ELPHINSTONE, M.P., and Sir FRANCIS BARING, M.P.. were present at the 108th anniversary of the Beneficial Society, celebrated at Portsmouth. on Oct. 15, and both gentlemen spoke at some length. Sir JAMES, in the course of his speech, made the following allusions to the war in America: "The events of the last month appear to me to bring the period for us to mediate nearer than it ever has been. Both parties have tried their hands at invasion, and have found that, while they are capable of defending their own soil, they are not able to hold possession of each other's territory. It appears that the line of the Potomac is the natural boundary between the two dissentient parties, and I cannot help thinking that the time approaches when the Powers of Europe can be brought together to offer to mediate. Although that mediation may be rejected, and probably rejected with scorn, still it would form a nucleus, which men of moderate opinions in America would be able to fall back upon." Sir F.T. BARING, speaking on the same subject, said: "As far as I can judge from circumstances, there seems to be, I am sorry to say, a stroug feeling in America against this country, and I am afraid the interference of this country would rather damage the cause of mediation than benefit. What may happen some time hence I will not venture to prophesy; but at the present moment I very much question whether any attempt at mediation would be taken in that spirit of friendliness in which it would be offered. I need not say that our object would be that the two unfortunate parties in America should make up as far as may be possible, the quarrel between them, and should become what they will be under any circumstanses. I believe there exists on the part of the Government of this country an earnest desire to contribute, as far as possible, to peace between the contending parties. I believe they are the best judges, know most, and have the best information on the subject. [Hear, hear.] I believe, therefore, that we may fairly rely on their judgment, and leave it to them to interpose if they see there is the slightest possibility of doing so with effect."

abstract: The Harrisburgh (Penn.) Telegraph gives the following particulars of Rev. Dr. HAY'S experience at Baltimore, whither he was taken, under arrest, by Gen. WOOL'S orders:
lead_paragraph: "Dr. HAY arrived at Baltimore at 1 o'clock, and was ushered at once into the headquarters of Gen. WOOL. After waiting some time, the General appeared, seemingly very much excited, and after examining several papers lying on his table, he accused Dr. HAY with being the writer of different articles published in the Baltimore American, remarking at the same time that they were all a pack of lies.

abstract: FIRE IN THE BOWERY. -- About 8 1/2 clock, Friday evening, a fire was discovered on the fourth floor of the building, No. 17 Bowery, Mr. ISAAC OPENHEMER, manufacturer of hoop skirts, was the occupant of this part of the building. His damage will amount to about $900. He is insured for $1,200 in City Companies. Mr. JACOB LEWIS occupied the third floor as a cord and tassel manufactory. His loss is about $1,500 upon which he has an insurance for $2,000, in the St. Nicholas and Williamsburgh Insurance Companies. The second floor was occupied by LEOPOLD HANKE; his loss is trifling. Mr. WM. ROTHMAN occupied the first floor as a feather store: his loss is very heavy both by fire and water, but how much could not be ascertained: he is not insured. FREDERICK JENISON occupied the basement as [???] saloon: his damage is about $300. The adjoining building, No. 19, occupied by Messrs. MULDOON & GUNN as a carpet store, suffered considerable from water. Their loss will probably amount to $1,000. They are insured in the Rutgers Insurance Company for $2,000, and in the East River Company for the same sum. The property on the fifth floor, occupied as a painter's shop, was damaged about $200. The Fire Marshall will investigate the origin of the fire to-day.

abstract: The Louisville papers publish Maj.-Gen. L.H. ROUSSEAU'S report of Chaplin Hills. He thus describes the opening of the engagement:
lead_paragraph: "On the morning of the 8th, on the march, Gen. MCCOOK showed me an order of Gen. BUELL, in which it was said he should move cautiously on approaching Perryville, as the enemy would probably make resistance in that vicinity. When near Chaplin Hills battle-ground, and perhaps three miles from Perryville, the report of artillery to our right and front was heard, and Gen. MCCOOK ordered me to advance my cavalry and infantry in reconnoissance leaving the artillery on an eminence in the road. I moved on with the infantry, preceded by [???] companies of the Second Kentucky Cavalry, Col. [???] BOARD, and when near the [???] of battle Col. BOARD reported the enemy in sight. I [???] the command, sent back for Gen. MCCOOK, and he and I rode forward to front, examined the ground, and chose a line of battle to be adopted if the enemy advanced upon us, and soon afterward moved up to RUSSELL's house, on the hill overlooking the field, and there halted the head of the column. [???] there, the artillery (two pieces) of Capt. HARRIS' Battery, with Gay's Cavalry, continued to fire, and small arms were also heard. GAY addressed a note to me, saying he had been pressing the enemy all the morning, was pressing him then, and much needed a regiment of infantry to support his pieces. I ordered the Forty-second Indiana Regiment to do so, and rode forward to his pieces, and found him and Capt. HARRIS there. The enemy was just disappearing in the woods, far to the front, and out of range of HARRIS' ordinary brass pieces. I then ordered up [???] with two of his Parrott guns, and he shelled the woods, the enemy now and then appearing, until finally he was no longer to be seen, and the firing was ordered to be erased. Everything indicated that the enemy had retired, and it was so believed. Gen. MCCOOK rode off to see Gen. BUELL, understood to be two or three miles on our right. Waiting, perhaps, an hour, I concluded to resume the march to Chaplin Creek, then probably a [???] our front, to get water for my men, who were [???] intensely for want of it."

abstract: Dispatches from Washington
snippet: Dispatches from Washington
lead_paragraph: It is a sad thing -- the most of us have been accustomed to think -- that the flower of the land should be mown down by the sword and the grape. The lists of the killed and wounded have struck most of us as making the gloom of that great National picture, of which loyalty and courage are the glory and the light. Mr. WILLIS surveys the scene, and lo! all that was dark grows bright -- the landscape loses its shadows. The war to him, like the world to Mrs. Nickleby's ancient admirer, is "all gas and gaiters." And why?

abstract: Mr. ORISON BLUNT was first nominated by citizens of the Fifteenth Ward, irrespective of party, on account of his known devotion to the Union, and because it seemed important that some one who was not a partisan should be brought forward, in order that all who desired to support the Government in this its hour of greatest need, might have a true Union War man to represent them in Congress.
lead_paragraph: At this meeting a Committee was appointed to meet delegations of citizens irrespective of party. The delegations from the three Wards comprising the District met, and the result was the nomination of Mr. BLUNT by acclamation. Mr. BLUNT being waited upon by a Committee, and asked if he would accept the nomination, and run under any circumstances, replied that he would. Up to this time no other nomination for Congress had been made in the District, and it was supposed that this expression of feeling on the part of the people would have caused the adoption of Mr. BLUNT by the Republicans, he having always affiliated with that party. But notwithstanding Mr. BLUNT's nomination and acceptance, and his expressed determination to run; notwithstanding he had been posted and advertised as [???] candidate, when the Republican Convention did meet, Mr. FREDERICK A. CONKLING was nominated -- and immediately, in a lengthy speech, accepted the nomination and declared his intention to run.

abstract: Between 9 and 10 o'clock last evening, a terrible murder was committed in a saloon at the corner of Rivingston-street and the Bowery. It appears, from the statement of the proprietor of the saloon, PATRICK O'BRIEN, and his brother THOMAS, who was tending bar at the time, that five persons came in and ordered drinks; that while they were drinking an altercation ensued relative to the draft, in the course of which one of the parties, whose name is unknown, drew a pistol and shot another, the ball penetrating the skull just under the nose, and lodging in the brain,producing almost instant death. The four men then fled, and the police, who appeared directly afterwards' took the two O'BRIENS into custody. The names of all the parties and their whereabouts are unknown. Deceased was about 25 years of age, but up to a late hour last night had not been identified.

abstract: Will the French invasion of Mexico prove a success? Public opinion, both in this country and Europe, decides that it will. The Mexican people are represented as being still bitterly divided among themselves. ZARAGOSA, one of their best and most patriotic Generals, has just died, and the Juarez Government is said to be too weak to offer any effectual resistance.
lead_paragraph: The English Press concedes success to the arms of NAPOLEON, and the English Government and nation appear not only to acquiesce in this result, but to relish it. This is one of the strangest characteristics of the whole affair. When at first England urged France on to the invasion of Mexico, there was very good reason to believe that she did so in the belief that it would bring her rival and enemy into collision with the United States. If such was the motive of England, it can scarcely be said to hold at the present time, for England is now acting under the conviction that not only is the division of the Union a fixed fact, but that neither North or South will come out of the struggle powerful enough to contest the occupation of Mexico with France. There is, therefore, some mystery to be cleared up on this point; for England must surely know that if France obtains possession of Mexico, or the control of that wide domain, it will add incalculably to her wealth and greatness, and render her the leading Power of the world. England, we believe, would be the last to accord such a position to the French nation.
headline: {'main': 'The French in Mexico.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The French in Mexico.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Our special correspondents at Washington and Harper's Ferry send us reports that cannonading has been heard in front, leading to the supposition that skirmishing has already commenced, preliminary to a serious engagement. Gen. BAYARD'S Cavalry, belonging to Gen. SIGEL'S rrmy, is known to have been attacked on Friday at Aldie, and from the fact that he encamped near that point at night, it is inferred that the attack was repulsed.
lead_paragraph: At Harper's Ferry, cannonading was heard, last night, in the direction of Snicker's Gap and Winchester. The Sabbath may again bring with it the account of a great battle.

abstract: Editorial says vote for Seymour is vote for Union demise; Editorial says vote for Seymour is vote for Union demise
snippet: Editorial says vote for Seymour is vote for Union demise; Editorial says vote for Seymour is vote for Union demise
lead_paragraph: Intervention is something widely different. Intervention would mean the espousal of the Confederate cause by foreign Governments and a determination to help maintain it. Recognition may come. Indeed the concession of "belligerent rights" to the rebels, early made by England and France, carried with it pretty nearly the full value of a recognition of their independence. For all practical purposes in the conduct of the war, recognition of Confederate belligerent rights was a recognition of Confederate independence.

abstract: The steamship Matanzas, Capt. LIESGANG, from New-Orleans and Matanzas, arrived yesterday. We are indebted again to Mr. HUERTA, the purser, for acilities.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Creole, Capt. COUCH, also came up this afternoon from New-Orlpans and Key West he brings a mail from the fleet. She made the run from the Balize to Key West in forty-eight hours, and experienced strong head winds and very heavy weather the rest of the passage. The advices from New-Oreleans are to the 25th ult. The purser will please accept our thanks for favors received.

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the sreamship Edinburgh, we have advices from Europe to the 16th ult., and the Arabia at Halifax brings us intelligence three days later still -- to the 19th. It was reported by the Spezzia correspondent of the London Daily News that two rebel privateers were in the Mediterranean, and that they had already destroyed a dozen American vessels, but the impression was that the report grew out of the raid of the "290" among the whalers off the Western Isles. American [???] were being very generally discussed by the British Press, and the howl for recognition was almost universal among them, Mr. GLADSTONE's views being very generally indorsed. Lord PALMERSTON had been making several speeches at Winchester, but he carefully abstained from any allusion to American affairs. M. THOUVENEL, the French Foreign Minister, had resigned, and Baron DE L'HUYS had been appointed his successor. There were rumors of further changes, but nothing definite. There, is not his else of special importance from the Continent. The sales of cotton in the Liverpool market for the week had been only 15,500 bales, and the market closed dull and nominal, at a decline of 1 1/2d.@2d., under heavy arrivals from India. Breadstuff's and provisions were both declining. Consols were quoted at 93 [???] for money.

abstract: At the meeting of the Council of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce yesterday, the question of the recognition of the Southern Confederacy came up for discussion. Mr. MCFIE, one of the members, had given notice of a motion on the subject, intending that a special meeting of the Chamber should have been called to consider the propriety of memorializing Government in favor of the recognition. After some conversation, Mr. MCFIE intimated that he wished to recall his intention on the subject --a statement which was received with general satisfaction, several members present observing that the policy maintained by the Government hitherto was, in their opinion the only correct policy to be pursued under the circumstances. Mr. BARUCHSON, one of the members of the Liverpool Chamber, who attended the recent Social Science gathering at Brussels, said that so far as he could ascertain, the majority of the public associations were not in favor of agitating the question at present.
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Council of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce yesterday, the question of the recognition of the Southern Confederacy came up for discussion. Mr. MCFIE, one of the members, had given notice of a motion on the subject, intending that a special meeting of the Chamber should have been called to consider the propriety of memorializing Government in favor of the recognition. After some conversation, Mr. MCFIE intimated that he wished to recall his intention on the subject --a statement which was received with general satisfaction, several members present observing that the policy maintained by the Government hitherto was, in their opinion the only correct policy to be pursued under the circumstances. Mr. BARUCHSON, one of the members of the Liverpool Chamber, who attended the recent Social Science gathering at Brussels, said that so far as he could ascertain, the majority of the public associations were not in favor of agitating the question at present.

abstract: Current scene
snippet: Current scene
lead_paragraph: Ma. MAYOR AND GENTLEMEN: I join with you in deeply lamenting the sanguinary struggle which we see still unhappily continued on the other side of the Atlantic; and I am sure it is the duty of us all fervently to pray the Giver of all good that He may "Incline the hearts of men to peace." and may be pleased in his mercy to stop those floods of bloodshed which are beginning more and more to shock the sense of the world. [Cheers.] You have alluded, Sir, in terms of kindness, in the address, to the conduct of Her Majesty's Government, when during the last Winter, occasion arose for the vindication of the honor of England. Sir, it is my deep conviction that, although we are a people becoming more and more attached to the arts of peace, yet we are also a people who, as respects the vindication of England's true honor, never intend to depart from the traditions of our forefathers, [Loud cheers.] Nor can any minister, I am certain, ever hope to stand before an assemblage, such as this, and experience a reception such as that which has been too liberally and too kindly bestowed upon me [cheers] unless he belongs to a Government which has shown itself both sensible in theory of its duty, and ready to apply that duty in practice. [Hear, hear.] There never was, I believe, a case more clear than that ease, in which it was the duty of the Government during the last Winter to indicate that they were prepared to maintain rights which involved, in the first place, the flag of England, but involved, in the second place, all the principles that regulate the intercourse of nations -- [loud cheers] -- and we felt, Mr. Mayor, that we were engaged in vindicating not merely a British interest, and that this was no mere matter of opinion, because it will be in your recollection that with a ready and generous frankness the other Powers of Europe, the greatest among them, above all and beyond all the rest, the great Empire of France, lost not one moment instead of waiting, as has been perchance the policy of some parties and of some States -- instead of waiting to draw some selfish advantage from the quarrels of their neighbors -- lost not one moment in taking rank upon our side, and in declaring that we were charged with the execution of no selfish purposes, but that we were, in the course we had to take, the champions of the honor and of the interests of the civilized world. [Cheers.]

abstract: editorial compares Buchanan "infamy" with Scott "honor,"
snippet: editorial compares Buchanan "infamy" with Scott "honor,"
lead_paragraph: He takes up the averments of Gen. SCOTT categorically, controverts a few of the minor points in the General's statement, assails some of his dates, accuses him of a "violation of sacred confidence." of a "singular want of memory." and of making certain assertions in the face of certain facts. But he does not touch the main point in which the public once were interested, and concerning which history will require other evidence than the small controversial twaddle in which he indulges. Was he knowing to the disunion plot of the Southern conspirators by whom he was surrounded, and was he an accomplice, virtual or conscious, of that plot? This is what Gen. SCOTT practically charged him with, and this is the question which he entirely evades. The opinions of the nation on the matter -- which were formed from the events daily developed in the last four months of BUCHANAN's administration -- are pretty firmly settled in this matter. The old functionary, however, protests his loyalty and his opposition to the rebellion --quite after the style of those of his party in the North who now propose to revive his policy, to walk in his footsteps, and adopt his manner of "putting down" the rebellion.
headline: {'main': 'Buchanan vs. Gen. Scott.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Buchanan vs. Gen. Scott.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The call last evening for a meeting in Tammany Hall, in order to listen to JOHN VAN BUREN, was a failure, In consequence of the non-appearance of Mr. VAN BUREN. The meeting was called to order by Hon. ELIJAH F. PURDY, who staled that a dispatch had been received by Mr. HARDEE, Secretary of the General Committee, that Mr. VAN BUREN could not be in town, in consequence of his having agreed to address a meeting in Washington County. The meeting then adjourned, and a private meeting of the General Committee was held, in which it was decided that the Ticket Committee should meet to-day for the distribution of tickets.
lead_paragraph: The call last evening for a meeting in Tammany Hall, in order to listen to JOHN VAN BUREN, was a failure, In consequence of the non-appearance of Mr. VAN BUREN. abstract: are divided into two camps. In the one camp, led by a soldier and a patriot, there is not one man to be found who sympathizes with the rebels, not one who has any ifs in his loyalty, any conditions attached to his desire to preserve the nation. In the other, led by a politician and a submissionist, is collected every man among us who loves treason, and would help the rebels, every one who has drawn back from helping the nation, every one who prefers Slavery to Freedom, every one who prefers a "splendid tyrant" to a magistrate elected by the people, every traitor, every secessionist, every submissionist in the State. Those who are not such, and who yet follow the banners of Mr. SEYMOUR, are in very bad company. If they prefer such company, they cannot complain it they are treated accordingly. If they dislike it, let them make haste, before it is too late to come to the loyal camp.

abstract: Matters political in the Second Assembly District are in a terrible snarl. The Submissionists have placed before the People Mr. "E. O. PERRIN, of Tennessee," ex-Know-Nothing, whose antecedents political are not such as entitle him to the votes of any save the parties who nominated him and the stock
lead_paragraph: holders of certain city railways. Also, by the Opposition-to-Government Party, Mr. BERNARD HUGHES, is nominated. Neither of these gentlemen represent the loyal sentiment of the Second District, and we would be glad to chronicle their defeat. This would be an easy task were the Union men united in a nomination. The Republicans proper have nominated Mr. HENEY A. BOWEN, a young man of no political experience whatever, while other parties, undoubtedly loyal, have nominated Mr. MARQUIS D. MOORE, a good and true man, but whose political anfecedents have made for him enemies as well as friends. The consequence is that the Union vote of the District will be divided.

abstract: Editorial on People's Union Party candidates
snippet: Editorial on People's Union Party candidates
lead_paragraph: In the call of the Union State Convention and of the various local Conventions for the nomination of Union candidates, the Republicans and Union men have acted together. Special pains were taken to secure to both a perfectly just and fair representation in all these Conventions, and the nominations that have been made do represent the actual preferences of the great body of both these parties, as nearly as those preferences can ever be arrived at. As a matter of course, individual aspirants have been disappointed in some cases, and designing intriguers, who had special political purposes to serve, have been foiled. Acting upon their resentments, and anxious to ruin where they fail to rule, these men have set on foot machinery by which they hope to defeat the Union candidates in districts which they failed to control.
headline: {'main': '"The People\'s Union."', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': '"The People\'s Union."', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Gen. WALBRIDGE's tour of his District on Saturday was a complete ovation. The electors had given up, in despair, the expectation of offering any opposition to BEN. WOOD, and had settled down into a sullen indifference as to their fate. The sudden appearance of Gen. WALBRIDGE was hailed with all the enthusiasm that men can feel and express when a great and threatened calamity is averted. We can neither find may hear of a single individual that really wishes to vote for WOOD; on the contrary, he is thoroughly detested by every class in the district. He has not a redeeming quality. Cold and selfish, he expected to make the canvass without exhibiting himself to the people. He thought he had a sure, thing, and that he could well afford to spend his time on Long Island. Such has been the force of party machinery that billeted out the district to WOOD, that resistance was almost given up as hopeless. But the change wrought in a few hours, that Gen. WALBRIDGE had consented to run, was magical. The Corn Exchange led off with a grand ratification meeting at half-past one. From thence Gen. WALBRIDGE proceeded on a tour through the district, speaking to large audiences that collected on a few moments' notice in the Second, Fourth, Fifth, Sixth and Eighth Wards. Everywhere was he met with the same outburst of enthusiasm, which was intensified as it became more and more apparent that Mr. WOOD would be nowhere in the contest. To-day, the General makes another triumphal march through the district, speaking at short intervals and receiving the congratulations of the public.

abstract: Editorial backs Ward
snippet: Editorial backs Ward
lead_paragraph: are well characterized as the Peace Party or Submissionists, and the Unconditional Union or War Party. The indications now are that the latter will to-morrow carry the State. The candidate presented by the Union men of New-Jersey -- MARCUS L. WARD, of Newark -- is a gentleman who, from the very commencement of the struggle, has given his whole time and influence to the cause of the Union, and to the interests and comfort of the soldiers in the field. Of a generous as well as statesmanlike character, his large and enlightened patriotism has been unremitting in every effort, both to sustain the Government, and to lighten the burden of the soldier. He has, without a thought of remuneration, completely devoted himself to the soldier. He has organized and systematized a method of forwarding the pay of the volunteers to their families, taking charge personally of the distribution of the money, and he has always been in advance of the tardy Government payments with sums from his private purse, reaching many thousands of dollars. He has lent a ready and sympathetic car to the wants of those dependent upon the gallant men who are fighting their country's battles, writing their letters, sedulously guarding their interests, protecting them from imposition, and in all respects acting toward the thousands who looked to him for help, as a father or friend. He has personally and frequently visited the various military camps and hospitals, to ascertain their condition, and minister to the wants of the sick and wounded. He has been the founder of a noble hospital at Newark, designed first for New-Jersey volunteers, but afterward being found by the Government so admirably appointed, it was adopted as a United States institution, and now contains over 1,300 patients from all parts of the Union. It is no wonder, therefore, that Mr. WARD is idolized by the soldiers, who have bestowed upon him the title of the "Soldier's Friend," a prouder title than that of Lord or Prince. It is the almost unanimous desire of the New-Jersey contribution to the army that Mr. WARD should be elected Governor; for they feel that, understanding their wants, and with his heart enlisted in their welfare, their interests and comfort would be greatly advanced under his management of State affairs.

abstract: Within the last ten days the Union cause has made rapid and immense progress in every section of the State. There is not a county of which this is not strictly and literally true. At the outset of the canvass the Union men, exhausted by their constant and energetic efforts
lead_paragraph: in raising volunteers for the war, came slowly up to the work. They were unquestionably surpassed by the Seymour men who had been lying back for this political campaign, and who opened it with great vigor and energy, and with great confidence of success. They have had, moreover, the aid of the Liquor Dealers' Association, who have perfected their organization, raised large amounts of money, and resolved, in State convention, to pay no attention to the political affairs of the country, but to devote themselves wholly to their personal interests as sellers of rum.

abstract: A naval officer has been good enough to send us a report of the trial trip of the United States ironclad frigate Chilicothe, which has been finished, manned, and sent to sea on her first trial trip within the past two days. The vessel left the wharf at Jeffersonville, in compliance with orders from head
lead_paragraph: quarters, for a trial trip of 72 hours, on which he machinery and armament were to be tested. The latter consisted of two tremendous 11-inch guns. Having got down the river firing commenced at various distances, from 100 to over a thousand yards. The result may be summed up thus in a paragraph. There was no unusual recoil, no shaking of decks no bursting of turrets, or giving way of gun-gear. The experiments with ordnance were, in short, successful in every sense, and the consequence is that the Navy Department is to be informed to-morrow (26th) that the Chilicothe is ready for any service to which she may be ordered on this coast. The machinery worked very satisfactorily, giving the ship a speed of eight miles an hour, or two miles more than that specified in the contract. The chilicothe is one of the "Ohio River iron-clads," and was built at Cincinnati by BROWN, MCCORD & JANGER. She is 158 feet long, 50 feet wide, and 5 1/2 feet deep. Her armor is put on in plates -- on the deck one inch. on the sides two inches thick. She has two engines with cylinders 22 inches in diameter and 4 feet stroke. The machinery was built at St. Louis. The Chilicothe is new in commission, and will soon be actively employed.
headline: {'main': 'OUR IRON-CLADS.; An Iron--Clad Tried and Reported; Ready for Sea--The Keokuk Finished.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'OUR IRON-CLADS.; An Iron--Clad Tried and Reported; Ready for Sea--The Keokuk Finished.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the steamship Edinburgh, we have advices from Europe to the 16th ult., and the Arabia at Halifax brings us intelligence three days later still--to the 19th. It was reported by the Spezzia correspondent of the London Daily News that two rebel privateers were in the Mediterranean, and that they had ...
lead_paragraph: already destroyed a dozen American vessels, but the impression was that the report grew out of the raid of the "290" among the whalers off the Western Isles. American affairs were being very generally discussed by the British Press, and the howl for recognition was almost universal among them, Mr. GLADSTONE's views being very generally indorsed. Lord PALMERSTON had been making several speeches at Winchester, but he carefully abstained from any allusion to American affairs. M. THOUVENEL, the French Foreign Minister, had resigned, and Baron DR L'HUYS had been appointed his successor. There were rumors of further changes, but nothing definite. There is nothing else of special importance from the Continent. The sales of cotton in the Liverpool market for the week had been only 15,500 bales, and the market closed dull and nominal, at a decline of 1 1/2d.@2d., under heavy arrivals from India. Breadstuffs and provisions were both declining. Consols were quoted at 93 3/4 for money.

abstract: He that is not for me is against me," said the author of our religion; and by it He meant unqualified, unconditional, unhesitating, uncompromising devotion. He knew no other kind of fidelity. There is no acceptance of duty to Him with ifs and buts. Neither ought there to be in the most sacred of all earthly obligations -duty to country. The man who subordinates his patriotism to this or that object, who makes it dependent upon this or that condition, is not a true patriot. The man who inclines to meet treason half way, and parley with it, and make terms with it, is himself half a traitor at heart. Treason is a crime which we do not compound, or compromise with. When the rebels lay down their arms, then, and not till then, may there be talk of an adjustment -- and even then an adjustment only under that Federal Constitution which is "the supreme law of the land."

abstract: -It is a sicken  MORE REBEL PRIVATERING.--It is a sicken  ing record we have, to-day, of the continued depredations of the rebel privateer Alabama, on American Commerce. Eight more vessels have fallen into her power, and six of the number have been destroyed.
lead_paragraph: And her ability seems quite as great to capture or sink eighty as eight and the impunity as perfect. Merchantmen are helpless; they have not the speed to escape a steamer, nor the power and to fight. They can only surrender, pillaged burned. In this kind of warfare, the odds are a thousand to one against us. The rebels have comparatively no commerce afloat; whilst every sea is white with ours. When they let fly a privateer, it is like sending a hawk into a flock of barn-yard fowls, or turning a wolf into a sheep-cote. The only business is to slay and cat.

abstract: Editorial holds NY capitalists will favor Wadsworth party
snippet: Editorial holds NY capitalists will favor Wadsworth party
lead_paragraph: And we doubt not this fact will create very general surprise; for the idea has got abroad in some way that the Money-Bags of New-York are strongly tinctured with secession sympathy. But a little reflection will explain the error of this view. Omitting all considerations of patriotism in the matter, there is enough in the mere selfishness of human nature to make the New-York Money Kings earnest in support of the Government and the war. Our capitalists have taken too much stock in the Government, to be willing for it to come to an untimely and ruinous end, by the triumph of Secession and the final overthrow of the Union.

abstract: Our advices from the Army of the Potomac this morning are highly important, and explain the heavy cannonading spoken of in our dispatches yesterday. Gen. PLEASANTON came up with the enemy's cavalry and artillery at Phillimont, about 11 o'clock in the forenoon, and engaged them. The fight was conducted wholly by artillery, and
lead_paragraph: lasted about five hours, when the rebels retreated to Union, a small town three miles beyond. Our loss in this affair was but one man killed, and fourteen wounded. Yesterday morning, Gen. PLEASANTON renewed his attack at Union, and being soon afterward reinforced by a brigade of infantry, at 1 o'clock the rebels again fell back, and our forces occupied Union. In the afternoon, the firing in that direction was very heavy until dark, but no further results are known. A heavy dust was observed at Ashby's Gap yesterday, indicating a movement of some kind by the rebels, but in what direction could not be ascertained. Another portion of our army took possession of Snicker's Gap yesterday, and some firing was heard there in the afternoon, following the movement of a rebel force along the west side of the mountain, but what it amounted to we have not yet heard.

abstract: We see now and then pleasantries indulged in over the phrase "Muscular Christianity." Without discussing here the applicability of the descriptive word in such connection, we hold it is eminently fit when applied to politics. There is a pressing necessity at this time--on this day--for the display of "muscular politics." It is not easy always to get to the polls. But to-day it must be done.
lead_paragraph: It is not pleasant ever to wait in a crowd for hours to get your turn. But to-day it may have to be done. It is not agreeable to have to urge up indifferent or indolent men, whose hearts are right, to the polls. But, to-day, of all days, in time, it must be done. It is not comfortable nor always personally safe to come between a fraudulent voter and the ballot-box. But whenever you can, and at whatever risk or cost, it must be done. All this work at and around the polls requires the exercise of "muscular politics;?" and however much averse all amiable, quiet, orderly citizens may be to the rough usage and uncivil temper displayed often at voting places, no patriot should sacrifice his duty to his personal inclinations by staying away and losing his vote.
headline: {'main': 'Muscular Politics.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Muscular Politics.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Harlow Roys vs. James C. Willett. Sheriff,-- This action was brought to recover possession of certain goods, taken by the Defendant, as Sheriff, in 1857. Plaintiff and appellant claims that in July,  1857, the firm of Duncan, Sprague  Brown, was indebted...
lead_paragraph: to him, for goods sold, cash lent, and his indorsements for them to the amount of $22,000. He occupied the same store with them, and was on terms of the closest intimacy with the firm. In August of that year, the members of the firm were absent at their glove factory in Gloversville. N.Y., and the clerks in the store in New-York applied to Roys for aid in raising money for the firm, and he alleges that the information he then acquired respecting their want of money, gave him his first fear of their insolvency, and made him anxious to secure himself. On the return of the partners, on the 4th of August, a [???] of sale was made of certain goods then in transit from Gloversville.

abstract: At every voting place in the City to-day a policeman will stand, all day long, with a list in his hand of the names of all persons who have sworn themselves to be aliens. If any man of this class presents himself to vote, he will instantly be arrested for having criminally attempted to evade the draft. There are seventeen thousand persons in the City who, in order to escape the draft, have sworn that they are aliens. It will not be safe for any one of these to be found interfering with the elective franchise. The result will be a quiet poll, and a considerable deficit in the Seymour vote.

abstract: The season of argument is past, and the hour of action is at hand. Within the brief hours of sunlight alloted to this day will be done the work that may fix the destiny of the Republic for generations.
lead_paragraph: We must feel that these hours of work are more precious than all others that have gone before in the canvass. A noble campaign has been conducted. The State has been broadly traversed, tens of thousands of voters have been addressed, the patriotic feelings of the people have been excited, the electors of the State are convinced in judgment and prepared, if they vote, to sustain the Government by a sweeping majority. But what if they should not vote? What if business should keep a few thousand from the polls; and rain or mud deter a few thousands more; and a crowd about the polls discourage other thousands who are reluctant to wedge their way through a mob; and delay, till too late an hour, prevent other thousands from getting in their ballots? Is it not clear that our majority may be fritted away and the victory lost?
headline: {'main': 'How Victory may be Lost in Defeat.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'How Victory may be Lost in Defeat.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Camille of Miss MATILDA HERON has been so long before the public, and has so often and so broadly received the seal of approbation, alike from those who criticise and also those who accept from long habit whatever may be set before them without any attempt at criticism, that to bestow praise upon it now seems almost...
lead_paragraph: a work of verbal supererogation. And yet this lady in her personation of the character at Niolo's Garden on Saturday evening -- her first appearance upon the stage since being torn from it by a domestic affliction, which made any attempt to shadow forth the unreal sorrows of a fictitious character something not to be thought of -- developed throughout her acting so many new points of passion and of pathos, giving to the picture so many more touches of life and beauty and tenderness than it had when she first flashed it on the stage, startling and electrifying audiences, that a few words relative to it may not be out of place.

abstract: The Baltimore American a day or two since had an able article on the "New Element of Disunion in the Field," in which filaments the "sudden expansion to formidable  dimensions of a disloyal faction in the loyal States." and adds:
lead_paragraph: "Hardly known but a little time ago, it has lately become emboldened to the last degree in its attempt to distract the North, and to throw distrust upon the Government; and unless the people watch and thwart its purposes, the mischief it may do will prove incalculable. One of the worst effects of its advent, already apparent, is to encourage the traitors in the field with false hopes -- something that cannot but tend to prolong a useless struggle, causing more loss of life and more distress, otherwise unknown. At the head of these malcontents, so tolerated, is the notorious FERNANDO WOOD, whose very name, so long identified with the worst phases of New-York municipal affairs, seems only a synonym with corruption and all that is disreputable."
headline: {'main': 'Border-State View of Our Election.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Border-State View of Our Election.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We have studied faithfully the speeches of Mr. SEYMOUR, Mr. VAN BUREN and the WOODS. We find there many denunciations and many epithets of eulogy. We hear continually of the sufferings of a small class of traitorous Northerners, who, in a time of great public peril, have been sent to prison without benefit of habeas corpus.
lead_paragraph: We listen, also, to the story of the wrongs and the calamities of Southern traitors. No words of hatred and scorn are too strong against the great party at the North who have opposed the extension of Slavery, and who now seek to destroy the rebellion. Even the old Abolitionists come in for a share of their reproach, and the poor, despised slaves, whom any man of common humanity would at least pass by in silent pity at such a time as this, are not too low to be objects of their anger and ribaldry.
headline: {'main': 'An Omission in Democratic Speeches.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'An Omission in Democratic Speeches.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The operations of the advance of the Army of the Potomac on Sunday resulted in a very important advantage to the National arms in the capture of Snicker's Gap--a strategic point of the first magnitude. This success is announced in a dispatch from Gen. MARCY, Gen. McCLELLAN'S...
lead_paragraph: Chief-of-Staff, to the President. Gen. HANCOCK's forces arrived there at 3 o'clock P.M., and found it occupied by the rebel cavalry, who were at once driven out by a column of from five to six thousand infantry. HANCOCK's Division held the Gap until night, when SYKES' Division took its place. The rebels, our special correspondent says, were evidently taken by surprise, and foiled in their intentions, which were to hold Snicker's and Ashly's, Gaps, and to give Gen. MCCLELLAN battle with these advantages. They were marching up on the other side of the mountains to occupy [???] Gap when our forces entered it, but were turned back on the double quick by a few shots thrown among them. This movement was independent of Gen. PLEASANTON's, who had, meantime, it will be recollected, driven the enemy's cavalry several miles beyond Union.

abstract: At a meeting of the Twenty-first Ward Republican Union Association last evening, WM. CURTIS NOYES, Esq., was present, and spoke on the issue of the pending canvass. He drew a graphic contrast between the conduct of Gen. WADSWORTH and of HORATIC SEYMOUR in relation to the country since the....
lead_paragraph: war broke out; the one dedicating himself and fortune, all the energies of a generous and noble nature to the cause of his country; the other, who had received a military education at PARTRIDGE's Academy, Middletown, and whose place should have been at the heat of a corps d'armee, holding coldly and selfishly back, lending no hand to help on the war, or to provide for those engaged in it, but devoting his influence and his time to the work of embarrassing the Administration, finding fault with every measure, exciting discontent at home, and affording sympathy to the rebels.

abstract: To-DAY decides whether New-York stands by the Government, or takes ground against it, and throws her weight into the scale of the rebellion. This is the simple issue. No sophistry can disguise it, nor can any ingenuity divert attention from it. It is not a matter of nice points to be argued:--it is simply a question of taking sides.
lead_paragraph: Gen. WADSWORTH stands for the Government, -- in favor of supporting it in a vigorous, resolute, hearty and effective prosecution of the war, -- opposed to needless delays, to all temporizing expedients, to compromises of every kind with the rebellion, to measures of conciliation or of peace, until the rebellion has been crushed, and the leaders in this awful crime punished as they deserve. Every vote east for him is cast for vigor and energy in the field, for unity and courage in the Cabinet, and for high-toned determination to preserve the honor of the nation and the liberties of the Republic, in the public heart. He is for ending the war by fighting it through. He is for stopping taxation by quelling the rebellion. He is for preserving the Union by crushing those who would destroy it, -- and for supporting the Government in everything that tends to that result.
headline: {'main': 'Which Side Do You Take?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Which Side Do You Take?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We have received sundry protests against our remarks on the division among the Union men of the Sixth District:--but we see nothing to change our conviction that every vote cast for Mr. BLUNT will really go to aid the election of the Seymour and secession candidate. Indeed, we believe that the object of those who have been foremost in nominating Mr. BLUNT has bean, and still is, not to elect him, but to defeat CONKLING.
lead_paragraph: We have been told, on unquestionable authority, that the gentleman who has been, perhaps, the most efficient in this matter, has said that they would give BLUNT votes enough to elect Ward, -- it nothing more.

abstract: The election of Members of Assembly that Rail derives special importance from the fact, that the Legislative this Winter has to choose a United States Senator in place of PRESTON KING, whose term of service will expire. Every loyal man feels it to be of the utmost...
lead_paragraph: importance, either that Mr. KING himself, who has been true to the principles on which he was chosen, should be reelected, or that some one equally reliable and equally qualified for the position should be appointed in his plane. To place a Seymour Submissionist in that high position for six years, would be a prostitution of the influence and power of the Empire. State to which no loyal citizen would willingly submit. The only way of securing the election of a Union Senator is to secure the election of loyal men to the Assembly; and line is the special duly which devolves upon the electors of this City and State to-day. Next in importance to the election of a Union Governor and of Union members of Congress, stands the election of the Union candidates for the Legislature.

abstract: An hour spent in the rooms of the Draft Commissioner of the Nineteenth Wars, last Saturday,satisfied us of the very through manner in which the causes are scrutinized of those persons who claim exemption from military duty. We found acting in this Ward, RICHARD A.McCURDY, Commissioner, and FRED. WIDDOWS, Clerk--Dr. VAN BUREN, the Surgeon to the Commission.
lead_paragraph: The Commission has been in session twelve days, and has had about two hundred applicants for exemption daily. About one-third of he applications are based on over age -- about one-sixth on alienage, and about one-sixth on physical disability. The remaining third is made up of firemen, preachers, teachers, members of existing military organizations, &c. The proportion claiming exemption from over age appears large -- one-third of all who come. Yet when it is remembered how many young looking men there are in the community just turned of 45, the fact will be explained. Several citizens, quite gray and old looking and swearing to ages from 50 to 62, claimed exemption and got it on Saturday in the Nineteenth Ward. The enrollment of such was obviously absurd. Others swore to being 50 years old who hadn't a gray hair in their heads, and whose appearance otherwise did not indicate over 40. Proofs of good character and credibility were exacted of all such doubtful cases.

abstract: Mr. ORISON BLUNT was first nominated by citizens of the Fifteenth Ward, irrespective of party, on account of his known devotion to the Union, and because it seemed important that some one who was not a partisan should be brought forward, in order that all who desired to support the Government in this its hour of greatest need, might have a true Union War man to represent them in Congress.
lead_paragraph: At this meeting a Committee was appointed to meet delegations of citizens irrespective of party. The delegations from the three Wards comprising the District met, and the result was the nomination of Mr. BLUNT by acclamation. Mr. BLUNT being waited upon by a Committee, and asked if he would accept the nomination, and run under any circumstances, replied that he would. Up to this time no other nomination for Congress had been made in the District, and it war supposed that this expression of feeling on the part of the people would have caused the adoption of Mr. BLUNT by the Republicans, be having always affiliated with that party. But notwithstanding Mr. BLUNT's nomination and acceptance, and his expressed determination to run; notwithstanding he had been posted and advertised as such candidate, when the Republican Convention did meet, Mr. FREDERICK A. CONKLING was nominated -- and immediately, in a lengthy speech, accepted the nomination, and declared his intention to run.

abstract: summary of candidates for Congress
snippet: summary of candidates for Congress
lead_paragraph: BEN. WOOD, of Love and Secession fame, would be returned to his seat in Congress. But politics, as do lotteries, turn like weather cocks, and it is far from good policy in outsiders to bet on results. Mr. GILSON, the Republican nominee, in a card which does honor to his head and heart, has withdrawn in favor of Gen. HIRAM WALBRIDGE. Mr. ELLSWORTH, of the People's Union, (whatever that is,) has also got out of the way, and thus the contest is narrowed to a single-handed combat between a friend and a foe to the National Government. Last night heavy odds were offered to the Wooden-men in favor of WALBRIDGE, but with no takers. The impression is that unless some high and mighty game of 4, 11, 44 is played, Gen. WALBRIDGE will succeed in exhibiting to his friends to-night the political scalp, brains and all, of his opponent, Hon. BEN. WOOD.

abstract: MURDER OF A PEDDLER.--The body of a man was found murdered on Saturday noon on the Hunterfly road, Brooklyn, near the county line, by Mr...
lead_paragraph: STEPHEN L. VANDERVEER and Mr. VAN SINDERN's residents of the neighborhood. The deceased was short, stout man, with [???] brows, recently shared face: dressed in a white shirt, light plaid Marseilles vest, dark plaid cotton pantaloons, Kentucky Jean sack coat, gaiter shoes, and black cloth cap. The cap was perforated by a bullet and the wound in the head showed that the deceased was in a stooping position when the shot was fired. The ball penetrated at the crown of the skull; and although the man was alive when found he was unable to give any account of any thing that had transpired. He was conveyed to the county hospital in the town of Flatbush, where he expired. The deceased was evidently a peddler, and from appearances, a Jew. His pack, which was a box covered with black muslin, was found near him, the various articles which it contained strewed about, and stained with blood. Finger-marks were on some of the articles, as if the murdered man tried to gather them up after he had been shot. His pockets were turned inside out, showing that they had been rifled of whatever they might have contained. No money was found; in one of his vest pockets a pair of mits was discovered. Coroner NORRIS has taken charge of the body, and will commence an investigation to-day. Meanwhile the body will be retained for identification.

abstract: For full ten years the New-York Express has proscribed Irishmen, reviled "Cross JOHN HUGHES." and persecuted the Catholic Church. One of the Brookses has been elected to Congress, where he labored to restrict the elective franchise against adopted citizens. The other Brooks was elected to the Senate of this State, as a "Know-Nothing," where is persecuted and calumniated Bishop HUGHES. The Express has existed upon its hostility to Irishmen and Catholics. It now exhorts Irishmen and Catholics to elect JAMES BROOKS to Congress. Will they do it? We shall see. But if they do, we shall witness a degree of debasement and ignominy which will make every manly Catholic hide his face.

abstract: The latest journals from the Confederacy and from England, manifest the liveliest interest in our elections, and are of one accord in wishing the success of what they call the Democratic tickets. The Richmond Enquirer congratulates the rebels upon the results of the elections in Ohio and Indiana, as....
lead_paragraph: "showing that the Northwest is weary of the war." The Richmond Examiner, referring to the New-York election, "the most important of all." says that "it is not to be denied that a Democratic victory at the North would be a subject of much gratification." It yet warns the South against indulging in "too sanguine expectations from the advent to control of the Democratic politicians of the North," representing that "while now and then are to be found one PIERCE, one VALLANDIGHAM, one Wood and TWO SEYMOURS, like the five just men in Sodom, yet the great body of our Northern friends are as fierce in their apostacy to former princiciples as BUTLER himself." The London Times, of Oct. 13, declares that "the only chance of any terms the South may offer being considered is in a change in the position of the political parties of the North. The State elections there are now pending, and the result of the contest is almost of more importance than any immediate operations in the field." The London Post and the Manchester Guardian, also, have articles on the same subject, which look to the triumph of the Democratic candidates as a means of restoring peace and disrupting the Union.
