abstract: Coroner COLLIN held and inquest Saturday, at the Tenth Precinct Station-house, upon the body of the unknown man who was shot in an affray in a public house in the Bowery on Saturday evening, an account of which we published in the Truss of yesterday. There was a large amount of testimony taken, all tending to show that the deceased, the prisoner, and some six or eight other parties were...
lead_paragraph: drinking and carousing at the public place known as the "One Mile House," kept by PATRICK O'BRIEN, on the corner of the Bowery and Rivington-street; that between 8 and 9 o'clock in the evening the parties became involved in a dispute, during which one WM. C. WHITTLESEY, drew a revolver and fired two shots in quick succession. One of these shots took effect in the right breast of the deceased, killing him almost instantly. As soon as the shots were fired all the parties fled from the house, in every direction. Capt. DAVIS, of the Tenth Precinct, with officers MCCLOUD and MCCORD were promptly on hand, and after a long and diligent search, the accused was found at a disreputable house in Canal-street, near Elizabeth. He was taken to the Station-house and locked up. The coroner's jury rendered the following verdict: "That deceased came to his death by a wound from a pistol at the hands of the prisoner, WM. C. WHITTLESEY." In answer to the usual questions by the Coroner, the prisoner stated that he was 29 years of age, a native of Connecticut, and resided at No. 88 Elizabeth-street. He said the occurrence was entirely accidental on his part, he not having the most remote intention of injuring any one at the time.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. In addition to containing the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, will be found in the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriage and deaths of the week.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. In addition to containing the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, will be found in the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES. abstract: An audience which about two-thirds filled the Church of the Puritans in Union-Square, assembled on Sunday light, to listen to a sermon of Rev. Dr. CHEEVER on the exciting questions of the day. The Reverend gentleman, in his opening prayer, alluded to the coming election as one of the great crises of our National history, and earnestly besought Heaven....
lead_paragraph: [???] so direct and guide the hearts of men that they might choose rulers who should serve the holy interests of Freedom, and rigidly and religiously bear testimony against the great iniquity that had brought upon us the evils of civil war. Previously to announcing his text, he gave notice that on Monday evening a prayer meeting would be held in the Church, to be devoted to special prayer for the right issue of the elections of the morrow, and that next Monday -- to-day week -- would be observed as a day of fasting and prayer for the country, and it was hoped other churches would join in the services incident to the occasion. Then selecting his text from the first chapter of Malacut, at the fourth verse: "Thus saith the Lord of hosts. They shall build, but I will throw down, and they shall call them the border of wickedness and the people against whom the Lord hath indignation forever." The preacher proceeded to declare the reality and sure fulfillment of the prophecies of God, wherein he declares his hatred of oppression and cruelty, and applied the specific one he had selected as his text to our present condition. To avoid the overthrow and destruction so solemnly announced, we must as a people disavow and withdraw ourselves from all complicity with the barbarous, odious and satanic system of slavery, so separating ourselves from our enemies, who, as the opposers of the weak and helpless, are directly and really under the divine denunciation. To escape this vial of wrath, we must discard what politicians tell us -- that it is expedient for a while to submit to wickedness and oppression -- and firmly place ourselves upon the ground of principle. We have hitherto doomed, and are now dooming ourselves to destruction as a people by disdaining the word of God against Slavery. The President had hesitatingly and partially proclaimed the word of emancipation, but by this very timidity and hesitancy of the act had weakened its moral force. It would have needed no more than the 75,000 men of the first call of defenders to crush utterly and forever the rebellion, had we started with principle and justice on our side. But we had carefully abstained from making any declaration against Slavery, and had taken pains to clear ourselves of any suspicion of fighting for the emancipation of the black man. We found infinite fault with Great Britain for giving the lie to all her Anti-Slavery declarations by refusing to aid us in our contest with the South, and willingness to give aid to our enemies. Great Britain was not a whit worse than we, who had declared and were now ready to receive back the Confederates, nourishing still the great iniquity of Slavery in their bosom, into the Union, in the event of their laying down their arms. We would, they so returning, give perpetual protection and sanction to that most diabolical of institutions, return fugitive slaves, repeal personal liberty bills, restore the slaveholder to Christian communion, and yet expect the blessing of God. But destruction would be our reward. How can we then find fault with England? Our lack of principle is as great asher's. The preacher believed that the contest, between Expediency and Principle was to be the not far distant and general contest in which Europe and America was to be engaged. He warned his hearers against the treachery to justice and right which was now planning to receive back to the Union the rebellious States, with renewed and strengthened guarantees for their [???] system of Slavery. He would not take back a single State or a single shred of a State, except on the terms of full and unconditional submission and freedom to every slave. To no other terms could we expect the acquiescence of God, and they alone would save us from the wrath of Heaven which threatens our destruction. We must not ask consequences in a thing of moral obligation. To do so is to serve the Devil and not God, who bids us obey his law unreservedly. He protested against proclaiming emancipation merely as a war measure. We must do it as an act of moral obligation, which undone is sure to bring upon us the Divine wrath. It is not enough to emancipate the slaves of rebels alone, assuring protection to loyal slaveowners and slavedealers. We must sweep the whole, iniquity away even though every man of us die fighting to clear our skirts of the pollution. He referred to the probability of the recognition by England of the Confederacy, and said that when the representative of cruelty and Slavery should be presented to Her Christian Majesty, there ought at the same time to be presented the Envoy of the King of Dahomey -- both the representatives of the [???] system if man-stealing and man-selling and that when the Southern Confederacy was admitted to the family of nations, Dahomey also should be welcomed as a Christian Kingdom.

abstract: TWO INGENIOUS COUNTERFELLERS CAUGHT--A very ingenious mode of swindling the banks of this City and State has just come to tight, through the arrest and examination of two noted counterfellers named JOUN CANNON AND Mr. YOUNG.
lead_paragraph: The former was arrested, a few days since, in this City, by Officers RADFORD and LEARE, of the Detective force. A about the same time, YOUNG was taken into custody, at Binghamton, in this State, both upon the charge of having been guilty of forgery, under the following circumstances: About three weeks ago, the accused parties went to the Butchers' and Drovers' Bank to this City, where they made a special deposit of the sum of $15, at the same time receiving the usual certificate, signed by the Cashier and paying-teller of the bank. They then went to an engraver named FREDERICK KIMBEL doing business at No. 85 Nassau-street, where they made an arrangement to have a large number of fac similes of this certificate engraved, and also to have a large number of photographs of the names of R.P. PERPIN, the Cashier, and G.G. BRINCKERHOFF, the Paying Teller of this Bank, ready for them at a given time. The examination made yesterday, before Justice CONNOLLY, revealed the fact that after the engraver had executed the order, he then went to the bank and informed the officers thereof of the fraud which he believed was about to be practiced upon them. But the mischief, it is feared, had already been done, and a large number of spurious certificates of deposit were already in circulation. Quite a number of them have been presented to banks in this City, one of which was paid before the fraud was detected. The fact that more than a week elapsed between the time when the rogues were furnished with the false certificates, and the time of their arrest, and also that one of them had traveled as far West as Binghamton, induces the belief that many banks, and perhaps private parties, have been defrauded. The prisoner, CANNON, was yesterday committed to the Tombs in default of ball. Officers RADFORD and SEASE are entitled to credit for their diligence in working up the case and securing two of the most notorious and dangerous counterfeiters, with which this City is infested.

abstract: In Kings county the Republicans and Union much have very wisely put in nomination for reelection several members of the last Legislature. They will thus secure for the protection of their interests and for the general service of the State, the experience of one session, which is always of the greatest value, and adds greatly to the ease as well as the efficiency with which these duties are performed.
lead_paragraph: Among the members thus renominated are Messrs. WM. M. THOMAS, S.T. MADDOX and CHAS. L. BENEDICT -- and each one of them has well earned this mark of confidence at the hands of his constituents. Mr. THOMAS is a man of excellent judgment, careful and painstaking in the performance of his duties, and of the most unimpeachable integrity. He was always in his place, and was always reliable. He enjoyed the regard and confidence of all his fellow-members.

abstract: The Democrats in the Eighth District have withdrawn their candidate, and given JAMES BROOKS, who represents the Know-Nothing rump in the secession coalition, a clear field against ELIOT C. COWDIN, the Union candidate. MR. BROOKS expects the Catholic and foreign vote, on account...
lead_paragraph: of his life-long persecution of both. He will get it, if Catholics and foreign-born citizens love their enemies better than their religion or their country. If not, not. Mr. COWDIN is a merchant of high standing, a gentleman of ability, and in every way worthy the hearty and effective support of loyal men. He can and ought to be elected.

abstract: Men acquainted with the locality, insist that the rebels cannot mean to make a stand in their supposed position in the rear of Goose Creek, the ground offering no such advantages as they have heretofore invariably insisted upon securing before measuring arms with the forces of the Union.
lead_paragraph: Men acquainted with the locality, insist that the rebels cannot mean to make a stand in their supposed position in the rear of Goose Creek, the ground offering no such advantages as they have heretofore invariably insisted upon securing before measuring arms with the forces of the Union. The first stand they can make, it is said, will be behind their line of defensive works stretching from the Rappahannock to Gordonsville.

abstract: There has not been an election in this city for years, in which, during the after part of the day, the excitement was so great as it was yesterday. Not even the Presidential election elicited so much strong feeling. Betting ! during the day, throughout the city (confined, of course, to gambling politicians), was...
lead_paragraph: There has not been an election in this city for years, in which, during the after part of the day, the excitement was so great as it was yesterday. Not even the Presidential election elicited so much strong feeling. Betting ! during the day, throughout the city (confined, of course, to gambling politicians), was strongly in favor of the election of SEYMOUR; and there has not been an election, State, County or City, on which there has been so many gambling bets. In Wall-street wagers were laid on the result from $100 to $5,000 -- the bets being generally even in amount, with the exception that the SEYMOUR men agree to pay in gold, while all they asked, should they lose, was "Government currency." And that offer was not confined to the speculators in elections in Wall-street -- about the same percentage was offered freely throughout the City; and when the returns began to come in at the several newspaper offices, showing, as is usual, at an early hour after the closing of the polls majorities in favor of the Opposition, the Seymour men gathered in great numbers, and were exceedingly jubilant. The quiet confidence which they had manifested during the day resulted in the greatest enthusiasm at night, and the feeling among them was common, that SEYMOUR would go out of New-York City with 36,000 majority; and that Brooklyn, in proportion would do better. There was great confidence in the power of money potently applied. The day was beautiful -- the weather as fine as could be desired for an election day, and the voting was carried on orderly in almost every Ward. The same was true of Brooklyn. The arrests made during the day were chiefly of those who had claimed exemption from the draft on the ground that they were aliens -- but few attests were made for disorderly conduct; and for the sympathizers with SEYMOUR, all went "merry as a marriage bell," until late in the evening, when the returns from the "rural districts" were placed upon the bulletin boards. Soon after that, the friends of SEYMOUR and Compromise discovered that it was quite late, and retired to their homes -- or somewhere else. Just previous to their arrival at the above conclusion, many jokes were perpetrated at the expense of prominent Wadsworth and Union men. For instance, from the Tribune office, at about 11 o'clock, numerous newsboys rushed out with what purported to be "extras," shouting "the suicide of HORACE GREELY," &c. But such jokes were failures, and when, as we have said, the returns from other parts of the State began to come in, the boys could not find any one who was willing to expend a quarter in postage stamps to perpetuate the fun. Nevertheless, among the Union men of the City there was profound sorrow, in consequence of the success of the WOODS, as against the patriotic men who had opposed them. As an evidence of the belief in which the main portion of the Seymour vote had been cast in this City, and that a majority of those voting for him were not knowingly disloyal, the cheers, when a Seymour majority was declared, were mainly for GEORGE B. MCCLELLAN. The belief seemed to be that a vote for SEYMOUR was so far an indorsement of Gen. MCCLELLAN. The particulars, however, of the doings and enthusiasm at the various prominent places of meeting are given at length below.

abstract: The State of New-York, at the annual election yesterday, elected, from the present complexion of the returns, the entire Democratic State Ticket, headed by HORATIO SEYMOUR for Governor, and from sixteen to eighteen Democratic members to the next Congress, of the...
lead_paragraph: The State of New-York, at the annual election yesterday, elected, from the present complexion of the returns, the entire Democratic State Ticket, headed by HORATIO SEYMOUR for Governor, and from sixteen to eighteen Democratic members to the next Congress, of the whole delegation of thirty-one members. The returns, on this point, are conclusive from the first fifteen districts in the State, numbering from Staten Island to Troy, inclusive, and there is little doubt that the Buffalo District has elected Mr. GANSON over Mr. SPAULDING.

abstract: The election in the City and State of New-York, yesterday, resulted in a complete revolution in the ascendency of parties, so far as the State and Congressional tickets are concerned. The Democrats carried the City by over 30,000, Kings County by 5,500, and the State by a majority not...
lead_paragraph: The election in the City and State of New-York, yesterday, resulted in a complete revolution in the ascendency of parties, so far as the State and Congressional tickets are concerned. The Democrats carried the City by over 30,000, Kings County by 5,500, and the State by a majority not yet ascertained in its extent, though there is no present reason to doubt that it will be decided. The Congressional delegation will stand 10 or 18 Democrats, to 13 or 15 Republicans. The Legislature is Republican in the Senate, elected for two years in 1861, and probably Republican in the Assembly.

abstract: Printing House-square was the great centre of attraction daring the evening. The streaming crowds of merchants, clerks, mechanics, laborers, and sewing women, had stopped a moment, on their up-town journey, to look with incredulous eyes at the staring capitals upon the World Bulletin, which announced  of course incorrectly a great Democratic majority.
lead_paragraph: Printing House-square was the great centre of attraction daring the evening. The streaming crowds of merchants, clerks, mechanics, laborers, and sewing women, had stopped a moment, on their up-town journey, to look with incredulous eyes at the staring capitals upon the World Bulletin, which announced of course incorrectly a great Democratic majority Massachusetts, before even the canvassers there had time to collect, much less to count the votes -- but the mass of the streaming populace waited to cat a hasty evening meal before returning to expend their enthusiasm over victory or exhaust their patience over defeat, when the full and correct returns should be displayed upon the newspaper bulletins. At 7 o'clock the space in front of the TIMES Office was beginning to be rapidly filled with the eager faces of the expectant citizens, and half an hour later, an impatient, eager, but really orderly crowd was assembled. The City returns come in somewhat more slowly than usual, but at 7 1/2 o'clock the figures began to be pasted upon the bulletin boards which had been conspicuously placed. Democratic majorities from the City came in first, and drew from the Submissionist portion of the throng repeated cheers. The Wadsworth man maintained a cheerful silence, declaring that they expected nothing from the City, but much from the country. The industrious clerks in the TIMES newspaper office continued every few minutes to paste up -- the crowd meanwhile stretching their necks had straining eyes to catch sight of the figures -- the Seymour majorities of the City Wards, and groans and cheers followed the appearance of the returns. As every Ward began to appear strongly on the wrong side, the Wadsworth men, some of them, grew disheartened, but others clung to their predictions of a fully counter-balancing coming vote. Bets began to be offered. JOHN MORRISSEY, hedging, so it was said, pressed heavy sums upon SEYMOUR, and found some takers, but the majority preferred to wait for fuller returns before committing themselves and their money. The interest in the result of the contest between WALBRIDGE and WOOD was intense. The returns came in slowly. The report from the Second Ward, as announced upon the Tribune, giving the plucky War Democrat a majority, was received with repeated cheers for the supposed successful candidate. But as fuller reports from other Wards and Districts came, in, the loyal men were forced to keep silent. And so the evening passed -- cheers and groans, enthusiam and depression alternating with one another, the Seymourites jubilant, the Wadsworth men incredulous and confident of the general result.

abstract: The news of the death of Maj.-Gen. O. M. MITCHEL, Commander of the Department of the South, at Beaufort, S.C.,  will fall upon the country as painfully as the loss of a great battle.
lead_paragraph: The news of the death of Maj.-Gen. O. M. MITCHEL, Commander of the Department of the South, at Beaufort, S.C., will fall upon the country as painfully as the loss of a great battle. To the sense of a heavy calamity, will be added the shock of a sharp surprise. We had not accustomed ourselves to think of him as of one who could die. His very nature was instinct with life. His spirit was ever exultant and scaring, and marked out grand fields of enterprise, which his heart, his brain and hands were restless and untiring to pursue. We cannot realize that this living man is dead.

abstract: The long expected falling off in importations of Foreign merchandise is beginning to be apparent. For several months our importations have been very large, even for times of peace, and every month it has been prophesied that they must decrease; notwithstanding, when the monthly returns of the Custom...
lead_paragraph: The long expected falling off in importations of Foreign merchandise is beginning to be apparent. For several months our importations have been very large, even for times of peace, and every month it has been prophesied that they must decrease; notwithstanding, when the monthly returns of the Custom House have been made, the diminution has not been apparent. Those of the month of October, how ever, show that the receipts for duty were about $1,000,000 less than during the month preceding. The falling off was greater toward the end of the month than at its beginning, the value of the merchandise imported into New-York during the last week of the month being but little greater than during the corresponding week of last year, and being nearly $1,500,000 inferior to that of those imported during the same week of 1860. The figures for the week are as follows:

abstract: There has not been an election in this city for years, in which, during the after part of the day, the excitement was so great as it was yesterday. Not even the Presidential election elicited so much strong feeling. Belting' during the day, throughout the city (confined, of course, to gambling politicians), was ...
lead_paragraph: There has not been an election in this city for years, in which, during the after part of the day, the excitement was so great as it was yesterday. Not even the Presidential election elicited so much strong feeling. Belting' during the day, throughout the city (confined, of course, to gambling politicians), was strongly in favor of the election of SEYMOUR; and there has not been an election, State, County or City on which there has been so many gambling bets. In Wall-street wagers were laid on the result from $100 to $5,000 -- the bets being generally even in amount, with the exception that the SEYMOUR men agree to pay in gold, while all they asked, should they lose, was "Government currency." And that offer was not confined to the speculators in elections in Wall-street -- about the same percentage was offered freely throughout the City; and when the returns began to come in at the several newspaper offices, showing, as is usual, at an early hour after the closing of the polls majorities in favor of the Opposition, the Seymour men gathered in great numbers, and were exceedingly jubilant. The quiet confidence which they had manifested during the day resulted in the greatest enthusiasm at night, and the feeling among them was common, that SEYMOUR would go out of New-York City with 36,000 majority; and that Brooklyn, in proportion would do better. There was great confidence in the power of money potently applied. The day was beautiful -- the weather as fine as could be desired for an election day, and the voting was carried on orderly in almost every Ward. The same was true of Brooklyn. The arrests made during the day were chiefly of those who had claimed exemption from the draft on the ground that they were aliens -- but few arrests were made for disorderly conduct; and for the sympathizers with SEYMOUR, all went "merry as a marriage bell," until late in the evening, when the returns from the "rural districts" were placed upon the bulletin boards. Soon after that, the friends of SEYMOUR and Compromise discovered that it was quite late, and retired to their homes -- or somewhere else. Just previous to their arrival at the above conclusion, many jokes were perpetrated at the expense of prominent Wadsworth and Union men. For instance, from the Tribune office, at about 11 o'clock, numerous newsboys rushed out with what purported to be "extras," shouting "the suicide of HORACE GREELY," &c. But such jokes were failures, and when, as we have said, the returns from other parts of the State began to come in, the boys could not find any one who was willing to expend a quarter in postage stamps to perpetuate the fun. Nevertheless, among the Union men of the City there was profound sorrow, in consequence of the success of the WOODS, as against the patriotic men who had opposed them. As an evidence of the belief in which the main portion of the Seymour vote had been cast in this City, and that a majority of those voting for him were not knowingly disloyal, the cheers, when a Seymour majority was declared, were mainly for GEORGE B. MCCLELLAN. The belief seemed to be that a vote for SEYMOUR was so far an indorsement of Gen. MCCLELLAN. The particulars, however, of the doings and enthusiasm at the various prominent places of meeting are given at length below.

At 6 o'clock the "unterrified" began to assemble in front of the Wig- wam and at seven the doors of the upper hall, were thrown open to the surging multitude who, with cheers, cat-calls, howls of every varied pitch and tone, and huzzas for "SEYMOUR and the Democratic ticket," poured irresistibly in, until every corner was densely jammed and packed with an eager mass of humanity.

abstract: The general quiet and good order which prevailed in Brooklyn throughout the day was scarcely, if at all, disturbed in the evening. It is true, the boys burned tar barrels in honor of the successful candidates, and at the Police Headquarters and some other public places citizens assembled to learn the result of...
lead_paragraph: The general quiet and good order which prevailed in Brooklyn throughout the day was scarcely, if at all, disturbed in the evening. It is true, the boys burned tar barrels in honor of the successful candidates, and at the Police Headquarters and some other public places citizens assembled to learn the result of the day's contest, but at all these places the best of feeling and good order prevailed. And at the principal hotels, and other public places, there was an entire absence of anything like excitement. All parties had done their duty in voting, and they seemed quietly and willingly to acquiesce in the result.

abstract: It is agreed on all hands that dissatisfaction with the conduct of the war has been one of the main causes of the heavy popular verdicts against the Administration. Had the canvass turned solely on that point, the votes would substantially have all gone the same way.
lead_paragraph: It is agreed on all hands that dissatisfaction with the conduct of the war has been one of the main causes of the heavy popular verdicts against the Administration. Had the canvass turned solely on that point, the votes would substantially have all gone the same way. Those who gave their ballots on the side of the Administration did so in spite of, not by reason of, its management of the war, and because they considered that the election involved other issues yet more vital. They believed, and still believe, that the motive of the leaders of the Opposition was not the invigoration of the war, but its discontinuance. And yet they cannot doubt that the great body of the Opposition were actuated by an honest desire that the war should be effectively pushed on, and that they meant that their votes should weigh "to that extent -- no more."

abstract: There appears to be no reason to doubt that HORATIO SEYMOUR is elected Governor of the State by a majority of about 6,000 votes. His friends claim a larger majority, but we cannot find it in the returns. The Congressional delegation will stand Democrats, 17; Republicans, 13; Independent, 1. The complexion of the Legislature is not changed, though the Republican majority in the Assembly is considerably reduced.

The complexion of the Legislature is not changed, though the Republican majority in the Assembly is considerably reduced.

abstract: A grand "Fremont festival" came off in St. Louis, on Saturday evening last. The occasion of it was the presentation of a sword to the Major-General by the people of St. Louis. Delegations from the towns in the vicinity of St. Louis, and from all the city wards, joined in the demonstration.
lead_paragraph: A grand "Fremont festival" came off in St. Louis, on Saturday evening last. The occasion of it was the presentation of a sword to the Major-General by the people of St. Louis. Delegations from the towns in the vicinity of St. Louis, and from all the city wards, joined in the demonstration. As early as 6 o'clock the people began to gather in Market-street, and an immense crowd was gathered at the time fixed for the presentation. Thirty thousand people, the Democrat says, had collected in Chonteau-avenue, and cheered themselves hoarse for Gen. FREMONT. Finally he appeared on the balcony of the Brant House, amid the greatest enthusiasm, and the burning or Bengal fires, Mr. EMIL PRETCRIUS presented the sword to Gen. FREMONT, with the following brief address:

abstract: editorial says Sioux should be removed from state since their own safety is now threatened
snippet: editorial says Sioux should be removed from state since their own safety is now threatened
lead_paragraph: -- We are very glad to learn from Washington that it is not the purpose of the Government to deal in a sanguinary manner with the lately belligerent red men of Minnesota. The large number of "big Injuns," of all grades and dignities, and with all sorts of unpronounceable names, who had been condemned to the gallows, will be respited, and subjected to some punishment which will be more effective in preventing outbreaks in the future. The war, if such it may be called, is entirely over. A mere show of power on the part of the Government put an end to the difficulties; and Gen. POPE has had no use whatever for the large number of men that were assigned to his department. The whole thing seems to have been but a burst of rage on the part of the redskins, incited by the atrocious injustice to which they had been subjected; and their savage fury being raised, they fell upon the white settlers, and slew them indiscriminately. Most of the Indians who were condemned had given themselves up to justice, declaring their innocence, and asserting that the massacres were the work of a few bad men among them -- as indeed seems to have been the case.

abstract: A brief message comes by telegraph, announcing that Maj.-Gen. ISRAEL B. RICHARDSON died at Sharpsburgh on Monday night, of wounds received in the battle of Antietam. So great a loss was seldom told in so few words.
lead_paragraph: A brief message comes by telegraph, announcing that Maj.-Gen. ISRAEL B. RICHARDSON died at Sharpsburgh on Monday night, of wounds received in the battle of Antietam. So great a loss was seldom told in so few words. The nation is called to mourn one of its staunchest supporters, the army one of its most gallant leaders. His comrades in battle -- and in few battles has our flag been borne where "Fighting Dick" did not lead the van -- will learn their loss with heavy hearts, and for his death alone the future historian will write the victory of Antietam dearly bought.

abstract: The country will hail with hearty exultation the news that the Army of the Potomac is advancing upon the rebel forces in Virginia. Its inaction since the battle of Antietam, in the absence of any apparent reason, has weighed like a nightmare upon the public mind. The people began to suspect that no further attempts upon the rebel army were to be made this Fall, -- and that our army was to go into Winter quarters, content with having saved Pennsylvania and Maryland, with the Capital at Washington, from rebel occupation. It is to the despondency and discouragement to which this suspicion gave rise, far more than to any other cause, that the result of the recent elections is due.

abstract: The Na-  tional Intelligencer suggests, that under the Confiscation act of the last session of Congress, Gen. SHERMAN, Military Governor of Memphis, has no right to permit slaves who have escaped from service, and come within our lines, to return to their masters. Hitherto, while he refuses to allow them to be ...
lead_paragraph: -- The National Intelligencer suggests, that under the Confiscation act of the last session of Congress, Gen. SHERMAN, Military Governor of Memphis, has no right to permit slaves who have escaped from service, and come within our lines, to return to their masters. Hitherto, while he refuses to allow them to be forcibly taken away, he has allowed them to return if they desire it. The Confiscation act provides that all slaves of persons in rebellion "escaping from such persons, and taking refuge within the lines of the army, shall be deemed captives of war, and shall be forever free." The Intelligencer deems this conclusive, and doubts Gen. SHERMAN's right to return them to Slavery, even with their own consent.

abstract: We suppose our various armies and military detachments in the Southwestern States will very soon now be beginning their Winter's work. We have a heavy column of troops in Northwestern Arkansas, and a column in Eastern Arkansas, on the line of the Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: We suppose our various armies and military detachments in the Southwestern States will very soon now be beginning their Winter's work. We have a heavy column of troops in Northwestern Arkansas, and a column in Eastern Arkansas, on the line of the Mississippi. We have the large army of Gen. GRANT at Memphis, with detachments on the line of the Memphis and Charleston Railroad, including the veteran force with which ROSECRANS lately defeated the combined rebel columns at Iuka and Corinth. We have in Kentucky the magnificent army lately under BUELL, but now headed by that valorous soldier, ROSECRANS. We have also considerable detachments at Nashville and at other points in Tennessee, which, in case of offensive forward movements, could be united with the main body or bodies. Beside all these, we have the late army of Cumberland Gap, in Western Virginia, which is prepared to cooperate either with the movements of the Southwestern armies or with the movements of Gen. MCCLELLAN.

snippet: editorial on Seymour victory; Editorial on necessary missions to be accomplished by Union in Southwest
lead_paragraph: Gov. SEYMOUR has been elected. Of this result there can be no longer any doubt. He comes into office on the first of January -- long after the draft will have been completed. He will send to the Legislature a Message embodying his views on the war, -- but as they have already been fully set forth in his public speeches, that document can contain nothing very new. The moral effect of his election, both at home and abroad, will be considerable: beyond that, it is not easy to see how it can have any marked influence on the practical conduct of affairs.

abstract: Ashby's Gap, we learn by our dispatches from the Army of the Potomac, was taken quiet possession of by our forces on Monday evening the rebels retreating, and leaving us in undisturbed possession of the mountains, from which a good ...
lead_paragraph: Ashby's Gap, we learn by our dispatches from the Army of the Potomac, was taken quiet possession of by our forces on Monday evening -- the rebels retreating, and leaving us in undisturbed possession of the mountains, from which a good view of the Shenandoah Valley and Winchester could be obtained. No large body of the enemy was discovered. Piedmont was occupied by the cavalry and artillery under PLEASANTON and AVERILL on Monday night, and on Tuesday morning they pushed on, and after a spirited skirmish, occupied Marquette, and obtained command of the approaches to Manassas and Chester Gap, on the left of the Blue Ridge Mountains.

abstract: SAILING OF THE FRENCH WAR STEAMER MASSENA. -- This line-of-battle ship steamed from her anchorage at the Southwest Spit this morning, and proceeded to sea. She arrived here on the 16th October, and her draft at that time was 27 feet. She has since taken in stores and fuel, and when she passed down the Ship Channel, was drawing 28 feet 3 inches -- the greatest draft ever yet carried out of this harbor by way of Sandy Hook. She was piloted to sea in perfect safety by Mr. GEORGE EVANS, of pilot-boat Fannie, No. 17.

abstract: The return game between these "amateur" nines was played on Monday at the grounds of the Union Club, Morrisania, and resulted in a victory for the Sunday Times. Each party having won a game, the conquering game will be played next ...
lead_paragraph: The return game between these "amateur" nines was played on Monday at the grounds of the Union Club, Morrisania, and resulted in a victory for the Sunday Times. Each party having won a game, the conquering game will be played next Monday. Notwithstanding the cold, high wind, some very good play was shown on both sides, among which were a number of fly catches; from two of them, one man on each side being run out before getting back to his base. BERGEN, of the Sunday Times, retired from his position as pitcher in the third innings of his antagonists, but resumed it in the remaining innings; and DONALDSON took hold of the pitching in the fourth innings of his antagonists -- and subsequently -- with considerable effect; the short stop catching out the third man on the fly in good style, but making two bad misses of fly catches, after two men were put out without a run in the fifth innings -- the four runs being made before the third man was got rid of. This mishap entirely altered the complexion of the game. DONOHUE received a severe contusion on the leg early in the game, which somewhat marred his excellent play as catcher for the "Dailies."

abstract: Nothing is more important, at this crisis, than a through and cordial union among all  who desire to support the Government in a vigorous prosecution of the war.
lead_paragraph: Nothing is more important, at this crisis, than a through and cordial union among all who desire to support the Government in a vigorous prosecution of the war. We are in the presence now of a powerful political enemy, flushed with popular triumphs, and eager to overthrow the Administration, upon which alone we must rely for a deliverance of the country from the terrible dangers which threaten it. We cannot afford to quarrel among ourselves. Personal animosities, party ambitions, preferences as to measures even, must give way to a common zeal for the common good.

abstract: The Chamber of Commerce yesterday listened to an interesting address from Hon. TOWNSEND  L. HARRIS, late U.S. Minister to Japan, on the  subject of commercial affairs in that country. A Committee was appointed to investigate and...
lead_paragraph: The Chamber of Commerce yesterday listened to an interesting address from Hon. TOWNSEND L. HARRIS, late U.S. Minister to Japan, on the subject of commercial affairs in that country. A Committee was appointed to investigate and report as to what action is necessary with reference to the depredations of the rebel pirate Alabama. The existing Committee upon Harbor Defences, was requested to urge upon the Government the necessity of strengthening our preparations to meet any emergency which may arise from the attempt of an enemy to enter our harbor. A letter was read from JOHN CHADWICK, Esq., approving of the sentiments of an article in the New-York TIMES, headed "Loyalty of British Workingmen," and subscribing one hundred dollars to aid the suffering people of Stalybridge and Blackburn.

abstract: Our dispatches from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac inform us that Gen. PLEASANTON remained on Tuesday night at Markhall, and on Wednesday morning moved toward the mouth of Chester Gap, encountering STUART'S whole force of cavalry, 3,000 strong, on the way.
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac inform us that Gen. PLEASANTON remained on Tuesday night at Markhall, and on Wednesday morning moved toward the mouth of Chester Gap, encountering STUART's whole force of cavalry, 3,000 strong, on the way. The enemy had artillery posted on the hills, but they were speedily driven off, when the Eighth Pennsylvania Cavalry charged upon the rebels and routed them, taking several prisoners. During the flight of the rebels, a squadron of the Sixth Pennsylvania charged upon their flank, and our artillery threw shells among them. They left ten dead upon the field, while our loss was but one killed and five wounded. On Wednesday Salem was also occupied by BAYARD's cavalry, after driving out the First Virginia Cavalry and capturing seven prisoners.

abstract: The question has been asked so often of late, "when will we have iron-clads ready to fight," that it is worth while to answer it definitely. We believe
lead_paragraph: The question has been asked so often of late, "when will we have iron-clads ready to fight," that it is worth while to answer it definitely. We believe the time specified in the contract Between Mr. ERICSSON and the Government has expired, yet three vessels of his first nine are not yet launched, and not one of those that are can be called ready for sea. The Navy Department has sent on here officers for the Passaic, but that vessel will not be turned over to them until the problem is decided whether a cannon can be fired without protruding through a port-hole. Yesterday, at Greenpoint, workmen were engaged in making an iron box near the port, into which the gun is supposed to move.

abstract: AN AFFRAY BETWEEN THE POLICE AND THE ROWDIES IN THE FOURTH WARD. -- Between 10 and 11 o'clock yesterday morning, a disturbance occurred in the Fourth Ward, which but for the prompt action of the Police would doubtless have resulted very seriously. A gang of rowdies, connected with Fulton Market, were parading through William-street, near Frankfort, and acting in a very disorderly manner. Officer TEMPLETON, of the Fourth Precinct, fearing that there would be a breach of the peace, undertook to arrest the ringleaders, when he was attacked by the whole gang, knocked down, and badly beaten. Word was immediately sent to the Station-house, and a large force under Sergt. EASTEROOK, was at once detailed to the scene of the riot. The disturbers of the peace, upon the approach of the Metropolitans, dispersed rapidly in every direction, but all of them soon after met at Fulton Market, where they were largely reinforced, and it was only through the prompt and vigorous action of Sergt. E. and the men under his command, that a serious not was prevented. The excitement was finally brought to an end by the arrest of two of the principal leaders in the disturbance. Upon being taken before Justice CONNOLLY, they gave their names as JOHN PETTY and MARTIN MILLER. They were committed for examination at the Tombs. Officer TEMPLETON was seriously, though not dangerously injured.
lead_paragraph: AN AFFRAY BETWEEN THE POLICE AND THE ROWDIES IN THE FOURTH WARD. -- Between 10 and 11 o'clock yesterday morning, a disturbance occurred in the Fourth Ward, which but for the prompt action of the Police would doubtless have resulted very seriously. abstract: We have conversed with several shipmasters who were captured by the British pirate Alabama, and are convinced that she could be easily crippled, if not destroyed, by any of our smart three-masted schooners, if properly armed and manned. The tact is notorious that every vessel she has captured has been deceived by her appearance, and that some of them, had they suspected her, could have eluded her; for thus far she has used only her sails.
lead_paragraph: We have conversed with several shipmasters who were captured by the British pirate Alabama, and are convinced that she could be easily crippled, if not destroyed, by any of our smart three-masted schooners, if properly armed and manned. The tact is notorious that every vessel she has captured has been deceived by her appearance, and that some of them, had they suspected her, could have eluded her; for thus far she has used only her sails.

abstract: There was something of a sensation in this City, yesterday, caused by a statement in the Washington telegrams of the TIMES, that dispatchss of a grave character had been submitted by the French Legation to the Secretary of State.
lead_paragraph: There was something of a sensation in this City, yesterday, caused by a statement in the Washington telegrams of the TIMES, that dispatchss of a grave character had been submitted by the French Legation to the Secretary of State. The information contained in our Washington dispatch is doubtless correct; but there is not, we apprehend so much, danger of a sudden diplomatic difficulty with France as the public seemed ready to believe.

abstract: However enforcedly dull the book trade may be the presses of Franklin-square very seldom stand idle.
lead_paragraph: -- However enforcedly dull the book trade may be the presses of Franklin-square very seldom stand idle. Like busy giants they work on, not stopping to inquire whether the world around them is awake or asleep, at peace or at war. The HARPERS seem very early to have recognized the truth that the demand for good hooks can never be supplied, and evidently they intend to act on it just as long as paper can be found in market. It is a notable fact that a book bearing the indorsement "HARPER & BROS,'" on its back is generally safe to read or to buy. Running through the long list of their publications for the past twenty years, very few can be found that had better have been left unpublished, very few that are not works of permanent value as well as of momentary interest, and calculated to enrich as well as adorn the library. Of course, Franklin-square has its amiable weaknesses, and occasionally publishes a young author merely for his gratification, and not at all with a view to its own profit and renown. Fortunately, however, these instances are so rare as to be almost phenomenal, serving, like other freaks of Nature, only to prove what may happen -- not to indicate what is likely to.

abstract: There is no disguising it; it is just that, pure and simple, whatever the spirit of the leaders. It is precisely such a vote as in Parliament which under the theory of the British Constitution is sovereign is always succeeded by the resignation of the Ministry, from the Premier down.
lead_paragraph: There is no disguising it; -- it is just that, pure and simple, whatever the spirit of the leaders. It is precisely such a vote as in Parliament -- which under the theory of the British Constitution is sovereign -- is always succeeded by the resignation of the Ministry, from the Premier down. What shall be its effect here? Under our Constitution it is the people who are sovereign. Surely, their power is as legitimate as that of the British Parliament, and their vote of dissatisfaction ought to tell potently in some shape. How?

abstract: Mrs. PIGGOTT, her son, three daughters, and all of her slaves, were arrested on Wednesday night  last, by the rebels, and taken to Richmond. Mrs. PIGGOTT is a bloomed lady, residing about nine miles above Williamsburgh, and a sister of Judge L.J. BOUDEN. Her only offence, as far as known, is that her brother is an uncompromising Union man. Measures are being taken which will undoubtedly lead to the liberation of this family.

abstract: editorial on campaign
snippet: editorial on campaign
lead_paragraph: map of Virginia this morning, for the purpose of showing the region in which our army is now operating, and its relation to the rebel position at Winchester. From Harper's Ferry one column under BURNSIDE has marched southward along the east side of the Blue Ridge, while another column, under SIGEL, has moved southward in the direction of the Bull Run Mountains, which run for a short distance parallel with the Blue Ridge. The work of these bodies has so far been confined to the capturing of the mountain gaps or passes, through which communication from Winchester is maintained with Eastern Virginia. The great importance of Snicker's Gap, which we look on the first day of this week, will be observed at a glance. There is a good turnpike leading directly from Winchester, through Berryville, to the Shenandoah River, at which crossing there is a bridge, and from thence it cuts through the various mountain ranges and spurs till you reach Aldie, from which a march north to Leesburgh or east to Fairfax Court-house or any point in front of Washington, is easy. Ashby's Gap, likewise in our hands, is of equal importance. The road from Winchester to this pass is very direct, and after cutting through the Blue Ridge, it divides into two lines, one leading southeast and the other directly east, the latter line converging at Aldie with the Snicker's Gap road, and from thence, of course, leading to the some places. Continuing south from Ashby's Gap, the next important pass we come to is Manassas Gap, which, at lates, advices, had not fallen into our hands. Through this runs the railroad leading into Eastern Virginia, and connecting at Manassas Junction with the Orange and Alexandria line. If Gen. BURNSIDE has [???] of, taken Manassas Gap, Gen. SIGEL, operating eastwardly from BURNSIDE, has captured. Thorough fare Gap, also on the Manassas line of railroad, and which lies between the Bull Run and Bond Mountains. Thus the rebel army at Winchester, if indeed it still be there, is pretty much barred from crossing the [???] over into Eastern Virginia and [???] are held by us, they will be compelled to make a long detour up the Shenandoah Valley, and round by Gordonsville, which SIGEL's army, from its present base, ought to reach long before they do -- if they have not reached it already.

abstract: John Frost, Esq., a lineal descendant of Haste T. Winter, in the most daring defiance of public desire, flouted fiercely through our streets all day yesterday. What, in the name of all precedent, this ferocious incoming of wintry blasts indicates we know not. Suffice it to say, that argument on its propriety, suggestion as to its desirability, theorizing as to its cause, are of no avail. It came and it conquered.

abstract: The United States vs. The schooner Joseph H. Toone and her cargo. This vessel was captured Oct. 1, 1861, in the Gulf of Mexico, between Timbalier Island and the S.W. Pass of the Mississippi, by the steamer South Carolina. The vessel was after her capture detained for the use and service of the Gov- ...
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The schooner Joseph H. Toone and her cargo. -- This vessel was captured Oct. 1, 1861, in the Gulf of Mexico, between Timbalier Island and the S.W. Pass of the Mississippi, by the steamer South Carolina. The vessel was after her capture detained for the use and service of the Government, but her cargo was transhipped to this port, with the papers found on board, her alleged owner, her master, two-seamen and a passenger taken on board. The process was issued against the cargo alone, and no arrest of the vessel was returned by the Marshal to the Court. The owner of the vessel appeared, and answered for himself, and also as agent for several parties, Spanish subjects and residents within the Spanish dominions, and claiming the cargo. One of the claimants also answered for himself.

abstract: How much longer is it proposed to continue the farce in which the Mayor and Aldermen are the leading actors, concerning the Street Commissionership? It is now eight or ten weeks since that office became vacant; and the Mayor has been making nominations at almost every subsequent meeting of the Board, which the Aldermen have rejected, -- not upon any grounds of objection to the nominees, but because, as they avow, the Mayor has not consulted them in advance. They allege that, according to the charter, vacant offices are to be filled by the appointment of the Mayor. "with the advice and consent of the Board of Aldermen;" and that the Mayor is bound to get this "advice and consent" before he makes the nomination.
lead_paragraph: How much longer is it proposed to continue the farce in which the Mayor and Aldermen are the leading actors, concerning the Street Commissionership? It is now eight or ten weeks since that office became vacant; and the Mayor has been making nominations at almost every subsequent meeting of the Board, which the Aldermen have rejected, -- not upon any grounds of objection to the nominees, but because, as they avow, the Mayor has not consulted them in advance. They allege that, according to the charter, vacant offices are to be filled by the appointment of the Mayor. "with the advice and consent of the Board of Aldermen;" and that the Mayor is bound to get this "advice and consent" before he makes the nomination.

abstract: Who are our friends in England? Has the struggling Union any friendly recognition in that country, which we used fondly to designate as our mother-country? Not certainly among its rulers; for not a kindly word, ...
lead_paragraph: Who are our friends in England? Has the struggling Union any friendly recognition in that country, which we used fondly to designate as our mother-country? Not certainly among its rulers; for not a kindly word, nothing but cold formalities, mingled with insidious insults, have come to us from them since our fearful war broke out. Not among the aristocracy and governing classes; for they see in our great struggle only a strife of vulgar democrats, fighting for we know not what. Not in Parliament. Not among the snobs, flunkies and shopkeepers, which form so large an element in British society; for they merely reflect the opinions, as they ape the manners, of those whom they consider their "betters." Not in the Press; for have not the columns of almost every journal in England been perpetually foul with abuse of us? have they not heaped every conconceivable insult upon us, and applied to us every degrading epithet, and accused us of every atrocious crime, until our blood boiled with desire of vengeance against our maligners? Not in Oxford; for did not its halls on a late public occasion ring with cheers for JEFF. DAVIS and with groans and hisses upon President LINCOLN and the cause of the North. Not from the hierarchy, nor the pulpit, nor the clubs, nor the drawing-rooms -- not even from the Anti-Slavery party for Exeter Hall have we received the common justice and consideration which savages might claim. Nearly every voice from almost every class in England has been the voice of hatred and scorn, and of a base malignity and injustice of which we had hardly supposed human nature to be capable.

abstract: - The third article in the series on Plymouth Church is published in to-day's Courier. The advertisement specifies its subject to be the Prayer Meetings of Plymouth Church, as conducted by the Pastor, the Deacons and the Young Men. The article is written from the standpoint of an outside observer, and presents the subject as it seemed to him, though doubtless not as it would appear to a participator in the spirit of the meeting.

abstract: -- There will be no draft in Brooklyn, if the records of the Board of Supervisors are accepted by the State authorities. The recent canvass of the Wards authorized by the Board has been completed, and shows that the total number of men enlisted in Kings County since the 2d of July last is about 300 above the total number required under both calls of the President. Mr. W. TUTTLE, Chairman of the Committee having the matter in charge, states that 2,287 men enlisted before the bounties were paid, and bounties have been paid to 6,470 men, making a total of 8,757 men who have enlisted. The number required to fill the quota was 8,400 men.

abstract: Editorial on ex-Mayor Wood views on war now he has been elected to Congress
snippet: Editorial on ex-Mayor Wood views on war now he has been elected to Congress
lead_paragraph: Nobody who knows the vaulting audacity of the man FERNANDO WOOD, can doubt, now that he is elected, that he will make good his promise to his liegemen, to "go to the President and tell him that without we have a change of measures, so help me God! we will make a change of men." The President may as well make up his mind at once to be soon bullied and brow-beaten in a style that he has never before seen or heard of; -- that is to say, if he does not "put his foot down" at the first rampant word. Of course FERNANDO does not intend to operate slope. He will choose unto himself seven other spirits as presumptuous as himself, and with them he will assume to speak in the name of the triumphant Democratic Party. Not entirely without reason, either. Every reader of history understands that in revolutionary times. It is almost invariably the holdest and the most violent who lead; and really if the Democratic Party, as revived, is to have any leadership in Washington, we know of nobody so likely to succeed to it as FERNANDO WOOD. At all events, whatever the power behind him, this man will attempt to use against the Presdent all the airs of authority and all the arts of intimidation, of which his long discipline in the democratic politics of this city -- the most mephistophilian school extant -- has made him the complete master.

abstract: -- THE STORM. -- The storm which raged so fearfully over our City all yesterday extended over an immense extent of the United States. We hear of it as far north and east as Portland, Me., and as far south as the furthest points reached by our telegraphic wires in Virginia. It was a storm of fierce wind, driving alternately streets of rain, snow, sleet and hail before it, and veering from point to point of the compass during the day, as it dashed its wet, cold burdens in dismal deluge upon [???] and beast, and upon their habitations and upon all the face of the earth. Through the live-long day and till the late hours, of night, the bleak tempest raged with unspent fury. The sea had its horrors, we may be sure, or which we shall be hearing the sad details as weeks to come. But the land will be a greater sufferer than the sea, in the aggregate of [???] produced. No one could think with out a shudder of the ten thousand tenements of the poof in this and in other cities and throughout the States that would be found unequal to protect the infancy and the sickness within from the piercing cold and fury of the blast.

abstract: It will be recollected that an account has been circulated in the public journals throughout the country, to the effect that an armed force from the United States steamer Montgomery, Capt. CHARLES HUNTER, had driven ashore and burnt an English steamer, near the port of Havana, while a Spanish officer and guard were in possession of the vessel, and a Spanish flag hoisted thereon. This account was derived from the statement of the captain of the vessel destroyed, on his arrival in Havana, and has been widely circulated in this country to the discredit of the commander of the Montgomery, Capt. HUNTER, representing the attack as an act of recklessness, offensive to the Spanish nation and against the usages of international laws.

abstract: -- The journals of the country are speculating largely on the preposterous statement put forth by a letter in the Evening Post, a day or two since, that Mr. BUCHANAN took no steps in regard to the rebellion, during the last few months of his Administration, without consulting Mr. SEWARD. The statement was at once met very directly by a card from Mr. WEED, stating that Mr. SEWARD did not even speak with Mr. BUCHANAN on the subject during the period in question.

abstract: LETTER ECONOMY. --   The Post-Office Department furnishes this morning, in the columns of the TIMES, some very valuable information in regard to the use of stamped envelopes. We do not remember to have ever heard it asserted before that Government can have work done more cheaply than it can be done by private enterprise, where competition is open to all but Postmaster-General BLAIR asks us to believe this in regard to his Department, and indeed, his figures seem to leave no doubt about it -- in the matter of envelopes for the letters we write.

abstract: -- First Lieut. SAM. H. THOMPSON, of the Sixteenth Connecticut Volunteers, who died at East Windsor Hill, Conn., on Oct. 22, was a son of Rev. Dr. THOMSON, a Professor in the Theological Seminar in that place. Lieut. THOMPSON received his fatal wound at the battle of Antietam. He had spent the two years previous to his enlistment in Phillips Academy at Andover, in preparation for college, with a view to the Ministry, and would have entered college this Fall, had he not devoted himself to the service of his country.
lead_paragraph: -- First Lieut. SAM. H. THOMPSON, of the Sixteenth Connecticut Volunteers, who died at East Windsor Hill, Conn., on Oct. 22, was a son of Rev. abstract: Reception given to 41st Massachusetts Regiment, Astor House, NYC; Maj. Gen. Banks, others speak
snippet: Reception given to 41st Massachusetts Regiment, Astor House, NYC; Maj. Gen. Banks, others speak
lead_paragraph: The reception breakfast given to the Forty-first Regiment, announced in the TIMES as likely to be an interesting affair, owing to the fact that Major-Gen. BANKS and Staff would be present, came off yesterday morning at the Astor House. The organization known as the "Sons of Massachusetts" had made every arrangement to celebrate the occasion handsomely, and the energetic agent of the "Old Bay State," Col. FRANK E. HOWE, had put forth all his strength.

abstract: The advance corps of Gen. McCLELLAN's army, under Gen. REYNOLDS, took possession of the town of Warrenton on Thursday afternoon, the rebels evacuating the place without a fight. Seven of them were captured, two of whom, belonging to the infantry, said their regiments had gone up the Valley. Gen. PLLASANTON reported on Thursday ...
lead_paragraph: The advance corps of Gen. McCLELLAN's army, under Gen. REYNOLDS, took possession of the town of Warrenton on Thursday afternoon, the rebels evacuating the place without a fight. Seven of them were captured, two of whom, belonging to the infantry, said their regiments had gone up the Valley. Gen. PLLASANTON reported on Thursday that Stonewall JACKSON was occupying Chester Cap with his command. Chester Gap is an opening in the Blue Ridge between Ashby's Gap and Manassas Gap, and is evidently considered by the rebels as an important position, from the fact of the duty of holding it having been intrusted to JACKSON. Here, doubtless, will occur a heavy battle, if it has not already occurred.

abstract: By the steamship Norwegian, which passed Father Point yesterday on her way to Quebec, we have advices from Europe five days later. The weather continued very hoisterous on the English coast, and marine disasters in considerable members were reported. The English papers were busily engaged in discussing our affairs, and the usual diversity of views continued. There ...
lead_paragraph: By the steamship Norwegian, which passed Father Point yesterday on her way to Quebec, we have advices from Europe five days later. The weather continued very hoisterous on the English coast, and marine disasters in considerable members were reported. The English papers were busily engaged in discussing our affairs, and the usual diversity of views continued. There appears to be nothing new regarding recognition or intervention. The destruction of American ships by the pirate Alabama caused a considerable rise in the rates of insurance for American bottoms at Lloyd's. From France we learn that PERSIGNY and FOULL had consented to remain in the Cabinet -- it is said on assurances from the Emperor that there was nothing reactionary in his present policy regarding Italy, but that he declined to take any hurried step with respect to Rome. GARIBALDI had been removed to Spezzia, and his health was said to have improved again. An advance had taken place in Cotton in the Liverpool market breads offs were firm, but Provisions contended [???]. The market for American Securities was there.

abstract: Editorial answers charges by Democratic organs that party was persecuted during election
snippet: Editorial answers charges by Democratic organs that party was persecuted during election
lead_paragraph: It suits the purposes of some among the Democratic organs to complain of having been terribly persecuted during the recent canvass. They are specially aggrieved at having been styled traitors for supporting Gov. SEYMOCB, who has also, in their judgment, been greatly outraged by similar aspersions upon his loyalty.

snippet: Details of draft rules to be effected in NYS
lead_paragraph: The Draft will take place on Monday. That is so, Gen. ANTHON says it will, and he is the great Mogul of the Conscription -- the "I am" of the enrollment -- the Chief Commissioner of Drafting. It is the purpose of this article to give some idea of the method of making the enrollment and the final completion of the Draft.

abstract: A splendid troop ship and transport has just been added to the navy. She is almost quite ready to go wherever her services may be required, which makes her the more valuable. She is called the Pocohontas, and has been constructed within a few months at Baltimore. Her length is 180 feet; beam, 30 feet; depth, 10 feet, and 900 tons burden. She was built to replace the old Pocohontas, which was wrecked on the Burnside Expedition. The new vessel is only chartered at present by the Government, but may ultimately be purchased. Her loominess is such that she can carry 1,000 troops between decks, and 600 tons of freight in the hold.
lead_paragraph: A splendid troop ship and transport has just been added to the navy. She is almost quite ready to go wherever her services may be required, which makes her the more valuable. She was built to replace the old Pocohontas, which was wrecked on the Burnside Expedition. The new vessel is only chartered at present by the Government, but may ultimately be purchased. Her loominess is such that she can carry 1,000 troops between decks, and 600 tons of freight in the hold.

abstract: Charles H. Winfield vs. Samuel B. Potter. -- This was an action to recover the sum of $1,125, on a written agreement given by the defendant to pay a certain debt contracted by F.F. Belts & Co. It appears that the firm of F.F. Betts & Co. had a contract with the United States Government for the making and delivery of 5,000 sets of military equipments, at $3 45 per set. One of the members of that firm, after the contract was nearly completed, sold and transferred all the assets of the firm, including the contract to the defendant, under an agreement with the defendant that the defendant should pay the firm debts, all of which were contracted for the properly so transferred to the defendant. At the time the property was transferred to the defendant, a portion of it had been delivered at Governor's Island, and the plaintiff held the receipts given therefor as collateral security for money he loaned the firm of F.F. Betts & Co. After the property was transferred to the defendant, he went to the plaintiff and induced him, as is alleged, to give up his collateral receipts on the defendant's giving him a written obligation to pay the debt as soon as he received the money from the Government on the contract of F.F. Betts & Co. The plaintiff alleges be gave up his receipts, and took the defendant's agreement to pay him.

abstract: We are informed by a gentleman who has just come from Wilmington, N.C., that the majority of the people of that city are heartily tired of the war, and would gladly hail a cessation of hostilities and a restoration of the Union. They have seen enough and suffered enough, not only in Wilmington, but throughout the old North State, to satisfy them of the utter folly and wickedness of the rebel attempt to break up the Government. Hundreds of families who, before the rebellion, were living in luxury, are now suffering from absolute want.

abstract: We have advices from Holly Springs to Wednesday morning. There had been no movement of forces from that point, except the transfer of VILLIPIGUE's Division to Meridian. Neither PRICE nor VAN DORN had made the least forward movement. They are not ready to do so, even if there was anything to be gained by it. On the contrary, they were pouring in reinforcements there at a rapid rate. Every day there were fresh and large arrivals, principally from Louisiana and Texas.

abstract: It will be seen by our dispatches this morning that Gen. McCLELLAN has been relieved of his command, and that Gen. BURNSIDE is now in command of the Army of the Potomac. The order was delivered to Gen. McCLELLAN at 11 o'clock...
lead_paragraph: It will be seen by our dispatches this morning that Gen. McCLELLAN has been relieved of his command, and that Gen. BURNSIDE is now in command of the Army of the Potomac. The order was delivered to Gen. McCLELLAN at 11 o'clock on Friday night by Gen. BUCKINGHAM in person, and his last official act was the issuing of an address to his soldiers yesterday, informing them that the command had devolved upon Gen. BURNSIDE, and taking an affectionate leave of them.

abstract: Report on marine disasters resulting from East Coast snowstorm
snippet: Report on marine disasters resulting from East Coast snowstorm
lead_paragraph: Capt. RANTON, of the British bark Mary Rogerson arrived yesterday in the Scotia, and reports that on the 29th of October, in latitude 49, longitude 39 55', the Mary Rogerson was overtaken by a hurricane from the northwest, which hove down the bark, and every thing was washed off the deck. All the masts were cut away to lighten her but to no effect. During the gale JONEPH SEAMAN, of London, was washed overboard and lost. On Nov. 1, in latitude 49 18', longitude 38 16', was taken off the wreck by the Scotia. The Mary Rogerson was from London, Sept. 23, bound for New-York, with 388 tons of coal, consigned to J.A. BELL, of this City. She was built at Newcastle, 388 tons burden, and was named after her owner.

abstract: The Commissioners to whom Judge NELSON referred it, to ascertain the amount of that portion of the missing cargo of the prize ship Hiawatha, which was delivered to Mr. Thomas Ports and not accounted for by him, have filed their report. abstract: Catherine Stallman vs. Philip Palander, This is an action to recover $2,000 damages for an alleged breach of promise to marry. An order of arrest was granted, and the defendant was arrested, and held under $1,000 bail. The affidavits upon which the order was made show that the plaintiff was employed as a domestic, and the defendant as a foreman...
lead_paragraph: Catherine Stallman vs. Philip Palander. -- This is an action to recover $2,000 damages for an alleged breach of promise to marry. An order of arrest was granted, and the defendant was arrested, and held under $1,000 bail. The affidavits upon which the order was made show that the plaintiff was employed as a domestic, and the defendant as a foreman in the establishment of a certain prominent baker and politician in the Fourth-avenue; that the defendant on several occasions promised to marry plaintiff on the 1st ult., and then succeeded in seducing the plaintiff; that she is now pregnant with child, and the defendant has absolutely refused to marry her. She further states that she suffers greatly in body and mind from the improper acts of the defendant. An application is now made to discharge the defendant from arrest or reduce the amount of bail, on an affidavit made by defendant in which he positively denies ever having promised to marry the plaintiff, and he also denies the charge of seduction, and says that advances of an improper character were upon several occasions made by the plaintiff toward the defendant, and defendant says be believes this action has been instituted against him with the view of making him disgorge. He also states that he has no property. The affidavit of the defendant's employer, which was read on behalf of Polander, gives the defendant an unexceptionable character. After hearing the argument the Court took the papers, and this morning refused to grant the application.

abstract: CELEBRATION OF THE DEMOCRATIC VICTORY IN NEW-YORK. -- At sunset the Democratic Artillery, under command of Capt. FRANK CLARK, of the Eleventh Ward, fired a salute of one hundred guns. At 6 o'clock precisely the whole of old Tammany was simultaneously illuminated. The effect was good, and elicited the loud cheers of the assembled multitude. The indomitable Capt. RYNDERS was around as usual, superintending arrangements, and keeping the boys in good humor and in order. Robertson's Band enlivened the occasion by their most popular and patriotic airs. Owing to the condition of the streets, and the threatening aspect of the weather, the attendance was not as large as expected. No regular meeting was organized, but a number of volunteer speeches were delivered in the Hall. The assemblage broke up shortly after the illumination was over, and the lights of Tammany faded into darkness.
lead_paragraph: CELEBRATION OF THE DEMOCRATIC VICTORY IN NEW-YORK. -- At sunset the Democratic Artillery, under command of Capt. FRANK CLARK, of the Eleventh Ward, fired a salute of one hundred guns. abstract: We are now in the centre of the great military movements in this department for the relief of Nashville, Tenn., and Southwestern Kentucky. To-day Gen. FRY's Division marched through town. They will camp at Mill Cave, four miles south of Bowling Green. Gen. SILL'S Division is still encamped there. Some surprise and impatience have been manifested because the troops have not moved forward.
lead_paragraph: BOWLING GREEN, Monday, Nov. 3, 1862.

abstract: Editorial on dangers to commerce in time of war; editorial speculates on reasons for return
snippet: Editorial on dangers to commerce in time of war; editorial speculates on reasons for return
lead_paragraph: It is now pretty generally conceded that a period of war is not necessarily one of commercial disaster. War is an enormous consumer. Its demands are active and imperi- ous. They admit of no delay, and must be supplied at whatever cost. Commercial activity in such circumstances is a necessity. That this activity may be -- frequently is -- something very different from real commercial prosperity, we are willing to admit, but that it may be made conducive to the highest and most substantial prosperity of a country, is abundantly proved by the history of European States. The commercial progress of Great Britain at no time stands out more conspicuously than in the period in which it was engaged in its great struggle with NAPOLEON -- during a part of which time it stood against the combined commercial opposition of Europe.
headline: {'main': 'The Danger of Overtrading in a Time of War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Danger of Overtrading in a Time of War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial on reasons Great Britain wants to keep peace in present crisis; Editorial points out dangers to commerce in time of war; Editorial says some of Seymour backers are not in sympathy with Union in war; Editorial on Lyons return to US
snippet: Editorial on reasons Great Britain wants to keep peace in present crisis; Editorial points out dangers to commerce in time of war; Editorial says some of Seymour backers are not in sympathy with Union in war; Editorial on Lyons return to US
lead_paragraph: The experiences of the existing war in the United States are establishing, beyond all cavil, the supreme importance of American products to the continued welfare of European nations. When peace shall return to our shores, and commerce fall again into its former channels, we may rest assured that no foreign Government having the military power to do us harm will be at all inclined, on any ground short of the necessity of its own existence, to renew the reign of strife.

abstract: There are many persons in this our great Metropolis of New-York, who saw the late mar- ble Custom-house of our noble port rise upon the ruins of the buildings which originally stood upon its site. There we saw the vaults of the eloquent Dr. PHILLIPS' church opened, and felt...
lead_paragraph: There are many persons in this our great Metropolis of New-York, who saw the late mar- ble Custom-house of our noble port rise upon the ruins of the buildings which originally stood upon its site. There we saw the vaults of the eloquent Dr. PHILLIPS' church opened, and felt the nothingness of human things exemplified in the small piles of dark dust, and shingly, tapering pieces of saturated, decayed coffin-wood, which was all that remained of those aforetime active citizen like ourselves, who had been laid into the ground with many tears.
