abstract: Brig.-Gen. C.D. Jameson who died at Bangor, Mo., on Nov. 6, was born in Cumberland County, in that State, on Feb. 24, 1827. He had no military education and but limited opportunities for literary culture. Early in life he embarked in the lumber trade on the Penobscot and by his energy and strict attention to business amassed a large property, which was nearly...
lead_paragraph: -- Brig.-Gen. C.D. Jameson who died at Bangor, Mo., on Nov. 6, was born in Cumberland County, in that State, on Feb. 24, 1827. He had no military education and but limited opportunities for literary culture. Early in life he embarked in the lumber trade on the Penobscot and by his energy and strict attention to business amassed a large property, which was nearly all swept from him by the commercial reverses of 1857. When the rebellion broke out, although his business had so revived as to give him every reason to believe that he might speedily repair his pecuniary losses, he relinquished everything and at once offered his services to the Governor of the State. He was appointed Colonel of the First Maine Regiment and commanded it with such skill and bravery in the battle of Bull Run, that he received the official commendtion of Generals Keyes and Tyler. On Sept. 3, Col. Jameson was made Brigadier-General. His troops were the first to enter Yorktown after its evacuation by the rebels, and during the Peninsula campaign he conducted himself in such a manner as to show that his promotion was deserved. At the battle of Fair Oaks he received the wound from the effects of which he finally died.

abstract: FELLOW CITIZENS: I thank you for the honor conferred upon me by this assembly, though I need not say that in accepting your kindness I take it rather as a mark of interest in the branch of the service which I represent. Massachusetts, by furnishing her men and resources freely and with a loyal spirit, has given ample proof of her devotion to the Union. I can say with pleasure that no men have taken the field who have been more true to their duty than the men of Massachusetts. When victory is won, and I trust it will be won at no distant day, perhaps no other State will [???] contributed more to the result. No shout of joy will be raised in the rebel camp nor in rebellion when the result of to-days election shall be known. I know not what ground those take who have raised this factious opposition, still I cannot believe that any considerable portion of the citizens of the State have a purpose to throw serious obstacles in [???] of the Government.

abstract: Editorial again says some of Seymour backers are not in sympathy with Union in war
snippet: Editorial again says some of Seymour backers are not in sympathy with Union in war
lead_paragraph: Throughout the whole of the late political campaign we recognized the fact that the votes to be cast for Mr. SEYMOUR would come from two entirely opposite classes of voters; that every one who opposed the war and was in favor of peace, immediate and on any terms, would be found voting for him, and that many would also vote for him who were earnestly and honestly in favor of prosecuting the war vigorously till the rebellion was suppressed. We recognize this fact now. The Tribune declares that it found no supporter of SEYMOUR, who did not support him "as the Peace candidate." Our own experience is different. We found many who supported him claiming that he would push on the war heartily. They seemed to us under a very strange hallucination, and we warned them repeatedly that they were going in bad company, and were in danger of being cheated upon this very point, which seemed to us a vital one. They did not give heed to our warnings, and the election of Mr. SEYMOUR is the result.
headline: {'main': 'The Democrats and the Election.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Democrats and the Election.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The steamship Scotia came up to the City yesterday morning, and her advices, which are two days later than those by the Norwegian, are pub- lished this morning. She left Liverpool on the 25th, and Queenstown on the 26th ult. Mr. CAMERON, our Minister to Russia, came as passenger on board the Scotia; also, Lord LYON, the British Minister to this country.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Scotia came up to the City yesterday morning, and her advices, which are two days later than those by the Norwegian, are pub- lished this morning. She left Liverpool on the 25th, and Queenstown on the 26th ult. Mr. CAMERON, our Minister to Russia, came as passenger on board the Scotia; also, Lord LYON, the British Minister to this country. The steamer Gladiator, from Nassau, had arrived at Liverpool, having on board 1,500 bales of cotton. She took over sundry rumors in regard to the proceedings of Commodore WILKES, which had caused some little excitement on 'Change in London and Liverpool. It was alleged that WILKES, with his squadron, had blockaded Bermuda, and refused to withdraw his ships at the request of the Governor. This report lacked confirmation and received but little credence, but it nevertheless had its effect. Mr. GLADSTONE had reiterated his sentiments on the American question, in a letter written to a Manchester merchant. He took occasion to say, however, "that to form opinions upon questions of policy, to announce them to the world, and to take, or be a party to taking any of the steps necessary for giving them effect, are matters which, though connected together, are in themselves distinct, and which may be separated by intervals of time, longer or shorter, according to the particular circumstances of the case." All of which signifies that the time for English recognition or intervention has not yet arrived. The violent gales which had visited England, had also prevailed all over France for several days, inflicting consideraple damage in some sections. The Liverpool cotton market was dull, though no change of prices had taken place. Breadstuff's were steady and firm, and Provisions were flat and heavy. Consols were quiet at 93 1/2 @ 93 2/8 for money.

abstract: Editorial on Vermont settlement of State and Federal issue of parties in state discouraging the draft
snippet: Editorial on Vermont settlement of State and Federal issue of parties in state discouraging the draft
lead_paragraph: One of our cotemporaries, some time ago, in the course of a series of attacks upon the Gov- ernment, for what it claimed were dangerous assaults upon the liberty of the citizen, took occasion to rejoice over a prospect which it thought was impending in Vermont between the National Government and the State Government and the Courts. Some parties had been arrested by order of the Government and locked up in jail for discouraging enlistments -- and a habeas corpus having been issued by the United States District Judge, the Marshal refused, by order of the Government, to bring the men before the Court; whereupon the Judge made an order directing the Marshal to show cause before him why he should not be attached for contempt of Court.

abstract: Gen. McCLELLAN has been removed from the command of the Army of the Potomac and Gen. BURNSIDE appointed in his place. The immediate cause of this removal has been Gen. McCLELLAN's refusal to advance against the enemy, even under the most peremptory orders of the General-in-Chief. It will be seen, by a letter from Gen. HALLECK to the...
lead_paragraph: Gen. McCLELLAN has been removed from the command of the Army of the Potomac and Gen. BURNSIDE appointed in his place. The immediate cause of this removal has been Gen. McCLELLAN's refusal to advance against the enemy, even under the most peremptory orders of the General-in-Chief. It will be seen, by a letter from Gen. HALLECK to the Secretary of War, which we publish in another column, that on the 1st of October Gen. MCCLELLAN was urged by Gen. HALLECK to cross the Potomac and give battle to the enemy, -- being at the same time reminded of the disadvantages of delaying until the Potomac should be swollen, and the roads impaired, by the autumnal rains. Finding that this produced no effect, Gen. MCCLELLAN was "peremptorily ordered" by Gen. HALLECK, on the 6th of October, to "cross the Potomac and give battle to the enemy or drive him South." For three weeks this order was not obeyed, and the only excuse given for not obeying it, so far as appears, -- the want of supplies, -- is shown by the letter of Gen. HALLECK to have been utterly without foundation. The disclosures of that letter, concerning Gen. MCCLELLAN's constant and reiterated complaints of lack of supplies, are very remarkable and deserve special attention.

abstract: A most daring attempt was made during Wednesday night and yesterday morning to rob the Government vault at the Custom-house, which contained at the time one million two hundred and fifty thousand dollars. The vault is built of bricks, cement and iron. The walls of the Custom-house form two sides of the vault which stands in a corner of the room occupied by the Collector of Customs.
lead_paragraph: A most daring attempt was made during Wednesday night and yesterday morning to rob the Government vault at the Custom-house, which contained at the time one million two hundred and fifty thousand dollars. The vault is built of bricks, cement and iron. The walls of the Custom-house form two sides of the vault which stands in a corner of the room occupied by the Collector of Customs. The vault is strongly constructed. The walls are about fourteen inches thick and between every layer of bricks there is also a layer of crossed and riveted iron firmly imbedded in the cement. The vault contained all the money belonging to the Pay Department, as well as a large sum to be disbursed by Major HILL, who is acting as mustering officer here. The burglars, though amply provided with tools, could not open the heavy iron door of the vault, so they set to work with crow-bar and chisel to dig a hole through the only exposed side. They succeeded in digging out the bricks and making a large aperture in the wall, but the iron still remained and could not be removed. The portion of the money not contained in small iron safes, but in packages and bags, was located at a point some four or five feet from the aperture in the vault. Not being able to get into the vault, the burglars improvised a hook, with which they attempted to drag the bags up to the aperture, but again the iron bars interfered. They could see and feel the money, but could not get at it. The work accomplished by the rascals must have occupied several hours, and it is thought that the early dawn must have caught them in the state of progress we have described, and thus they were compelled to abandon their work without taking away a single red cent.

abstract: The mines are located in Sussex County, N. They were known, and extensive mining operations were carried on, before any permanent, settlements...
lead_paragraph: The mines are located in Sussex County, N. J., and yield an ore unique in its lithological characteristics, and is the only known locality where Franklinite and red oxide of zinc has been found, but by whom and at what era these mines were discovered, is not authentically established. They were known, and extensive mining operations were carried on, before any permanent, settlements were made by the whites, in their immediate neighborhood, as several shafts and galleries still remaining on Sterling Hill clearly prove. These old works, from the fact that Lord STIRLING was once the owner of the lands upon which they are situated, have been attributed to him. The time Lord STIRLING became the owner has not been ascertained, but an original survey of the tract made in 1749 describes "the old mine holes." A section has been taken from the remains of a red cedar, that has grown in one of the pits since the working was abandoned, and it proves that period to have been more than one hundred and twenty years ago. In 1755, an old mining pick was found in one of the galleries by a hunter, who subsequently settled in the vicinity, and has a son, now a very aged man, living in the county.

abstract: * * * There is KRUPP, the Prussian, who forges 10-inch steel columbiads, solid, and whose guns are used all over Europe. And there is HOWELL, the Englishman, whose cast-steel forgings are as homogeneous as copper and resist a tensile strain of 100,000 pounds, while that of the best iron is 70,000. Plates of this steel are found to offer above twice the resistance of iron plates to shot.
lead_paragraph: * * * There is KRUPP, the Prussian, who forges 10-inch steel columbiads, solid, and whose guns are used all over Europe. And there is HOWELL, the Englishman, whose cast-steel forgings are as homogeneous as copper and resist a tensile strain of 100,000 pounds, while that of the best iron is 70,000. Plates of this steel are found to offer above twice the resistance of iron plates to shot. But we need not go abroad. An equally good metal is similarly made in Pittsburgh, and if the Franklinite ore found in Sussex County, New-Jersey, prove to be what it is represented, the best iron ore of the world, the material for the production of the most perfect steel in the world will be in our possession. * * *

abstract: The Delaware Bank at Delhi, Delaware Co., N.Y., was entered and robbed in a similar manner a year or two ago. The burglars effected their object by tunneling under the building and attacking the bottom of the vault; this, although covered by heavy flag-stone, was broken and forced upward by two powerful jack-screws, and thus the bank vault was relieved of its valuable contents.
lead_paragraph: The Delaware Bank at Delhi, Delaware Co., N.Y., was entered and robbed in a similar manner a year or two ago. The burglars effected their object by tunneling under the building and attacking the bottom of the vault; this, although covered by heavy flag-stone, was broken and forced upward by two powerful jack-screws, and thus the bank vault was relieved of its valuable contents. Although it was evident that the rogues must have been days, and perhaps weeks, in making their underground excavations, so nicely were their whole operations carried on that no suspicions were excited, until the Cashier, one fine morning, found himself unable to unlock his vault. The rogues had plugged or fastened the lock from the inside, after perpetrating the robbery, and the authorities of the Bank, naturally supposing that the lock of the vault only was out of order, were some two days in trying to effect an entrance, before cutting into their doors; in the mean time the robbers were far away with their booty, and it is hardly necessary to add, no traces of them or their treasures have ever been discovered.

abstract: Mr. COBDEN's speech before theManchester Chamber of Commerce, which we give in full this morning, on the subject of a reform of maritime law, and an alteration in respect to belligerent rights, with special reference to the question of commercial blockades, will be read with general interest. It is an ingenious and, from a theoretical point of view, in the main, just exposition of the evil and impropriety of commercial blockades; and Mr. COBDEN states broadly, and confirms logically, the old and oft-asserted American doctrine on the subject. He is led to his conclusion, however, which is antagonistic to the European doctrine, and to the current English view, simply by the evils that are being suffered in Lancashire from our blockade of the rebel ports, and the consequent stoppage of the cotton supply. "So grave and alarming has this evil become," says Mr. COBDEN, "that it presents itself to those who look forward for six months (if the war goes on) in such a hideous aspect, that it is apt to beget violent thoughts in our minds as to some violent remedy." He acknowledges, however, that recognition of the South would do nothing to obtain cotton, and nothing less than successful war would avail, and Mr. COBDEN of course opposes all belligerent action. It is a question that he is arguing at present merely in its theoretical aspect, and the present state of affairs furnishes a forcible illustration of his theory. One of the points Mr. COBDEN makes is that England would not have recognized the principle of closing the Southern ports by proclamation, which principle was at one time so strongly favored in Congress and by a portion of the Press -- but that she would recognize nothing less than a legitimate effective blockade.

One of the points Mr. COBDEN makes is that England would not have recognized the principle of closing the Southern ports by proclamation, which principle was at one time so strongly favored in Congress and by a portion of the Press -- but that she would recognize nothing less than a legitimate effective blockade.

abstract: Brooklyn Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum destroyed; 2 killed
snippet: Brooklyn Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum destroyed; 2 killed
lead_paragraph: About 2 1/2 o'clock, Sunday morning, a fire broke, out in the extensive building on Bedford-avenue, between Willoughby and DeKalb-avenues, Brooklyn, occupied as an Asylum for Roman Catholic orphan boys, and resulted in its complete destruction, together with the loss of two lives. The structure is of brick, 150 feet front by 100 in depth, and five stories in height. The grounds attached comprise fourteen lots, and extend from Bedford-avenue to Spencer-street, affording ample space for exercise in fine weather. About 150 feet in the rear is a wooden shed about 30 by 75 feet in extent, which is designed for a play-house in inclement weather. The main building is divided into apartments for the accommodation of the Superintendents and Assistants, and conveniences are provided for 350 children. The second, third and fourth floors were used as sleeping apartments. Heat was furnished by means of furnaces, two of which were located in the basement under the north wing, and two under the south wing. The main entrances in front and rear of the centre building, the halls and stairways, were all of wide dimensions, and to this feature, together with the presence of mind and the activity displayed by those in charge, it is mainly owing that the conflagragration did not result more disastrously -- for, as near as could be ascertained, two children only, out of 248, lost their lives.

abstract: Gov. SEYMOUR made a speech at Utica on Thursday night, to a large crowd that came to congratulate him on the result of the election. We find no report of his speech, and only a meagre reference to it in the Utica papers. We do not see that he threw much light on the specific manner in which his election is to restore the Union, though he was profuse in declarations that it would have that effect. "The success of the Democracy," he said, "would bring back the country to the position of years ago, when the Constitution was the supreme law, and the laws were impartially administered. Henceforth the laws were to be obeyed, and constitutional authority respected." We can understand how all this may happen in the North, -- but not how Mr. SEYMOUR's election is to restore that happy time to the Southern States. He says that "from this time henceforth it would seem there is a great Union party all through the South, who desire to cooperate with a party they know to be ready to welcome them back into the Union." This may be so -- but as yet we don't see it.

abstract: Report on discovery of crystalized iron (Franklinite), a residue of zinc, mined only in New Jersey
snippet: Report on discovery of crystalized iron (Franklinite), a residue of zinc, mined only in New Jersey
lead_paragraph: CRYSTALITED IRON, or "Franklinite," is the production of the mine of the New-Jersey Zinc Company. There is but one mine of this ore in the world. The zinc being first extracted from the ore, the residue is the brilliant and singular metal which we have named "Crystalized Iron." For many years, no use was made of this metal, and it was simply kept in small specimens in gentlemen's cabinets as a curiosity. However, a use has at last been found for it, and, since it has proved so superior in this instance, many other avenues for its introduction are now opening, and it bids fair to prove not only one of the most remarkable, but one of the best metals the world has ever known. As a preventive against drilling, when combined with wrought iron and steel, it is the best and most perfect protection against a burglar now known. Chilled iron, by late improvements in hardening drills, can be easily bored. Hardened steel is not only so brittle as to be almost useless, but its temper can be drawn by a blow-pipe, and then it is at the mercy of the burglar's tools. With "the crystalized" the case is different; it can be furnished any thickness, is not so brittle as any other hard metal, cannot be affected by a blow-pipe, and is the hardest material to bore through ever yet produced.

abstract: Mr. GRAU'S brief season of opera--for, according to the advertisement, it is not to extend beyond ten nights--commences this evening. GUERRABELLA will make her debut. Report speaks highly of the lady's talent. BRIGNOLI, AMODIO and SUSINI sustain the other parts.

abstract: The steamship Scotia came up to the City on Saturday morning, bringing advices two days later than those by the Norwegian. She left Liverpool on the 25th, and Queenstown on the 26th ult. Mr. CAMERON, our Minister to Russia, came passenger on board the Scotia; also, Lord LYON, the British  Minister to this country. The steamer Gladiator, from Nassau, had arried at Liverpool, having on board 1,500 bales on cotton.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Scotia came up to the City on Saturday morning, bringing advices two days later than those by the Norwegian. She left Liverpool on the 25th, and Queenstown on the 26th ult. Mr. CAMERON, our Minister to Russia, came passenger on board the Scotia; also, Lord LYON, the British Minister to this country. The steamer Gladiator, from Nassau, had arried at Liverpool, having on board 1,500 bales on cotton. She took over sundry rumors in regard to the proceedings of Commodore WILKES, which had caused some little excitement on 'Change in London and Liverpool. It was alleged that WILKES, with his squadron, had blockaded Bermuda, and refused to withdraw his ships at the request of the Governor. This report lacked confirmation and received but little credence, but it nevertheless had its effect. Mr. GLADSTONE had reiterated his sentiments on the American question, in a letter written to a Manchester merchant. He took occasion to say, however, "that to form opinions upon questions of policy, to announce them to the world, and to take, or be a party to taking any of the steps necessary for giving them effect, are matters which, though connected together, are in themselves distinct, and which may be separated by intervals of time, longer or shorter, according to the particular circumstances of the case." All of which signifies that the time for English recognition or intervention has not yet arrived. From Greece, we learn that King OTHO had abdicated the throne in favor of his brother, but the people being still dissatisfied, the Bavarian line had been entirely deposed. The violent gales which had visited England, had also prevailed all over France for several days, inflicting considerable damage in some sections. The Liverpool cotton market was dull, though no change of prices had taken place. Breadstuffs were steady and firm, and Provisions were flat and heavy. Consols were quiet at 93 1/2 @ 93 5/8 for money.

abstract: Editorial lauds Pleasanton, now pursuing Stuart cavalry
snippet: Editorial lauds Pleasanton, now pursuing Stuart cavalry
lead_paragraph: -- Almost every day for the last two months, we have recorded some splendid exploit on the part of that valiant and invincible cavalry officer, Gen. ALFRED PLEASANTON. He first appeared prominently after the battle of Antietam, when he harassed terribly the enemy's rear, pursued them hotly to the Potomac, and played havoc among their faltering regiments. Subsequently he was sent in chase of STUART, being permitted to start just about the time the rebel officer was sweeping along our left line; and though it was preposterous to suppose that he could actually overtake STUART, yet he and his men made one of the most remarkable gallopades that we have had in the course of the war. Since our army began to move along the east side of the Blue Ridge Mountains, PLEASANTON seems to have been in perpetual pursuit of the foe and perpetual fight; and in every case has he been victorious. He has met STUART and his men, heretofore the terror of our army, on half a dozen occasions, and in every instance STUART's horse has shown PLEASANTON his tail. On Saturday we gave a vivid pen-picture, from our correspondent, of the three days' exciting chase after STUART's cavalry, which ended on Monday evening last, and in which, after a brisk fight of two or three hours, STUART's force was defeated with heavy loss. On Saturday last, PLEASANTON had another tilt with his rebel foemen, of which we have a telegraphic mention this morning. It was at Little Washington, some forty miles south of the place where the previous fight was fought, and our redoubtable cavalryman had his usual luck -- capturing three pieces of STUART's artillery and a number of his men.

abstract: It will beseen that both of the advancing columns of our army are pushing down into Eastern Virginia with some celerity. Gen. PLEASANTON, from what lately was BURNSIDE's column, has reached Little Washington, in Culpepper County, some twenty-five miles south of the Manassas Gap Railroad; and Gen. BAYARD, from SIGEL's column, has reached the Rappahannock River, and holds the railroad bridge of the Orange and Alexandria Railroad. What may be the succeeding movements of the bodies it is difficult to tell -- whether one or both will advance onward to Gordonsville, or whether one or both will move down the Rappahannock to Fredericksburgh, and try our luck by that route to Richmond. If we knew positively where the rebel army is, we might speculate on these points. But the newspapers and the correspondents seem to know pretty nearly as little of the enemy's whereabouts as our Generals do. It is confidently asserted to-day that they have retreated to their fortified base at Richmond, that they still threaten to enter Maryland, that they are at Waterloo, and that they, are at Gordonsville, where they have been joined by BRAGG's army from Tennessee. It is likely that there is more or less truth to each and all of these stories, excepting that one which implies that they propose again to attempt to enter Maryland or Pennsylvania. There seems little doubt that LEE has left Winchester, as no army would dare to permit itself to be outflanked as that position now is by our forces.

abstract: A very singular and important case has just been tried in the Common Pleas, Judge LUDLOW. It involves the validity of a will made by a colored woman, NANCY COOTS, by which she devised a great part of her property, real and personal, to MERCI K. WILLIAMSON, the wife of PASSMORE WILLIAMSON, who had been acting as trustee for NANCY COOTS. The suit was brought by REUBEN COOTS, the husband of...
lead_paragraph: A very singular and important case has just been tried in the Common Pleas, Judge LUDLOW. It involves the validity of a will made by a colored woman, NANCY COOTS, by which she devised a great part of her property, real and personal, to MERCI K. WILLIAMSON, the wife of PASSMORE WILLIAMSON, who had been acting as trustee for NANCY COOTS. The suit was brought by REUBEN COOTS, the husband of NANCY, against PASSMORE WILLIAMSON. NANCY COOTS, who made the will, was originally a slave in Virginia, and, after securing her freedom, came to Philadelphia, about twenty years ago, and resided for the most of her time in the Twenty-fourth Ward. She was industrious, and succeeded in accumulating a property amounting in value, it is estimated, to about $10,000, although some of the witnesses fixed it as high as $12,000. She was twice married, her second husband being REUBEN COOTS, the plaintiff in the present case, to whom she was married nine years ago. Three years before her death, which took place in 1861, PASSMORE WILLIAMSON was introduced to her, by a Mr. CRENSHAW, as a proper person to take charge of her business, and in August, 1859, a deed of trust was executed, by which PASSMORE WILLIAMSON was made trustee for the estate, "to hold, devise, manage, and take care of the same, and the rents, income," &c., and to pay over "to her, for her separate use, free from any control of her said husband, the rents and income thereof, after deducting necessary and proper costs," &c. The right to make a will was also reserved by NANCY in the deed of trust.

abstract: The term "Burglar-Proof" is so often applied to work that is unworthy of the name, that it is advisable, in these times of ingenious robberies, for Bankers themselves to use a little of their own good sense, and inquire particularly into the mode and manner in which their safes are made "secure against thieves." It is too frequently the case that Bankers and others allow themselves...
lead_paragraph: The term "Burglar-Proof" is so often applied to work that is unworthy of the name, that it is advisable, in these times of ingenious robberies, for Bankers themselves to use a little of their own good sense, and inquire particularly into the mode and manner in which their safes are made "secure against thieves." It is too frequently the case that Bankers and others allow themselves to be imposed upon by representations of interested manufacturers, that their particular make cannot be drilled, broken or forced. This has aneffect where such personal assurance are implicitly relied upon, but we tell the banking community, that burglar-proof safety depends entirely upon the price they pay, and it is for themselves only to dictate how much or how little security they desire to have.

abstract: Gen. McCLELLAN, it will be seen by our dispatches this morning, has been relieved of the command of the Army of the Potomac, and Gen. BURNSIDE has been installed in his place. The outer making this new arrangement was delivered to Gen. McCLELLAN at Headquarters at 11 o'clock on Thursday night, by Gen. BUCKINGHAM, of the War Department, in person.
lead_paragraph: Gen. McCLELLAN, it will be seen by our dispatches this morning, has been relieved of the command of the Army of the Potomac, and Gen. BURNSIDE has been installed in his place. The outer making this new arrangement was delivered to Gen. McCLELLAN at Headquarters at 11 o'clock on Thursday night, by Gen. BUCKINGHAM, of the War Department, in person. Gen. MCCLELLAN's last official act was the issuing of an address on Saturday to the army, giving the information in a few words that the command had devolved upon Gen. BURNSIDE, and taking an affectionate leave of his fellow-soldiers. The General and his Staff were to leave yesterday for Trenton.

abstract: The recent news from England indicates that there is to be no immediate change of the policy of that Government toward the United States. Mr. GLADSTONE explains his late speech, in which he gave his personal recognition of the Jeff. Davis Confederacy, by leaving it wholly unexplained. The substance of the two letters he has written on the subject...
lead_paragraph: The recent news from England indicates that there is to be no immediate change of the policy of that Government toward the United States. Mr. GLADSTONE explains his late speech, in which he gave his personal recognition of the Jeff. Davis Confederacy, by leaving it wholly unexplained. The substance of the two letters he has written on the subject is, simply, that the speech expressed an opinion that he had long entertained. How far the personal conviction of a Minister goes toward the initiation of Government policy is left to the public as a very wide field for speculation.

abstract: We are glad to see that Gen. FITZ-JOHN PORTER is about to be tried on sundry charges that have been preferred against him by officers of the army. These charges, we understand, come from four different sources, and are very serious. They are such as no man can have hanging over his head without absolute disgrace, and Gen. PORTER must therefore be personally anxious for their speedy examination.

abstract: lican friends in the interior find it hard to resign themselves to the small help they get from, the City in their political contests. They think, it is asking a little too much to expect them to carry the State against 38,000 majority, in New-York City and Brooklyn alone. There is great justice in their complaint, -- but it is not quite easy to see where we can find the remedy. The Republicans of this City have worked with vigor and energy in the canvass just closed. They knew in advance that they had up-hill work before them, and tried to secure from the State Convention a nomination that would lighten the burden. They failed, however, to convince their friends from, the interior of the necessity of any such concession to City prejudice, and were forced; accordingly to contend against difficulties which proved too formidable for them. It is barely possible that these things may be more judiciously managed hereafter; though we think the Oswego Times is not far out of the way, when it concludes that they must make up their minds to carry elections hereafter without the help of New-York.

abstract: editorial says 4 of 9 new Congressmen are emancipationists
snippet: editorial says 4 of 9 new Congressmen are emancipationists
lead_paragraph: quite certain that at least four, and probably five, of the nine Congressmen just elected in Missouri, will be Emancipationists. This result is worthy of special attention, as showing a progress in the public sentiment of the Slave States on this subject, which is in the highest degree encouraging. While certain portions of the people of the Free States are terribly alarmed lest Slavery should be in some way damaged or interfered with, the people of the loyal Slave States are preparing to meet this inevitable issue with courage and common sense. One of the worst features connected with Slavery in the South, has been the absolute silence forced upon the people in regard to it. No evil is intolerable so long as the community in which it exists is free to discuss it. For in the long run every community, which is free to speak and to act, will adopt the policy required by its permanent and substantial interests. Error is not to be feared so long as truth is left free to combat it.

abstract: Editorial on coming municipal elections
snippet: Editorial on coming municipal elections
lead_paragraph: not seem to be aware that we are to have an election for City officers within a month. We hear none of the usual notes of preparation. There seems to be an absolute lull in the political field. The fact is the Democrats made so clean a sweep of our City, at the last election, that the Republicans seem to think, it scarcely worth while to contest the matter further. The chances of success are not flattering enough to elicit any great degree of activity from those who usually take the lead in political movements. Whether the Republicans intend to surrender the City offices without a struggle we do not know; but if not, it is quite time they were making preparations for it. It was supposed that the Comptrollership would be the principal bone of contention; -- but the only struggle thus far for its possession seems to be in the Democratic ranks. According to present appearances the election is likely to be allowed to go by default.

abstract: Editorial on Assembly election results

lead_paragraph: far make it certain that sixty-four Republicans and Union men have been elected to the State Assembly. Besides these, Mr. CUTLER, elected in Albany, was nominated as a Union man, and elected without opposition, -- and although he has been hitherto a Democrat, his vote is confidently claimed for the Union side. In Montgomery County also, there is a chance of the election of the Union candidate, and in Onondaga the official returns may show that Mr. LEAVENWORTH has been elected instead of Mr. CLARK, his Democratic opponent, for whom only six majority are claimed. If any one of these three chances are decided in their favor, the Republicans and Union men will have a majority in the Assembly, and will be able to organize the House and elect a United States Senator.

abstract: In three weeks, counting from yesterday, Congress will meet in annual session. It has been very much the habit to predict of every approaching session of Congress that it will be "the most important ever held." Up to this time, however, there has been no unusual interest attached to the ensuing session. There are several reasons for
lead_paragraph: In three weeks, counting from yesterday, Congress will meet in annual session. It has been very much the habit to predict of every approaching session of Congress that it will be "the most important ever held." Up to this time, however, there has been no unusual interest attached to the ensuing session. There are several reasons for this; but the chief reason is that the late session of Congress seemed in its legislation to have covered the whole ground of the rebellion and the necessities of the war. The Confiscation and Emancipation Acts, the Tariff and Internal Revenue Bills, the Pacific Railroad Charter, and the Act declaring freedom forever in all Territories of the Union -- these great measures provided for the support of the Government and the direction of its policy for present and future, in time of war and time of peace; and it seemed at the close of the session that the Government might go on for years successfully without another meeting of Congress. Hence no interest has been excited by the near approach of the time for the reassembling of Congress; and the declaration made a few days since that the President was preparing the materials for his Message was forgotten almost as soon as made, and no speculation has been indulged in as to its contents.

abstract: ARREST OF AN ALLEGED MURDERER. -- A negro named JOSEPH PIGEN, was arrested by Officer HARNEY, of Jersey City, near the Morris Canal Basin, onSunday evening, on a charge of committing a murder in Pennsylvania nearly two weeks ago. It appears that a man named EDWIN S. BENNER, residing at Bethlehem, Penn., was at a public house on the evening of the 27th ult., engaged in playing a game of bagatelle. Two negroes were present, and one of them getting in the way Mr. BENNER made some remarks at which the colored men took offence, and soon afterwards went out. Later in the evening, Mr. BENNER started for home, and on his way was waylaid by the negroes and beaten with clubs, sustaining injuries which caused his death the following day. The negroes escaped, but one of them, named JOHN G. CLARK, was arrested in Newark on Saturday and the other was arrested as above-stated. He was committed to await a requisition from Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF AN ALLEGED MURDERER. -- A negro named JOSEPH PIGEN, was arrested by Officer HARNEY, of Jersey City, near the Morris Canal Basin, onSunday evening, on a charge of committing a murder in Pennsylvania nearly two weeks ago. abstract: It will be remembered that notice of a very bold robbery, at the Bank of America, was published a few days since, whereby the firm of RIGGS & Co., of Wall-street, had stolen from their possession, a tin bank box, containing bonds, certificates of stock, and other securities, representing value in the sum of $500,000. The crime was accomplished in some mysterious manner, on Wednesday last, between the hours of 3 1/2 and 4 1/2 o'clock in the afternnoon. The victims were sorely puzzled as to how or by whom this daring theft had been committed, and forthwith they resolved to place the whole matter of recovering the property, and arresting the offender, in the hands of the shrewd New-York detectives. Messrs. KELSOE and RADFORD were accordingly set to work upon it after being informed of all the facts and circumstances connected with the robbery, which were in the possession of Messrs. RIGGS & Co. In the meantime a reward of $1,000 was offered by the firm for the return of the box and its contents, or for such information as would lead to their recovery. Subsequently the reward was increased to $2,000, and notice thereof published in the City papers, notice was also given to the proper officers to stop the payment or transfer of all the bonds, certificates, &c., minutely describing each one of them. Yesterday the detectives succeeded in recovering the box and its contents. It is understood, however, that no arrests have been made, and in what manner the recovery of the property was effected has not yet been made public by the officials.

abstract: NUM's Hotel de Curiosity, corner of Broadway and Ann-street, may be seen three of the queerest-looking specimens of humanity this side of the North Pole. With unpronounceable names, non-understandable gibberish, and most outrageous tout ensemble, three genuine Esquimaux make their bows continually for several hours during each day of the week. Mr. C.F. HALL., the Arctic Explorer, is responsible for their introduction to this clime. We understand that during the inclement weather of Saturday and Sunday they fairly stood upon their heads in inexpressible ectasies of joy at the sight of the snow and the chill of the raw East wind.

abstract: Democratic victory rally, NYC; Wood, Van Buren, others speak
snippet: Democratic victory rally, NYC; Wood, Van Buren, others speak
lead_paragraph: The headquarters of the Democratic Union Association, corner of Twenty-second-street and Broadway, were crowded last evening, on the occasion of a grand jollification got up with a view to celebrate the recent Democratic victory in this State. The various inscriptions and banners which have done service throughout the campaign were again brought into requisition, and a fine band of music on the balcony vied with the Eleventh Ward big Seymour gun in the street, to attract the faithful. The first sign of life inside the room was an enthusiastic response to a call for "three cheers for MCCLELLAN." These were followed up with cheers for WOOD, MCSWEENEY, JOHN VAN BUREN, more cheers for MCCLELLAN, groans for WADSWORTH, laughter at the same, "three groans for the whole Republican Party," also for any other man. The band then played "Come Love! Come!"

abstract: The wall of a new building in process of construction by the bakery firm of HECEER BROTHERS, near the corner of Rutger and Monroe strests, fell down last evening at about 8  o'clock, burying alive an entire family, consisting of a man, his wife and three children, of whom two only are likely to survive their injuries. The name of the unfortunate
lead_paragraph: The wall of a new building in process of construction by the bakery firm of HECEER BROTHERS, near the corner of Rutger and Monroe strests, fell down last evening at about 8 1/2 o'clock, burying alive an entire family, consisting of a man, his wife and three children, of whom two only are likely to survive their injuries. The name of the unfortunate family is SEABROOK, and their residence was a two-story and basement frame building, directly in the rear of the HECKER bakery. Mr. SEABROOK had just returned from his day's work, and having taken supper, was assisting his wife in preparing their young children for bed, sitting in the basement, excepting their oldest child, a boy of ten years, who was asleep on the second floor. Suddenly they were startled by a swaying of the tenement, accompanied by a dull, dead sound, and a gradual settling of the ceiling down upon their heabs. With parental instinct, the father clutched his youngest child, a babe nine months old, and the mother took the re-remaining little one, a girl of four years, and both awaited the terrible fate which they saw to be inevitable. But their own misfortune did not make them unmindful of the peril of their boy, whom they called, and bade him fly for his life. Singularly enough, he succeeded in reaching the street unscathed, his escape being incomprehensible both to himself and everyone else. The thundering crash of the fallen wall aroused the entire neighborhood, and, in a short time, several hundred people had assembled in great excitement, and in genuine earaestness to render assistance. As soon as it was ascertained that several poor creatures were beneath the mass of brick, mortar and shattered wood, Officer CARNES, of the Seventh Precinct Police, on whose post the accident happened, crept through an aperture in the debris scarcely large enough to admit of the passage of his body, and at the imminent risk of his life began the work of extrication. In consequence of the contracted space in which he was compelled to labor he found the task to be difficult and tedious, but by downright and persistent effort, he finally made a breaeh through the floor of the second story, which was crushed to a level with the pavement of the street, and Roundsman LOCKE immediately entered to aid him. In about an hour they wereable to reach the sufferers, whose cries of distress filled the hearts of the heroic men with anguish, and awakened liveliest sympathy and torturing suspense in the crowd outside. A more painful scene can seldom have been witnessed. The dead body of the infant was first extricated, and soon afterwards Mrs. SEACROOK was taken out. Both her legs were found to he broken, and the chance of her surviving is small.

abstract: The California steamer of to-morrow will have among her passengers one of the Brothers LELAND, of the Metropolitan Hotel, of this City. He goes out to San Francisco to aid and assist his nephew. LEWIS LELAND, now there, furnishing and equipping the new and magnificent "OCCIDENTAL HOTEL," recently erected, and to be opened on the 1st of January next. [See advertisement.] The "Golden City" of the West will hereafter rank with our Atlantic cities in possessing an hotel of adequate capacity, elegance and excellence, to the wants of travellers. The well-sustained reputation of the Messrs. LELAND, as practical hotel-keepers, is a sufficient guarantee that the "Occidental" will be conducted with care and liberality, assuring the most fastidious that their comfort will be amply provided for.

abstract: On Sunday evening the regular monthly meeting of the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum was held in the male schoolroom connected with St. James Cathedral, on Jay-street, Mr. F.G. TURNER, Vice-President, in the Chair. After the minutes of the preceding meeting had been read, the Chairman called attention to the fact of the Male Orphan Asylum having been destroyed by fire that morning, causing 242 children to be thrown destitute on the community. He hoped that some action would at once be taken to alleviate their sufferings. A subscription, on motion of Mr. J. O'DONNELL, was then opened, and the following donations made:

abstract: We have received sundry communications touching JOHN VAN BUREN's publication of Gen. SCOTT's letter. We do not publish, them, because we think Mr. VAN BUREN's explanation of that matter, unless objected to by Gen. SCOTT, must be deemed satisfactory by everybody else. He states that Gen. SCOTT gave him first a copy of the letter and afterwards the original autograph. He made no request that it should not be published, nor did he give him to understand in any way that it was to be deemed a confidential letter.

abstract: The trial trip of the steam propeller Union, which was to have taken place on Sunday, did not come off on account of the high storm which prevailed. Capt. WATSON, however, announced that the trip would be undertaken on Monday morning, if the weather should prove favorable. In accordance
lead_paragraph: The trial trip of the steam propeller Union, which was to have taken place on Sunday, did not come off on account of the high storm which prevailed. Capt. WATSON, however, announced that the trip would be undertaken on Monday morning, if the weather should prove favorable. In accordance therewith, quite a goodly company, including many ladies, were on hand at 7 o'clock yesterday morning, when the hawser was thrown, and the vessel slid away, scarcely any one being conscious of the fact until she was clear of the dock. With colors living and "Peter" set, she sped away down the stream as prettily and gracefully as could well be desired. Her course was from the foot of Thirteenth-street down to the "Horse Shoe," and up again to the foot of Beach-street. Nothing unusual marked the sail down, except the interception by the United States Revenue Cutter, opposite Quarantine, which, on learning the nature of the voyage, drew off and allowed the Union to prosecute her trial trip. On the way up, a fine collation was served up by Capt. WILSON, under the superintendence of Steward MILLS, which was partaken of by the company with, at least, an appreciative feeling.

abstract: The cases which have arisen out of the capture of the slaver Nightingale, and which were disposed of yesterday in the United States Circuit Court, will rank among the most remarkable of the Slave-trade cases. The vessel was captured with her cargo of negroes on board -- and it is almost incredible that in such a case every one of those who were captured while engaged in the act should escape scot free. Yet such has been the result.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- There is so much pleasure in the opening night of the Academy that it is probably from benevolent motives that Mr. GRAU has heretofore had a new season and a new opening night for almost every week of his management. The agreeable excitement of meeting familiar faces in well remembered spots, the pleasant pressure at the doors, the immense display of new things that help to drape the fair, and a general and seemingly meritorious abandonment to a new regime, are some of the characteristics that mark the event, and disappear forever afterwards. Toward the end of the season (except when Mr. GRAU saves sinners by having the beginning and the end unsymmetrically near to each other) one gets tired of always sitting next to Jones, with that fright of a Smith directly in front, and the gentle pressure is referred to as a disgraceful crowd and the new things act as irritants, provoking wrathful reflections, and the manager is unanimously voted to be a humbug. Let us hope that these awful changes of sentiment will not be produced by Mr. GRAU's season of ten nights -- the first of which series came off last evening, and was brilliant and delightful as such things could be. The house was well filled, every desirable seat being occupied. The opera selected for the opening, was VERDI's "Traviata" -- a work which is always popular with a New-York audience.

abstract: Editorials on work to be done by Congress when it reconvenes; editorial on Van Buren speech
snippet: Editorials on work to be done by Congress when it reconvenes; editorial on Van Buren speech
lead_paragraph: A significant meeting of the Democracy was held last evening at the headquarters of the Democratic Union Association, corner of Twenty-- second-street and Broadway. JOHN VAN BUREN made a speech favoring the declaration of an armistice, to enable the people of the South to go home and elect representatives to Congress before the last of January, so as to avoid the coming proclamation of freedom to their slaves. He was also in favor of a Convention to amend the Constitution so as to admit of the restoration of the old Union. FERNANDO WOOD and JAMES BRIGGS made speeches in favor of interposing the power of the State to prevent the encroachments of alleged usurpation by the General Government.

abstract: Yesterday the remains of the late venerable Doctor BERRIAN were consigned to the earth, amid the solemn and beautiful ceremonies in which he officiated during the greater part of the last half century. Shortly after his decease his residence was besieged by a host of friends, a large number of them being his fellow-clergymen of this City, who mingled their grief with that of the family, and mourned with them the great loss which they, the church and the public sustained in the venerable clergyman's departure.

abstract: Our correspondents with the army, who write since the removal of Gen. MCCLELLAN, do not mention any indications of that mutinous spirit which some who knew nothing about the army feared might ensue upon the displacement of a commander whom the soldiers honored and loved. On the contrary, several letters which we publish this morning, from correspondents with different corps of the Army of the Potomac, expressly state that the army is well satisfied with the change, and that the soldiers in general are delighted at the prospect of more active and effective work under Gen. BURNSIDE.

abstract: The Supervisors met at noon yesterday as a Board of County Canvassers. The returns were unusually correct, and only in one or two instances was it found necessary to lay them over for correction. In these cases the errors were those of omission, and evidently clerical.The majorities do not differ in any material degree, and the total vote will not be affected. The Wards canvassed were the First, Second, Third, Fourth, Sixth, Seventh and Thirteenth. The Board adjourned to meet to-day, at noon.

abstract: -If wit is the "conjunction of opposite ideas," then certainly the brightest scintillations of wit which fell from the lips of JOHN VAN BUREN, professed wit as he is, at the meeting of the Young Men's Democratic Union Association on Monday evening, must pale and grow dim before the brightness of that flash which broke from the lips of the individual, who in the midst of JOHN'S remarks about Honest AZARIAH FLAGG, &c., flashed forth the ejaculation "Honest FERNANDO WOOD!" The audience were not slow to perceive the point of the remark, and "great laughter" broke out all over the room. The ideas were felt to be not only opposite but incompatible.

abstract: The Philadelphia Ledger of Nov. 8 has this interesting paragraph: " Mr. Truman Head, whose exploits as a sharpshooter have attained him wide celebrity in the army, where he is known as California Joe, arrived in this city on Thursday evening. He is on his way home to California, his right eye
lead_paragraph: -- The Philadelphia Ledger of Nov. 8 has this interesting paragraph: "Mr. Truman Head, whose exploits as a sharpshooter have attained him wide celebrity in the army, where he is known as California Joe, arrived in this city on Thursday evening. He is on his way home to California, his right eye having become impaired by too frequently and constantly scrutinizing the "countenances of rebels through a telescope, with rifle attached. Mr. Head accepted an invitation to be present at the Cooper Shop Refreshment Saloon last evening, where he created much interest. He is an intelligent looking man, of dark complexion, regular features, full beard and long curly hair, and is apparently about 50 years of age. Contrary to what might be supposed, he is gentle in his deportment and deplores the taking of life. He is one of Berdan's sharpshooters, and during the campaign on the Peninsula was constantly employed, using his rifle with almost mathemtaical precision. His plans of operations was to take his food with him to the morning, and seek a favorable position, from which he would shoot during the entire day, only ceasing at night, after closing the existence of all rebels on whom he could draw bead. Recently, while thus engaged, his rifle was struck by a ball, which glanced and scraped his nose and cheek, leaving a deep scar, but doing him no further injury. By the advice of a physician he has, for the present, retired from active duty, having received a brief furlough, at the expiration of which he will resume his services."

abstract: FRANK LEMON, Thirty-second New-York Volunteers, who was wounded in the battle of South Mountain, the same action in which Col. MATHESON of the same regiment fell, died on Monday, Nov. 10, in Frederick, Md. Major LEMON was about 43 years of age at the time of his death. He served in the Mexican war in Col. STEVENSON's regiment, and was one of the pioneers of California. His body will reach here in a day or two and should be received with some public demonstrations of respect.

abstract: We find it utterly impossible to account, on any just principles, for the hostility evinced in Democratic quarters to the President's Proclamation menacing the rebels with emancipation of their slaves unless they return to their allegiance. It is a purely military proceeding aiming at the overthrow of the re
lead_paragraph: We find it utterly impossible to account, on any just principles, for the hostility evinced in Democratic quarters to the President's Proclamation menacing the rebels with emancipation of their slaves unless they return to their allegiance. It is a purely military proceeding -- aiming at the overthrow of the rebellion and the restoration of the Union. If its object were the abolition of Slavery, it would have decreed that abolition, as it might have done under the law of Congress, at once, and as a penalty for past offences. But it does nothing of the sort. It merely gives the rebels notice that, if they persist in rebellion beyond a certain time, their slaves shall be set free. It is precisely such a notice as is sent to a besieged town -- that unless they surrender by a fixed date their town will be bombarded.
headline: {'main': "The President's Proclamation.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The President's Proclamation.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Our latest advices from the Army of the Potomac lead us to the belief that a portion of the rebel army is still in the Shenandoah Valley exactly where is not yet ascertained. The forces under Stonewall JACKSON and A.P. HILL, are said to be there those under LONGSTREET and other commanders at Culpepper having been
lead_paragraph: Our latest advices from the Army of the Potomac lead us to the belief that a portion of the rebel army is still in the Shenandoah Valley -- exactly where is not yet ascertained. The forces under Stonewall JACKSON and A.P. HILL, are said to be there -- those under LONGSTREET and other commanders at Culpepper having been thrown forward to prevent our army from getting between the main body of the rebel army and Richmond. LEE is also said to be now at Culpepper, where he has his headquarters. We have no reports of the movements made by our army yesterday.

abstract: -Gen. McCLEL-  LAN'S brief farewell address to the Army of the Potomac is an exceedingly neat and effective, and thoroughly loyal and soldierly document. His address of over a year ago, on assuming the command he has now laid down, will be remembered as possessed of the same characteristics, though it was somewhat more enthusiastic in tone, and promised quick and decisive results, for which the people have waited long and patiently.
lead_paragraph: -- Gen. MCCLELLAN's brief farewell address to the Army of the Potomac is an exceedingly neat and effective, and thoroughly loyal and soldierly document. His address of over a year ago, on assuming the command he has now laid down, will be remembered as possessed of the same characteristics, though it was somewhat more enthusiastic in tone, and promised quick and decisive results, for which the people have waited long and patiently. The reports, bulletins, and dispatches with which he has favored the public during the period of his command have been very few and very brief; and were it not for the correspondents of the Press, the country and the world would have known very little of the battles and campaigns he has fought and planned. But of this touching adieu, every line does him honor.
headline: {'main': 'McCLELLAN AND BURNSIDE.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'McCLELLAN AND BURNSIDE.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: ABRAHAM B. MEADE, whose death is announced in our obituary list of to-day, has long been known as a leading and public-spirited citizen of New-York. He was for many years connected with the apprais-
lead_paragraph: ABRAHAM B. MEADE, whose death is announced in our obituary list of to-day, has long been known as a leading and public-spirited citizen of New-York. He was for many years connected with the appraiser's department of the Custom-house. He found it in a loose and ill-organized condition, wanting in [???] arrangement necessary to order and accuracy, [???] and perseverance he brought it to a high state of discipline, and for near thirty years continued to discharge the duties of his post with efficiency and faithfulness. The commercial interest owes to him many reforms and economics, which are still the rule of the appraisers' department. Unswerving adherence to duty and rigid justice and impartiality characterized his long career of public service. He was equally above the influence of frowns by superiors in office, and of [???] or temptation by those whose interest in was his duty to protect but not to favor.

abstract: COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS BEFORE JUDGE McCUNN. JAMES WELSH, aged 19, and JOHN KELLY, aged 21, were yesterday tried and convicted of burglary in the third degree, in entering the porter-house of CHAS. F. BRUNING, No. 222 South-street, on the night of the 8th of October, and taking therefrom property to the value of $5.
lead_paragraph: COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS -- BEFORE JUDGE MCCUNN. --JAMES WELSH, aged 19, and JOHN KELLY, aged 21, were yesterday tried and convicted of burglary in the third degree, in entering the porter-house of CHAS. F. BRUNING, No. 222 South-street, on the night of the 8th of October, and taking therefrom property to the value of $5. They were remanded for sentence on Saturday. ELIZA FARRANT, a London seamstress, aged 29, was tried and convicted of stealing $56 in bank bills from the trunk of JOHN MULLER, No. 674 Ninth-avenue, on the 15th of September last. She was sentenced to the State Prison for two years.

abstract: IRVING HALL. -- Miss NINA FOSTER, a young lady of whom we have frequently spoken in terms of high commendation, gives a musical and literary entertainment at this establishment to-night. The ability of the lady as a reader of the first rank, and the acknowledged talent of the artists whom she has drawn to her aid point it out as one of the most pleasant affairs of the week, and as for other reasons it is a meritorious act to assist Miss FOSTER on this occasion, we hope to see Irving Hall crowded to its greatest capacity. Mrs. C. FARNHAM, a celebrated soprano, Mr. CASTLE, the tenor, and Mr. THEODOR THOMAS, the violinist and conductor, will cooperate with Miss FOSTER -- who will read some of her best selections.

abstract: This vessel, belonging to Boston, went ashore on Barnegat Shoal on the night of the 8th, and went to pieces before morning. All the crew were, no doubt, drowned, one of them having been found this morning south of the inlet. The remnants of the vessel lie on different parts of the shoal. There are no signs of cargo as yet coming ashore. Some of her rigging and sails will be saved.

abstract: RETURN OF A FUGITIVE MURDERER. -- Officer HARVEY, of Jersey City, returned home on Tuesday from Bethlehem, Pa., where he had been to deliver up the negro JOSEPH PIGEN, charged with the murder of Mr. E.S. BENNER at that place. Upon the arrival of the officer with the culprit at Bethlehem, before daylight yesterday morning, he found about three hundred citizens in waiting, with the avowed intention of inflicting summary vengeance upon the murderer. Through the persuasion of the Marshal and others they were finally prevailed upon not to use violence; but to allow the law to take its course, and the negro was committed to prison.
lead_paragraph: RETURN OF A FUGITIVE MURDERER. -- Officer HARVEY, of Jersey City, returned home on Tuesday from Bethlehem, Pa., where he had been to deliver up the negro JOSEPH PIGEN, charged with the murder of Mr. E.S. abstract: Mr. COBDEN had addressed his constituents at Rochdale. He spoke at length on the prevailing distress at Lancashire. He regarded that distress as a National question, and if public and private aid proved insufficent to relieve it, Parliament would have to make provision for it. He then referred to the American war, and said that it would be a waste ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. COBDEN had addressed his constituents at Rochdale. He spoke at length on the prevailing distress at Lancashire. He regarded that distress as a National question, and if public and private aid proved insufficent to relieve it, Parliament would have to make provision for it. He then referred to the American war, and said that it would be a waste of time for foreigners to attempt to influence the combatants. To interfere in the war, or to recognize the South, would do more harm than good, and fail to bring forward cotton. As to how the contest was going to end, he confessed his inability to form any opinion; but if compelled to make a guess, he would not make the same guess that Earl RUSSELL and Mr. GLADSTONE did. He did not believe that if the war should soon be brought to a termination if would end in the separation of the North and South. He thought those who professed so much for Italian unity ought to appreciate more the same union in America. Interference by force would do more than anything else to strengthen the Federal Government, and the cost to England in six months would be more than sufficient to feed the distressed cotton-operatives for ten years. Mr. COBDEN concluded by reproaching the Palmerston Government for its extravagance. and advocated retrenchment.

abstract: Editorial on increased cost of making newsprint; links cotton shortage; Editorial on increased cost of making newsprint
snippet: Editorial on increased cost of making newsprint; links cotton shortage; Editorial on increased cost of making newsprint
lead_paragraph: -- We have loud complaints from every quarter of the country of the increased cost of making newspapers. Printing paper of all kinds has risen fifty per cent. within the last three months, while the tax on paper, ink, advertisements and everything else connected with the business, still further aggravates the difficulty. The rise in paper, moreover, is still going on, and as it is due to the lack of cotton, it is not easy to say when it will stop. Under these circumstances publishers all over the country are raising the price of their papers, or raising their charges for advertising, or both, in order to meet this increased cost of production.

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the steamship City of Baltimore, and the Nova Scolian off Cape Race, we have advices from Europe four days later, to the 31st ult. The news is interesting and important. The pirate Alabama was known to have destroyed the bark Wave Crest, from New-York for Cardiff. Lord LYONS' departure for...
lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port of the steamship City of Baltimore, and the Nova Scolian off Cape Race, we have advices from Europe four days later, -- to the 31st ult. The news is interesting and important. The pirate Alabama was known to have destroyed the bark Wave Crest, from New-York for Cardiff. Lord LYONS' departure for his post, and the proceedings of Commodore WILKES at Bermuda, are coupled by the London Globe in some comments on British relations with the United States, which are not, in the opinion of that semi-official journal, at all likely to become unfriendly. Mr. GLADSTONE's rash prophecy has brought out many counter declarations of sympathy with the North, which, it is noticeable, have everywhere been favorably received. There are many signs of a reaction in the English mind. Speaking of the proceedings of Com. WILKES at Bermuda, the Times thinks the Federals justified in a vigorous prosecution of the right of search where contraband traffic is so brisk. The report of the abdication and flight of King OTHO, of Greece, is fully confirmed. Cotton had taken a decided tumble in the Liverpool market -- 2d.@3d. for American, and 1d. for Surats. The stock in port is estimated at 312,500 bales, of which 18,000 are American. Breadstuffs were steady, and Provisions flat. Consols 93 3/8@93 1/2 for money.

abstract: editorial on policy
snippet: editorial on policy
lead_paragraph: We receive from London this morning an inkling of the instructions brought by Lord LYONS on his return to this country, and concerning which there has been such a large amount of portentous speculation, based on nothing. By this we are reassured once again in regard to the improbability of foreign, or at least of British, interference in our affairs; and though the protestations of continued neutrality are not yet given in their official form, the statements may be regarded as semi-official, and their authenticity and accuracy as beyond question. The precise point, as stated, is that "Lord LYONS takes out with, him the most full assurance that while England will be eager, in concert with other civilized nations, to adopt any step that may tend to promote a permanent return of peace, either through a restoration of the Union on the old or any new basis, or an agreement for a friendly separation, she will, meanwhile, individually refuse to depart one hair's breadth from her course of non-interference." To this the London Globe adds, that there is no doubt that Lord LYONS' "intercourse with the President's Government will remain as peaceful and uninterrupted as the best friends of England and America could wish," and that "on the part of Her Majesty's Ministers no course will be pursued calculated to give any just cause of offence to the still great State beyond the Atlantic." So if, as is to be hoped, there be no diplomatic hypocrisy about these fine phrases, those who have been disturbed in their souls about intervention may now lapse into quiet for some time longer. There will be no stoppage, of course, to the building and equipping of ships and rams for the rebels in British yards; there will be no surcease to any of the innumerable acts of practical unfriendliness which the British Government has so long winked at. These, to be sure, will continue as ever; but, than these, there will be nothing more.

abstract: CANVASSING THE RETURNS OF THE ELECTION.  The Kings county Board of Supervisors are now in session at the Brooklyn City Hall as a Board of Canvassers. Mr. WILLIAM J. CROPSEY, of New Utrecht was appointed chairman, and Mr. J.N. STEARNS, the county clerk, officiates as Secretary by virtue of his ...
lead_paragraph: CANVASSING THE RETURNS OF THE ELECTION. -- The Kings county Board of Supervisors are now in session at the Brooklyn City Hall as a Board of Canvassers. Mr. WILLIAM J. CROPSEY, of New Utrecht was appointed chairman, and Mr. J.N. STEARNS, the county clerk, officiates as Secretary by virtue of his office. The returns are round to be mainly correct, and but little time has thus far been consumed in sending them back to the District Inspectors. Yesterday the votes cast in the first ten City Wards were canvassed. The final result will probably be declared on Saturday evening, though perhaps not till Monday, The City Board of Canvassers meet in the Common Council Chamber this evening.

abstract: Editorial says Government and people must be faithful to each other
snippet: Editorial says Government and people must be faithful to each other
lead_paragraph: The excellent spirit with which Gen. MCCLELLAN has given his hand to his successor, and parted from his army, should be imitated by his admirers, and by all loyal men. It is clear that the purpose of the President, in making the change, has been to remedy, if possible, the slow progress of the war, in response to the dissatisfaction which has been so emphatically expressed at the polls. The people have rightly chosen to hold the President responsible for the delays rather than his Generals. They look to the Commander-in-Chief, even though he is a civilian, for the right management of the war. The President overcomes his natural indisposition to interfere, and comes promptly up to the full work of his constitutional responsibility. All the movements indicate that it is fully decided that nothing shall prevent the utmost possible activity in military operations through the coming Winter months. We are, in all probability, entering the decisive stage of the war. It would be too much to hope that it will not have its varying fortunes. The uncertainty of arms has always been proverbial. But there are the best grounds for believing that the triumph will be with us. This much at least seems certain, that the Government means to put forth its utmost available strength, and that it will be no fault on its part if the rebellion is not writhing in its death-struggles before the Spring equinox. The President, in assuming the responsibilities and committing himself so unreservedly as he does to all the risks of this great work, but meets the call of the people, and he has a right to their staunchest moral support.

abstract: The Journal of  Commerce says that Gov. SEYMOUR "boldly proclaims the war for the Union and the Constitution, in opposition to the radical theories of a servile war, with insurrection and massacre, for the purpose of opposing Slavery, Union or no Union."
lead_paragraph: -- The Journal of Commerce says that Gov. SEYMOUR "boldly proclaims the war for the Union and the Constitution, in opposition to the radical theories of a servile war, with insurrection and massacre, for the purpose of opposing Slavery, Union or no Union." We heartily concur with Gov. SEYMOUR in this potion. So do the great mass of the people of this State, without distinction of party. Of those who voted against him at the late election, ninety-nine hundredths, we venture to assert, assentfully to this doctrine. Indeed, we should feel greatly obliged to the Journal of Commerce if it would point to any party, or any considerable number of persons, who would prosecute this war "for the purpose of abolishing Slavery, Union or no Union." We know no such men.

abstract: It is not very cheerful news for the Navy Department that we receive to-day from Charleston, S.C. On the night of the 18th of October, a rebel steamer ran the blockade and entered the harbor, paying not the slightest attention to the guns of the blockading vessel, the Flambeau, that endeavored to arrest her course.
lead_paragraph: -- It is not very cheerful news for the Navy Department that we receive to-day from Charleston, S.C. On the night of the 18th of October, a rebel steamer ran the blockade and entered the harbor, paying not the slightest attention to the guns of the blockading vessel, the Flambeau, that endeavored to arrest her course. It is alleged that the rebel was iron-plated, as the shots of the Flambeau, twenty-two in number, fired, we are led to believe, at point-blank range, "fell off from her sides like hail."

abstract: NUMISMATIC SALE. Messrs. BANGS, MERWIN  Co. offered for sale by auction, on Tuesday evening, a large number of old coins. The attendance of purchasers was large and the bidding spirited. The catalogue embraced the American portion of the Finotti collection of coins and medals, now the property ...
lead_paragraph: NUMISMATIC SALE. -- Messrs. BANGS, MERWIN & CO. offered for sale by auction, on Tuesday evening, a large number of old coins. The attendance of purchasers was large and the bidding spirited. The catalogue embraced the American portion of the Finotti collection of coins and medals, now the property of Mr. W.E. WOODWARD, of Roxbury, Mass. The auction opened with United States dollars, one of 1795 in fair preservation, selling at $2 25; one of 1796 small date, at $2 75; several varieties of 1798 at $1 50 and one of that year, with small eagle and fifteen stars, at $5 25. A flying-eagle dollar of 1836 brought $8 75; and one of 1838, a brilliant proof, reputed very rare, $26. A fine proof set of 1850, of six pieces, was bought at $14. Similar sets of 1854 and 1855 were sold respectively at $18 and $17. One of 1856 brought $13 and one a year later $12. The sale of half dollars then commenced, embracing dates from 1794 to 1860. These brought various sums, ranging from 87c. to $26 -- the latter being the price at which a half dollar of 1796, described as excessively rare, was sold. Quarters were then offered, one of 1796 being purchased at $2 75, and one of 1804 at $2 25. The others brought smaller sums. Dimes were next on the catalogue. The highest prices obtained for these were as follows: A dime of 1791, $3 75; one of 1800, $5 75, and one of 1804 at $6 25. Half dimes were next offered, one of 1805 bringing $5 25, one of 1829 and one of 1838 (proofs) $1 each. The prices of others ranged from 15 to 87 cents. A few three-cent pieces, from 1851 to 1860, were bought at from 20 to 50 cents, the latter being the price of a fine proof of 1860. The sale was continued by President and Political tokens. WASHINGTON copper medals brought only from 30 to 55 cents. A splendid medal bearing the bust of JEFFERSON and a variety of patriotic designs, brought $15. One bearing the equestrian figure of Gen. ANDREW JACKSON, in silver, was knocked down at $150; and a Van Buren medal, silver, struck in honor of his Presidency, was sold at $9 50. Several medals dedicated "to the Hero of Tippecanoe," Gen. WM. H. HARRISON, and bearing references to the battles in which he fought, were purchased at from $1 25 to $8 25, the latter price obtaining a silver specimen, containing a fine representation of the Bunker Hill Monument.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. All the best characteristics of Mme. GUERRABELLA'S finished style were displayed to advantage last evening, when the lady appeared as Leonora in VERDI'S opera of "II Trovatore." The skill and elegance with which she manages a...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- All the best characteristics of Mme. GUERRABELLA's finished style were displayed to advantage last evening, when the lady appeared as Leonora in VERDI's opera of "Il Trovatore." The skill and elegance with which she manages a voice somewhat thin and not very fresh, is a satisfaction to every correct ear, and furnishes a new illustration of what art can accomplish where natural resources are not great. In the earlier portions of the opera Mme. GUERRABELLA was so good that it almost became a matter of regret that she had not made her debut therein, rather than as Violetta -- a role which inevitably excites comparisons. In the last act, however, Mmme. GUERRABELLA had lost some of her power, and the exigencies of the Miserere, with its multiple effects, overtaxed her voice and roughened it. But the intelligence and taci of an artiste were there, and these traits, as they become better recognized, will, we are sure, enhance the estimation in which Mmme. GUERRABELLA is already held. In this scene Signor BRIGNOLI was unusually admirable; his voice pealing forth in magnificent volume. During the entire performance he was in superb condition.
