lead_paragraph: A meeting of Episcopal clerygymen of this City was held at Trinity Chapel schoolroom, yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of giving expression to the general esteem for the late Dr. BERRIAN, of Trinity Church. Bishop POTTER presided, and after the meeting had been opened with prayer. Rev. Mr. REED was chosen Secretary. Among those present were Rev. Dr. Higbee, Dr. Seabury, Dr. Houghton, Dr. Thrall, of California, Dr. Haight, Dr. Leonard, Hon. Mr. Stocking, Rev. Dr. Eigenbrodt, Rev. Messrs. Ogilby, Hawley, Clarkson, Reed, Upjohn, and others of note.

abstract: Sherwood, Samuel; NY lawyer
snippet: Sherwood, Samuel; NY lawyer
lead_paragraph: He recorded a few days ago the death of Samuel Sherwood, Esq., at the advanced age of nearly eighty-four years, probably the oldest, as he certainly was one of the ablest lawyers of this State. He was born in Washington County, New-York, in 1779, his father then being in command of a body of levies stationed -- on what was our western frontier -- at Fort Stanwix, now Rome. In the Autumn of 1780, a large marauding party of Tories and Indians, led by the British Col. Carlton, made an incursion from Canada upon that part of the country, burning the houses of the Whigs, including that of Mr. Sherwood's father at Sandy Hill. His mother, forced to fly through the wilderness with her two children, sought refuge at Fort Miller, leaving her home wrapped in flames, so that her infant son, the subject of the present notice, literally beheld the fires of the Revolution.

abstract: Now that the circulation of the new currency is becoming quite general in this City, many stores, saloons, stage routes, and car lines have concluded, on and after the 15th instant, (Saturday next,) to accept no more postage stamps as a circulating medium. Probably before the lapse of many weeks the use of postage stamps as a substitute for small change will have become a thing of the past.

abstract: A meeting of journeymen house and ship painters was held at Military Hall, Bowery, last evening, P. READY, President, in the Chair, to hear the report of the Committee appointed at the previous meeting to consult with boss painters relative to an increase of journeymen's wages from 17  to 25 cents per hour. The Committee, through Mr. McGRATH,...
lead_paragraph: A meeting of journeymen house and ship painters was held at Military Hall, Bowery, last evening, P. READY, President, in the Chair, to hear the report of the Committee appointed at the previous meeting to consult with boss painters relative to an increase of journeymen's wages from 17 1/2 to 25 cents per hour. The Committee, through Mr. McGRATH, reported the names of a large number of boss painters whom they had visited, a majority of whom cheerfully coincided with the request of the journeymen, as expressed through their circular. Some bosses objected to the hourly rates, and proposed paying wages by the day. A few refused to give any answer to the demands of the circular, or to have anything to say to the Committee uponthe subject. Considerable discussion ensued, with reference to the action which should be taken, or whether the meeting should take any definite action. The idea of a strike was unanimously disapproved of, and it was thought that a majority of the bosses of the City would admit the reasonableness of the journeymen's demand for an increase of wages, and that a compromise could be effected that would be satisfactory to both parties. With this view the Committee were instructed to continue their visits to bosses, and report further at the next meeting, on Thursday evening next. Meantime all journeymen were requested to assist in distributing the circulars among the bosses.

abstract: A JERSY LADY ROBBED IN A STAGE.--Yesterday afternoon Mrs. MENA FREUND, a German lady, living in Newark, N.J., was riding up town in a stage from the Jersey Fery, when she missed her satchel, containing money and jewelry worth $42.
lead_paragraph: A JERSY LADY ROBBED IN A STAGE. -- Yesterday afternoon Mrs. MENA FREUND, a German lady, living in Newark, N.J., was riding up town in a stage from the Jersey Fery, when she missed her satchel, containing money and jewelry worth $42. Mrs. FREUND had but a moment before seen the satchel on the seat beside her. Suspicion at once rested upon a woman who had just left the omnibus, and the stranger was followed. Finding that she was about to be arrested, the suspected femaledropped the missing property on the sidewalk; Immediately after which Officer DIPPLE, of the Broadway squad, arrested her, The prisoner, who gave her name as MARGARET SCHWARTZ, was taken to the Tombs, where she ably pleaded her own case before Justice BRENNAN, contending that she could not be held as the property was not found in her possession. Unfortunately for the accused, there was a witness in Court who had seen her drop the property, and he made affidavit to that effect. MARGARET is not an entire stranger to some of the Court attaches. Justice BRENNAN locked her up for trial.

abstract: Prize Court, yesterday, counsel appeared on behalf of the claimants of the schooner Elmira Cornelius and cargo, and presented the preliminary papers. This is the first vessel from a Northern port captured in an attempt, as alleged, to run the blockade. She sailed out of New-York with a clearance for Port Royal, which she reached in July last. After lying there several months without unloading, she cleared for New-York, and was captured in Bull's Bay, by boats' crews of the United States ship Restless. The captain of the schooner was in court, yesterday, and made a voluntary statement in reference to the voyage and capture of his vessel. He denied that there was any intention from the first to run the blockade, and said that the story of the steward of the schooner to the effect that he (the captain.) had declared such to be his intention was false. When the vessel was run ashore, he said that she was leaking badly and that he made for the beach to keep her from filling. His flag of distress he had taken from the cabin with the intention of hoisting it, but had forgotten to do so. When the boats of the Restless boarded the schooner, a file of marines came on board, and he and his crew were forced into the boats at the point of the bayonet. He was afterwards taken on board the Restless and asked for an explanation of his conduct, and replied that he had nothing to say then, but at the proper time he was ready to make a full statement. The material parts of the Captain's statement will be embodied in an affidavit. In view of the perishable nature of the settlement can do the Court ordered a sale of it, the supercargo of the vessel not objecting. -- Philadelphia, Ledger, Nov. 11.
lead_paragraph: Prize Court, yesterday, counsel appeared on behalf of the claimants of the schooner Elmira Cornelius and cargo, and presented the preliminary papers. This is the first vessel from a Northern port captured in an attempt, as alleged, to run the blockade. She sailed out of New-York with a clearance for Port Royal, which she reached in July last. After lying there several months without unloading, she cleared for New-York, and was captured in Bull's Bay, by boats' crews of the United States ship Restless. The captain of the schooner was in court, yesterday, and made a voluntary statement in reference to the voyage and capture of his vessel. He denied that there was any intention from the first to run the blockade, and said that the story of the steward of the schooner to the effect that he (the captain.) had declared such to be his intention was false. When the vessel was run ashore, he said that she was leaking badly and that he made for the beach to keep her from filling. His flag of distress he had taken from the cabin with the intention of hoisting it, but had forgotten to do so. When the boats of the Restless boarded the schooner, a file of marines came on board, and he and his crew were forced into the boats at the point of the bayonet. He was afterwards taken on board the Restless and asked for an explanation of his conduct, and replied that he had nothing to say then, but at the proper time he was ready to make a full statement. The material parts of the Captain's statement will be embodied in an affidavit. In view of the perishable nature of the settlement can do the Court ordered a sale of it, the supercargo of the vessel not objecting. -- Philadelphia, Ledger, Nov. 11.

abstract: Editorial on cost of war
snippet: Editorial on cost of war
lead_paragraph: The letter of Mr. CHASE which appeared recently in our columns, confirming as it does the semi-official statement we published a few days ago as to the amount of our National Debt, is of no small interest at the present crisis. Many a loyal citizen will be conscious of a glad sense of relief at the assurance, on the very highest authority, that, notwithstanding all that rebel sympathizers at home and abroad have said to the injury of the National credit, our total debt on the 1st of October was no more than $620,000,000, and that, as the disbursements since that date, together with all outstanding claims on the Treasury, amount to $60,000 more, the whole debt on the 27 th of October did not exceed $680,000,000.

abstract: be remembered that the office of the St. Croix Herald, a journal of the Province of New-Brunswick, has been twice mobbed, and finally destroyed by infuriated Blue-noses, because of its sympathy with the cause of the American Union. The proprietor, nothing daunted, has now removed the seat of his business to the American side of the St. Croix, and from his new position at Calais, Me., will no doubt do yeoman's service for the cause. Those who are disposed to aid it by subscriptions or advertising will find him at any time this week at the Astor House, by applying for Mr. J.S. HAY. We are glad to see the names of His Honor the Mayor and other leading citizens already figuring upon Mr. HAY's list.

abstract: editorial urges cut in taxation covered by bill since more revenue than necessary is being collected
snippet: editorial urges cut in taxation covered by bill since more revenue than necessary is being collected
lead_paragraph: THE INTERNAL REVENUE. -- The thorough manner in which Congress did its work, last session, in the preparation of its Internal Revenue bill, is entitled to all praise. The minuteness of its details shows that its authors had studied and fully comprehended the vast number of available resources of revenue in a free and prosperous country. But it is beginning to appear that Congress, however advanced in knowledge, on most subjects connected with revenue necessary to their intelligent action, did not at all comprehend the productiveness of the sources of income they incorporated in their bill. The Ways and Means Committee estimated a revenue of One Hundred and Fifty Millions from their measure. But the work of the Assessors has so far progressed, and the rate of income from stamp duties so far been established, as to indicate a very great increase over the Committee's estimate. There are those who have given the subject attention that predict an income of Two Hundred Millions of Dollars the first year, and others still who declare that at least Two Hundred and Fifty Millions will be derived from the Internal Revenue laws now in force.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN -- FAREWELL BENEFIT OF EDWIN BOOTH. -- Mr. EDWIN BOOTH on this evening takes his farewell benefit, and makes his fast appearance but one, in the characters of Pescara, in which he is now without a rival on the stage, and as Shulock, in the fourth Act of the "Merchant of Venice." We doubt not that this occasion will be seized on by his many admirers and friends to offer an ovation to an artist who during an engagement of unusual brilliancy and length, has gathered around him a more refined and cultivated interest than any actor of our time. The entertainment presents unusual attraction, Mr. BOOTH appearing in two parts.

abstract: Editorial notes how little California has been affected by war
snippet: Editorial notes how little California has been affected by war
lead_paragraph: Our countrymen on the Pacific Coast are having a pretty easy time of it in the existing war. Their very great distance from the scene of hostilities makes it too expensive to bring their "quotas" of volunteers under the different calls into the field. The consequence is, the voice of the recruiting Sergeant is never heard in their land; their population has not been decimated by the appointment of Brigadiers; and contractors and sutlers are unknown to them, save in the current history of the war written in the newspapers of the Atlantic States. Whenever an enterprising Californian has desired to achieve distinction or turn a penny in following the fortunes of war, he has been obliged to leave the peaceful shores of the Pacific and return to the Eastern States. But in the main, the Pacific Coast has had very little to do with the war. We have never heard nor read of the Fifth, Tenth or Fifteenth Regiment of Oregon or California Volunteers, and we doubt if the Government pay-rolls show the enrollment of any such regiments -- although it is in that quarter, if anywhere, their existence would be discerned.

abstract: -We see advertised a sale of valuable books, by order of Collector BARNEY, which we understand composed the library which was captured at Beaufort, South Carolina. The announcement strikes us with surprise. We enter our protest against any such disposition of that library. If the Government shall sell at public auction a library thus captured in the Southern States, it will be guilty of an act which will be a stain upon our reputation. Those who malign us will not be flow to cite it as a proof of that barbarism which they absurdly say is rolling over us -- that we who have prided ourselves upon the value we give to educational influences -- that we, above all, who have sneered at the Southern States for their poverty in literature, and in schools, in libraries, should seize by force of arms and sell at auction one of the few public libraries which had existence there.

abstract: The trial of AMANDA THOMPSON (colored) for the murder of her husband, by cutting his throat with a razor, at No. 41 Sullivan-street, on the morning of the 29th of September last, was commenced in this Court yesterday before his Honor Judge McCUNN.
lead_paragraph: The trial of AMANDA THOMPSON (colored) for the murder of her husband, by cutting his throat with a razor, at No. 41 Sullivan-street, on the morning of the 29th of September last, was commenced in this Court yesterday before his Honor Judge MCCUNN. There was a large number of spectators in Court, including many colored people. The prisoner is a rather good-looking mulatto, apparently about twenty-two years of age. JOHN H. ANTHON, Esq., Ex-Assistant District-Attorney, appeared as her counsel, and the prosecution was conducted by the present Assistant District-Attorney, O.L. STEWART, Esq.

abstract: APPOINTMENT. -- J.W. WOODRUFF, Esq., the Superintendent of the New-Jersey Railroad, received a commission yesterday from Gov. OLDEN, as Deputy Quartermaster of the State of New-Jersey, with the rank of Lieutenant-Colonel. Mr. WOODRUFF, during the past eighteen months, has taken a great interest in the welfare of the troops that have passed over the New-Jersey Railroad, always accompanying the soldiers to the end of the road, and in many instances providing the men with food. These facts being made known to the Governor during the past week, he at once conferred the above appointment upon Mr. WOODRUFF, who will enter upon his new duties next week.

abstract: third Precinet Police, arrested the mate of the brig Margaret, lying in the Atlantic Dock Basin, about 1  o'clock yesterday morning, on the charge of having in connection with the mate of the same vessel, caused the death of a hand on board, named WILLIAM LITTLE, by brutal treatment. The name of the...
lead_paragraph: third Precinet Police, arrested the mate of the brig Margaret, lying in the Atlantic Dock Basin, about 1 o'clock yesterday morning, on the charge of having in connection with the mate of the same vessel, caused the death of a hand on board, named WILLIAM LITTLE, by brutal treatment. The name of the mate is JAMES W. COOK, and of the steward, WILLIAM JONES. The vessel cleared from Belfast, Ireland, on the 20th of September last, and arrived at this port on Wednesday evening. The crew came on shore, and, proceeding to the Forty-third Precinct Station-house, related the circumstance to Capt. RHODES. According to their statement, LITTLE was employed by the Captain (SMITH) before setting sail, as man of all work, at the rate of $10 a month. When the vessel got out to sea the mate ordered him to perform the duties of an able seaman, which he was totally disqualified from doing, and in consequence of his inability to perform those duties, was subjected to such a course of brutal treatment that in eighteen days after leaving port he was prostrated by illness, and soon after died. The mate, as stated by the sailors, took occasion to beat LITTLE with whatever he had in his hand, whenever he failed to do his work as directed, or as it was done by other sailors; and the steward, taking a dislike to LITTLE, joined the mate in abusing him. On one occasion, LITTLE, with some others, was sent aloft to stow the topgallant sail. The seamen informed him that he could be of no use to them and told him to go down. When he reached the deck the mate asked him why he did not help the seamen, and while trying to explain he struck him on the head with an iron belaying-pin, inflicting two severe gashes, and knocking him insensible. He was picked up and taken to the hold, and was for some days unable to perform duty. On recovering sufficiently to be about the deck, the mate and steward, as alleged, continued to abuse him on every possible occasion, until at length he became exhausted and was taken below, where he remained until he died, which was on the afternoon of the 13th of October. The sailors are detained as witnesses. Their names are Henry Edwards, John Mahoney, John Taylor, James Walker, Wm. Johnson and Henry McAnnally. The two latter smuggled themselves on board the vessel at Belfast, and succeeded in reaching New-York without paying their passage. The accused parties have been taken before the United States authorities for examination.

abstract: Editorial on unjust system of allowing regular army to recruit from volunteer regiments in Virginia
snippet: Editorial on unjust system of allowing regular army to recruit from volunteer regiments in Virginia
lead_paragraph: We are sorry to hear that there is still great dissatisfaction and complaint in our volunteer regiments in Virginia,on account of the system of recruiting from their ranks for the regiments of the regular army. The thing is grossly unjust to the volunteer officers who raised brigades, regiments or companies. Many a man, after being authorized by the War Department to raise a regiment, went to work, assiduously applied himself to it night and day for months, spending all his own money and all he could obtain from his friends; and after being successful--after drilling his men for months, after leading them through the campaign of the Peninsula, or the Rappahannock, or the Shenandoah, and probably losing in this way one half of his force, he now finds a regular army officer authorized to enter and recruit from his ranks; and the regular officer probably succeeds, by various means, in seducing from the ranks of the volunteer officer a half of the remnant of the shattered regiment he had raised, and drilled, and led. In this way entire regiments have actually been struck out of existence, and their original officers left without a command; and in many cases, captains who by untiring efforts and lavish expenditure, raised a hundred men a year ago, now find themselves without a soldier to lead, and all their money and labor lost.

abstract: The fine fast iron steam-corvette Stellin was put formally in commission yesterday at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, in obedience to orders from Washington. She has been made a regular man-of-war, is well armed, and can steam fifteen miles an hour, or more. She goes to sea at once--probably to-mor-...
lead_paragraph: The fine fast iron steam-corvette Stellin was put formally in commission yesterday at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, in obedience to orders from Washington. She has been made a regular man-of-war, is well armed, and can steam fifteen miles an hour, or more. She goes to sea at once -- probably to-morrow, but the important nature of her business renders further particulars unnecessary. She will soon be heard from. Annexed is a list of her chief officers: E.V. EVANS, Acting Commander; George P. Lee, acting Master; Joseph Frost, Acting Ensign; Geo. R. Baily, Acting Engineer; E.P. Heberson, Acting Paymaster; J. Solis Cohen, Acting Assistant Engineer; Acting-Engineers John B. Edwards, Thomas Slater, Peter R. Robinston and Stephen B. Cornell.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. BELLINI'S grand tragic opera of " Norma" was revived here last evening to a house that made us forget that the work has seen the day of its greatest popularity, and is now, unjustly and almost sacrilegiously, voted slow. Mme.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- BELLINI's grand tragic opera of " Norma" was revived here last evening to a house that made us forget that the work has seen the day of its greatest popularity, and is now, unjustly and almost sacrilegiously, voted slow. Mme. LORINI (nee WHITING, an American, as our readers who can recall the last decade of opera will remember,) made her debut as Norma, and was supported in the contralto part by the new and favorite prima donna, Mlle. MORENSI. During the interval of seven years that has elapsed since Mme. LORINI was last heard in public, she has made the tour of Europe, and obtained a reputation which we can now estimate at its just value in the principal opera houses there. She returns to us fresher than when she left, with a method vastly improved and a style at once large and lyrically dramatic. The vastness of the Academy imposes a severe tax on the voice of the singer, and we should be lending ourselves to a fiction if we said that Mme. LORINI makes us utterly forget this circumstance. Nevertheless her voice is fuller and richer than any other soprano of American origin we have yet heard on the stage, and its genuine quality -- the true soprano sfogato -- enables the artiste to make her best effects in a way that the most distant listener can appreciate. There was no lack of appreciation last night; the house applauded every well-known morceau with enthusiasm, but the greatest treat was undoubtedly to that limited number who knew what constitutes art, and who had, in consequence, the pleasure of fully recognizing Mme. LORINI's great ability. The soft charm of a rich fresh voice, added to consummate skill of execution, and rare elegance of style, left really nothing to be desired. We cannot think of a singer who has created a more profound impression. Mme. LORINI suggests so much that may be said, that general commendation is the briefest form in which to express it. The lady must be pronounced the best of our native prime donne. We hope that the threat of her early departure for Europe will be speedily withdrawn, in view of a triumph and a recognition so complete.

abstract: From the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac we learn that a rebel brigade, which has for several days been reconnoitering in position on the Rappahannock, left the vicinity yesterday morning for Culpepper, harrassed on their retreat by Gen. PLEASANTON'S cavalry.
lead_paragraph: From the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac we learn that a rebel brigade, which has for several days been reconnoitering in position on the Rappahannock, left the vicinity yesterday morning for Culpepper, harrassed on their retreat by Gen. PLEASANTON's cavalry. There are indications that the rebels intend to evacuate Culpepper, probably with a view to concentrate at Gordonsville. The reports as to the whereabouts of JACKSON and his command are contradictory. At headquarters he is reported to be still hovering about Chester Gap, with not more than forty thousand men under his command, while at Harper's Ferry it is believed that he is again approaching that point -- our scouts reporting that he passed through Winchester in that direction on Monday, followed by Gen. HILL on Tuesday. In either contingency our officers are believed to be fully prepared.

abstract: Dr. HUNTER concludes in the present issue of the TIMES his first series of essays upon diseases of the throat and lungs. That they have been read widely and with profound interest, we have every reason to believe; and while many of the writer's views conflict with those of the profession at large, they have certainly commended themselves quite generally to the popular judgment. Many instances of successful cures effected under his prescriptions have been brought to our notice. Success is the test in medicine as in war. To this test the system of Dr. HUNTER has been put, and with the most surprising results.

abstract: Mr. SEYMOUR, in his recent speech at Utica, took occasion, as he has done before, to claim for himself and his party great virtue for speaking of the President of the United States in respectful terms. He quoted from former speeches of
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. SEYMOUR, in his recent speech at Utica, took occasion, as he has done before, to claim for himself and his party great virtue for speaking of the President of the United States in respectful terms. He quoted from former speeches of his own upon the virtue of obedience, and declared that he had before denounced reproaches against the President as "injurious to the dignity and the honor of our people." He charged upon his opponents, in substance, that they had been guilty of the sin of "speaking evil of dignities," and claimed for his election that it was a rebuke of that sin, and of his opponents for having been guilty of it among their many shortcomings.

abstract: CORONER'S INQUESTS. Coroner MORRIS held an inquest yesterday upon the body of PETER FITZGIBBONS, who died suddenly, York-street, on Thursday night, from disease at the heart. The deceased was employed in the Navy-yard. He leaves a wife and several children. An inquest was also held upon the body of DENNIS SHEHAN, residing at No. 29 Statestreet, who fell down stairs on Thursday night and sustained injuries which caused his death.
lead_paragraph: CORONER's INQUESTS. -- Coroner MORRIS held an inquest yesterday upon the body of PETER FITZGIBBONS, who died suddenly, York-street, on Thursday night, from disease at the heart. The deceased was employed in the Navy-yard. He leaves a wife and several children. An inquest was also held upon the body of DENNIS SHEHAN, residing at No. 29 Statestreet, who fell down stairs on Thursday night and sustained injuries which caused his death. The deceased was about 70 years of age. Verdicts in accordance with the facts were rendered in both cases. In the case of Mr. FITZGIBBONS, it appears that he was found dead on the sidewalk, and conveyed to the Forty-second Precinct Station-house. A large crowd soon gathered there, and several persons positively identified him as a Mr. BURNS, residing in that neighborhood. The family of the supposed deceased were informed that Mr. BURNS had suddenly dropped dead, and the wife and children were consequently much distressed. Some time thereafter the Coroner sent to the house for the wife, to enable her to identify the body, but when the messenger called ho found Mr. BUENS sitting by his stove, complacently smoking a pipe. The wife had dried her tears, and the children were as happy as could be. The deceased, FITZGIBBONS, was not identified till next morning.

abstract: - Thursday evening the monthly meeting of the New-York Sanitary Association was held in the chapel of the Home for the Friendless, No. 29 East Twenty-ninth-street. Mr. R.H. MCCURDY was in the chair, and after the reading of the minutes of the preceding meeting, introduced the lecturer of the evening, Dr. JOHN H. GRISCOM. The lecture was on "The Causes and Means of Preventing some of the most Important Diseases of the Army." Dr. GRISCOM stated that the cause of disease in the army was the want of proper ventilation in the tents now used, and the only way to insure perfect ventilation was to use a tent invented by Gen. G.W. MORGAN, known as the "ventilated [???] tent." Mr. J. HYSON assisted the Doctor, and demonstrated some interesting facts in ventilation. At the conclusion of the lecture officers for the ensuing year were [???], and the society adjourned till next month.

abstract: -- A large catalogue, the contents of the studio of the late lamented artist, RAMBRANT PEALE, are to be sold on Tuesday next at Philadelphia, without reserve, by the Executors. Among them are several famous heads of WASHINGTON, by the elder PEALE, PINE, STUART, and TRUMBULL, including a duplicate of the original, painted by the younger PEALE from life, in 1795. A large number of works of art, such as would naturally be gathered in the atelier of a devotee of the easel, during a life of more than half a century, will be found there, including a number of rare and choice engravings and pencil sketches. The advertisement of the sale will be found in another column.
lead_paragraph: -- A large catalogue, the contents of the studio of the late lamented artist, RAMBRANT PEALE, are to be sold on Tuesday next at Philadelphia, without reserve, by the Executors. abstract: Major H. ROBINSON, in compliance with a request from Mayor OPDYKE, Dr. BELLOWS, and others, lectured at Cooper Institute last evening, on the necessity of furnishing the Government with a more ef ficient cavalry force than we now have in the field. Commencing with a rapid sketch of the relations of science and art to war, and an allusion to the imperative necessity of the cavalry arm of the service to pro
lead_paragraph: Major H. ROBINSON, in compliance with a request from Mayor OPDYKE, Dr. BELLOWS, and others, lectured at Cooper Institute last evening, on the necessity of furnishing the Government with a more ef ficient cavalry force than we now have in the field. Commencing with a rapid sketch of the relations of science and art to war, and an allusion to the imperative necessity of the cavalry arm of the service to prosecute a successful war, Major ROBINSON passed to a running review of the progress of various nations in the use of cavalry, from the time of the first regularly organized troops of the Greeks to the terrible destruction of the Roman army by the light and heavy artillery of HANNIBAL, who killed forty thousand and captured thirty thousand out of an army of eighty thousand Romans. He showed how the Romans profited by this lesson, and were enabled in their turn to master the world. He depicted the daring achievements of the Hungarian cavalry, and drew a thrilling picture of the sacrifices which had been made by the Italian Republics, on account of their culpable neglect of cavalry. "In comparison with cavalry," he said, "rifled cannon and Minie muskets are but as naught." He narrated the achievements of the Milanese cavalry in their contest with the troops of FREDERICK, and the daring charge of the Cohorts of Death -- a handful of devoted cavalry who succeeded in capturing the royal standard, disorganizing the army, and compelling FREDERICK to flee for his life. He spoke of the terrible battle which decided the contest between LOUIS of Bavaria and FREDERICK of Austria, when 4,000 knights were slain. He related the interesting story of the retreat of the English commander HARKWOOD, in the fifteenth century, with 6,000 of his cuirassers, although confined on an island by the Italian commander. Although the first work on cavalry tactics is attributed to CHARLES the Bold, in 1443, there can be no doubt that works of the kind were written as long ago as forty years previous. Maj. ROBINSON sketched the progress of the cavalry service in Europe, especially of the English and French. He said that the aged soldier was very apt to be averse to the development of any military arm other than that by which he gained renown, but, that he would be quite surely defeated in his first great war by his younger adversary, whose genius might consist merely of a due appreciation of the lessons of military history, and of availing himself of those teachings without regarding them as innovations. Maj. ROBINSON detailed the masterly manner in which NAPOLEON handled his cavalry, and his divisions of his cavalry into three kinds. First, fifteen regiments of heavy cavalry; second, thirty regiments of lancers and dragoons, and third, forty regiments of hussars and chasseurs.

lead_paragraph: It is magnificent -- this prompt, universal acquiescence of the great Army of the Potomac in the removal of its chief. Despite all evil bodings to the contrary, not a resignation -- hardly a, murmur. Cheers for the out-going, cheers for the in-coming -- all blending in one undistinguishable swell of admiration for the men, and devotion to the cause.

abstract: The State election and its results no longer exciting the solicitude and zeal of our local politicians, that most useful class of citizens has turned its attention to ascertaining who shall be the nominees for party favor and support at the next Charter election. This, the reader is aware, comes off on the first Tuesday in December.
lead_paragraph: The State election and its results no longer exciting the solicitude and zeal of our local politicians, that most useful class of citizens has turned its attention to ascertaining who shall be the nominees for party favor and support at the next Charter election. This, the reader is aware, comes off on the first Tuesday in December. There are to be chosen a Comptroller in place of ROBERT T. HAWS; a Corporation Counsel in place of GREENE C. BRONSON; Aldermen for the First, Third, Fifth, Seventh, Ninth, Eleventh, Thirteenth, Fifteenth and Seventeenth Aldermanic Districts; a full Board of Councilmen, (twenty-four-six from each Senatorial District;) one School Commissioner, one School Inspector, and two School Truestees in each Ward. The bent of the contest, both for Republicans and Democrats, awaits the determination of the factions of the latter as to whether they will unite, and to what extent they will unite for the canvass, it being generally conceded that the Democrats will assuredly elect whatever candidate they fuse upon.

abstract: The steamship Europa arrived at Halifax on Thursday night, with advices from, Europe two days later than those previously received. A vessel which had arrived at Antwerp reported that she had been spoken by a rebel privateer of Cape Sable. This is likely to have been the Alabama, which a recent letter says was seen by steamship City of Washington, on her outward trip. The Engliah papers have but little to say on American affairs. The Times credits the North for its energy in the construction of a navy, but questions its effectiveness for regular naval warfare. The gunboat Tuscarora arrived at Lisbon on the 25th ult., from the Azores. Elections were to be held in Greece on the 10th inst. It is said that an understanding has been arrived at between France, England and Russia, by which Grecian affairs will be deprived of their importance for Europe. This amounts to the adoption of the principle of non-intervention. From China we learn that a British gunboat had seized all the mandarins and war janks and Custom-house officials at Tan-Kan, and also released all the teas detained there for the increased transit duty. From South America we learn of the death of President Lopez, of Paraguay. His son provisionally fills the vacancy. The Liverpool Cotton market had again taken an upward turn, prices having recovered 2d. on the decline reported by the previous arrival. Breadstuffs were steady and Provisions dull.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Europa arrived at Halifax on Thursday night, with advices from, Europe two days later than those previously received. A vessel which had arrived at Antwerp reported that she had been spoken by a rebel privateer of Cape Sable. This is likely to have been the Alabama, which a recent letter says was seen by steamship City of Washington, on her outward trip. The Engliah papers have but little to say on American affairs. The Times credits the North for its energy in the construction of a navy, but questions its effectiveness for regular naval warfare. The gunboat Tuscarora arrived at Lisbon on the 25th ult., from the Azores. Elections were to be held in Greece on the 10th inst. It is said that an understanding has been arrived at between France, England and Russia, by which Grecian affairs will be deprived of their importance for Europe. This amounts to the adoption of the principle of non-intervention. From China we learn that a British gunboat had seized all the mandarins and war janks and Custom-house officials at Tan-Kan, and also released all the teas detained there for the increased transit duty. From South America we learn of the death of President Lopez, of Paraguay. His son provisionally fills the vacancy. The Liverpool Cotton market had again taken an upward turn, prices having recovered 2d. on the decline reported by the previous arrival. Breadstuffs were steady and Provisions dull.

abstract: translation of his observations
snippet: translation of his observations
lead_paragraph: We are glad to see that translation of the Prince DE JOINVILLE's sketch of the campaigns of the Army of the Potomac is about to be published. It is written, of course, substantially ine the interest of Gen. MCCLELLAN, or at least gives his explanations of matters which may seem to require them. The PRINCE deals very sparingly in criticism, -- pays the highest compliments in the bravery, endurance, and versatility of the American troops, -- evidently thinks that MCCLELLAN lost opportunities which a more adventurous commander would have seized, and deplores the defeat of our army in front of Richmond, as substantially the turning point of the war.

abstract: editorial on movement in NYC to abolish method
snippet: editorial on movement in NYC to abolish method
lead_paragraph: There is a very general movement in the city to abolish postage stamps as currency after to-day. The stage lines and city railroads, the restaurants, the newspapers, and a large number of small dealers will hereafter neither take nor offer them. In the course of the coming week, the detestable things, we hope, will be altogether done away with, and the memory of them will remain only as a nightmare of the past. The public, we fear, will suffer a good deal of loss, as indeed they have suffered ever since they came into use; but we hope the Post-office authorities will be lenient as well as just, and receive at their full value all the cartloads of filthy, greasy, rumpled and torn stamps that may be brought to them, or pasted on letters or newspapers.

abstract: We wish to make an appeal [???] to the benevolent public in behalf of an unfortunate but worthy family. The father is now very low with consumption, and pronounced incurable, and the mother has struggled hard to support her family, but her little means being entirely exhausted and a hard Winter before her, we appeal to the friends of the poor on her behalf. Donations of coal, provisions and bedding, will be gratefully received and carefully disposed of by the ladies who make this appeal, at No. 93 Eighth-street, near Sixth-avenue, New-York. Any donations of money would be gladly received, as they are behind with their rent.

abstract: ure to announce that the books composing the library captured at Beaufort, which were advertised to be sold at auction next Monday, "by order and under the direction of the Collector of the Port of New-York" -- against which proceeding we entered a protest in our last issue -- were yesterday afternoon ordered to be withdrawn from exhibition and the sale has been indefinitely postponed. It is well that we have been saved the National disgrace of such a petty bit of -- what has been called vandalism -- though we are not aware that any Vandal auctioneer ever exposed to public roup and destruction any collection of "old, important and scarce works" that might have been captured in any of the wars of his tribe. We hope now, that the books will at once be removed from the auctioneer's shelves, and that this sale will not only be indefinitely postponed, but definitely prohibited. We suppose it would not be advisable to send the books back yet to South Carolina. They, should, however, be carefully got together again, under charge of some bibliographer, and safely put away in some public building, where neither mice, moths nor auctioneers can get at them. When we resumeour amicable relations with South Carolina -- as we hope to do some day -- we shall bind our friendship by sending back to her the trophies we have captured; and among those which will be of most value in her regeneration will be the old Beaufort Library, which, by the efforts of the Press, has been saved from the sad fortunes of war.

abstract: OPENING OF THE HOBOKEN AND NEWARK RAILROAD. --  The Hoboken and Newark Railroad, connecting with the Morris and Essex Railroad, was formally opened yesterday. A train containing the Directors of the Morris and Essex Road and their friends along the line, left Newark about 11 1/2 A.M., and ran over the road to Hoboken in 18 minutes. At the latter place a collation was partaken of at the Hoboken House, and speeches were made by Mr. J.P. BRADLEY. CORTLANDT PARKER, and others. The trains will commence running regularly on Wednesday and excursion tickets to Newark and return will be sold for 30 cents.
lead_paragraph: OPENING OF THE HOBOKEN AND NEWARK RAILROAD. -- The Hoboken and Newark Railroad, connecting with the Morris and Essex Railroad, was formally opened yesterday. abstract: Editorial sees rebellion completely suppressed in Southwest, from Ohio River to Gulf of Mexico
snippet: Editorial sees rebellion completely suppressed in Southwest, from Ohio River to Gulf of Mexico
lead_paragraph: To all appearances, the backbone of the rebellion, in the West, is thoroughly broken. In no quarter, from the Ohio River to the Gulf, are the rebels found to exist in formidable force. Their late chief columns, that threatened to advance, and actually did advance, with proud menace, are falling back everywhere, beaten and demoralized, before our victorious armies. And no point appears on which they can rally.

abstract: Within the past few days grave charges have been made by the United States officials, against certain merchants, clerks, Custom-house officers and others, implicating them in gross dishonesties and frauds upon the Government.
lead_paragraph: Within the past few days grave charges have been made by the United States officials, against certain merchants, clerks, Custom-house officers and others, implicating them in gross dishonesties and frauds upon the Government. These facts have been known to us since their earliest development, but at the request of the United States Marshal we have refrained from giving them publicity. Other journals have deemed it well to spread hints, innuendoes and partial facts before their readers, to the annoyance of the Government, and, in one case, to the certain frustration of justice.

abstract: Editorial says while war has abated in Southwest it has been growing in Virginia
snippet: Editorial says while war has abated in Southwest it has been growing in Virginia
lead_paragraph: Gen. BURNSIDE has issued an important general order dividing the army under his command into three grand divisions, named respectively the Right, Left and Centre Grand Divisions. The first, consisting of the Secoud and Ninth Corps, will be commanded by Gen. SUMMER; the second, consisting of the First and Sixth Corps, will be commanded by Gen. FRANKLIN, and the third, consisting of the Third and Fifth Corps, will be commanded by Gen. HOOKER. In addition to these there will be a Corps of Reserve, consisting of the Eleventh Corps and such other troops as may hereafter be assigned to it, under command of Gen. SIGEL. Other new and important arrangements are indicated in the order.

lead_paragraph: Henry T. Capen vs. Nehemrah P. Mann. -- This was an action to recover of the defendant, as owner of the brig Alma, the anomnt of a bill of supplied furnished to the versel by the libelant. The proofs showed that the respondent was mortgagee of the ship, and that about the time when the supplies were furnished, one Brown, the mortgage who had ordered the bills, without the knowledge of the respondent, executed an absolute bill of sale of the vessel to him, and subsequently, at Brown's request, the usual oath of ownership was taken at the Custom House by the respondent, and the register changed. There was conflicting evidence as to whether the supplies were furnished before or after the bill of sale was given, and there was some testimony to show that the respondent had admitted that he was the owner.

abstract: has reached the enormous amount, all told, of three or four hundred millions of dollars; whereas, in England, it is less than two hundred millions. We find also that the volume of our paper currency is still increasing with alarming rapidly; whereas in England, it is carefully and absolutely limited. But more important than either of these two joints of contrast is the fact that in England the business of putting forth a paper circulation is confided to a Department having no interest and no power to unduly augment it; whereas, with us, an unlimited power of manufacturing paper is given to a corporation (the Confederate Government) having unlimited uses for money, and thus subjected to an irresistible necessity of increasing the paper circulation indefinitely. The experience of England on this subject of paper currency is worth more than that of all other countries and communities whatever; and if the fact be so, then the condition of the paper currency of the Confederate States presents a subject of most serious concern to both Government and people."

abstract: The five thousand men employed at our Navy-yard hare been paid off. A day's pay was deducted from last month's wages for the relief of families of soldiers in the service, and another for a different purpose. Laborers are now employed in beautifying the square where the "non-combatant" cannon is placed. The immense amount of iron-work going on requires an increase of blacksmith shops, and six new fires are now operating. There are about twenty vessels in the stream and four on the stocks. The famous victor of Cowes, the little yacht America, is about to be armed with a formidable rifle gun. She will be a useful little vessel. The Stettin went down the Bay yesterday. She is a fifteen-knot vessel, and is dispatched on business that requires speed. The Eagle storeship has left for the Port Royal Squadron. A fleet of troop ships is expected. The Mackinaw, a new side-wheel steamer, is progressing rapidly. The new iron-clad Miantonamah is making progress in the western ship-house. Her bottom will be almost flat. Capt. GANSEVOORT is now released from all obligations to attend the Lyceum, and will soon report for duty.

abstract: A correspondent of the Cincinnati Commercial gives this sketch of Major-Gen. THOMAS! He is an impressive man, his deportment is as quiet and simple as that of a poet's farmer. He look's heavy. It takes an occasion to move him, I should say, but when he moves his momentum is enormous. There is much lymph in his composition, although he has the complexion of a sanguine temperament; he is a close
lead_paragraph: -- A correspondent of the Cincinnati Commercial gives this sketch of Major-Gen. THOMAS! He is an impressive man, his deportment is as quiet and simple as that of a poet's farmer. He look's heavy. It takes an occasion to move him, I should say, but when he moves his momentum is enormous. There is much lymph in his composition, although he has the complexion of a sanguine temperament; he is a close observer, but a better thinker, and is wedded to his profession. Long after he was commissioned a Brigadier-General, he persisted in wearing his Colonel's passants. Finally he donned the solitary star, probably because the eagle l'argent on his shoulder's was worn out. Some months have elapsed since he was appointed Major-General, and he appears to be waiting for the lone star to wear out. Some of the "boys" are discussing the propriety of purchasing the twin stars for him, if they can get assurance that he will mount them. His aspect is peculiar -- not stern, but rather benevolent and grave, with a strong cast of firmness. His figure is so square and large, that, together with considerableCorpulence, it seems to rob him of several inches of stature. He is fully six feet high and big, almost as great as Nelson was. The former swelled, you know, as you looked at him. Manners, more than matter, were the cause of that optical delusion. Gen. Thomas don't magnify until you begin to measure him. Sandvish hair and whiskers closely cut; keen blue eyes of medium proportions, sunken under shaggy brows; straight nose, not strikingly prominent, but strong; ruddy features, deeply seamed; square face and body; large, compact head; general bigness; heavy, but firm, step -and you have the man, personally. He is patient, persevering and persistent, even-tempered and energetic,speaks deliberately and not frequently, and sometimes indulges in grim pleasantry -- which is rather astonishing than otherwise. Altogether, the [???] describe him best when they tell you about "Pap" Thomas. His escort occasionally get a little impatient at his deliberate way of riding, and press too hard upon him. He is accustomed to remind them of their indisecretion by giving the command, "slow trot!" so the boys got to naming him old"Slow Trot." General Rosecrans entertained such an exalted esteem for him at the Military Academy that he was accustomed to call him "General Washington." His regard for him has not diminished. Heis an active of Virginia; is aged about forty-five.

abstract: The Richmond Christian Advocate, of the 16th ult., has an overture for a Convention or the Chris- tian Churches, of all denominations in the Confeder- ate States, to unite in a formal solemn testimony in vindication of their position to the sanguinary con- flict which the Federal Government is waging against them. It wants such a testimony to demonstrate to our enemies and to the world that the Southern Churches are a unit in their unalterable resolution to maintain the independence of this Confederacy and defend their conservative and Scriptural principles on the Slavery question. The Advocate thinks that the Convention should consist of one or more ministers from every Church and from every State, and that they should prepare and send forth an address, embody- ing their principles, to the Northern Churches and to the world.

lead_paragraph: The steamship Etna passed Cape Race yesterday afternoon, with European advices four days later than those by the Europa. The political news is not particularly important. A slight collision is reported to have occurred between the Austrian and Italian troops on the frontiers, but quiet was soon restored. The London Times denies that any blame can be attached to England in reference to the pirate Alabama, but the Daily News take an opposite view. Mr. BRIGHT has written a letter applauding President LINCOLN's Emancipation Proclamation. Cotton was still on the advance in the Liverpool market. Breadstuffs and Provisions were dull. abstract: The determination of street railroads, omnibuses, ferry companies, newspaper offices, and other institutions and branches of business receiving a large part of their income in small change, not to receive postage stamps after the 15th (yesterday) as money, will go pretty far to annihilate that particular species of currency in this City. Happily the introduction of the postage currency bills is proceeding rapidly, and they are already found in sufficient abundance to take the place very nearly of the rejected stamps.

abstract: The question as to who shall be the candidates for the offices of Comptroller and Counsel to the Corporation has been seriously agitated for some weeks. But while the fight of the Roses has been going on in Old Tammany, together with this billing and cooing of FERNANDO and MOZART, "Vir
lead_paragraph: The question as to who shall be the candidates for the offices of Comptroller and Counsel to the Corporation has been seriously agitated for some weeks. But while the fight of the Roses has been going on in Old Tammany, together with this billing and cooing of FERNANDO and MOZART, "Vir Populi" stepped in late last evening, and gave three cheers for JOHN S. CHILDS for Comptroller -- who claims to have been once elected over A.C. FLAGG, though the Courts, unfortunately for him, decided to the contrary -- and RICHARD O'GORMAN, Esq., for Counsel to the Corporation, who has already received several outside nominations for the office.

abstract: AUSCHAUS' Gailery some new pictures lately received attract much attention. A group of sheep, by ROBRE, of Brunelies; a superb landscape by PAUL WEBER; two Oriental scenes, by THEO, FRERE; also, choice specimens by Van Marcke, Carand, Claes, Brochart, Monfallet and others, are well worthy of the attention of picture buyers. BISCHOFF'S "Golden  Wedding" and HERNER'S "Pastor's Blessing" and  "The Homeless" are decidedly among the best speci- mens of genre pictures of the German school.
lead_paragraph: AUSCHAUS' Gailery some new pictures lately received attract much attention. A group of sheep, by ROBRE, of Brunelies; a superb landscape by PAUL WEBER; two Oriental scenes, by THEO, FRERE; also, choice specimens by Van Marcke, Carand, Claes, Brochart, Monfallet and others, are well worthy of the attention of picture buyers. BISCHOFF'S "Golden Wedding" and HERNER'S "Pastor's Blessing" and "The Homeless" are decidedly among the best speci- mens of genre pictures of the German school. We need hardly remind our readers that VAN [???] celebrated work of art, "Cinderella and her Sisters," is also at SCHAUS' rooms -- a work which is one of the finest, if not the very finest, specimen of the Pre-Raphaelite school of art, and fully equal to MILLAIS' best. We trust that some of our merchant princes will never permit this picture to leave the City.

abstract: Editorial asks aid for poor during coming winter
snippet: Editorial asks aid for poor during coming winter
lead_paragraph: If we are not mistaken, the approaching Winter will be one of severer strain on the purses of the people, than any we have ever before had in New-York City. In any town of large population there will always be a great amount of want and suffering. The most active and boundless charity will never be able to meet the wants and heal the distress that idleness, misfortune, sickness, poverty and crime are constantly producing. Under favorable circumstances, the charitable of our City have always had their hands full, and have been pained to know that their most strenuous efforts have not sufficed to abate one-half the sum of human misery around them.
headline: {'main': 'The Poor of New-York City.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Poor of New-York City.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial on prospects for future US trade with Great Britain; Editorial on prospects for food trade with Great Britain
snippet: Editorial on prospects for future US trade with Great Britain; Editorial on prospects for food trade with Great Britain
lead_paragraph: Never, in the history of the world, has one great nation been so dependent on another as is England on the United States. The keys of her granaries have, as it were, been placed in our hands. As a consequence, chiefly, of the undue development of her manufacturing industry, in whose triumphs she takes such pride, England is more than ever compelled to subsist on foreign-grown food. Every year we are sending large supplies of grain and provisions to her ports. From September, 1861, to June, 1862, she bought from us food equal to the supply requisite for between three and four millions of people for twelve months. And so pressing was the emergency, that, as Mr. COBDEN remarked in his recent speech at Manchester, "If this food had not been obtained in America, all the money in Lombardstreet could not have purchased it, for it did not exist."
headline: {'main': 'Our Future Trade with England.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Our Future Trade with England.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: ST. JOSEPH's HOSPITAL. -- The Mt. St. Vincint Academy buildings in Central Park are now in service as a soldiers' hospital under this name. The institution is in charge of the Sisters of Charily, under the direction of the General Government. This result has been brought about by the persistent efforts of Alderman FARLEY, who spent some time in Washington to accomplish it, after the plan of establishing the hospital had failed in the Common Council, by veto of the Mayor. His Honor thought the expense should be borne by the State or General Government, and not the City. The hospital is devoted mainly to those soldiers who have suffered amputation. The pupils of Grammar School No. 53, situated in Seventy-ninth-street, have contributed money and clothing to the institution to the amount of $300. On Sunday, the 9th inst., about 120 patients arrived at the hospital from Washington. The buildings were then hardly prepared for them, but the Sisters succeeded in making them feel quite comfortable. Since then ample preparations have been made for their care and comfort.
lead_paragraph: ST. JOSEPH's HOSPITAL. -- The Mt. St. Vincint Academy buildings in Central Park are now in service as a soldiers' hospital under this name. lead_paragraph: Today our citizens will undoubtedly avail themselves of the bright and cheerful sunshine to enjoy a promenade in their Winter styles, to attend Di- vine services and to improve their moral condition. We cheerfully old them in these laudable interests, by stating that at Prof. MATTESON's in Forty-first-street, near Sixth-avenue the Pastor with preach on "The Better Country." and the Hutchinson Family will aid in the singing. At the City Alliance meeting at the Assembly ROOLIS to-morrow night. Rev. Mr. GOSS will preach, and the "Old Folks," under the direction of Father [???] will provide the music. There will be services in the Historical Society's building to-morrow morning and evening, Rev. G.T. ELANDERS preaching, on the "Voices of the Dead." At Hope Chapel, morning and evening, Rev. G.L. HARRIS will preach. At Dr. BURCHARD's Church, Thirteenth-street, to the morning, the children of the Missionary Association Sunday-School will hold their fifteenth Anniversary and be [???] by various speakers. At Rev. The curious conclave of people who meet on Sundays at No. 187 Bowery will discuss, at 3 P.M., "The Constitutionality of the Emancipation Proclamation," and in the evening will discern: "The Signs of the Downfall of the Republic."

abstract: -- Mrs. FRAUVISIA KLEIN has just finished a beautiful flag for the Fourth Metropolitan Regiment, which work of art is exhibited at the music store of Messrs. HALL & SON. The flag shows on white silk the Goddess of Liberty, dressed in the American colors, and holding in the right hand the Constitution, while the left hand grasps the shield and an olive branch. At the feet of the Goddess lies a broken crown and sceptre, and the Goddess is accompanied by an eagle, who holds the thunderbolts, and seems prepared for the contest. The reverse shows the coat-of-arms of the State and an inscription. The effect of the whole is very beautiful.

abstract: -- It would be difficult to point to a single revolutionary movement that has convulsed any part of Christendom during the present century in which the capitalists of England have not played a part of more or less importance. That our present struggle forms no exception to this uniform rule, we are reminded by the piratical exploits of the Alabama, as well as by other equally significant proofs. Prominent among these kind offices of international friendship, we may mention the exertions of a certain class of English journals, which, mindful of the fact that over two hundred millions of our stocks are held in Europe, have conceived the plan of making the speculations of the Press and the speculation of the Stock Exchange materially help each other.
lead_paragraph: -- It would be difficult to point to a single revolutionary movement that has convulsed any part of Christendom during the present century in which the capitalists of England have not played a part of more or less importance. That our present struggle forms no exception to this uniform rule, we are reminded by the piratical exploits of the Alabama, as well as by other equally significant proofs. abstract: The steamer Maurice arrived at New-Orleans Friday, the 30th, with eighty of the prisoners taken at the battle of Labadieville. These men mostly be longed to the Crescent regiment, raised among the elite of this city, and as soon as it was announced on our bulletin-board that they had arrived, hundreds began to wend their way toward the levee to see them, and, perhaps, to recognize old friends, or acquaintances, or relatives. When we reached the steamer, the wharf was already crowded, and the prisoners were holding uninterrupted communication with all they recognized on shore. A battalion of infantry shortly made its appearance, and cleared a wide space on the levee in front of the boat, but it was soon withdrawn, and the crowd was again allowed freely to talk with the prisoners from the wharf. And many were the joyful recognitions that took place. Everything, however, was done in the most orderly style, and with the greatest decorum. The prisoners looked very well, were dressed as finely as could be expected under the circumstances, and appeared quite cheerful. Late in the evening, they were transferred to another vessel, which is to be their prison, we understand, for the present. They are receiving the best of treatment, and have no cause of complaint, other than that of being deprived of the freedom of the city for the present -- but soldiers are used to privations.
lead_paragraph: The steamer Maurice arrived at New-Orleans Friday, the 30th, with eighty of the prisoners taken at the battle of Labadieville. abstract: In an article, yesterday, on the military prospects in the Southwestern States, we stated that the rebellion, as a, great military force, was practically broken down in that half of the Confederacy.
lead_paragraph: In an article, yesterday, on the military prospects in the Southwestern States, we stated that the rebellion, as a, great military force, was practically broken down in that half of the Confederacy. Battles may yet be fought there, cities besieged and forts assaulted -- but there can, we think, be no future battle of anything like the magnitude of those that have already taken place. Missouri will not see another battle like Springfield, for not only has the rebellion in that State had its backbone broken, but every bone in its body has been ground to powder, and there is not an organized rebel force anywhere in the great central State of the Union. Arkansas will not witness another day when so many combatants will struggle so fiercely on her soil as they did at Pea Ridge; for the small bodies of our troops who have scoured nearly the whole of the State, have nowhere met a rebel force capable of seriously interrupting their progress. Kentucky is not likely to behold another such battle as the late one at Chaplin Mills; for we cannot conceive it possible that we will ever again have a commander who is such a superlative imbecile as to permit a rebel force to march into and through a State from which one-fifth of his army could have kept them back. Tennessee will hardly again be the scene of such conflicts as those at Donelson and at Shiloh, or such naval fights as those at Island No. 10 and at Memphis, for in the central and western parts of the State there is no foe who does not flee from our advance; and we should think that ROSECRANS' strategy -- considering the immense force at his command --would easily secure the expulsion of BRAGG from East Tennessee. Northern Mississippi is hardly likely to see another battle equal in magnitude to those at Corinth and Iuka, for already GRANT has penetrated below Holly Springs without getting sight at an enemy. There may be a contest between Gen. PRICE and our Mississippi column, at Jackson or at Vicksburgh; but, if the fortunes of war go against the Confederates there -- as they inevitably must -- there will not, so far as we know, be an organized rebel force of any magnitude in all the vast region we have reviewed.

abstract: -- The funeral of James S. Green, whose death at Princeton, N.J., we have already noticed, was held in that place on Nov. 8. Among those present were Chancellor Green, Ex-Chancellor Williamson, Jos. B. Bradley, Esq., Hon. Joel Parker, the Governor elect, and many eminent in railroad affairs and political life. Rev. Dr. Macdonald preached the funeral discourse. Mr. Green had been long and much in public life; he had a protracted term of service in the Legislature, was United States District-Attorney under Presidents Jackson, Van Buren and Folk, was Director of the Delaware and Rarttan Canal Company since its organization in 1830, Treasurer of the Camden and Amboy Railroad Company for a long time, and for more than forty years Treasurer of the Theological Seminary in Princeton. He was a son of Rev. Ashbel Green, D.D., long a President of the College of New-Jersey, one of the most eminent ministers of his time, and grandson of Rev. Jacob Green, for more than fifty years pastor of the Presbytetian Church at Hanover, N.J. He was in his 71st year, and was in the active discharge of his numerous duties up to a short time previous to his death. He leaves a widow.

abstract: As the care and attention extended to the sick and wounded soldiers who are sent to this City for treatment is of great interest to all, and of vital importance to the soldier himself at this time, and should the campaign be prosecuted this coming Winter, of perhaps still greater importance in the future, we propose to give briefly an idea of what has been done, what is doing now, and the preparations for the future. Among the various hospitals for the object named, the one put in operation by the Managers of the Northeastern Dispensary, and the very capacious new one now growing out of its establishment are entitled to prominent notice. The Managers of the Northeastern Dispensary, after having procured a charter in April last, applied to the Municipal authorities for a suitable building for the accommodation and treatment of sick and wounded returning from the war. The result was a transfer to them of the edifice which had been erected for a Foundling Hospital; but as an hospital for such a purpose had come to be considered as rather encouraging than otherwise the number of foundlings, the building was almost useless for that purpose. The ground upon which the building stands, in Lexington-avenue, cost $50,000, and the building cost $46,000 more. Soon after the transfer a number of ladies -- among them many were the wives of our most prominent citizens, headed by the wife of the present Mayor -- commenced the work of preparation, and selected Dr. MOTT as Chief Physician, and paid for clothing and other necessary articles for the soldiers. The Managers of the Dispensary gave at once all the rooms necessary, and then applied to the Common Council to approve of their acts. The Board of Councilmen gave its approval, but the Board of Aldermen laid the approval on the table, and kept it there.

abstract: The Richmond Enquirer, referring to the recent execution of ten prisoners in Missouri, says: "Those ten good men that were foully murdered by a coward ruffian, who calls himself General, demand to be avenged. Their blood cries out to us from the very ground which drank it. And, if the simple charge of taking a citizen from his home and carrying him off, and refusing to restore him, justifies such retaliation as our enemies have adjudged, how many of their own soldiers they have exposed to death by the arrest and imprisonment of our citizens, let the Old Capital Prison, in Washington, testify. At thelast delivery, the number released for exchange, and after long confinement in most cases, was, we believe, about one hundred and forty. At the rate of ten sacrifices for each captive, a regiment and a half of LINCOLN's captured soldiers would have been slaughtered for these alone. Such is the example which the enemy practically demands of us to imitate!

abstract: Capt. J Ericsson invention of firing 20-ton gun inside turret displayed at launching of ship Passaic
snippet: Capt. J Ericsson invention of firing 20-ton gun inside turret displayed at launching of ship Passaic
lead_paragraph: Yesterday the naval authorities of this vicinity were the witnesses of a great experiment. As early as 7 o'clock, a visitor to the Navy Yard, or to any of the iron-clad yards, would have easily discovered that something was going to turn up. The great trial trip of the Passaic was to come off, and the question would be decided whether one inventor, or "twenty-five naval officers, among whom were two Admirals," occupied the correct position on a disputed point. All the navy, all the newspapers, (ourselves included,) all the contractors, and all the mechanics of the town, who knew of the affair, did not see how a gun twenty-one tons in weight could be fired inside a turret twenty-one feet in diameter, without having its muzzle protrude through the porthole. Alone among the faithless, with only one engineer to join him, was Mr. ERICSSON. The opinions of the great twenty-five, (including the two Admirals,) and of all the rest of mankind was nothing -- the thing must be proved a humbug.

abstract: The first week of Mr. GRAU'S season at the Academy of Music was brought to a brilliant conclusion by Saturday's matinee, when "Il Trovatore" was given, with Mesdames GUERRABELLA and MORENGI and Messrs. BRIGNOLI and AMODIO in the cast.
lead_paragraph: The first week of Mr. GRAU's season at the Academy of Music was brought to a brilliant conclusion by Saturday's matinee, when "Il Trovatore" was given, with Mesdames GUERRABELLA and MORENGI and Messrs. BRIGNOLI and AMODIO in the cast. The three prime donne which Mr. GRAU has had the good fortune to present to the public have met with so much favor and the desire to see them in other works is so universal, that the impressario has wisely determined to postpone the production of MEYERBEER's new opera until Monday next. In this way there will be additional time for rehearsal, and the public will not be over hurried from one excitement to another. Tonight BELLINI's opera of "Norma" will be repeated, with Madame LORINI as the heroine. On Wednesday Madame GUERRABELLA will appear as Maria, in the "Daughter of the Regiment;" on Friday, "Lucrezia Borgia" will be produced for the last night of Madame LORINI, and on Saturday the week will terminate with a grand matinee. We are desired by the manager to state that the patrons of the opera will consult their interests by not purchasing tickets of speculators at the doors. Some inconvenience, we are informed, has been experienced from this cause. To prevent misrepresentations, the manager desires it to be understood that a certain number of seats equal to the average demand for them, is always set apart for the evening sale, and no one need purchase a ticket outside, in the belief that the regular office of the establishment has "sold out" all its vouchers.

abstract: The artists of this friendly and admirable association open their third annual Exhibition to-day, at the Gallery of the Fine Art Institute, No. 625 Broadway. There was a private view of the collection Saturday evening, when the artists were present to entertain, with frank hospitality, their many friends.
lead_paragraph: The artists of this friendly and admirable association open their third annual Exhibition to-day, at the Gallery of the Fine Art Institute, No. 625 Broadway. There was a private view of the collection Saturday evening, when the artists were present to entertain, with frank hospitality, their many friends. The principal feast was of course the pictures, among which were many fine specimens by Church, Kensett, Hennessy, Eastman, Johnston, Bierstadt, Gifford. Boughton. Gignoux, and the other leading representatives of the modern school of landscape and genre. We have rarely seen a finer show of cabinet subjects. The pictures thus liberally contributed, will of course be sold for the benefit of the fund. But the interest of the Exhibition is not limited to the pleasant contemplation of these free-will offerings. The Society has succeeded in borrowing from wealthy collectors an assortment of the best works of art in the Metropolis, and the result is an exhibition which exceeds in general interest and intrinsic value any exhibition that has preceded it. Those who would know what American artists have accomplished, may here do so. It is indeed an opportunity which no one should neglect, for it may not occur again. In addition to choice pictures by Stuart, Allston, Trumbull, Cole, Inman, and our first living American artists, there are several fine specimens of foreign works from the collection of WM. H. WEBB, Esq.

abstract: ING, ASSAULTS, &c. -- The recent strike of the Irish laborers employed on the Manhattan Gas Works, foot of Fourteenth-street, East River, for higher wages, has resulted in their discharge and the employment of Germans by the Gas Company. This enraged the strikers, and many of them have determined not to submit quietly, and on Saturday evening a few of the disaffected men collected at the Gas Works, evidently bent on mischief. Soon afterwards, as GEORGE CLINE and JAMES EGAN were closing their work to go home, they were set upon and terribly beaten. CLINE was struck on the brow with a hammer and EGAN had his skull fractured by a blow from a bar of iron in the hands of one of the rioters. HENRY MORROW and TIMOTHY SULLIVAN were arrested by the Eighteenth Ward Police, charged with being the persons who inflicted the violence. They were taken before Justice KELLY and committed to answer the charge of assault and battery and rioting.
lead_paragraph: ING, ASSAULTS, &c. -- The recent strike of the Irish laborers employed on the Manhattan Gas Works, foot of Fourteenth-street, East River, for higher wages, has resulted in their discharge and the employment of Germans by the Gas Company. abstract: Large iron works, church, several other buildings destroyed, Houston St, NYC
snippet: Large iron works, church, several other buildings destroyed, Houston St, NYC
lead_paragraph: Between 12 and 1 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out in a large five-story manufactory, situated on the southeast corner of West Houston and Greene streets, which, spreading with terrible rapidity, despite the most vigorous exertions of the firemen, soon enveloped the entire building in flames, and thence communicated to the adjoining buildings. When the roof and walls of the structure, where the fire originated, fell, the roof and steeple of the SecondAssociate Presbyterian Church, a large stone edifice on the southwest corner of Greene and West Houston streets, caught fire, and although by this time there were at least a dozen streams of water playing upon it from steam and hand engines, the flames very soon spread rapidly all over the church, defying the earnest and well-meant efforts of the hardy firemen to stay the terrible conflagration. The old stone church, which for years -- how many we know not -- has stood there in the centre of vice and crime, a monument of virtue, and always with open doors, inviting the citizen and the stranger to come within, was at length compelled to succumb to the fiery element. It is now nothing but a heap of smouldering rains. The parsonage also, No. 147 Greene-street, a three-story brick building, adjoining the church, occupied by the Pastor, Rev. JAMES HARPER, was consumed, nothing being left except the bare walls.

abstract: are glad to see that active measures are about to be taken by our Government to put this harbor in a complete state of defence. We do not share the alarm of many on this subject, for we do not believe that any rebel rains...
lead_paragraph: are glad to see that active measures are about to be taken by our Government to put this harbor in a complete state of defence. We do not share the alarm of many on this subject, for we do not believe that any rebel rains are building, either at the South or in England, sufficiently seaworthy to reach this City, or powerful enough to pass our defences if they should reach it. Nevertheless, precautions against such a visitation are always wise, and we shall be very glad to see them provided.

abstract: This corps, under command of Col. W.S. RowLAND, has been assigned to Gen. BANKS' expedition. Four companies are now full, and will embark with the advance. By an order of the Adjutant-General of this State, Col. ROWLAND has been placed in command of all the sharpshooters organizing in the State.
lead_paragraph: This corps, under command of Col. W.S. RowLAND, has been assigned to Gen. BANKS' expedition. Four companies are now full, and will embark with the advance. By an order of the Adjutant-General of this State, Col. ROWLAND has been placed in command of all the sharpshooters organizing in the State. Gen. BANKS is very desirous that the command shall be filled immediately, in order that it may be assigned to its important position at the earliest possible moment. The several War Committees, and the people of the State, should aid in every possible way to accomplish this end. We suggest that some action should be taken at once to fill up the New-York City company of this corps. The men are to be armed with the best rifles the Ordnance Department can command.

abstract: --TheLondon and China Telegraph learns from its correspondents that Mr. BURLINGAME lately applied to the Chinese Government for a site whereon to establish the American Consulate, urging his claim to similar privileges with France and England. He was informed in reply that he had come to Peking in a manner different from that of those two nations, and could not have a site granted to him, but that he should have every assistance in renting a building suitable for the American Legation.
