abstract: on another page, an article containing some very valuable details concerning the African Slave-trade, a perusal of which will show the necessity of the vigilant measures now being taken by the United States Courts and officials in this City to drive from our midst, utterly and forever, the traffickers in human flesh.
lead_paragraph: on another page, an article containing some very valuable details concerning the African Slave-trade, a perusal of which will show the necessity of the vigilant measures now being taken by the United States Courts and officials in this City to drive from our midst, utterly and forever, the traffickers in human flesh. The trade has been a stupendous one; and it was from this port that a large proportion of the vessels sailed, and in this City that the extensive organizations for the traffic existed. We have the names of over one hundred and fifty vessels which were engaged in the nefarious business during the two years preceding the incoming of the present Administration, and forty-five of these craft are known to have landed their human cargoes in Cuba -- cargoes which comprised not less than sixty thousand Africans. This fearful state of things is now all happily changed; and during the last year not two thousand negroes have been landed in Cuba, find these by vessels fitted out at foreign ports. The traffic so far as New-York is concerned, may be considered completely extinguished for the present, and indeed forever, unless the atrocious scoundrels under whose auspices it flourished in our City shall again attain power.

lead_paragraph: The steamship Etna passed Cape Race Saturday afternoon, with European advices four days later than those by the Europa. The political news is not particularly important. A slight collision is reported to have occurred between the Austrian and Italian troops on the frontiers, but quiet was soon restored. The London Times denies that any blame can be attached to England in reference to the pirate Alabama, but the Daily News takes an opposite view. Mr. BRIGHT has written a letter applauding President LINCOLN's Emancipation Proclamation. Cotton was still on the advance in the Liverpool market. Breadstuffs and Provisions were dull. abstract: Article on extent of African slave trade prior to April 1861 and successful efforts to suppress it
snippet: Article on extent of African slave trade prior to April 1861 and successful efforts to suppress it
lead_paragraph: Perhaps no commerce was ever more profitable than the traffic in Africans, provided those engaged could go on unmolested. But the enormity of the crime is too great to be let pass, although for a time, money seemed to buy its success. Nor did the public know to what extent the traffic was carried. But the recent efforts to suppress it have brought out its extent and condition, and the manner in which it has been so long concealed and carried on.
headline: {'main': 'THE AFRICAN SLAVE-TRADE.; EXTENT OF THE TRAFFIC. Successful Efforts to Suppress It.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE AFRICAN SLAVE-TRADE.; EXTENT OF THE TRAFFIC. Successful Efforts to Suppress It.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: When the little folk learn that "Aunt Fanny, author of the Night-Cap stories, has Written a book for grown people, they will naturally...
lead_paragraph: -- When the little folk learn that "Aunt Fanny, author of the Night-Cap stories, has Written a book for grown people, they will naturally be very wroth and indignant. We rather apprehend that the door of that lady's residence will be besieged by clamorous crowds in short frocks and jackets, remonstrating, both in sorrow and in anger, against such an act of secession on her part. They will, perhaps, send in petitions, as constituents do to Congressmen, and if these petitions are disregarded, peremptory demands may follow. We fear that "Aunt Fanny" will be compelled to return to her allegiance by sheer force of arms -- outreaching childish arms -- whose mute appeals she cannot resist, though she do the threatenings of clenched little fists. Certainly in the success she has achieved in The Wife's Stratagem -- published by the APPLETONS -- there is temptation enough to make an ordinary woman dismiss children and night-caps forever, and busy herself with the heads of adult audiences. The book is not so strategical as the title would indicate. All the plot can be told in a few words, all the stratagem laid bare in a sentence. A pretty little wife -- whose husband, in consequence of the wicked secession of the South, and the non-payment by the chivalry of debts due to Northern mudsills, stood on the verge of bankruptcy, in morals as well as in means, and began to manifest an alarming fondness for broiled bones, deviled crabs, whisky punches and other strong inventions of the enemy -- hit upon the expedient of starting a literary society, which should meet regularly to read and discuss papers and stories written by the members. The plan worked to a charm, and we behold the young husband surrendering his latchkey and resolutely turning his back on the devil and all his crabs. The stories written and read at these meetings form the staple of the book. Throughout it is pleasant and piquant. Written in the same sprightly vein which made the Night-Cap stories so charming to both old and young, and with uncommon grace of diction, we can heartily recommend Aunt FANNIE's book to all who desire to spend a few of the spare hours of the approaching long Winter evenings pleasantly and profitably.

abstract: Editorial on food shortage in Southern States as result of Civil War; Editorial on food shortage in Confederate States
snippet: Editorial on food shortage in Southern States as result of Civil War; Editorial on food shortage in Confederate States
lead_paragraph: There was much written in the beginning of the rebellion to show that the South would soon be starved into submission. The fact that the labor of the Gulf States was almost exclusively devoted to cotton, and that nearly all the food consumed was obtained from the North west, and the agricultural implements from the Eastern workshops, appeared to make a clear case of it -- that with a thorough blockade of the seceded States, the rebellion would quickly die of starvation. For how could a people subsist who grew cotton only, who were not prepared to grow anything else, and who were not permitted to exchange what they had for what they wanted?

abstract: The gaps in the Blue Ridge, through which an army can pass, are seven in number, viz.: Vestall's, eight miles from Harper's Ferry; Sniker's, twenty-four miles from the Ferry, through which passes the Alexandria and Harper's Ferry turnbike; Ashby's, thirty-eight miles from Harper's Ferry, through which passes a branch pike from Alexandria to Winchester; fourteen miles below Ashby's is Manassas Gap, through which runs the railroad; eight miles below is Chester Gap -- a road not much traveled passes through it, twenty miles still further down is Thornton's Gap, through which the supplies for LEE's army were hauled in wagons from Gordonsville and Culpepper.

abstract: It has been common to excuse the dilatory movements of some of our Generals in the field, by supposing that they were acting in the interest and upon the advice of loyal men in the Border States. The letter written by Gov. JOHNSON, of Tennessee, to President LINCOLN...
lead_paragraph: -- It has been common to excuse the dilatory movements of some of our Generals in the field, by supposing that they were acting in the interest and upon the advice of loyal men in the Border States. The letter written by Gov. JOHNSON, of Tennessee, to President LINCOLN the 1st of September, which we copy in another column, will do something to dispel that delusion. He complains in the most emphatic terms of the conduct of Gen. BUELL for permitting BRAGG to enter the eastern portion of the State, and accuses him, almost in direct terms, with acting in the interest of the Southern Confederacy. The letter is couched in very strong and earnest language, and unquestionably had a good deal to do with Gen. BUELL.'s removal from command.

snippet: Editorial lauds 5-yr. imprisonment of owner of slave trader City of Norfolk
lead_paragraph: American participation in the Slave-trade has received another severe blow, in the condemnation of ALBERT HORN, guilty of fitting out the slave steamer City of Norfolk, to five years' imprisonment. All the efforts to save him from this disgraceful doom, on the score of previous respectability, and his only indirect connection with the transportation of the slaves, proved of no avail. He receives the penalty prescribed by law.

abstract: Editorial offers proposals for use of Union-held cotton fields in Tennessee and Mississippi; Editorial proposes use for Union-held cotton fields in Tennessee and Mississippi
snippet: Editorial offers proposals for use of Union-held cotton fields in Tennessee and Mississippi; Editorial proposes use for Union-held cotton fields in Tennessee and Mississippi
lead_paragraph: In the case of the rapid march of Gen. GRANT'S army southward into the State of Mississippi, there is one thing observable. We have no reports of cotton burning in the pathway of his advance. It is not to be supposed that the country traversed and occupied has no cotton in it. On the contrary, we know that there is not a more fertile and favored cotton district in all the South than the northern part of Mississippi. Holly Springs and Hernando, flourishing towns now held by the United States forces, are famous depots for Mississippi "Uplands." The region of country surrounding them is high and healthful; it is among the most populous of the interior districts of the South, being filled with enterprising, intelligent and wealthy planters, who have built railroads, traded to Memphis, and become largely liberalized by commercial influences.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. In addition to containing the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, will be found in the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The information has come from Richmond, and our Washington correspondent telegraphs us the fact, that the Army of the Potomac is changing its base of operations to Fredericksburgh.
lead_paragraph: The information has come from Richmond, and our Washington correspondent telegraphs us the fact, that the Army of the Potomac is changing its base of operations to Fredericksburgh. On Sunday morning last, all its corps commenced their march down the Valley of the Rappahannock, from the line of the Orange and Alexandria Railroad; and by the close of the week we presume the whole of the great force will have reached -- not its destination, perhaps, but the point from which Richmond may be most conveniently approached. From the mouth of Aquia Creek, the distance to Richmond is only about sixty miles, and the whole route is practicable and direct, with good communications, and easy means of obtaining supplies. Gen. SIGEL will remain on the east side of the mountains, defending the Gaps, watching Stonewall JACKSON, and guarding the approaches to Washington; and Gen. BURNSIDE, cooperating probably with forces south of Richmond, can devote his entire attention to the defeat of LEE the capture of the rebel capital.

abstract: Commodore VAN BRUNT, who has been for some days on special duty at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, has received instructions from the Secretary of the Navy to report at once to Gen. BANKS for service. He will be replaced by another officer who has not yet been named. GRESHOM G. VAN BRUNT is a native of Jersey, and has been in the service since 1818. He is expected to have an important command in the Banks Expedition.
lead_paragraph: Commodore VAN BRUNT, who has been for some days on special duty at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, has received instructions from the Secretary of the Navy to report at once to Gen. BANKS for service. He will be replaced by another officer who has not yet been named. GRESHOM G. VAN BRUNT is a native of Jersey, and has been in the service since 1818. He is expected to have an important command in the Banks Expedition.

abstract: Editorial discusses practical lessons of statecraft in light of British assurances of non-intervention
snippet: Editorial discusses practical lessons of statecraft in light of British assurances of non-intervention
lead_paragraph: That there has been a recent and unusually emphatic decision of the Cabinets of the English and French Governments in regard to American affairs, it is impossible not to believe. And that decision is adverse to the hopes of the Confederates. In many ways does the evidence of the fact reach the world. But we desire nothing more conclusive than the outgivings of the Richmond Press on the subject. These organs of the rebellion announce the news with the positiveness and circumstantiality that they would employ in publishing any other fact bearing upon their interests. It is declared that the decision was unexpected, that it broke up negotations of Confederate bonds abroad, which had already commenced at rates so favorable as eighty-six cents on the dollar; and the Southern people are exhorted, in view of the foreign news, to cast away all thought and all hope of the recognition of the Confederacy by foreign Powers, and trust to their own unaided efforts to secure independence. The hope of recognition has been an ever-present and inspiriting support of the Confederates in their struggle hitherto. We may rest assured that their leaders would not permit so discouraging a communication to be made to them unless it were beyond doubt true and irremediable.

abstract: MR. T. MASON JONES AT IRVING HALL. Mr. T. MASON JONES brings us a new species of entertainment, which is, to some extent, a positive sensation.
lead_paragraph: MR. T. MASON JONES AT IRVING HALL. -- Mr. T. MASON JONES brings us a new species of entertainment, which is, to some extent, a positive sensation. He is not a lecturer after the manner commonly known among us, but delivers, unincumbered with notes, or any kind of written reference, effective, brilliant orations. These orations are eloquent, critical summings up of individual character. Most of them are eulogies of famous Irishmen -- Dean SWIFT, CORRAN, GRATTAN, BURKE, SHERIDAN, O'CONNELL and TOM MOORE among the rest. He has, however, devoted his undoubtedly fine talents to other subjects. Last night, for instance, he drew a vidid portraiture of the hero of Italian independence -- GARIBALDI. Mr. JONES is an amazingly fine speaker. He has a good presence, a rich, melodious, powerful voice, and he possesses the faculty of swaying the passiens of his audience beyond the control of calm, deliberate judgment. He is evidently in earnest, and is himself carried away by the enthusiasm which he imparts to others. His fame attracted quite a crown to Irving Hall last night, and his future orations are likely to become the correct thing for society to do during the coming Winter.

abstract: A very large amount of land in this State was this season planted in corn, and it was reasonable to expect an enormous crop, capable of supplying that species of food in superabundance, at a low price.
lead_paragraph: A very large amount of land in this State was this season planted in corn, and it was reasonable to expect an enormous crop, capable of supplying that species of food in superabundance, at a low price. But this season was marred by a drought, and in many parts of the State the corn crop was seriously injured, so that there will be no superabundance, and scarcely more than was produced last year from much less land planted in that greatest of cereals. The production of rice, too, this year, has been curtailed to a considerable extent, by the removal of planters from the tide-water region.

abstract: The public mind is much more hopeful than it has been for a long time in regard to the war. There are signs of activity and of
lead_paragraph: The public mind is much more hopeful than it has been for a long time in regard to the war. There are signs of activity and of earnestness in various quarters, which have done much toward meeting the universal demand of the people for vigor and energy on the part of the Government. The successes of our armies in the West, -- the expulsion of the rebels from Kentucky and Middle Tennessee, the victories of Gen. CURTIS, and the complete reduction of his Department to the National sway, have been received as proofs that kindred triumps will follow kindred efforts wherever they may be put forth.

abstract: WALLACK'S THEATRE The comedy of "The Clandestine Marriage" has been so seldom played of late years, that its revival is an event of almost as much interest as the production of a new piece
lead_paragraph: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- The comedy of "The Clandestine Marriage" has been so seldom played of late years, that its revival is an event of almost as much interest as the production of a new piece representing, like it, the manners of the last century. It is one of the best constructed and most amusing of the comedies of the period, and must be regarded as a far higher order of piece, artistically considered, than the domestic dramas so plentifully manufactured by MORTON and the younger COLMAN. COLMAN, pere, wrote "The Clandestine Marriage," and GARRICK subsequently touched it up and polished it; among other improvements amplifying the part of Lord Ogleby, and making it worthy the acceptance of WILLIAM KING, a famous performer of that day -- the original Puff, in "The Critic," and Sir Peter Teazle. After KING's retirement from the stage no one was thought capable of playing the part until, in 1818, the late Mr. FARREN, then quite a young man, astonished the town with his special genius for embodying the peculiar characteristics of gentleman-like old age. He virtually monopolized the part throughout a long career, and those who recollect him declare that he never can be equaled in it. It is a fact that Fate, in distending the person of Mr. BLAKE beyond the limit usually allowed to man, effectually prevented his attempting, and Mr. WALLACK has, in consequence, been hitherto unable to produce it in his theatre. With Mr. JOHN GILBERT, in place of Mr. BLAKE, this difficulty is now removed, and the piece can be given with very fine effect. Mr. GILBERT is a performer who has trained in the most careful and conscientious of schools, and any part he undertakes is sure to be satisfactorily -- even admirably -- acted. In Lord Ogleby he has fine opportunities, and he does not neglect them. The part requires a great deal of elaboration, and this it receives from him very thoroughly. Mr. GILBERT is among the best of the patently elaborate school of actors, as distinguished from the apparently spontaneous school, whereof Mr. BLAKE is the ablest exemplar. The other parts in "The Clandestine Marriage" are filled with that near arrival at perfection which renders all dramatic entertainments at Mr. WALLACK's Theatre so completely enjoyable. It is almost superfluous to say that Miss Sterling could not be so charmingly played by any one as by Mrs. HOEY; that Fanny Sterling is made irresistibly pretty and interesting by Miss MADELINE HENRIQUES; that Betty -- a specimen of the maid-servant whom our ancestors used to tolerate, but whose smartness would, in this degenerate age, be rewarded with prompt and ignominious dismissal -- becomes delightfully quaint and natural in the hands of Miss GANNON; that, as Mrs. Heidelberg, Mrs. VERNON gives further proof of her being the greatest of living comedians; and that Messrs. MARK SMITH, C. [???], JOHN SEFTON, REYNOLDS, and FLOYD, make up an ensemble of excellence which cannot be approached elsewhere.

abstract: Last Friday was a bright and balmy day, and Gen. RIPLEY, by appointment, went down to review the garrison at Fort Sumter, consisting of the First Regiment of South Carolina Artillery. A large number of ladies were present. The General looked as fine as a fiddle, and performed his part with style and expedition. The splendid corps at the post appeared to great advantage before their original and honored commander. The excellent band added much to the occasion. After the exercises on the parade, a 10-inch columbiad was fired for the benefit of the ladies, and also a casemate gun. After a luncheon, the visitors retired in a state of decided gratification.

abstract: The United States steamship Dacotah, J.P. MCKINSTRY, Commander, arrived yesterday from a cruise in search of the rebel steamer Alabama. She sailed hence on the 5th inst., and has been cruising between the east end of Long Island and Cape Hatteras, in the track of our transport ships. She has spoken a large number of vessels. She has returned for coal, and will probably sail again soon. She is at anchor off Pier No. 6 North River.

abstract: When  the rebellion first broke out the rebels drew great comfort from the belief that the pressure of war would force the laboring classes of the North into riot and insurrection.
lead_paragraph: When the rebellion first broke out the rebels drew great comfort from the belief that the pressure of war would force the laboring classes of the North into riot and insurrection. We had moving pictures of the terrible scenes that were to be enacted in New-York and other Northern cities, as soon as any attempt should be made to resist by force of arms the secession of the Southern States. Mobs would instantly occur throughout the North. In all the manufacturing districts, the operatives, who were to be thrown out of employment by the war, would rise in insurrection and plunder their employers, and in every section of the North the cry of "Bread or blood" was to be raised, and was sure to compel acquiescence in the demands of the Southern rebels. These senseless expectations were shared by many here at home, whose strong political sympathy with the South led them to indulge in similar predictions, if not hopes.

abstract: On Sunday last the authorities at Police Headquarters received information that the soldiers of a Metropolitan Regiment, stationed at Riker's Island,
lead_paragraph: On Sunday last the authorities at Police Headquarters received information that the soldiers of a Metropolitan Regiment, stationed at Riker's Island, were in a state of revolt, and that it would be necessary to forthwith dispatch a large body of policemen to the scene of disturbance, if it were proposed to keep the solders there stationed from devouring each other in a general fight. Upon the reception of this notice, Mr. Inspector CARPENTER, with characteristic promptness, immediately dispatched one hundred and fifty men, most of whom were reserves, connected with the Precincts adjoining that in which the Central office is situated -- to the place above-named, with explicit instructions to the officer in command of the force, to put down the expected riot at all hazards.

abstract: The Army of the Potomac, it will be seen by our dispatches, is again on the move not toward Richmond by way of Gordonsville, but toward Richmond by way of Fredericksburgh.
lead_paragraph: The Army of the Potomac, it will be seen by our dispatches, is again on the move -- not toward Richmond by way of Gordonsville, but toward Richmond by way of Fredericksburgh. In other words, the base of operations has been changed to Aquia Creek, and the advance is to be made along the Richmond and Fredericksburgh Railroad. A glance at a map of the country north of Richmond will be sufficient to convince any one of the propriety of this movement. Fredericksburgh is nearer to Richmond than Gordonsville, and will be occupied without a battle. This change in the programme, our Washington correspondent informs us, was known in Richmond twelve hours before our army commenced to move, -- so there can be no impropriety in announcing it to the loyal North.

abstract: In January, 1861, the Americans had 41 vessels of all rates in commission. There are now 256 menof-war carrying the Federal flag, so that the navy has been multiplied six-fold in less than two years.
lead_paragraph: In January, 1861, the Americans had 41 vessels of all rates in commission. There are now 256 menof-war carrying the Federal flag, so that the navy has been multiplied six-fold in less than two years. This, however, though denoting a wonderful effort on the part of the nation, is not a very extraordinary result, when the circumstances are reviewed. On the same conditions we could send a thousand cruisers to sea even in a shorter time. The fact is, as we have before taken occasion to remark, that the Americans were driven out of their old tactics by the sharp pressure of instant necessity. Instead of concentrating their energies and their expenditure on one or two monstrous specimens of their respective classes, they pressed at once into their service every floating vessel that could be found. River steamers, ferryboats, mail-packets, merchantmen, and coasters were all bought up, hastily armed, and sent to sea under the pennant. The result, of course, was an astonishing increase of the national marine, and, as it happened, an efficient one, too. The Federals were fighting against an enemy who had no navy at all, and, consequently, any fleet was good enough for the purpose. A really effective squadron might have made short work of these makeshifts, but the Confederates had no squadron of any kind, and so the extemporized fleet of the Northerners succeeded in keeping the sea, and blockading the helpless ports of the helpless South, Although, however, the Federals acted with this judicious decision upon the spur of the moment, they lost no time in putting some better work in train. They accepted very promptly the conclusions of European Governments respecting iron-cased vessels, and ordered a good many ships on the new model. At the present moment they have between 25 and 30 of these vessels actually afloat, and no fewer than 27 building. Yet even here we must not delude ourselves with the belief that the "iron-clad steamer" of the Federal Navy List represents anything like such vessels as are now included in our own squadron at Lisbon. The same urgency in the demand, and the same peculiarity in the contemplated service, have been at work were also to affect the efficiency of the ships turned out. We know by experience what is required for such constructions as these; and when we hear that even improved and powerful models are launched in a few months, and for 80,000 a piece, we can form a very good idea of their general quality.

abstract: FIRES. -- Yesterday forenoon a fire occurred in the upper story of Washington Hotel, kept by JOHN BERRYAN, corner of Grand and Hudson streets, Jersey City, which was speedily extinguished by the Fire Department. Damage between $400 and $500, principally by water. Fully insured.. Between 2 and 3 o'clock yesterday morning the St. Barnard's Episcopal Church, at Roseville, near Newark, was destroyed by fire. It was a two-story wooden building, valued at about $2,500. The fire was supposed to have been the work of an incendiary.

abstract: The body of Mr. THEODORE MANGUEM, the Insurance Patrolman who was buried in the ruins at the Houston-street fire on Sunday morning, as reported in yesterday's TIMES was recovered about 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: The body of Mr. THEODORE MANGUEM, the Insurance Patrolman who was buried in the ruins at the Houston-street fire on Sunday morning, as reported in yesterday's TIMES was recovered about 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The body was found deeply imbedded in the debris of the rear of No. 31 West Houston-street. The front part of this building, which is a saloon known as the "House of Commons," was comparatively uninjured. The extension in the rear, however, was a total wreck. The body was entirely free from bruises, the bead being the only part of the person which gave any indication that the deceased had been crushed under the great mass of brick and mortar, and literally buried alive beneath the ruins. The body was taken to the Headquarters of the insurance Patrol, No. 90 Crosby-street, where Coroner WILDEY held an inquest. A verdict of accidental death was rendered after the introduction of such testimony as could be obtained. The body was then taken to the house of Hose Company No. 13, the deceased, at the time of his death, being an exempt member of this Company. Here the body was prepared for burial before sending it to his family in Williamsburgh. The members of the Insurance Patrol, and of Hose Company No. 13, are entitled to much credit for their persevering efforts in searching for the body, they having labored almost constantly for near twenty-four hours in removing the rubbish in order to secure the remains of their lost comrade. The deceased was a native of New-York, and was about 28 years of age. He is believed to be the only person whose life was sacrificed at this fire, although several others are reported as having been seriously injured.

abstract: The Fall River Line advertises that its hour of departure from this time until further notice is 4 o'clock P.M., instead of 5. The City of Boston and the City of New-York compose the active fleet, and for speed, staunchness and comfort they are unsurpassed.

abstract: At the regular meeting of the City Council, held on Tuesday last, the Mayor stated that, in accordance with the resolution passed at the last meeting, he had conferred with Mr. FORMAN, Chairman of the Commission appointed by the Governor and Council for providing for the removal of the women and children from the city in the event of an attack, and found that the Commissioners were progressing in the work assigned them.
lead_paragraph: At the regular meeting of the City Council, held on Tuesday last, the Mayor stated that, in accordance with the resolution passed at the last meeting, he had conferred with Mr. FORMAN, Chairman of the Commission appointed by the Governor and Council for providing for the removal of the women and children from the city in the event of an attack, and found that the Commissioners were progressing in the work assigned them. He also had an interview with Adjutant-Gen. JORDAN, (Gen. BEAUREGARD being absent,) and was informed by him that no provisions could be expected from the army for non-combatants.

lead_paragraph: On the 29th, Mr. CORDEN addressed a large meeting of his constituents at Mr. TATHEM'S machine shop, Rochdale. The room, which will hold about three thousand persons, was densely crowded. The Mayor of Rochdale presided, and there were present the Mayors from several of the neighboring towns, a large proportion of the principal manufacturers, and a mass of operatives.

abstract: There are no 'egg-shell plates' in this vessel. The mail is solid iron, 4  inches thick, worked in form with immense sledges and fires.
lead_paragraph: There are no 'egg-shell plates' in this vessel. The mail is solid iron, 4 1/2 inches thick, worked in form with immense sledges and fires. Frequently a week is required to bore a single hole through this tough mass. * * * There is the same thickness of armor in the bow and stern, as on the sides -- and this cannot be said of any other iron-clad vessel in the world. * * * She has two turrets, one more that the Ericsson Batteries." -- Post.

abstract: editorial on Cobden speech
snippet: editorial on Cobden speech
lead_paragraph: Mr. COBDEN made some sensible and practical remarks on American affairs in a late speech at Rochdale, which will be found in our foreign extracts. He don't see that there is any use in English politicians and the English Press abusing us -- can't see that it will stop the war; he don't believe that the struggle will end by a separation of the South from the North; he shows that England and France could not successfully intervene in our contest; and, if they did intervene, it would only end in harm; he don't imagine that military interference would get cotton; and even if there is a prospect that it might do so, it would be cheaper to feed all the population engaged in the cotton manufacture on turtle steaks, champagne and venison, than to try and obtain the staple by force of arms. Beside all this, he indulges in some remarks that are neither very pert nor very philosophical regarding the undesirability of great territorial empires, and contrasts the vast empires of "Assyria, Persia and the rest," with the glorious little States of Greece and Italy, all of which has no bearing whatever upon the Union question, and no point of analogy with this Republic or its war for existence. "Assyria, Persia and the rest," were great despotisms; "Greece, for instance, or Italy." -- in their days of glory, were free States; and the littleness of the latter had no more relation to their glory than the vastness of the former had to their corruptioe and decay. This Republic is at once vast in its territory and perfect in its freedom -- vaster, by far, than "Assyria and the rest," and freer than "Greece, for instance;" and all its glories have sprung from, and depend upon, the principle of Union. What Mr. COBDEN likes to see better than vast empires is, the "development and elevavation of the individual man;" and no one knows better than he how grandly that end has been secured by this Republic. The triumph of Disunion and Slavery would assuredly result in its extinction.

abstract: Capt. HOWK, of the British bark Free Trader abandoned at sea, makes the following statement sailed from Qucbec, Sept. 13, with a cargo of lumber for Penarth Roads. All went well until Oct. 4, In
lead_paragraph: Capt. HOWK, of the British bark Free Trader abandoned at sea, makes the following statement sailed from Qucbec, Sept. 13, with a cargo of lumber for Penarth Roads. All went well until Oct. 4, In latitude 49 North, longitude 35, experienced a strong gale from west southwest, during which sprung aleak; put all hands to the pumps, and kept them continually going without intermission until Oct. 9, when the ship having seriously increased her leak could not longer keep her free; she finally became water-logged, the sea making a complete breach over her, carrying away everything movable about decks, and compelling all hands to take shelter in the tops. Oct. 13 was spoken by the British bark Claribel, of Glasgow, bound East and desired him to send a boat; it blowing very heavy could not comply, but remained with us two days and eventually left us without rendering any assistance. Oct. 18, a ship hove in sight showing American colors, who, on perceiving us immediately bore down to our assistance; it blowing a gale with a very heavy sea at the time. She proved to be the ship Montebello, Capt. ANDERSON, from Londonderry for New-York. He immediately lowered his boat, manned by the chief mate and four men, who, at the risk of their lives, succeeded in getting us on board after making two trios to our vessel, and treated us with the greatest kindness, and finally bringing us to the port.

abstract: -- In the late dashing and successful expedition of Gen. WEITZEL against the rebel camp on the Bayou La Fourche, a short distance west of New-Orleans, be captured a curious and somewhat mixed lot of things. In the first report of the affair, which we published on Monday, he mentioned that he had captured several freight cars, laden with arms, ammunition, accoutrements, shovels, and sugar, besides taking 208 belligerent rebels; and in a subsequent report, which we give this morning, he states that he had also collected a large number of cavalry and artillery horses and mules, and further still that the discomfited enemy had left behind them over 400 wagon-loads of negroes, all of which had fallen into his hands. Of a good deal of this remarkable lot of plunder, the General can easily dispose; but he is at his wits' end to know what to do with the contraband children of Ham. The 208 rebels he says he released on parole; the horses and mules can be put to immediate service by his own men; he will also find abundant use for the arms, ammunition and accoutrements, and, perhaps, even for the shovels; and with the sugar he and his boys can sweeten their coffee, but the 400 wagon-loads of negroes, alas! what can be done with them. "Now," says he vigorously, in his report to his superior officer, "what shall I do with them? I have already twice as many negroes in and around my camp as I have soldiers within. I cannot feed them; as a consequence, they must feed themselves. The community, of whom already quite a number have taken the oath of allegiance, is in great terror, fearing trouble with the negroes."

Of a good deal of this remarkable lot of plunder, the General can easily dispose; but he is at his wits' end to know what to do with the contraband children of Ham. The 208 rebels he says he released on parole; the horses and mules can be put to immediate service by his own men; he will also find abundant use for the arms, ammunition and accoutrements, and, perhaps, even for the shovels; and with the sugar he and his boys can sweeten their coffee, but the 400 wagon-loads of negroes, alas! what can be done with them. "Now," says he vigorously, in his report to his superior officer, "what shall I do with them? I have already twice as many negroes in and around my camp as I have soldiers within. The community, of whom already quite a number have taken the oath of allegiance, is in great terror, fearing trouble with the negroes."

abstract: Last evening the Democrats of the Twenty-second Ward met in convention, for the purpose of selecting a candidate for Alderman, at Riley's Hotel, corner of Ninth-avenue and Forty-second-street. The Convention was organized by calling Mr. JOHN R. VANDERVOORT to the chair. There was a great deal of enthusiasm manifested in favor of NICHOLAS SEAGRIST, the former Alderman of the ward, and he was declared unanimously nominated. Messrs. Goetzel, Loeber and Gelhare, a Committee appointed for the purpose, informed Mr. SEAGRIST of his nomination. The nominee made a brief and fitting speech in acknowledgment, and then all adjourned to work for the success of the candidate.

abstract: The Atlanta Confederacy has been informed that the citizens of Huntsville, Alabama, lately hung in effigy, NICH, DAVIS, JERRY CLEMENS and GEORGE LANE, of that place, on account of their Unionism. LANE is openly for LINCOLN, and went off with the retiring Yankees. CLEMENS and DAVIS remain at home, but it seems that the people have no confidence in their fidelity to the South.

abstract: The letter of CORTLANDT PARKER, Esq., which appears in another column, disavowing all responsibility for the posthumous publication of Gen. KEARNY's letters from the camp, deserves attention. Its remarks on this subject are eminently just and timely. We have no doubt that the gentleman by whom these publications have been made, believed that the welfare of the country and the interests of the service would justify the course he decided to take. A popular belief in Gen. MCCLELLAN's military infallibility seemed to be betraying the country into serious and fatal disasters, and he may very well have deemed it his duty to bring the declarations of one who had so fully established his own military reputation as had Gen. KEARNY, to bear against that mischievous but wide-spread public error.

abstract: WARRENTON, Va., Monday Morning, Nov. 17, 1862. It would be neither wise nor patriotic for me to speak of the important movements which are now transpiring here. A few days at the furthest will make known everything. I can say one thing, however. Gen. BURNSIDE, instead of settling himself down to digging trenches and starving out the enemy, proposes "to move immediately on their works." He has just issued a General Order, dated Nov. 14 dividing his army into three Grand Divisions. The Second and Ninth Corps are to be commanded by Gen. SUMNER; Third and Fifth by Gen. HOOKER; First and Sixth by Gen. FRANKLIN.

abstract: JOHN CRAWFORD, a recruiting Sergeant in the Second Regiment, DURYER'S Zouaves, was placed on trial yesterday, charged with manslaughter in the third degree, in causing the death of a deserter from the regiment, named GEORGE A. DOMERTY, at the Old Bowery Theatre, on the evening of the 7th of October last.
lead_paragraph: JOHN CRAWFORD, a recruiting Sergeant in the Second Regiment, DURYER'S Zouaves, was placed on trial yesterday, charged with manslaughter in the third degree, in causing the death of a deserter from the regiment, named GEORGE A. DOMERTY, at the Old Bowery Theatre, on the evening of the 7th of October last. It appeared from the evidence that the prisoner met the deceased in the lobby of the theatre on the evening in question, and charged him with being a deserter, and endeavored to induce him to return to the regiment. An altercation ensued between the parties, pending which the deceased struck the prisoner in the mouth and about the head several times, and followed up the attack by seizing him by the hair of the head, bending him down between his legs and pummeling him at his leisure. The prisoner seeing no chance of escape, drew his Zouave knife and thrust it into the abdomen of DOHERTY, inflicting a wound from which he died two days after. It was proved that the prisoner had authority to arrest deserters wherever he found them; that he was first attacked by the deceased, who was a much heavier and more powerful man than himself, and that after inflicting the wound he made no attempt to escape, but acknowledged he committed the deed, and said that it was done in self-defence. At the conclusion of the testimony, the trial was adjourned till this morning at 11 o'clock. The prisoner is defended by TOWNSEND and BIRD; and CHAS. E. WHITHEAD, Assistant District-Attorney, appeared for the prosecution.

abstract: FELONIOUS ASSAULT ON A SOLDIER.--Officer BLOOMER, of the Twentieth Precinct, yesterday arrested WM. QUACKENBUSH, upon the Charge of committtng a felonious assault upon HUGH PORTER, a soldier in the Ninety-fifth Regiment, N.Y.S.V.
lead_paragraph: FELONIOUS ASSAULT ON A SOLDIER. -- Officer BLOOMER, of the Twentieth Precinct, yesterday arrested WM. QUACKENBUSH, upon the Charge of committtng a felonious assault upon HUGH PORTER, a soldier in the Ninety-fifth Regiment, N.Y.S.V. The latter had been informed that his wife, who was a woman of bad repute, had been living with QUACKENBUSH during his absence. He therefore went to the residence of the accused for the purpose of inducing his wife to return to her allegiance and to the home which he had provided for her. Upon his arrival at QUACKENBUSH's house he was accosted in a very rude manner, and when he began to explain the occasion of his visit, the prisoner immediately knocked him down, kicked and stamped upon him, thereby inflicting dangerous internal injuries. The injured man was conveyed to Bellevue Hospital, where he now lies in a critical condition. The prisoner was committed to the Tombs to await the result.

abstract: At 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon the Tammany Committee of twenty, appointed to nominate a candidate for the Comptrollership, met in Room 33, Tammany Hall. During the discussion, which was extremely animated, the sidewalk in front of Tammany, the halls and lobbies, were crowded with Democrats, anxious to hear the result.
lead_paragraph: At 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon the Tammany Committee of twenty, appointed to nominate a candidate for the Comptrollership, met in Room 33, Tammany Hall. During the discussion, which was extremely animated, the sidewalk in front of Tammany, the halls and lobbies, were crowded with Democrats, anxious to hear the result. But the consummation was not to be. After holding solemn conclave for two hours, it was announced that the Commitee had arrived at no decision, and had adjourned till noon to-day. The object of the adjournment was to confer with the various German Democratic Committees, and see whom they wished to be nominated. Before adjourning, however, an informal vote was taken, with the following result:

abstract: Gov. SHORTER's message was read on the 20th ult. to the Legislature of Alabama, now in session at Montgomery. The Governor, after an allusion to the war, and salt question, states that the salt works in Clark and Washington counties, Alabama, produce about 2,000 bushels daily, which the State can afford to dispense to her citizens at the rate of $2 per bushel of 50 pounds; and urges that other States be invited to assist in the development of the saline resources of Alabama. This policy is in pleasing contract with the course of the authorities of Virginia, and, if the offer is made, will, no doubt, be gladly and gratefully accepted by the States to which it will be tendered. The Governor also states that contracts have been made to receive for his State 30,000 bushels of salt from Saltville, Va., at the price of $1 24 per bushel. -- Mercury, 4th.
lead_paragraph: Gov. SHORTER's message was read on the 20th ult. to the Legislature of Alabama, now in session at Montgomery. abstract: Peter Morris Vs. Elizabeth Way, et al.--This action was brought to foreclose a mortgage made by the defendant, Mrs. Way, to the plaintiff, to secure $700. It appeared on the trial that some time prior to giving the mortgage the plaintiff and Mrs.
lead_paragraph: Peter Morris Vs. Elizabeth Way, et al. -- This action was brought to foreclose a mortgage made by the defendant, Mrs. Way, to the plaintiff, to secure $700. It appeared on the trial that some time prior to giving the mortgage the plaintiff and Mrs. Way entered into a contract in which the plaintiff was to convey to Mrs. Way six lots of land on Forty-second-street, and make certain advances to aid in the erection of six dwelling-houses thereon, Mrs. Way agreeing to erect the dwellings and take the conveyance, and give the mortgages back for the purchase money and advances. At the time this mortgage was given, as claimed, the defendant had received all advances under the contract, but was unable to complete the buildings for want of means, whereupon the plaintiff deeded the property to her and took mortgages for the price of the lots and all the advances which he had agreed to make; he then made the additional advance of $700, and took the mortgage sought to be foreclosed on all the property, to secure it; this was shown to be a necessary advance to complete the buildings, and that it was actually used for that purpose, and so as recorded on March 30, 1860. The defendant, O'Callaghan, having performed work and furnished materials on the buildings, filed his mechanic's lien on April 20, 1860, and established it by a judgment of foreclosure of his lien in the New-York Common Pleas.

abstract: Editorial on Union casualties in South from yellow fever
snippet: Editorial on Union casualties in South from yellow fever
lead_paragraph: -- The late frosts whichhave visited us in the North have also extended down to the far South, and, we may hope, have put an entire stop to the ravages of the yellow fever, which has for the last two or three months raged with considerable virulence at Wilmington, in North Carolina, at Beaufort and Charleston, in South Carolina, and at Key West and other of the Keys in Florida. At Beaufort our army of occupation has suffered from it severely, and, besides many gallant officers and men, we lost by it one whose loss cannot be supplied -- that admirable officer and man, Gen. MITCHEL. At Key West and vicinity both our soldiers and sailors have suffered; but at latest advices the disease had [???] entirely left that region. By [???] we have had from Wilmington it would appear that that city had suffered for more than any place under our jurisdiction; but we were glad to learn lately that it had abated there, as it has now probably since the frost entirely ceased.

abstract: The history of the political connection between the North and the South exhibits a steady effort, on the part of the former section, to obtain peculiary aggrandizement and political power, and on the part  of the latter to preserve independence and equality.
lead_paragraph: The history of the political connection between the North and the South exhibits a steady effort, on the part of the former section, to obtain peculiary aggrandizement and political power, and on the part of the latter to preserve independence and equality. And, although most persons in the South, are surprised at the coarse pursued by the North toward us since the disruption of the Union, it is really part and parcel of the old sectional policy. It has been the settled purpose of that section to use the South for their advantage. They blundered into the disruption of the Union, out of sheer lust of power, coupled with fanatical [???], and from ignorance of the tone, temper and capacity or our people. The war is but a further development of the same unscrupulous aggression for the sake of gain which has always marked their career toward us.

abstract: A Convention of the People's Union Party was held at No. 8 Union-square last evening, to nominate candidates for Comptroller and Corporation Counsel at the coming election. CHAS. H. MARSHALL was elected President, MARTIN THATCHER and Judge W.W. DRINKER, Vice-Presidents, and SAMUEL C. REED and A. DE W.M. BALDWIN, Secretariee. Between 70 and 80 delegates were present, representing the various Assembly Districts of the City. The nomination of Corporation Counsel was taken up first, and an informal ballot was had, resulting in 32 votes being cast for Ex-Judge Slosson, 14 for Charles S. Spencer, 11 for Alex. W. Bradford, 7 for Jas. M. Smith, 3 for Richard O'Gorman, 1 for Capt. Duffy, of the Sixty-ninth, 1 for Herby Sheldon and 1 for A.R. Lawrence, Jr. After a lengthy discussion about the availability and merits of the different candidates named, a formal ballot was taken, which resulted in 35 votes for Slosson, 31 for Bradford and 4 for Smith. On the next ballot, Slosson got 35, Bradford 33 and Smith 3. Two more ballots were taken, on the last of which JOHN SLOSSON received 39 votes, and was declared the nominee of the Convention.

abstract: Editorial analyzes election results; Editorial on futility of peace advances to Confederate States
snippet: Editorial analyzes election results; Editorial on futility of peace advances to Confederate States
lead_paragraph: Gov. VANCE, of North Carolina, replies to Gov. STANLEY, who had proposed a conference of Commissioners, that he will join in no procedure of this kind, and that North Carolina means to fight to its last drop of blood. Such is the result of a friendly advance to the rebel Governor who was elected three months ago as a "conservative," and who, of all the ten, was deemed to be the least of a fire-eater, and the best disposed toward a restoration of the Union. Of course we have no means of determining to what extent Gov. VANCE speaks the sentiments of his people, but there is no reason to believe that he materially misrepresents them. We may as well accept it as settled, that in old staid North Carolina, as in every other State under the Confederate dominion, the order of the day is war, and will so remain until that dominion is either accepted or exterminated.
headline: {'main': 'The Futility of Peace Advances.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Futility of Peace Advances.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: From a gentleman who left Richmond on last Friday week we gain the following interesting news: He has been in the South during the last five months, having reached the rebel Capital during the seven days' fight. Having ingratiated himself into the favor of the authorities, he was furnished with passes, which carried him throughout the entire South. About six weeks ago he was at Savannah which city he reports as being by no means strongly fortified. The fortifications are on the water front of the city, extending from near the river and to its right, up toward the suburbs. These works are mounted with heavy siege guns taken from the Norfolk Navy-yard.

abstract: We copied yesterday a paragraph from the Montgomery Mail, containing a report that Gen. BRAGG has been superseded in his Western command by Gen. JOSEPH E. JOHNSTON. There is no foundation for such a report. Gen. BRAGG has, since his arrival in Richmond, communicated fully to the President all the facts and circumstances connected with his recent movements in Kentucky, and the President has expressed himself entirely satisfied with the explanation. Gen. BRAGG will return to Tennessee and resume his command as before.

lead_paragraph: In the TIMES, of Wednesday last, was published an account of the arrest of a counterletter, named GEORGE WHITE, of No. 233 Atlantic-avenue, Brooklyn, upon the charge of being extensively engaged in counterfeiting. Since his arrest on Tuesday of last week, some new facts have been brought to light in regard to the offender. He had a place of business at No. 88 Cedar-srreet, where for months past he has carried on his nefarious business under the name of T.H. Bentley & Co. WHITE is said to have been formerly an employe of the American Bank Note Company, but about seven months ago he left the emloy of that institution, and since that time it appears that he has been engaged in getting up, on an extensive scale, a great variety of plates for counterfeiting bills on the following banks, viz.:

abstract: The unfriendly attitude toward the Confederate States, and the timid attitude toward the United States, hitherto persistently occupied by Lords RUSSELL and PALMERSTON, do not lead to an easy credence of the intervention rumored as about to take place in American affairs. Nor would it be wise for our Government or people, in lending a willing ear to those assertions, to relax, in the smallest degree, the great efforts necessary to safety in our present position of danger. Expectations of this nature have more than once proved disappointments.

abstract: It is gratifying to note the discoveries of Europe concerning the people of the Confederate States. Deriving information and views from Northern sources, through the distorting medium of Northern newspapers, Northern books and Northern travelers, and very much confining their personal observations to that section, they have been led to believe the Southern States mere colonies -- feeble in power and semibarbarous in character. Their own prejudices and preconceptions have pondered and encouraged such absurd notions. Hence the surprise now felt and exhibited at manifestations of strength and capacity on our part. They were ignorant and lent themselves to deceptionï¿½ The disappointment of their expectations of our easy and speedy overthrow, renders them now largely ready to yield their delusive ideas regarding us, and to give us credit for achieving much more than was expected by them. They extol our statesmanship and our valor. While their former ignorance and prejudice are mortifying, they do not yet appear to realize our actual capacities. They are above the mark in some of their praises, and still do not entirely comprehend the resources and character of our people.

abstract: This Brigade of Cavalry, which is organizing under the direction of the gallant Col. DE FOREST, of the Fifth New-York Cavalry, is already nearly completed. Before the idea of forming an "Ira Harris Brigade" was conceived, Col. DE FOREST had formed two regiments, and now when his own (the Fifth) had been decimated by continual action, he has returned to recruit. The fame of the regiment of which he took command, was of the best in the army. It has been in, with honor, thirteen skirmishes and four general engagements, as follows: Port Republic, Harrisonburgh, New-Market, Woodstock, Front Royal, Middletown, Bolivar Heights, Columbia Bridge, Martinsburgh, Sperryville, Culpepper Court-House, Madison, Orange Court-House, Cedar Mountain, Kelly's Ford and the second Bull Run fights. The brigade is now nearly full, but there is still room for more of those who want fighting. There is no commander of cavalry who can better instil into his men "the dash" so necessary to success in cavalry movements, than the intrepid Colonel. All who desire to become good horsemen, skilled in the use of the sabre, and, at the same time, serve their country with distinction, had better join Col. DE FOREST's lia Harris Brigade.

abstract: A case has just been before the Court, now in session, of great interest. abstract: Editorial urges ending arbitrary arrests of rebellious persons
snippet: Editorial urges ending arbitrary arrests of rebellious persons
lead_paragraph: The prompt disavowal by the Federal Government of any agency in the Brinsmade arrest, and its avoidance, of late, of all similar procedures in the loyal States, give general satisfaction. All candid friends of the Administration freely admit that, owing to the super-serviceable zeal of certain officials, there was at one time a serious abuse of this power of summary imprisonment. In the recent canvass the Republicans forbore to take issue on that point at all, though their opponents made much of it. They contented themselves with trusting that the good sense and fidelity of the President would soon take note of the evil, and apply the appropriate remedies. This seems already to have been very effectually done, and, doubtless, would have been just as soon done had the elections resulted differently. The war devolved an immense variety of momentous duties and responsibilities upon the Administration, and, in the nature of the case, time was necessary for its subordinates to understand them justly, and fulfill them correctly. All reasonable men have recognized this, and, sure of the President's uprightness of intention, have made generous allowance for errors.

abstract: To-day we publish the text of the remonstrance of the New York Chamber of Commerce. They have issued a "report" upon this subject, in which not one word occurs as to the negligence or inefficiency of their own navy; but they declare that "the most wide-spread exasperation" is rising...
lead_paragraph: To-day we publish the text of the remonstrance of the New York Chamber of Commerce. They have issued a "report" upon this subject, in which not one word occurs as to the negligence or inefficiency of their own navy; but they declare that "the most wide-spread exasperation" is rising against this country, because the Confederate war steamer Alabama burnt the Federal merchant ship Brilliant. Their reason for this exasperation is that the Alabama was built in this country, and that the guns with which she is mounted were also bought in this country. We have no doubt of these facts, although we have no special information as to them. But what has England to do with this? Suppose we had knowingly allowed a ship-of-war to be built, and armed, and provisioned, and manned, and to go, flying the Confederate flag, out of one of our seaports, we should have done wrong. We should have done what the United States did when, during the Russian war, they sent the America across the Pacific to the Russians in the Yellow Sea. We should have done what the United States did when the Russian war ship, the Great Admiral, was laid down in an American dockyard. But we have done nothing of the sort. Our shipowners have sold a ship as they are every day selling ships. Whether she was better adapted for war or for peace is nothing to them or to us. She left our port an unarmed vessel. Depend upon it, she infringed no law municipal or international, for Mr. ADAMS and his agents, as well as the secret Committee which sits in London, had all their eyes upon her. Whether she would have been a lawful prize when she had left our waters, we know not; that must depend upon her papers; but she was not a ship which our Government had a right to stop. How many steamships does the New-York Chamber of Commerce think our shipbuilders turn out in a year? Are we to shut up our ship-yards as well as our factories as a homage to the Federal lust of conquest? The New-York Chamber of Commerce, and especially Mr. Low, who seems to be their mouth-piece, would appear to be of this opinion. They have "heard with amazement" that other ships are being built in England and Scotland which may possibly become at a future time Confederate vessels of war. Mr. Low has, moreover, heard that an iron-clad ship is being built here for that purpose, and he was also read in the patch papers that a ship loaded with Confederate stores was lately such in the Clyde.

The most  important news by this arrival is the announcement that the Spanish Government has demanded the punishment of the Americans alleged to have violated the Spanish flag on the coast of Cuba.
lead_paragraph: Advices one day later from Europe are received by the arrival off Cape Race of the steamship Anglo-Saxon on her way to Quebec. The most important news by this arrival is the announcement that the Spanish Government has demanded the punishment of the Americans alleged to have violated the Spanish flag on the coast of Cuba. Our Minister at Madrid had had an audience with the Queen in regard to the matter, and had given assurances that the United States Government did not authorize the acts of the Captain of the gunboat Montgomery. Mediation rumors were again current in London, but they are probably worthy of no more attention than those which have preceded them. The French Cabinet is said to be more at variance than ever regarding the Roman question. It was thought that a majority of the Ministers would resign unless the Emperor should resolve to give Rome to the Italians. The Grecian question still remained unsettled -- it being uncertain whether the Provisional Government would decide in favor of a monarchy or a Federal Republic. The Bank of France had advanced its rate of discount to four per cent. The sales of cotton at Liverpool for the week had been 47,000 bales, and the market closed dull. Breadstuffs were quiet and steady, and Provisions dull. Consols were quoted at 93 1/2@93 5/8 for money.

abstract: THE NEGRO ANDRESON IN CUSTODY. The negro ANDERSON, who, it is alleged, brutally assaulted a young girl near Hackensack, N.J., on Friday last, knocking out her teeth, beating her until she was insensible and finally outraging her person, was arrested on Tuesday by Detective MOORE.
lead_paragraph: THE NEGRO ANDRESON IN CUSTODY. -- The negro ANDERSON, who, it is alleged, brutally assaulted a young girl near Hackensack, N.J., on Friday last, knocking out her teeth, beating her until she was insensible and finally outraging her person, was arrested on Tuesday by Detective MOORE. The description of ANDERSON was very little to proceed upon, but the detective was fortunate enough to have a small scrap of cloth similar to that worn by the prisoner. With this in his possession, he succeeded in getting the man after about an hour's search. ANDERSON was brought to Police Headquarters and lodged in No. 4, where he will remain until this morning, when he will be conveyed to New-Jersey. He is a sensual looking negro, about 20 years of age, and was sullen and taciturn after his arrest, refusing to speak upon the subject, other than to say he knew some of the parties in the case. The young girl in question is now confined to her bed and is not expected to survive the brutal treatment received. The arrest is important, and is the first one of any moment made by Officer MOORE since his appointment on the Detective force. His connection with the Jefferds case is still fresh in the minds of our readers, his testimony being that upon which JEFFERDS was convicted.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. DONIZETTI'S opera of the "Daughter of the Regiment," was played here last evening to a good audience. Signor SUSINI as Sulpice, was admirable, both vocally and dramatically. The rest of the artists did not make themselves sufficiently prominent to call for extended notice.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- DONIZETTI's opera of the "Daughter of the Regiment," was played here last evening to a good audience. Signor SUSINI as Sulpice, was admirable, both vocally and dramatically. The rest of the artists did not make themselves sufficiently prominent to call for extended notice. We may add, however, that Madame GUERRABELLA, who acted superbly, did not appear to be in good voice, and in the character of Maria suffered seriously by comparison with her previoas efforts.

lead_paragraph: We have nothing from the Army of the Potomac this morning excepting the assurance that it is in motion. We shall soon, no doubt, hear a good account of it. Relative to the movements of the rebels, the latest intelligence received in Washington believed to be reliable, is to the effect that their main army has succeeded in reaching a point between our army and Richmond -- probably at Hanover Junction. JACKSON and STUART are said to be between Culpepper and Warrenton, and it may be that LEE will have to fight without their cooperation.

abstract: What the proud Spanish people will say to their Queen's Representative having his face slapped on board the British ship he had taken under his care, by a Yankee subordinate, we may well imagine.
lead_paragraph: What the proud Spanish people will say to their Queen's Representative having his face slapped on board the British ship he had taken under his care, by a Yankee subordinate, we may well imagine. A Spanish frigate set forth immediately in search of the offender, who had, however, by that time got himself well out of harm's way; but the Spanish Government will doubtless remonstrate effectually with the impudent Yankees for the shameless violation of their neutral waters, for destroying a ship under the protection of their flag, as well as that of a neutral and friendly nation, and for the personal insult to a national authority. Mr. Lincoln will have to apologize not only in words, but in that metal so precious in the North that he must pay a premium of thirty or forty per cent. to get it.

abstract: The second lecture by Mr. T. MASON JONES was delivered last night at Irving Hall; subject "CURRAN, and the Wits and Orators of the Irish Bar." Notwithstanding the inclemency of the weather the ball was crowded with a highly fashionable and intelligent auditory, and the applause given the speaker was frequent.
lead_paragraph: The second lecture by Mr. T. MASON JONES was delivered last night at Irving Hall; subject "CURRAN, and the Wits and Orators of the Irish Bar." Notwithstanding the inclemency of the weather the ball was crowded with a highly fashionable and intelligent auditory, and the applause given the speaker was frequent. He most happily touched off the prominent traits in the character of JOHN PHILPOT CURRAN; and his comparison of that learned barrister's style of eloquence with that of PITT, FOX, FLOOD, GRATTAN, O'CONNELL, and other prominent Irish orators was of a character warranted by what is told us in the biographies of those learned men. His peroration on the versatility of CURRAN's genius and the nobleness of his character, was a most rhetorically finished, picture, and drew forth great applause. Quite an episode occurred while Mr. JONES was in the middle of his oration. Speaking of Mr. CURRAN's defence of ROWAN, before an English Court, for libel on the Crown, Mr. JONES quoted from the learned barrister's speech that portion which so highly eulogises Universal Emancipation, and incidentally alluded to the Briton's boast, that the foot of no slave can press the soil of the British Empire or any ground covered by the British flag, and said that he hoped the time would soon come when the same might with truth be said of another flag -- the star-spangled banner. "Oh," said the speaker, "if you only knew the derision that foreign nations cast upon you in consequence of the stain of Slavery that is on that flag, there is no Democrat or Pro-Slavery man at the North" -- Here the speaker was interrupted by a number of hisses, the noise of which was soon drowned in a tremendous outburst of applause, that lasted for some time. Mr. JONES again essayed to proceed, when the hisses were renewed and much confusion created, Cries of "put 'em out," "hear him," &c., were frequent, while the friends of the sentiment partially avowed by the speaker having the majority, drowned all opposition by their applause. Order being restored. Mr. JONES said:

abstract: While the Alabama was in course of construction at Birkenhead, the American Consul at Liverpool made a representation on the subject to the Customs authorities. Nothing came of it, and further representations were made, we believe, to the Board of Trade.
lead_paragraph: While the Alabama was in course of construction at Birkenhead, the American Consul at Liverpool made a representation on the subject to the Customs authorities. Nothing came of it, and further representations were made, we believe, to the Board of Trade. This also proving ineffectual, the opinion of Mr. COLLIER, Q.C., was taken on the lawfulness of the proceeding, under the Queen's proclamation of neutrality. The learned gentleman's, opinion was decidedly against the builders or owners of the vessel, and was, therefore submitted to the Foreign Office. The law officers of the Crown were then consulted on the matter, and their opinion, we understand, entirely coincided with that of Mr. COLLIER, it became, therefore, the duty of the Government to prevent the departure of the Alabama, but by the time this decision was arrived at she had left the Mersey, and, perhaps, commenced her career of depredation and destruction.

abstract: BROKERS. -- The recent movement in behalf of an open and free Board of Brokers is in accordance with the progressive spirit of the times, and will certainly be successful and popular. It will, it is granted, place those who engage in it in a hostile attitude to the present Board of Brokers. In this respect the movement will by many be regretted, inasmuch as the present Board is an honorable and patriotic association, and has always enforced the most stringent rules of personal and public faith. But personal considerations should yield before great principles of commercial liberalism, and the open Board should be allowed, without resistance, to occupy the field heretofore filled by the other. At the present day, if we find the owners of flour, fuel, salt or any other articles of prime necessity, meeting together and resolving not to furnish those articles for a less price than shall be fixed on from time to time by a majority of themselves, we feel that the interests of society are endangered. Such course of action destroys competition and subjects a community to the odious restrictions and oppressions of monopoly. It annihilates the value of enterprise, industry and courtesy in business, and in this way operates to the serious injury of the young members of any trade or profession, who need to work for less at the start, if only to make the opportunity of showing their capacity for business, and thus being enabled to obtain commissions against older and wealthier parties.

abstract: Lieut. WELLS, commanding Company H, Eighth New-Hampshire Regiment, at the battle of Labadieville, was hit on the breeches pocket by a half-spent canister shot, which cut a hole in his surtout coat and completely smashed up his powder-flask. The Lieutenant was knocked clown by the force of the blow. A little lameness supervened, but he has attended to his company duties daily since.
lead_paragraph: Lieut. abstract: -- In the large cities of the South, captured by our arms, there are very hopeful and cheering manifestations of the Union sentiment. The Memphis papers of the 11th bring us long and glowing accounts of an "immense Union demonstration" in that city on the preceding day. There was a prodigious procession of citizens -- over three thousand being in line; there was a prodigious mass meeting in the theatre, at which glowing speeches were delivered by distinguished gentlemen; there were flags and bands of music; there were two Union Clubs, German Turners, and citizens on horseback; there were boys and girls costumed in white, and bearing devices and emblems; there was (to quote the Memphis Bulletin) a "magnificent car, of immense proportions, covered with pink, and drawn by twelve gray horses, while in the centre rose a dome of blue, resting on pillars, and within the circle of the dome, stood a tall young lady of a regal style of beauty, (whose name the Memphis editor does not hesitate to give,) habited in the costume of the Goddess of Liberty." In short -- for we cannot add to the ornamental skill of the Bulletin -- "beauty was there, brave warriors, loyal men, flouting banners, streamers wantoning in the wind, flags displaying the emblems of our proud nationality, and martial and patriotic airs pealing from trumpets and bounding from drums, added an exultant feature to the magnificent display."
lead_paragraph: -- In the large cities of the South, captured by our arms, there are very hopeful and cheering manifestations of the Union sentiment. abstract: The British Brig Alma, of Nassau, Capt. BODE, from Nassau Nov. 7, with fruit and old junk to DARRELL  Co., arrived yesterday. She left schooner Ettie in port, to leave for New-York in three days. The British steamer Pacific, hence, arrived Nov. 1, and sailed for Havana, to return to Nassau. The Confederate steamer Kate, from Wilmington, N.C., with a cargo of cotton, arrived at Nassau 4th inst., having passed the blockade.

abstract: At noon yesterday the Tammany Committee of twenty met again in Tammany Hall to nominate a candidate for the Comptrollership. On the formation of the meeting a delegation from the German Central Club was introduced. Dr. MERKLE who was the spokesman, stated that the German Democracy were in favor of no special candidate, but would prefer not having Alderman BOOLE nominated. The delegation then withdrew.

abstract: We are requested to state that the report published in the TIMES of yesterday, that Mr. C.A. DANA has been appointed Assistant Secretary of War, is erroneous. Mr. WOLCOTT still holds his office, and neither Mr. DANA, nor any other person, so far as we are aware, has been appointed in his place.

abstract: PROBABLE MURDER OF AN INFANT AND ATTEMPTED SUICIDE. About three weeks ago, a young colored woman belonging in New-York went to reside with a family as a domestic, at No. 44 Morrisstreet, Jersey City. Nothing particular transpired until yesterday morning, when the girl complained of a severe sick headache, and the kitchenwork was accordingly done by the ladies of the house.
lead_paragraph: PROBABLE MURDER OF AN INFANT AND ATTEMPTED SUICIDE. -- About three weeks ago, a young colored woman belonging in New-York went to reside with a family as a domestic, at No. 44 Morrisstreet, Jersey City. Nothing particular transpired until yesterday morning, when the girl complained of a severe sick headache, and the kitchenwork was accordingly done by the ladies of the house. It was observed, however, that whenever coal or anything was wanted from the cellar, the girl would immediately go for it, and her manner appeared somewhat excited. Subsequently, after the work had been finished up in the basement, the girl went up to her room. The curiosity of the ladies having beenaroused, they proceeded to the cellar, and there found the lifeless remains of an infant, buried under a quantity of ashes, over which had been thrown a piece of sheet-iron, tubs, and other articles. Upon going to the girl's room, she was found lying insensible. Dr. HADDON, City Physician, was called in, and, from the symptoms, is of opinion that the woman had taken poison for self-destruction, but that the object was defeated by swallowing an over-dose, thereby causing her to vomit. The proper remedies were applied, and the Coroner was notified. An investigation will be commenced to-day.

abstract: ANOTHER BOUNTY CASE. Officer LAURENCE CAREY, of the 20th New-York Precinct Police, yesterday arrested CHARLES H. WEEDON, a private in the Fifty-second Regiment, stationed at Camp Stranahan, near Flatbush, on charges of obtaining bounties illegally. As alleged, he enlisted in a company of Monitors at Newark, N.J., on the 30th ult., and...
lead_paragraph: ANOTHER BOUNTY CASE. -- Officer LAURENCE CAREY, of the 20th New-York Precinct Police, yesterday arrested CHARLES H. WEEDON, a private in the Fifty-second Regiment, stationed at Camp Stranahan, near Flatbush, on charges of obtaining bounties illegally. As alleged, he enlisted in a company of Monitors at Newark, N.J., on the 30th ult., and made $102 by the operation. He then joined the Fifth Regiment Zouaves, of New-York, and received $100, -- when he came to Brooklyn and enlisted in the Fifty-second Regiment, and expected $140 more bounty, but had not been paid at the time of his arrest. The prisoner has a Lieutenant-Colonel's uniform and a Zouave uniform in his possession; also, about 500 letters from different parties whopromised to aid him in recruiting to fill up companies he had evidently represented he was about raising. He was committed for a hearing.

abstract: --We congratulate the London Times upon its acquisition of a special correspondent at Richmond, Virginia. We do not wonder at the tone of exultation in which it announces the fact to its readers. Now, at last, the European world will learn the truth in regard to the South. Hitherto it has been a great cause of complaint with the Times that its accounts had to be derived, in great measure, from the North; for, of course, a people who were so degraded as to be out of humor with England, and not to admire the London Times, could not be relied upon for any statement. We, it is true, have thought that the accounts of matters here, which have gone to the English people through the columns of the Times, were not unreasonably unfavorable to the rebellion, and certainly no one could find fault with the conductors of the Times if they were so. Had they not displaced one correspondent, whose letters betrayed some sense of justice to the North? Had they not sent over a special, whose sympathies as well as his accuracy, were well indicated by his relying upon the editorials of the Caucasian for information about the President's statements of his purposes? But still, even with the most favorable intentions, some things would get into the correspondence which told against the rebellion. That charge the new series of letters will undoubtedly be quite free from. Whether its statements will be entirely impartial and unprejudiced, and whether anything will be stated without indisputable evidence of its falsehood, time will show. As a sample of it thus far, we may refer to some of the averments in the first letter, which we give this morning.
