abstract: DEAR BROTHER: I suppose you read my letter to mother, describing an excursion along the mountains up the Shenandoah Valley. While we were three we sent out two companies at a time every day on picket at fords on the Shenandoah River, which at this place was about as wide as Grandpa's Mill Pond, but not so deep.

abstract: When it became generally known yesterday that Gen. McCLELLAN had left Trenton, in the State of New-Jersey, and had arrived at the Fifth-avenue Hotel, quite a number of his personal friends and admirers called to see him at his rooms.
lead_paragraph: When it became generally known yesterday that Gen. McCLELLAN had left Trenton, in the State of New-Jersey, and had arrived at the Fifth-avenue Hotel, quite a number of his personal friends and admirers called to see him at his rooms. Many of them, however, were disappointed, for the General left the hotel at 10 A.M. and did not return until 2 P.M. The fact that he was not at his published headquarters, created some doubt as to whether he was really in the City, and, consequently, there were but few callers until evening, when, as had been publicly announced, he was to be serenaded by the Young Men's Democratic Association. The time stated for the commencement of the serenade was 10 P.M., but as early as 9 o'clock there were several hundred people present. About that hour the Committee appointed by the Common Council to extend to him the hospitalitiesof the City, headed by Alderman FARLEY, was present and ready to perform the duty to which it had been assigned, but after many inquiries and a fruitless search for the General, the Committee retired -not over well pleased with the failure of the visit. There were also a number of other distinguished gentlemen present. Among them, Ex-Chief of Police MATSELL, Mr. BRENNAN, D. D. CONOVER, Alderman F. I. A. BOOLE, Alderman BRADLEY and others -- all anxious to see the General, but unfortunately for them he was not to be seen. He had gone out, so it was said, to visit some friends, and of course, was not in the hotel. Here was another disappointment; but as some members of the Seventh Regiment band appeared, it was taken for granted that the serenade would be given, and they all remained.

abstract: Yesterday morning was set apart by the Police Commissioners for the trial of Police-Superintendent Kennedy on the charge of the alleged imprisonment of Mrs. Brinsmade, of New-Orleans. There was a large attendance of witnesses, Police Captains and interested spectators.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning was set apart by the Police Commissioners for the trial of Police-Superintendent Kennedy on the charge of the alleged imprisonment of Mrs. Brinsmade, of New-Orleans. There was a large attendance of witnesses, Police Captains and interested spectators. Among the latter were District-Attorney A. O. Hall and Dr. Mahan -- the latter gentleman well known for his connection with the Beardsley Divorce case. The Police Commission was represented in the persons of Messrs. Bowen, [Acton and Bergen. Mr. S.L.M. Barlow appeared to aid in the investigation on the part of the complainant, and Mr. Kennedy was present with his counsel, ex-Judge Gilbert Dean. The small and cramped room was quite crowded with the necessary persons present, no small proportion of whom were representatives of the Press.

abstract: LADIES ASSOCIATION OF THE PROTESTANT EPISCOPAL CHURCH OF THE RECURRECTION.--The benifice sought to be conveyed by the present exhibition of tempting salables at the storeroom under the Fifthavenue Hotel, lately occupied by BRODIE  Co., comprises the extent lying between Thirty-fourth and ...
lead_paragraph: LADIES ASSOCIATION OF THE PROTESTANT EPISCOPAL CHURCH OF THE RECURRECTION. -- The benifice sought to be conveyed by the present exhibition of tempting salables at the storeroom under the Fifthavenue Hotel, lately occupied by BRODIE Co., comprises the extent lying between Thirty-fourth and Forty-seventh streets on the one hand, and Fifth and Sixth avenues on the other. This parish is young, and the Sunday School attached is but a beginning of what we may expect. Already have one hundred scholars gathered about its standard, and the prospects of the teachers -- fifteen in number -- are for many more. Rev. E. O. FLAGG, a thorough and well-informed missionary, has organized and is carrying out systematically a plan of usefulness in that portion of the City where activity is most needed. Among the articles exposed for sale in the Hall were what were called knit bonnets, a vary great improvement on anything in the way of hoods, and something that might become the prettiest complexion. They were of gray and white, mixed, and white and pink, suiting a most fastidious taste. A very tasteful arrangement of forest leaves into a crucifix was observable, and will no doubt sell well. There were oil paintings and an array of wax bouquets that would have tempted any one to linger in examination of their rare imitation of nature, yet, unless you have plenty of money, you had better not expose yourself to the allurement of charms that guard the inaccessible rarities. A sentiment of great goodness seems to exist, however, and if one is prepared with about half of what he would expect to lay out on previous occasions of the kind, he will without doubt find himself intensely popular. This Fair will continue until the end of the week.

abstract: The twenty-ninth annual Festival and Fair of the Brooklyn Orphan Asylum came off on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings. The children, numbering between one and two hundred, assembled in the large hall, and gave their friends a most acceptable treat in the rendition of certain melodies appropriate not only to their quiet existence, but descriptive of our country's disturbance.
lead_paragraph: -- The twenty-ninth annual Festival and Fair of the Brooklyn Orphan Asylum came off on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings. The children, numbering between one and two hundred, assembled in the large hall, and gave their friends a most acceptable treat in the rendition of certain melodies appropriate not only to their quiet existence, but descriptive of our country's disturbance. "The Ship at Sea," which they sung with accurate expression, was called for three times, and was sorrowfully remindful of what we are passing through in our domestic strife. It breathed of hope, however, and a promise which all seemed to justly appreciate. Beside the regular educational routine of school hours, the girls of the institution are taught light household duties and sewing, and prepared for general usefulness. Last year's fair and festival was particularly auspicious, and the liberal donations of the present, in spite of the inclement weather, inspire the Managers with hope that they may not find themselves lacking as the Winter approaches.

abstract: Our advices from the Army of the Potomac are not specially important. The bulk of our forces still remain on the north side of the Rappahannock, and the rebel pickets occupy the south bank. A company of rebel scouts, on Wednesday ...
lead_paragraph: Our advices from the Army of the Potomac are not specially important. The bulk of our forces still remain on the north side of the Rappahannock, and the rebel pickets occupy the south bank. A company of rebel scouts, on Wednesday night, burnt a bridge on the Orange and Alexandria Railroad, near Catlett's Station. Scouts and refugees report that the rebel Gen. EARLEY is at Shepherd's Mills with 9,000 men; that Gen. MACKALL is near the same place with a like number; that a rebel force of 10,000 is near Ashby's and Snicker's Gaps, and that a force of 8,000 rebels has advanced from Warrenton to Gainesville, which has been evacuated by Gen. SIGEL. The letters of our special correspondents will be found of much interest, as detailing the recent movements of our army.

abstract: The New-Hampshire Democratic State Convention to-day nominated IRA A. EASTMAN for Governor, and JAMES S. CHENEY for Railroad Commissioner. The resolutions adopted affirm the preservation of the Constitution as it is and the restoration of the Union as it was. There was a large attendance and entire harmony.
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.H., Thursday, Nov. 20.

Her news was up to the 21st ult., and mention is made of a meeting of Mexicans in San Francisco, on the 19th, for the purpose of arranging means to assist the Mexican Government ...
lead_paragraph: The steamer America, of the Nicaragua line, entered this port yesterday morning, on her way to NewYork, for the purpose of taking in coal, etc with 572 passsengers on board. Her news was up to the 21st ult., and mention is made of a meeting of Mexicans in San Francisco, on the 19th, for the purpose of arranging means to assist the Mexican Government with voluntary aid to resist the French invasion. The proposal was enthusiastically received, and books for subscription were opened at the office of the newspaper La Voz de Mejico. A considerable sum was likewise collected on the spot. LARA.

abstract: The military funeral which took place yesterday afternoon, and in which the Eighth Regiment took part, cannot fail to add additional honor to that distinguished corps.
lead_paragraph: The military funeral which took place yesterday afternoon, and in which the Eighth Regiment took part, cannot fail to add additional honor to that distinguished corps. During their three months, campaign, five of their members (privates) were slain in battle. Their bodies were recently recovered, and brought to this City, where they were laid in state in the Armory, under a guard of honor. Yesterday the funeral obsequies took place. The bodies were deposited in five handsome glass hearses, and accompanied by the regiment, were brought to Trinity Church, where the funeral services took place. The following was the order of the cortege:

abstract: Editorial on relation of slavery and war
snippet: Editorial on relation of slavery and war
lead_paragraph: The steamship Persia arrived at this port last night, with advices from Europe three days later than were received by the Nova Scotian. She left Liverpool on the 8th inst., and Queenstown on the 9th. Some of the papers were again giving currency to mediation rumors. The Paris correspondent of the London Times gives one to the effect that "overtures have been, or are to be made, by France to the Russian Government, with a view to taking into serious consideration the state of affairs in America; the disastrous effects of the civil war on Europe generally; and whether the time has not now come for the Powers to make a move toward mediation or recognition of the Confederate States." The London Herald also gives currency to a similar rumor. The depredations of the pirate Alabama were engaging the attention of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce, some of the members of which do not like the freedom with which SEMMES has disposed of British property on board some of his prizes. A memorial had been prepared on the subject, for presentation to Earl RUSSELL. The intelligence received by the Nova Scotian regarding the action of the Spanish Government in the case of the steamer Blanche is corroborated. The Spanish authorities, however, apprehend no difficulty in adjusting the matter satisfactorily. The Continental news by this arrival is not of special importance.

abstract: Editorial on struggle facing Union in Virginia; says if Lee's army is broken Confederacy will perish
snippet: Editorial on struggle facing Union in Virginia; says if Lee's army is broken Confederacy will perish
lead_paragraph: It is understood that a number of the Expeditions which were being gotten up for operating on the Southern coast and against points of secondary importance, have been abandoned, and that the forces in the field will now be directed to the main purpose of capturing Richmond and defeating the principal rebel army. The number of men at this moment in the military service of the Government is greater than ever before; but it is clear enough that if we abstract from our Eastern army troops sufficient to capture and hold Texas, to seize and occupy Charleston, Savannah and Mobile, and to operate in North Carolina, Louisiana and Florida, we shall really be able to bring not more than a moiety of our strength against that great rebel force in Virginia which gives to the Confederacy coherency and vitality. The main thing to be done, in a military point of view, and the chief thing which the country desires, is the defeat of Gen. LEE. His army broken, and the Confederacy will perish.

abstract: THE BROOKLYN BOARD OF ALDERMEN.--Now that the election is over, and the majorities of the successful candidates declared, there is an animated contest for the various positions in the gift of the Common Council.
lead_paragraph: THE BROOKLYN BOARD OF ALDERMEN. -- Now that the election is over, and the majorities of the successful candidates declared, there is an animated contest for the various positions in the gift of the Common Council. The Democrats having a decided majority, the appointments will probably all be made from that party; and the caucus nominations will therefore be equal to an election. There are several candidates for nearly all the offices. The Presidency of the Board is still unsettled. Alderman WHITNEY, of the First Ward; Alderman TERNAN, of the Ninth Ward, and Alderman O'KEEFE, of the Twelfth Ward, appear to be the most prominent candidates. For Counsellor of the Board there are three aspirants --Messrs. JOHN G. SCHUMAKER, WINCHESTER BRITTON, and ALEX MCCUE; and for the City Clerkship, Messrs. HENRY MCCLOSKEY and WM. G. BISHOP are the only contestants. Some of the less important positions will doubtless be filled by reappointing the present incumbents -- such as Keeper of the City Hall, Messenger of the Board, &c.; but there is a prospect of change in some, if not most of the more important offices; at least, such are the present indications. The new Board will stand -- ten Democrats and eight Republicans, with a vacancy in the Fifth Ward caused by the election of Alderman LYNCH as Auditor.

abstract: The Fiftieth Massachusetts arrived here yesterday morning, from Boston, vid the Norwich line. It comprises nine hundred men, who were principally recruited in Essex County.
lead_paragraph: The Fiftieth Massachusetts arrived here yesterday morning, from Boston, vid the Norwich line. It comprises nine hundred men, who were principally recruited in Essex County. They are fully armed and equipped, and in every respect add credit by their appearance, to the Bay State. Some of the officers are said to be very wealthy. The Colonel, Lieutenant-Colonel and Major, have been in active service -- the first two at Bull Run, and the latter has served thirteen months in one of the Massachusetts regiments. The corps is now at the Park Barracks. There is a band of fifteen pieces attached, which will be maintained by the officers. These troops are to join Gen. BANKS' Expedition. The following are the leading officers:

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. In addition to containing the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the diderent departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, will be found in the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and marketreports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Very unexpectedly, yesterday morning, Capt. WILSON, of the Revenue-battery Naugaluck, received orders to prepare for sea at once, and leave NewYork as soon as possible.
lead_paragraph: Very unexpectedly, yesterday morning, Capt. WILSON, of the Revenue-battery Naugaluck, received orders to prepare for sea at once, and leave NewYork as soon as possible. An excursion down the Bay had been planned, to try some ordnance experiments, Gen. BANKS and other distinguished personages being expected on board, but the Washington dispatch changed the programme. Everything was got ready as speedily as possible, officers ordered to "s and by," and last evening the final preparations being complete, the fast little "water-clad" man-of-war left her anchorage and will be probably outside the lights to-day. We printed a list of her officers on Tuesday.

abstract: THE MURDER OF AN INFANT.--Justice COWEN, of Jersey City, held an inquest yesterday upon the body of a colored infant, found buried in some rubbish in the cellar of house No. 44 Morris-street.
lead_paragraph: THE MURDER OF AN INFANT. -- Justice COWEN, of Jersey City, held an inquest yesterday upon the body of a colored infant, found buried in some rubbish in the cellar of house No. 44 Morris-street. Dr. HADDAM, City Physician, testified that the child had been born alive, and that death was caused by suffocation; also, that the right limb was displaced and broken, and that the whole appearance showed marks of violence. He found a colored woman, named MARGARET ROSE, in the house No. 44 Morris-street, who had all the appearance of being recently delivered of a child. Mrs. SPEAR testified to having found the remains of the child in the cellar. The jury rendered a verdict that the child was willfully murdered, and from the evidence they believe that said child was murdered by its mother, MARGARET ROSE. The woman was removed to the alms-house on Wednesday nignt, where she has remained most of the time in an unconscious state, as is supposed from the effects of poison, taken for the purpose of self-destruction. Her recovery is considered doubtful.

The weather has been exceedingly unfavorable,and the number of visitors was consequently not so large as on some previous occasions. The contributions have ...
lead_paragraph: A fair for the benefit of this Institution, situated in Cumberland-street, between Myrtle and Park avenues, has been in progress for three days. The weather has been exceedingly unfavorable,and the number of visitors was consequently not so large as on some previous occasions. The contributions have however, been liberal -- a large amount of clothing, vegetables, &c., having been sent in. A very welcome bequest of $5,000 was made to the Institution by the heirs of the late WILLIAM H. CAREY. This is the second bequest of a like amount since the organization of the Association. There are at present 110 children, between the ages of 3 and 12 years, cared for in the Asylum. All are well clothed, and present a healthy and contented appearance. There has been no sickness during the past Summer, and but one death during the year.

abstract: A pamphlet, entitled, A Brief Statement of the Objects and Results of the Prison Association of NewYork, during the seventeen Years of Its Existence, has been placed upon our table. It is a "statement" full of interest, as showing what may be done, what indeed has been done, to improve our prisons, and to ...
lead_paragraph: A pamphlet, entitled, A Brief Statement of the Objects and Results of the Prison Association of NewYork, during the seventeen Years of Its Existence, has been placed upon our table. It is a "statement" full of interest, as showing what may be done, what indeed has been done, to improve our prisons, and to raise the fallen and restore them to themselves and society. It has convinced us that the cheapest as well as the surest protection to society against the bad, is to make them good; to convert felons into upright and virtuous citizens. We learn from this pamphlet that of nearly 3,000 discharged convicts provided with situations by the Society, not five per cent. have ever returned to prison, while the great majority have been thoroughly reclaimed, are earning an honest living, and have the confidence and respect of the community in which they reside. This is surely a most respectable and impressive fact, and ought to conciliate the judgment and friendly interest of the public toward the Association, through which so important a work has been achieved.

lead_paragraph: A most heartrending case of abortion, resulting in death, has just been developed, and plunges a respectable family into the deepest grief. From the facts already brought to light, it appears that on the 25th ultimo Miss CLEMENTINA ANDERSON, a young lady of beauty and accomplishments, left [???] home of her parents, No. 370 Bleecker-street, suddenly, and under very mysterious circumstances. All efforts to find the missing girl [???] unavailing, and the family have been suffering the most poignant grief in consequence of her absence, which to them was wholly unaccountable, ab out 9 o'clock Wednesday evening, a carriage [???] up to the door of Mr. ANDERSON's residence, when two men and a woman alighted, dragging after [???] an emaciated and insensible girl; and on entering the house, she was recognized by Mr. ANDERSON as his lost daughter. She was evidently [???] a dying condition, and in a few minutes afterwards [???] breathed her last. Dr. TUCKER, who lives on the ne rived and arrested her. After the revelations she had made it was deemed important to secure Dr. BROWN, and accordingly Capt. SEBRING, accompanied [???] Officer ROLLINS, called on the Doctor, whom they [???] waiting for his woman, GORDON, to return from Dr. ANDERSON's.

abstract: The poor littleboys of the Children's Aid Society -- especially those in the Newsboys' Lodging-house -- are in great want of shirts and Winter clothing. Many suffer bitterly from the cold and the wet. The usual supplies from the country do not come in this year. If families would send in their cast-off children's clothes, shirts, stockings, coats and trousers, they could all be used with advantage. If the address be sent to the office, the articles will be called for. They can also be sent to the Children's Aid Society, No. 11 Clinton Hall, Astor-place.

abstract: our gunboats in watching the blockade-runners of Nassau excite a good deal of British indignation. It would be an interesting question to discuss, whether that indignation rose higher among the Bermudians or among the John Bulls "at 'ome." But of all the reasons ...
lead_paragraph: our gunboats in watching the blockade-runners of Nassau excite a good deal of British indignation. It would be an interesting question to discuss, whether that indignation rose higher among the Bermudians or among the John Bulls "at 'ome." But of all the reasons given for that indignation, that put forward by the Bermuda Royal Gazette bears off the palm. That Regal sheet, after announcing that our vessels kept a vigilant guard over all vessels entering and leaving their ports, says: "Our people are beginning to feel annoyed at the strictness of the blockade, and it is only natural, as all Britishers have a horror of the underhand."

abstract: The old adage to the effect that after a storm there comes a calm, has been verified in the past two days, during which Gen. McCLELLAN has been a guest at the Fifth-avenue Hotel. On the evening of the first day, there was a demonstration--in fact a storm.
lead_paragraph: The old adage to the effect that after a storm there comes a calm, has been verified in the past two days, during which Gen. McCLELLAN has been a guest at the Fifth-avenue Hotel. On the evening of the first day, there was a demonstration -- in fact a storm. It rained, the gas-lights furnished the lightning, RENDERS' gun the thunder, and the Young Men's Democratic Association completed the general disturbance, of the elements involved. But yesterday and last evening, all was serene. The General was not disturbed. As the reporters say, (with unusual propriety,) the General, after the fatigues of the past, was permitted to repose in the bosom of his family. During the morning, several gentlemen somewhat known in these several political districts called, but were not admitted. The General was busy. There were others more fortunate, among them Lieut.-Col. SWEETZER, U.S.A., and Senator LATHAM of California. In the afternoon Gen. MCCLELLAN returned the visit of Gen. SCOTT, both occupying rooms in the same hotel. During the evening there were few visitors and no unusual gathering in the halls. The night was rainy, and the people seemed to know that the General required repose. At the time our reporter left, the General's acceptance or domination of the hospitality of the City, tendered by vote by the Common Council Committee on National Affairs, had not been definitely determined on. It is understood, however, that the General will be at the Academy of Music to night, to witness a performance prepared for the occasion.

abstract: GENERAL CITY NEWS.  THE SECRETARYSHIP OF THE FIRE DEPARTMENT.--By the resignation of President WICKDAM, of the Fire Department, and the consequent promotion of the other officers, the Secretaryship becomes vacant. For this position there are two candidates-- ...
lead_paragraph: GENERAL CITY NEWS. THE SECRETARYSHIP OF THE FIRE DEPARTMENT.--By the resignation of President WICKDAM, of the Fire Department, and the consequent promotion of the other officers, the Secretaryship becomes vacant. For this position there are two candidates -- The trial of the negro, SHADRACH REID, for killing JOHN DONNELLY by stabbing him with a knife, on the 5th of October last, was concluded yesterday. One witness for the prosecution testified that he saw the prisoner stab the deceased, and another witness swore that prisoner said immediately after the occurrence that he stabbed one of the men in the affray. On the other hand, the defence proved that the prisoner had always borne an unexceptionable character, was an industrious man, and never was in the habit of carrying a knife. CHARLES S. SPENCER summed up the case for the defence, and argued that there was not sufficient proof of identity to convict the prisoner. CHARLES E. WHITEHEAD, Esq., closed the argument for the prosecution, and the Judge charged the jury, who, after being absent an hour returned with a verdict of manslaughter in the third degree. The prisoner was remanded for sentence to-day.

abstract: The inquest in the case of Miss CLEMENTINA ANDERSON, of Bleecker-street, was continued yesterday by Coroner BANNEY, at the Ninth Precinct Station-house. No further arrests had been made at a late hour last evening.

abstract: Samuel Boardman vs. Ann Elizabeth Boardman. --This was a motion made by the defendant for leave to amend her answer by setting up adultery and condonation, and a prayer for a divorce from the plaintiff. From the defendant's moving papers it appeared that the action was brought by the plaintiff to ...
lead_paragraph: Samuel Boardman vs. Ann Elizabeth Boardman. -- This was a motion made by the defendant for leave to amend her answer by setting up adultery and condonation, and a prayer for a divorce from the plaintiff. From the defendant's moving papers it appeared that the action was brought by the plaintiff to obtain a divorce on the ground of adultery, and that upon the service of a summons upon the dependant, she retained Richard Busteed, Esq., as her counsel, instructing him to set up in the answer adultery on the part of the plaintiff with a servant girl in the family, and also condonation. These allegations wore not pleaded in the answer, which set up only a general denial. Subsequently, Mr. Busteed retired from the case, and another attorney was substituted. This motion was then made, supported by the defendant's affidavit and the affidavit of two other persons, to the allegations set out.

abstract: The Fifty-second Massachusetts Regiment arrived at the Park Barracks yesterday morning, having reached this City in the steamer Etin City from New-Haven. The regiment numbers about 1,000 men, who are uniformed, armed and equipped. The men were provided with breakfast at the barracks, but, owing to the One Hundred and Sixty-first New-York Regiment being quartered there, they were obliged to remain in the area on the east side of the barracks,out in the pelting rain.

abstract: To-day is the festival of the patron Saint of Music, St. Cecilia. This Saint was a Roman lady, who lived and suffered martyrdom in the early part of the third century. So skillful was she in singing, ...
lead_paragraph: To-day is the festival of the patron Saint of Music, St. Cecilia. This Saint was a Roman lady, who lived and suffered martyrdom in the early part of the third century. So skillful was she in singing, that she has for centuries been regarded as the Patron Saint of Music, and several churches were built in her honor in Rome. St. Cecilia was a favorite subject with the old painters, and inspired RAPHAEL with one of his divinest conceptions -- the celebrated picture of the Saint in the gallery at Bologna.

abstract: A general movement of National troops is going on in the West, which portends anything but prosperity to the rebel cause. The Army of the Frontier, which was sent by Maj.-Gen. CURTIS to Southwest Missouri, to repel the threatened invasion of HINDMAN, PIKE  Co., after chasing the rebels from Maysville and Pea Ridge, in Northwest Arkansas, into and ...
lead_paragraph: A general movement of National troops is going on in the West, which portends anything but prosperity to the rebel cause. The Army of the Frontier, which was sent by Maj.-Gen. CURTIS to Southwest Missouri, to repel the threatened invasion of HINDMAN, PIKE Co., after chasing the rebels from Maysville and Pea Ridge, in Northwest Arkansas, into and beyond the Boston Mountains, commenced a retrograde movement on Springfield, Mo. The reason assigned at the time was the difficulty of procuring forage in Arkansas. But this was not entirely correct, it turns out. Gen. SCHOFIELD brought his army back to Springfield, but it has not rested there. Springfield having been strongly fortified the past Summer, a garrison only is left to hold it, and the Army of the Frontier has continued its retrograde movement to Rolla. This post gained, we may rely on it a quick transit by railroad will land the troops in St. Louis. And thence the movement will be down the Mississippi River. The Army of the Frontier exists now only in history. The troops that compose it will join, it appears, the army with which, by land or water, Gen. MCCLERNAND intends to move down from Cairo to New-Orleans. Some days since the Government chartered about twenty of the largest passenger steamers of St. Louis, and dispatched them to the towns of St. Genevieve, Cape Girardeau, and others on the river below. Upon these boats have embarked thousands of soldiers, veterans in the field, who are destined to share in the same grand movement down the Mississippi.

abstract: of the movements of the army with which Gen. BRAGG invaded Kentucky, since it crossed the mountains and entered East Tennessee a month ago. A Western correspondent, however, now states that a large part of this force has moved in a southwesterly direction, and ...
lead_paragraph: of the movements of the army with which Gen. BRAGG invaded Kentucky, since it crossed the mountains and entered East Tennessee a month ago. A Western correspondent, however, now states that a large part of this force has moved in a southwesterly direction, and that it reached Murfreesboro, below Nashville, on the 11th inst.; and among our news from the South this morning will be found an item to the effect that BRAGG himself, with 15,000 men, had reached Holly Springs, in Mississippi. It was given out from the West that Gen. GRANT held the last-mentioned place; but we fear it was only his advance which had reached it. We can hardly credit, however, that BRAGG had made the march from Murfreesboro to Holly Springs in the short space of time indicated -- considering the circuitous route he would have to take, and the difficult country he had to traverse. If it is his design to go there, it indicates that the final contest in the Southwest is to be on the eastern verge of the Mississippi. Such a movement on BRAGG's part would furnish a splendid opportunity for the army of Gen. ROSECRANS, now near Nashville, to march into East Tennessee.

abstract: Our advices from the Army of the Potomac are to the effect that the rebels still occupy Fredericksburgh, no effort having yet been made to dislodge them--for the reason, probably, that Gen. BURNSIDE is not yet ready for an advance, and does not care to cross the Rappahannock until ...
lead_paragraph: Our advices from the Army of the Potomac are to the effect that the rebels still occupy Fredericksburgh, no effort having yet been made to dislodge them -- for the reason, probably, that Gen. BURNSIDE is not yet ready for an advance, and does not care to cross the Rappahannock until everything is in proper order for an immediate advance to the vicinity of the rebel capital. From the movements of National forces, land and naval, in other quarters, the Richmond rebels are apparently gathering the idea that a movement is also to be made against them from some other direction than that of Fredericksburgh. A dispatch from Raleigh, N.C, announces that all our gunboats have left Albemarle Sound for the James River, and the Richmond Enquirer augurs from this that a new danger is threatening. "The enemy," it says, "are coming upon us from Fredericksburgh, or about to be transported to the Suffolk line of advance." We leave the Enquirer to find out from which point of the compass the danger is most imminent.

abstract: The great war in the Marine Corps is over. Capt. JOHN C. CASH (not CASE, as reported in the Washington dispatch,) is the new Paymaster, and a dozen disappointed expectants are no longer in suspense. There was understood to be a great "tie" between Capts. lead_paragraph: The great war in the Marine Corps is over. Capt. JOHN C. CASH (not CASE, as reported in the Washington dispatch,) is the new Paymaster, and a dozen disappointed expectants are no longer in suspense. There was understood to be a great "tie" between Capts. LEWIS, CASH and Lieut. FORNEY. The latter was the junior, in rank, of the others, but the political influence of his father, the editor of the Philadelphia Press, was supposed to be able to overcome serious obstacles. It failed, in this instance, however. Capt. LEWIS, like the successful candidate, like all the candidates, is a Pennsylvanian. An officer, who came here from Port Royal to look for the place, has gone back again. Capt. CASE has been 17 years in the navy. He got a brevet Captaincy in 1847, and a full one some years since. He has been nearly eight years at sea -- his last service being on the Sabine frigate. The late Major RUSSELL'S duties have, since his death, been attended to in the Pay Department.

abstract: The removal of Gen. McCLELLAN from the command of the Army of the Potomac seems to have aroused a bitterness of feeling in some quarters, quite beyond what would naturally have been expected. That some should be displeased with that removal was quite natural.
lead_paragraph: The removal of Gen. McCLELLAN from the command of the Army of the Potomac seems to have aroused a bitterness of feeling in some quarters, quite beyond what would naturally have been expected. That some should be displeased with that removal was quite natural. There were many men among us who believed sincerely in Gen. MCCLELLAN, who were heartily in favor of the most vigorous prosecution of the war until the rebellion was suppressed. But it is not this class who have shown this extreme bitterness. That has rather made its appearance among those whose loyalty has been doubtful, who are suspected of a desire for peace at any price, about whom there is and has been a taint, -- a suspicion. The mouths of such men, the columns of such papers, have been full of bitterness on the subject of this removal. If they had been soldiers under Gen. MCCLELLAN, their warmth of feeling might have been accounted for by the attachment of a soldier to his chief, but there has not been any great readiness on the part of these men to take an active part in the war. Their activity has taken the direction of politics instead of soldiering; they have been earnest in endeavors to embarrass the Administration rather than to fight the rebels, to keep out of power those who favored the heartiest prosecution of the war, and to prevent measures which should attack the rebellion in its vital part.

abstract: -- The corner-stone of the new meeting-house of the First Baptist Church at Greenpoint, L.I., has been laid with interesting services, in which the Pastor, Rev. W. REID, and Drs. WESTON and ANDERSON participated. This Church was organized in 1847. The first edifice, 22 by 40 feet, was erected in 1850, at a cost of about $1,000, the church being constituted with ten members. The present members number 132. The new house is 70 by 45 feet, of brick, and will cost about $12,000 with the lots, 70 by 45 feet. Toward this expense $7,000 have already been secured.

abstract: MASON JONES lectured at Irving Hall last evening, to a house full, on "JOHN MILTON." Portentious policemen parading the passage ways possibly preserved public propriety.
lead_paragraph: MASON JONES lectured at Irving Hall last evening, to a house full, on "JOHN MILTON." Portentious policemen parading the passage ways possibly preserved public propriety. At any rate, the lecturer was undisturbed, except by welcome plaudits. He commenced by taking the trouble to contradict certain allegations of a notorious daily journal relative to the disturbance at the last lecture, denying that he was the employe of any party, and stating that he came to this country simply to deliver his lectures, with a few thousand collars in his pockets and a few ideas in his head. He hated tyranny and loved freedom, and part of his intention in visiting this country was to write a book, and place the cause of the North correctly before the British public. He had no design to interfere in our local politics, and professed a profound ignorance of the distinction between Hard Shells and Soft Shells, and doughfaces, while to him the definition of a "butternut" was an inexpressible mystery. He dealt with principles as his topics suggested, and would, when occasion offered, enforce the lessons of history. He announced that his previous lecture would be repeated on Tuesday evening next at the Academy of Music.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Mme. LORINI'S success, last evening, in "Lucrezia Borgia," exceeded the best expectations of her friends, and surpassed, in musical interest, the promise of her debut. In the  difficult and dramatic music of the first act she sang so well, and delivered her voice with such a fine, artistic sense of its capacity, that its inadequacy for so ...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Mme. LORINI's success, last evening, in "Lucrezia Borgia," exceeded the best expectations of her friends, and surpassed, in musical interest, the promise of her debut. In the difficult and dramatic music of the first act she sang so well, and delivered her voice with such a fine, artistic sense of its capacity, that its inadequacy for so large a building ceased to be noticed, whilst its beautiful, fresh quality was as remarkable as the skill and taste of her method and phrasing. It is now evident that in Mme. LORINI we have an artist who is destined to grow upon the audience; one who leaves in each performance something pleasant to be expected in the next. In the majority of instances, our prime [???] play their best cards on the opening night, and lose ever afterwards.

lead_paragraph: Since the Exemption Commissioners concluded their labors, the enrollment has been corrected so that the names of all those who, under the examination of the surgeons, have proved themselves physically incapable of doing active military duty, have been stricken from the list. The officers under whose immediate directions the Draft will be made, are perfectly ready to proceed with its enforcement, and are only awaiting orders from Albany to do so. The wheels in which the names will be placed are in good working condition, and a gentleman has been selected to draw the names from them.

abstract: THE COUNTY CORONERSHIP.--The case of JOHN S. RYDER against REM R. HEGEMAN, was decided in the Brooklyn City Court yesterday, by Judge REYNOLDS, in favor of the plaintiff. Both parties were candidates for Coroner at the General Election in 1861. Mr. RYDER Obtained a majority of votes through-out ...
lead_paragraph: THE COUNTY CORONERSHIP. -- The case of JOHN S. RYDER against REM R. HEGEMAN, was decided in the Brooklyn City Court yesterday, by Judge REYNOLDS, in favor of the plaintiff. Both parties were candidates for Coroner at the General Election in 1861. Mr. RYDER Obtained a majority of votes through-out the County at large; but Mr. HEGEMAN received a majority in the District -- (the Third) -- a law having been passed by the Legislature the preceding sessions, providing that the County should be divided into four districts, and that a Coroner should be elected for each. Coroner HEGEMAN having been declared elected under the District law, commenced performing his duties within the country district, but finding that it did not pay, opened an office in the city and secured a large share of the business of the City Coroner, Mr. ALFRED HORTON. The latter brought an action against HEGEMAN in the Supreme Court, and it was there decided that the district law was unconstitutional and that any Coroner elected in the county had jurisdiction anywhere within its limits. In the present case it was contended on the part of the plaintiff that the District law having been declared unconstitutional, and RYDER having received a majority of the votes throughout the whole county, was entitled to the office. The Judge took a similar view and decided in favor of the plaintiff. Mr. RYDER will, therefore, be entitled to the office for the remainder of the term, ending Jan. 1, 1864.

abstract: The delegates to the City Convention met Thursday evening at the Republican headquarters, corner. Twenty-third-street and Broadway, to nominate a candidate for Corporation Counsel. E. DELAFIELD SMITH, Esq., President, occupied the Chair.
lead_paragraph: The delegates to the City Convention met Thursday evening at the Republican headquarters, corner. Twenty-third-street and Broadway, to nominate a candidate for Corporation Counsel. E. DELAFIELD SMITH, Esq., President, occupied the Chair. The roll of delegates having been called, Mr. ABRAM WAKEMAN presented a resolution, to the effect that a Committee of nine be appointed for the purpose of conferring with other political organizations in relation to the nomination of a candidate for Corporation Counsel, said Committee to report to the Convention on Tuesday evening next.

abstract: has elapsed since the transfer of the command of the Army of the Potomac, so far as we have seen, not a single journal of any political party, or any school of military criticism, in the whole country, has expressed any dissatisfaction with the appointment of Gen. BURNSIDE ...
lead_paragraph: has elapsed since the transfer of the command of the Army of the Potomac, so far as we have seen, not a single journal of any political party, or any school of military criticism, in the whole country, has expressed any dissatisfaction with the appointment of Gen. BURNSIDE or indulged in any unjust assaults upon him or his military movements. He is sustained with the highest degree of unanimity by both the Press and the people everywhere. With the soldiers -- with those bodies of them which he had previously commanded, he was always a favorite; and since he obtained his present position, his popularity and the confidence of the troops in his military skill and courage have grown till it pervades the entire army. No General ever had a firmer hold of his men; few armies ever had greater devotion to their leader. Not one of the evil results which it was predicted would ensue upon a change of command, has shown itself; and if they have not appeared by this time, they will never appear.

abstract: -- The number of vessels which have landed cargoes at the Brooklyn wharves during the month of October was 144, of which 53 were loaded with sugar and molasses, 7 with hides and tallow, 39 in ballast, 20 with salt, 7 with logwood, 3 with coal, 3 with naval stores, 1 with iron, 1 with Government stores, 2 with tar, 1 with coffee, 1 with India-rubber, 1 with rags, 2 with brimstone and 1 with fruit. In August there were 176 arrivals and in September 194, making a total of 514 arrives in three months, being an increase of ninety over the corresponding period in 1861.

abstract: Right Rev. Bishop POTTER, assisted by several clergymen, officiated in a special ordination ser  vice, yesterday afternoon, in the Church of the Incarnation, in which a candidate for the office of Deacon was received, and a Deacon advanced to the  Priesthood.
lead_paragraph: Right Rev. Bishop POTTER, assisted by several clergymen, officiated in a special ordination ser vice, yesterday afternoon, in the Church of the Incarnation, in which a candidate for the office of Deacon was received, and a Deacon advanced to the Priesthood. The services occupied over two hours, and were imbued with a solemnity and interest, which all present appeared to feel. In the chancel with the Bishop were the Rev. Dr. JOHNSON, of the General Theological Seminary; Rev. Mr. GALLAUDET, of St. Ann's; Rev. N.B. SMITH, of New-Jersey, and Rev. Mr. MONTGOMERY, Rector of the Church of he incarnation. Mr. ELLIOTT D. TOMPKINS was the candidate for the Diaconate, and EASTERN BENJAMIN for the Priesthood. The former gentleman will act as assistant to Rev. Mr. MONTGOMERY, and the latter is now settled at St. Mary's Church, Mott Haven. The ordination was preceded by Morning Prayer, which was rendered alternately by Rev. Messrs. SMITH andGALLAUDET.

abstract: Intelligence from Ozauke, Wis., to Sunday at noon represents everything as quiet in that excitable region. The draft in three or four towns was completed on Saturday, and in the remainder would proceed on Monday. The Provost-Marshal was still making arrests of persons who participated in the riots, and troops were scouring the country for fifteen miles around. So great was the fright that not an able-bodied man was visible within ten miles of the place -- the few loyal men excepted.

abstract: THE SANITARY COMMISSION.--Dr. BELLOWS has been invited to deliver an address at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, on Monday evening next, to inform the public of Brooklyn of the organization of the Sanitary Committee and of the facilities which have been granted to it by the cooperation of the Government, and of the immense amount of relief it has been ennabled to dispense. The lecture will be free.
lead_paragraph: THE SANITARY COMMISSION. -- Dr. BELLOWS has been invited to deliver an address at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, on Monday evening next, to inform the public of Brooklyn of the organization of the Sanitary Committee and of the facilities which have been granted to it by the cooperation of the Government, and of the immense amount of relief it has been ennabled to dispense. The lecture will be free. Those who have paid but little attention to the subject, will be led to realize its magnitude and importance, when informed that there are at present 130,000 sick and wounded in our hopitals, and that by the 1st of January it is estimated that the number may be increased to 200,000.

abstract: The statistical list of the exchange of prisoners effected at Aiken's Landing, James River, by Col. LUDLOW, Chief of Major-Gen. DIX's Staff, which we published a few days since, in its simple array of figures, hardly conveyed to the reader a proper conception of the importance and intricate nature of the arrangements which have been so successfully accomplished through the energy and labors of Col. LUDLOW.
lead_paragraph: The statistical list of the exchange of prisoners effected at Aiken's Landing, James River, by Col. LUDLOW, Chief of Major-Gen. DIX's Staff, which we published a few days since, in its simple array of figures, hardly conveyed to the reader a proper conception of the importance and intricate nature of the arrangements which have been so successfully accomplished through the energy and labors of Col. LUDLOW. The whole number of exchanges consummated includes nine hundred and twenty-six United States officers against one thousand five hundred and ninety-six rebel officers, and about twenty-four thousand privates, leaving a balance in favor of the United Slates of about six thousand privates. These exchange include all officers and men of both sides captured and paroled in either Maryland or Virginia up to Nov. 1, except our officers and men captured and paroled at Harper's Ferry. Against these latter we hold the excess of six thousand privates already delivered to the rebel authorities, will about ooverall those captured at Harper's Ferry, whom it is either necessary or desirable to exchange.

abstract: On last Saturday morning an expedition under command of Gen. abstract: Editorial on London Times reporting of war; Editorial on pauperism in Great Britain caused by lack of cotton in manufacturing districts; editorial lauds order
snippet: Editorial on London Times reporting of war; Editorial on pauperism in Great Britain caused by lack of cotton in manufacturing districts; editorial lauds order
lead_paragraph: Every mail we now receive from England is full of painful details in regard to the sufferings in the cotton manufacturing districts. It is the prominent topic in the English newspapers, and the first thought in the minds of English statesmen and humanitarians. The London Press dispatch special reporters to Lancashire to visit the factory towns, to take note of the idle mills, to describe the sad and hungry multitudes, to paint fully the present distress and expose the magnitude of the coming peril. For the time, this gigantic social disorder has overshadowed the American war, and the English public are more concerned now to save their own paupers from starvation than they were lately to preserve JEFFERSON DAVIS and his Confederate rebels from subjugation. They are learning a lesson of humiliation and propriety -- how to cure their own ills and quit intermeddling with others.

abstract: In several communications respecting the surrender of Harper's Ferry, the One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Regiment of New-York Volunteers has been stiginatized as having acted in a shameful manner. abstract: We have seen Mr. E.C. MIDDLETON's remarkable copies of STUART's celebrated portraits of GEORGE and MARTHA WASHINGTON, and cheerfully add our praise and commendation to that of very many journalists, artists and connoissieurs, as to their fidelity, beauty and incomparable life-likenesses. The pictures are photographs from the original paintings, retouched in oil. The process by which they are produced is as yet a secret, but there is and need be none as to the result. In these days of perfidy and treason, we regard that artist an honor to his country who, by the application of his art, can put within the power of every citizen a perpetual reminder of implied vow, and a never-failing suggestion of patriotism, such as is afforded in these admirable reproductions of the Father of our Country and his no less noble wife.

abstract: -- The President has shown wisdom and sound policy in his recent general order respecting the Sabbath in the Army and Navy. Besides its bearings on the health, morals and discipline of our soldiers and sailors, nothing could have been more comforting and assuring to the millions of households connected by the nearest ties to our brave defenders, and to the friends of morals and religion throughout, the country, than this manly. Christian proclamation, as to the rights and duties of Americans in arms. The National Intelligencer, of the 19th, reflects the opinion of the Press and the country when it says: "We doubt not that this general order will be hailed with pleasure by every Christian and patriot in the land, and will form an interesting item in the history of this remarkable epoch."
lead_paragraph: -- The President has shown wisdom and sound policy in his recent general order respecting the Sabbath in the Army and Navy. abstract: The news from the Army of the Potomac, this morning, is important and exciting. It indicates that the passage of the Rappahannock at Fredericksburgh is to be disputed by the rebels to the last--perhaps that a battle will he fought there which will have a commanding influence on the progress of the war.
lead_paragraph: The news from the Army of the Potomac, this morning, is important and exciting. It indicates that the passage of the Rappahannock at Fredericksburgh is to be disputed by the rebels to the last -- perhaps that a battle will he fought there which will have a commanding influence on the progress of the war. We yesterday published Gen. SUMNER's demand for the surrender of the city. To-day we have the reply of the Mayor, evidently written at the dictation of the rebel military authorities. It gives assurances, as from the rebel commander, that certain matters complained of shall cease; refuses to deliver the city into the hands of Gen. BURNSIDE, and closes with a complaint as to the shortness of the time given in which to remove non-combatants. Friday night, however, was busily occupied in the work of removing them, and daylight revealed the fact that it had also been busily occupied in another kind of work. A line of earthworks had been constructed to the right and rear of the town, and rebel cannon were already in position. Our artillery was immediately placed in the most favorable positions, and the encampments in range of the enemy's guns were moved further back. There were good reasons for not opening upon the city yesterday, unless the enemy should force it, and up to noon he had not done so, although the rebels had fired a few shots, as though to provoke it.

abstract: The inquest in the case of Miss CLEMENTINA ANDERSON was concluded at a late hour last evening. The jury found a verdict to the effect that deceased came to her death by inflammation produced by abortion, at the hands of Dr. BROWNE, and that SIMMS was an accessory before and after the fact. BROWNE was thereupon committed to prison, to await the action of the Grand Jury.  SIMMS has not yet been arrested.

abstract: The Commercial Advertiser of the 20th inst., assumes that France "will be able to go just as far as she may elect to go in her present purpose toward Mexico," and upon this assumption remarks: "We presume that we have no good ground for interfering in any mode or degree. Every nation has an inherent, indisputable right to compel, if it can, other Powers to fulfill contracts into which they have entered with it.
lead_paragraph: The Commercial Advertiser of the 20th inst., assumes that France "will be able to go just as far as she may elect to go in her present purpose toward Mexico," and upon this assumption remarks: "We presume that we have no good ground for interfering in any mode or degree. Every nation has an inherent, indisputable right to compel, if it can, other Powers to fulfill contracts into which they have entered with it. We presume, also, that Mexico, as a sovereignty, can enter into any arrangement with France that she may deem to be to, her interest, by a cession of territory as well as by mortgaging her revenues."

abstract: The forts in Nashville are the most complete of the kind in the country. "Fort Negley," situated on St. Cloud Hill, is the masterpiece, and was constructed almost entirely by negroes, under the engineership of Capt. MORTON, a Philadelphian. The work covers nearly twelve acres of ground, and communication is carried on by means of subterranean passages from one portion of the fort to another.

abstract: GENERAL ORDER No. 8. -- I. The laws of the Confederate States require that no person over eighteen years, or under thirty-five years of age, shall be enlisted in the "Partisan Rangers," and no soldier of the old regiments, who has not been discharged, can serve in such corps. It is therefore ordered that all persons coming within either of the above classes, be discharged from the Partisan Corps, and either rejoin their regiments or be enrolled as volunteers or conscripts, and officers who have such persons in their corps are required to enforce this order.
lead_paragraph: GENERAL ORDER No. 8. -- I. abstract: In the Prize Court, yesterday, Judge CADWALADER set aside the sale of the cotton brought to this port in the prize schooner Caroline Virginia. The sale took place in September, when there was a material difference in the price of cotton from that now obtained. The cargo had been wet, and was sold as damaged, yet part of it was appraised at 25 cents the pound, and the remainder at 30 cents. One of the grounds for setting aside the sale was that the cotton was sold below its appraised value, but this was not the principal ground which induced the action of the Court. It appeared that the bidder to whom it was knocked down at 24 cents the pound, took but half of the lot, and ordered the other half to be put down to another person, who was present but who did not bid. This, it was afterwards ascertained, was the result of a conversation before the safe commenced. The buyer asked the other if he intended to [???] the cotton. He replied that he did not. "Will you take half of it," asked the other. "If I buy? If id does not go above twenty-four or twenty-five cents the pound, I would not mind taking half of it." "I would not mind it," was the reply. While the Court did not think there was anything wrong in such an arrangement, it was of the [???] that it was [???] of itself, to justify [???] of the sale aside. By the arrangement the person who was to take part of the cargo if it did not go above a certain price was prevented [???] a bidder at all, and the [???] to whom it was knocked down might have been prevented [???] the price her pound specified, because the one who was to take the half of it was not willing to do so above the [???] open, Philadelphia [???].

abstract: It is difficult to arrive at the truth with reference to the report of the existence of a body of Yankees in Highland County. Yesterday we stated, upon what was deemed good authority, that there had been a Yankee raid upon Monterey. and last evenings a gentleman direct from Staunton assured us that no such raid had ever taken place. How these unfounded reports originate we are unable to state; but it is now a question for others to solve, "Are the Yankees in Highland or not?"
lead_paragraph: It is difficult to arrive at the truth with reference to the report of the existence of a body of Yankees in Highland County. Yesterday we stated, upon what was deemed good authority, that there had been a Yankee raid upon Monterey. and last evenings a gentleman direct from Staunton assured us that no such raid had ever taken place. How these unfounded reports originate we are unable to state; but it is now a question for others to solve, "Are the Yankees in Highland or not?"

abstract: In another month we shall probably be purusing a a second chapter in the history of the Mexican Expedition. It would not be very diflicult to forecast the ccontents of the narrative. The present state of affairs reminds us of Sir WILLIAM NAPIER'S introduction to one of the episodes of the Peninsular War, ...
lead_paragraph: In another month we shall probably be purusing a a second chapter in the history of the Mexican Expedition. It would not be very diflicult to forecast the ccontents of the narrative. The present state of affairs reminds us of Sir WILLIAM NAPIER'S introduction to one of the episodes of the Peninsular War, when "BLAKE, pursued by 50,000 enemies, was flying from Nava to Epinosa: CASTANOS and PALAFOX were quarreling at Tudela; the Conde DE BELVEDERE was at Burgos with 13,000 bad troops, and NAPOLEON was at Vittoria with 170,000 good troops." The Mexicans, according to the must recent accounts, were ostensibly preparing for a desperate resistance against the French columns which were marching on the Capital. To oppose these 20,000 excellent soldiers, they had raised by arbitrary conscription about 10,000 recruits, already demoralized. To defray the charges of the war, they had proposed a new loan, the scrip of which was qouted at [???] discount on the Mexican Exchange, it needs little power of divination to [???] the result of a contest on conditions like these, but when the French are actually in possession of Mexico a third chapter of the story will be opened, and the tenor of that chapter it would be very hard to predict. The problem involves nothing less than the settlement of Mexico -- a country in which an attempt at self-government has resulted. after in exhaustive trial, in an anarchy so brutal and hopeless as to be noxious to the world. Three European Power combined a short time ago to terminate a state of affairs from which their subjects had long been suffering, and the flags of England, France and Spam were seem flying together in Mexican waters. From this alliance England and Spain ultimately withdrew, and left France alone with a has was them thought the privilege, but what [???] moved to be the burden of the projected enterprise. We have explained on former occasions the circumstances under which this separation occurred. The alleged object of the expedition wasthe [???] of grievances. The combined Powers desired to obtain satisfaction for a multitude of wrongs, and this satisfaction the Mexican authorities were eager enough to offer. But, unless the whole proceeding was to be a farce, it was a necessary sequel of the original demand that some assurance should beforthcoming for the fulfillment of the promises so liberally made. If nothing more had been required than an understanding from the Mexican rulers for the time [???] to liquidate their just debts and refrain from outrages for the future, that a [???] of "[???]" could unquestionably have been obtained without any [???] at all. A single in theharbor at Vera Cruz might have been intrusted with the mission. The real purpose of the in their more serious proceeding was to terminate once for all the state of things which had [???] such [???] and though the convention under which they acted recorded their disinclination to [???] of the [???] affairs of Mexico, it is very difficult to see how the end of the expedition couldhave been accomplished if the Government of the country had been left to stand as it stood. The French however, stood alone in the logical conclusions of [???] point. They proposed, as an indispensable condition of peace, that the existing Government should abdicate, and when the suggestion was declined, resolved to enforce the demand. Upon this the British and the Spaniards retired -- the former from genuine reluctance to enter upon the undertaking before them the latter, it may be surmised, from an unwillingness to see themselves superseded by the French in the work of political reconstruction. An this way was the Emperor NAPOLEON left [???] with an obligation which her proved more [???] than was anticipated. Relying on the representations of a refugee, the French advanced upon the Capital with a force which would have been efficient to gave the ascendancy to an influential party in the State, but which was [???] overcome a condition of all the factions together It was supposed that the Emperor's policy [???] to the establishment of a monarchy under a foreign France, and as this, event presumed the extinction of all existing pretensions is united in opposition all classes of pretenders. The French were stopped on their [???] it is but recently that reinforcements [???] are [???] them to resume it. But what is to be [???] mere military miscalculations have [???] corrected? The Emperor has already [???] desire of forcing an unpopular Government on the Mexican people, but if the ruling factions merit no recognition, by what administration [???] is their rule to be superseded? We cannot impeach the force of the argument by which the French justified their advance upon Mexico. We believe that if the Allies, had occupied the promises of JUAREZ. in satisfaction of their demands, and then withdrawn their forces from Mexican territory, the state of affairs would have been just as bad in twelve months time as it was when the expedition was organized. [???], in this country there would always be a predisposition to strengthen the Liberal Party, and if that party in Mexico had established any pretensions to its title, we should have regretted to see its proposals set aside. No such claims, however, had been made out. On the contrary, we are convinced that any impartial observer of Mexican politics for the last ten years would admit that the factions which disputed the possession of power were alike destitute of all [???] to either confidence or support. We have seen it stated that there really was a change impending at the moment of the expedition, and that, but for the invasion of this country, JUAREZ would actually have taken measures, if not for the payment of debts, at any rate for the security of life and property. To this prediction we can only reply that it might possibly [???] have happened, but that the very same men had persisted in the very same courses for so long a time, and without the least symptom of repentance, that the miracle could be waited for no longer. As far as a very long experience enabled us to judge, there was not a pin to choose between "Constitutionalists" and "Absolutists," or, indeed, any reason for presuming that such designations implicit any principles at all. It follows necessarily, according to these views, that [???] the Government of Mexican has been in some manner reorganized, no arrangements for a settlement of the long-pending questions are likely to be successful. We have been [???] that in these speculations we are putting out of sight the rignts, interest:, and wishing of the Mexican people. We reply, than if we could discover a Mexican people anywhere, we should ask for nothing better than to leave it [???] of it own [???]. But throughout these long years of revolution and anarchy we have looked [???] for the appearance of any such phenomenon. We suppose there must be Mexicans who admire [???] JUAREZ nor MIRAMON, but we have never been able to discern the least expression of any [???] opinion as distinguishable from the cries of the contending factions. As each faction robs and [???] and, indeed, does little else, it is reasonable to presume that both factions have then enemies, and that even in Mexican there are men who desire to lead a quiet life. Our correspondent declares his conviction that there [???] such a party, though [???] that it has hitherto been invisible, and conceives thatit would make its appearance if the two old factions which have rent the State were kept down by arbitrary power. If this be, in deed, the case, the task of the French may be materially facilitated; but we must say that we have hitherto looked for such a public opinion in Mexico without the slightest success, and we certainly cannot [???] it directly or indirectly with either of the ruling parties. On this point we trust that our neighbors, if they are under any misapprehension, will promptly undeceive themselves. Our correspondent intimates that we are supposed to favor one party, while the French incline to the other. That we favor a principle is true, but not that we wish to commit ourselves to a faction. We are always ready as a people to advocate constitutional government, and, whenever the Mexican question is debated, that leaning will be perceptible. But we are not ready to defend the "constitutionalism" of JUAREZ and his friends, or to pronounce dogmatically on the policy for which Mexican affairs may call. In point of fact, by leaving the French with the work of the expedition, we have left them also with the privilege of shaping its results. We cannot pretend to much further voice in a transaction from which we have withdrawn, but though we certainly hope that the future Government of Mexico may repose on better foundations than those of absolutism and priestcraft, we have not the least desire to take up the cudgels for the worthless faction by which those principles have been ostensibly opposed.

abstract: -- We are pained to see that the London Times has been again exposing itself to disappointment. The amount of hope deferred, of confident expectation never realized, and of prophecy never to be verified, which that journal has been afflicted with since the rebellion broke out, are beyond estimation, and yet, like the Bourbons, it learns nothing by experience. The Union men still refuse to give up the existence of the nation; the "mob" quietly acquiesce in the determinations of the constituted authorities; the "financial bubble" obstinately refuses to burst; and the danger which the Times obviously fears more than any ether result of the war, viz.: the suppression of the rebellion, is still gathering on its horizon. These Yankees obstinately decline to guage their conduct by what the English organ lays down to be established laws, and it has been so often astounded by a result which was in its opini onsimply impossible, that it would be only reasonable to think it would give up expecting anything. But the ruin of the Union lies too near its heart to allow it to do so. And we find that it has fallen again into the same old ditch.

abstract: We would respectfully inform the Edinburgh Scotsman that the greater part of the people of New-Orleans are as yet unhang; Gen. BUTLER, for some reason or other, it may be for the lack of rope, has in fact only hung three men during the three-quarters of a year in which he has ruled that great city, and two of these were his own soldiers, who had been guilty of plundering. It is a mistake in our Caldonian cotemporary to suppose that the solitary rebel who has graced or disgraced the gallows in New-Orleans has materially diminished the population of a city of not less than 140,000 inhabitants.

abstract: Editorial says supreme issue of war is preservation of US as a whole
snippet: Editorial says supreme issue of war is preservation of US as a whole
lead_paragraph: The men who are fondest of the phrase -the Union as it was and the Constitution as it is, -- who have been the quickest to bandy it as a catchword -- are the very men who are least inclined to stand by its just significance. They are the people who turn the readiest ear to all suggestions for satisfying the rebels by a Convention to amend this Constitution -the people who are most averse to the spirit and policies which governed the Union in its happiest days. There is not one of them who, if closely questioned on these points, will not betray his leanings. Ask them if they are willing to compromise with the South by giving Slavery new Constitutional, guaranties, and you will get no answer in the negative. Put it to them whether they wish to see the Union permanently restored, as it existed for the last year before the war and very few of them will have the boldness to tell you, yes. You will very quickly discover that the phrase, as they use it, conveys no definite meaning, and is only just so much political cant.

abstract: During the past week, Capt. JAMES E. MCGEE, Sixty-ninth Regiment New-York Volunteers, (Irish Brigade) arrived in this City with the war-worn flags of this gallant command, which are about being replaced by new ones now being manufactured at TIFFANY's. The latter flags, which in design and finish are beautiful, will be taken on to Gen. MEAGHER next Wednesday, by his own Aid-de-Camp, Lieut. R.R. EMMET, and Capt. MCGEE. Capt. LEDDY also is about returning to the field, and intends taking with him a large detachment of convalescent soldiers and recruits. To this end, he has issued orders that all such shall report to him at No. 596 Broadway, on Monday, at 10 o'clock A.M., and hold themselves in readiness for transportation with him to Virginia, on that evening.

abstract: Various complaints having been made of horses being taken or exchanged by persons professing to belong to my command, I beg to state that in every such instance it has not only been done without authority but in violation of the most positive orders. Even in the enemy's country no soldier is allowed to press or exchange a horse, without first getting the ...
lead_paragraph: Various complaints having been made of horses being taken or exchanged by persons professing to belong to my command, I beg to state that in every such instance it has not only been done without authority but in violation of the most positive orders. Even in the enemy's country no soldier is allowed to press or exchange a horse, without first getting the written consent of his Captain, who is required to examine into the necessity for it, and this permission to be countersigned by the Colonel of the regiment, and approved by myself or my Adjutant-General. Immediately on arriving in a loyal country, the most positive orders were issued that under no circumstances would even an exchange be allowed except in the presence of a commissioned officer, and with the consent of the opposite party. All persons who have been sufferers are invited to call on me at my headquarters and reclaim their property, and assist in bringing to justice those men in the garb of soldiers who are a disgrace to any service.

abstract: The past week, although an inclement one as regards the weather, was not very disastrous to the theatres--except perhaps those two or three establishments where dress is as much an object as any other kind of pleasure. Indeed the general prosperity of all places of amusement seems to be so marked ...
lead_paragraph: The past week, although an inclement one as regards the weather, was not very disastrous to the theatres -- except perhaps those two or three establishments where dress is as much an object as any other kind of pleasure. Indeed the general prosperity of all places of amusement seems to be so marked this season, that nothing can well interfere with it. It follows naturally, therefore, that the various managements put forth their greatest force to receive the swelling tide. Several changes are announced for to-night. First, and of most importance, is the production of MEYERBEER's new opera of "Dinorah," at the Academy of Music. This being the first venture of Mr. J. GRAU, in the way of positive novelty, he has --as may well be imagined -- done the best to make himself remembered by the public. The costumes --which of late have been remarkably good -- are entirely new; the scenery appropriate, and prepared expressly for the opera. These circumstances, added to a new work, a distribution of parts which embraces some of the best names in the company, and the debut of Mile. CORDIER, cannot fall to attract one of the most crowded and fashionable houses of the season.

abstract: Editorial holds it unwise to concentrate forces in any 1 area at expense of weakening defenses in another
snippet: Editorial holds it unwise to concentrate forces in any 1 area at expense of weakening defenses in another
lead_paragraph: A correspondent dislikes the project of withdrawing the Military and Naval Expeditions intended to operate on the Southern coast, for the purpose of concentrating all our troops in the attack on Richmond and the main rebel army: First, says he, because these expeditions will operate as diversions against the rebels, and weaken their main army by compelling them to withdraw part of it for the defence of the points menaced; Second, Because as the rebellion originated in the Cotton States, and as Secessionism is strongest in that section, the war should be quickly carried there, and the great slaveholding rebels punished; Third, Because it is necessary to seize and hold the ports of the Southern coast, to perfect the blockade.

abstract: --A letter in the Athenaeum, dated Naples, Oct. 18, mentions some interesting discoveries at Pompeii. The writer says: "In an extreme corner of an inner room of a small and apparently poor house, have been discovered some human bones--a rare thing in Pompeii, where most of the population had time to escape. Further researches--and it was interesting ...
lead_paragraph: -- A letter in the Athenaeum, dated Naples, Oct. 18, mentions some interesting discoveries at Pompeii. The writer says: "In an extreme corner of an inner room of a small and apparently poor house, have been discovered some human bones -- a rare thing in Pompeii, where most of the population had time to escape. Further researches -- and it was interesting to observe with what extreme care and delicacy they were conducted -- revealed yet others, until the skeletons of five persons were visible -- four women and an infant, all crouched up in a corner. The sex and age of the victims, and the very form in which they were found, are suggestive of incidents and sufferings which would promise materials for an affecting tale. The arms seem to have been clasped as if all hope had been abandoned, and they had come there to die, whilst the legs were doubled up with the agony of their sufferings. The mouth of one skeleton was open, distended, and hard must have been the last expiring efforts of that poor person. The infant was in the extreme corner, where a mother's love, perhaps, had placed it, in the hope of its there finding greater protection from the storm of ashes which was raging around them, and penetrating into the most secret recesses of every building. Poor, helpless women they were too weak or too feeble to escape, and had been abandoned by husband, father, brother -- by every male friend. There were bronze armlets or bracelets round their freshless bones; and by the side of them lay what were evidently the remains of a purse, in which had been inclosed twenty silver Roman coins and two copper coins. Of course the material of the purse was imperfect, and was reduced to mere tinder; still the texture was perceptible, and this it was which contained the hurried gleanings of the unhappy party. There were considerable traces of cloth, too, in the ashes, all around the bodies or skeletons -- that is to say, on the ashes there were impressions as of cloth which had been laid over them, and then exposed to the fire. The probability appeared to be that they were the clothes of the wretched fugitives, for there were impressions as it were, of folds."

lead_paragraph: The inquest in the case of Miss CLEMENTINA ANDERSON was concluded at a late hour on Saturday. The jury found a verdict to the effect that deceased came to her death by inflammation produced by abortion, at the hands of Dr. BROWNE, and that SIMMS was an accessory before and after the fact. BROWNE was thereupon committed to prison, to await the action of the Grand Jury. SIMMS has not yet been arrested.
