abstract: Mr. WHEATLEY'S management at the Brooklyn Academy terminated on Saturday night. During the two weeks of his Brooklyn career he has been embarrassed by high rental, favored with an almost perpetual rain, and doubtless perplexed by the peculiar desires of the public.
lead_paragraph: Mr. WHEATLEY's management at the Brooklyn Academy terminated on Saturday night. During the two weeks of his Brooklyn career he has been embarrassed by high rental, favored with an almost perpetual rain, and doubtless perplexed by the peculiar desires of the public. Nevertheless he has ran the race manfully, done well his part and come out ahead. The attractions offered were Mr. FORREST in a round of characters and Miss HERON in Camille and Nancy Sykes.

abstract: It will be seen by the official order of Secretary STANTON, in another column, that the Government has directed the immediate release of all political prisoners, and of all now in confinement for having discouraged enlistments. We are very glad this order has been ...
lead_paragraph: It will be seen by the official order of Secretary STANTON, in another column, that the Government has directed the immediate release of all political prisoners, and of all now in confinement for having discouraged enlistments. We are very glad this order has been issued. It will put an end to much clamor against the Government, some of which has not been wholly without foundation. There can be no doubt that the power of arbitrary arrest, which has been asserted by the Government as a necessary precaution during this rebellion, has been exerted, in very many instances, with harshness, and in nearly all without that careful regard to the requirements of justice which should have been inseparable from its exercise.

abstract: correspondent with Gen. GRANT'S army in Mississippi writes that "the rush of contrabands to our lines resembles that of the Israelites escaping from the bondage and brickmaking of Egypt," and he sends a military order ...
lead_paragraph: correspondent with Gen. GRANT'S army in Mississippi writes that "the rush of contrabands to our lines resembles that of the Israelites escaping from the bondage and brickmaking of Egypt," and he sends a military order which Gen. GRANT has issued for their supervision and employment. The negroes are to be put into camp at Grand Junction, organized into companies, suitably cared for, and "set to work picking, ginning and baling all cotton outstanding in the fields." Gen. GRANT has taken hold of the contraband question in a practical manner. He could not send these flocks of fugitives back to their rebel masters; he could not banish them into the Free States; he could not employ them on military work; be could not maintain them in idleness. So he has adopted the only other alternative -- making them work for a living. As time passes on, and circumstances change the aspect of affairs, all this supervision of blacks must, of course, pass out of the hands of our Generals and soldiers. But, as a temporary thing, and until society in the South reconstitutes itself on the new basis which is inevitable, we do not see that any other plan is feasible.

abstract: from various indications of public sentiment, the recent sale of the Mozart Democracy by Ex-Mayor WOOD, does not meet unanimous approval. It was not supposed that Tammany was to take exclusive possession of ...
lead_paragraph: from various indications of public sentiment, the recent sale of the Mozart Democracy by Ex-Mayor WOOD, does not meet unanimous approval. It was not supposed that Tammany was to take exclusive possession of everything, when the arrangements for harmony in the State election were completed. But the Old Wigwam has done it. She has both Comptroller and Corporation Counsel -- not only with the consent, but through the active procurement of FERNANDO himself. All sorts of ugly stories are afloat as to the motives which have prompted such action on his part -- but whether true or not they do not affect the fact.

abstract: --The announcements of forthcoming works are many--an indication that the high price of paper cannot quite throttle the book trade. The most important and interesting of all these books, at present inchoate, but soon to assume form and shape, is that of Bishop COLENSO on the Pentateuch ...
lead_paragraph: --The announcements of forthcoming works are many--an indication that the high price of paper cannot quite throttle the book trade. The most important and interesting of all these books, at present inchoate, but soon to assume form and shape, is that of Bishop COLENSO on the Pentateuch and Book of Joshua -- a work which is creating a sensation in England only approached -- not paralleled -- by that produced by the "Essays and Reviews" some years since. And little wonder that something like an electric thrill should agitate the nerves of or on the insulated islanders, when a Bishop of the Church of England deliberately hints to them that he considers the Pentateuch decidedly apocryphal and the Book of Joshua a fabrication. Such a thing in the Church is quite startling, because infinitely more rare that the explosion of a shell in its own caisson.

abstract: An order comes to us from the War Department, bearing no date, directing the discharge of certain persons from arrest. First, those who have been arrested for discouraging enlistments, or opposing the draft in those States where the draft has been ...
lead_paragraph: An order comes to us from the War Department, bearing no date, directing the discharge of certain persons from arrest. First, those who have been arrested for discouraging enlistments, or opposing the draft in those States where the draft has been made, or the quota of volunteers has been furnished. Second, persons arrested by authority of the military commanders or Governors in rebel States, when such persons consent to give their parole not to do any act of hostility against the Government, nor to aid its enemies -- such persons, however, to remain subject to military surveillance, unless they choose to leave the loyal States.

On Saturday morning, the hense of Mr. J. FRY, No. 1 Classonavenue, was feloniously entered, and robbed of property ...
lead_paragraph: BURGLARIES. -- A large number of burglaries have recently been perpetrated in different parts of the city, especially on the Heights, where three adjoining houses were "cracked" the same night, and a large amount of property stolen therefrom. On Saturday morning, the hense of Mr. J. FRY, No. 1 Classonavenue, was feloniously entered, and robbed of property valued at $250. The entrance was gained by prying off one of the basement shutters. The residences of Mr. JAMES BOYCE, No. 321 Degraw-street, and WALTER BREWER, No. 20 Butter-street, were entered on Saturday night, and robbed of wearing apparel, valued at about $100. Sneak thieves are also abundant, there being hardly an evening that some halls are not robbed of overcoats, or any other articles that may be handy.

abstract: The obsequies of Capt. ALFRED ASHER DONALDS, who was mortally wounded at the battle of Bristow Station, Va., took place yesterday afternoon from the Governor's Room, City Hall.
lead_paragraph: The obsequies of Capt. ALFRED ASHER DONALDS, who was mortally wounded at the battle of Bristow Station, Va., took place yesterday afternoon from the Governor's Room, City Hall. Deceased was a Captain in the Fourth Regiment, Excelsior Brigade, known as; the Second Fire Zouave Regiment, and formerly a member of Engine Company No. 17. At 1 o'clock the members of the various fire companies began to form in line in the City Hall Park, the right resting on Broadway, corner of Murray-street. Shortly before 2 o'clock the remains were deposited in the hearse waiting to receive them, and the [???] procession moved across the Park to Chatham-street, up Chatham to the [???] thence to Grand, down Grand to Broadway and South Ferrry, [???] for Greenwood. The funeral cortege was most imposing -- consisting of a large number of the friends of the deceased in [???] soldiers of the Fourth Regiment, Excelsior Brigade, the Common Council, and members of the Fire Department. While the procession was passing along the route mentioned above, the different fire-bells in the City [???] a mournful requiem.

abstract: The rebels have announced their purpose of disputing Gen. BURNSIDE'S occupation of Fredericksburgh. He will have to cross the river in face of the rebel army--always one of the most difficult and dangerous of military operations. That it will be attempted, there can be no doubt.
lead_paragraph: The rebels have announced their purpose of disputing Gen. BURNSIDE's occupation of Fredericksburgh. He will have to cross the river in face of the rebel army -- always one of the most difficult and dangerous of military operations. That it will be attempted, there can be no doubt. Shelling the town, however, will scarcely accomplish the object, as the rebel forces do not occupy it, -- and we may reasonably doubt, therefore, whether it will be done. The crossing must be effected under cover of artillery -- unless it shall be found feasible to turn the enemy instead of meeting him directly in front: -- so that whatever battle may take place at that point will probably be, in the main, one of cannon.

abstract: This vessel sailed from Baltimore Oct. 27, for Demarara. After being out from Cape Henry four days, Nov. 1. experienced a heavy gale from northeast, during which spring aleak; was obliged to send,  and while so doing threw overboard a portion of the deck load; after which, hove the vessel to, when the ...
lead_paragraph: This vessel sailed from Baltimore Oct. 27, for Demarara. After being out from Cape Henry four days, Nov. 1. experienced a heavy gale from northeast, during which spring aleak; was obliged to send, and while so doing threw overboard a portion of the deck load; after which, hove the vessel to, when the gale increasing to a hurricane, threw the remainder of the deck load over to save the vessel from sinking. On the following day the wind changed to southwest, and blew a gale; bad to scud before it to get the hatches off to get at the cargo in the hold, threw over a portion of it from each end of the vessel; the sales had been blown away and split to pieces during the time, and the oakum was working out of the seams; the pumps continually going. Nov. 4. -- Still blowing heavy gales with squalls; found the bowsprit had started out of its bed; had to run before the wind, let it change to where it might. On the 9th found the planks had started from the timbers on each side, some twenty feel in length, the water running through into the hold. On the 10th was fallen in with by schooner Kasbec, Capt. ACKLEY, for New-York, for Arrayo, P.R., when having 3 feet 6 inches water in the hold, the men worn out laboring at the pumps, concluded to abandon her, which was done in lat. 21 30', long. 69 50'. The Louisiana was eight years old, of 150 tons burden, built in Dorchester, Md., and was owned by Capt. WM. MITCHELL, of Baltimore.

abstract: December
snippet: December
lead_paragraph: -- Harper's for December puts on a decidedly holiday look. It may be fancy, merely, but the present number seems to us to have a Christmas brightness throughout. In "Random Recollections of a Life," by J.H. SIDDONS, grandson of the SIDDONS, we have one of those galloping, gossippy papers that may only be likened to the whipped creams and exasperated froths occasionally set on the table with dessert, anything but a solid, and yet pleasant to take and taken by all. In it we are placed on conversational terms with the notabilities of London society, in the noon of that brilliant day of which only the deepening twilight at present remains. We have sketches of notable personages and characters that are vastly better and more life-like, we fancy, than stale portraits, albeit they are drawn with the brush of a snob. Here is an interview with THE DUKE OF WELLINGTON.

abstract: nals a few days since announced the arrest of two gentlemen well known in this City, on charge of having defrauded the Government. We copy from the Albany Argus an article giving the details of the alleged fraudulent transactions.
lead_paragraph: nals a few days since announced the arrest of two gentlemen well known in this City, on charge of having defrauded the Government. We copy from the Albany Argus an article giving the details of the alleged fraudulent transactions. Some allowance must unquestionably be made for the very strong partisanblas of the journal from which this report is drawn; still the statements are evidently prepared with care, and have every mark of substantial accuracy. The drift of the statement is that the Government neglected to deposit money with its agents here to meet the bills of contractors, recruiting agents and others, as they fell due; that the persons holding these claims, being pressed for money, were compelled to sell them at rates of discount rising gradually from five to sixty per cent.; and that finaally alterations were made in these bills, by the parties who discounted them, so as fraudulently to increase the amounts due upon them.

abstract: The most important piece of news that has reached us from Europe the present year, is that brought by the Arabia, and telegraphed off Cape Race last night, in relation to the proposed mediation of France and England in the American quarrel.
lead_paragraph: The most important piece of news that has reached us from Europe the present year, is that brought by the Arabia, and telegraphed off Cape Race last night, in relation to the proposed mediation of France and England in the American quarrel. It is at last verified that the French Emperor has seriously meditated intervention, and has actually proposed to the English Government a joint offer of mediation to stop the American war. The fact that it is Minister DROUYN DE L'HUYS, so recently taking his place in the Emperor's Cabinet, that initiates this movement, is significant, almost sinister, as indicating the willingness of the French Government to interpose its influence to stop the war, at a moment when all the advantages, in a military aspect, are in favor of the Union -- when its armies are largest and most efficient and prepared to give the finishing blow to the rebellion. This disclosure is not in accordance with concurrent testimony from France during the war and up to the present time. We had been led very generally to believe that no Government in Europe was more firmly fixed in the view of the utter impolicy of meddling with the American rebellion than that of the French.

abstract: We beg to acknowledge the receipt of a great many "replies to the London Times." They are sufficiently able and pertinent; but we must decline their publication, because it would answer no practical good purpose whatever. The London Times is an important and powerful journal, and its championship of the rebellion has exerted a prodigious ...
lead_paragraph: We beg to acknowledge the receipt of a great many "replies to the London Times." They are sufficiently able and pertinent; but we must decline their publication, because it would answer no practical good purpose whatever. The London Times is an important and powerful journal, and its championship of the rebellion has exerted a prodigious influence on the public sentiment of England and of Europe. But replies to its diatribes published here cannot offset or diminish this influence in the least. They do not reach the same readers: nor have they the slightest effect on the conduct of the Times itself. The most perfect and complete demonstration of the falsehood or fallacy of its articles would neither induce a correction nor prevent their repetition the very next day.

abstract: The steamship Arabia passed Cape Race yesterday morning, and her advices, which are one week later, are telegraphed. By this arrival we receive the important intelligence that the Emperor NAPOLEON has made a proposal for mediation between tho belligerents in the United States to the British Government, but that the latter has declined to become a party.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Arabia passed Cape Race yesterday morning, and her advices, which are one week later, are telegraphed. By this arrival we receive the important intelligence that the Emperor NAPOLEON has made a proposal for mediation between tho belligerents in the United States to the British Government, but that the latter has declined to become a party. Earl RUSSELL's official reply to the proposition, dated the 13th inst., is published in the London Gazelle. It recognizes the humane views and benevolent intentions of the Emperor, but observes that the concurrence of Russia, expressly desirable, had not been obtained; and after weighing all the information obtained from America, the Government concludes there is no [???] at the [???]to hope that the United States Government would accept the proposal, a refusal of which would prevent any speedy renewal of the offer of the Governments; therefore it is better to watch carefully the progress of opinion in America, and to embrace the first good opportunity for offering mediation which may occur. The publication of this dispatch produced no effect commercially. The Paris Moniteur says the answers of England and Russia are an adjournment of the question of mediation, but it thinks their hesitation has nearly reached its limit, as the recent elections in the North testify to the progress of peace opinions. From China, we learn that another engagement had taken place between the American WARD's Contingent and the rebels, in which WARD was killed. More outrageous murders of foreigners had taken place in Japan. The Liverpool Cotton market was dull and unchanged.

abstract: Editorial on Grant position in Tennessee and his ambition to invade Mississippi
snippet: Editorial on Grant position in Tennessee and his ambition to invade Mississippi
lead_paragraph: The public did not fully understand the military position in the Southwest at the time of Gen. GRANT'S recent advance toward Holly Springs; and hence anticipations have been indulged in, of immediate and decisive results, that were not fully justified. The bulk of Gen. GRANT'S army is still at Lagrange, Tennessee: the rest is at Grand Junction. These are not new positions to the Union forces. The rebels have not held either since Corinth was evacuated in the Spring. And Lagrange, the most advanced of the two, was occupied nearly all last Summer by Gen. HURLBERT with an entire division. Gen. GRANT, it is now stated, has not an army sufficiently strong to advance into the heart of Mississippi. But he took the advanced positions, Grand Junction and Lagrange, with the calculation that he was to be reinforced; and when that favored time arrives, he wishes to be as near the enemy as possible.
headline: {'main': 'What Seems a Mistake.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'What Seems a Mistake.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: About 5 o'clock yesterday morning, Capt. SEBRING, of the Ninth Precinct, aided by his officers, DAY and ACKERMAN, succeeded in effecting the arrest of AUGUSTUS L. SIMMS, who was implicated in the Coroner's verdict, rendered on Saturday night last, as being an accessory to the death of Miss CLEMENTINA ANDERSON.
lead_paragraph: About 5 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning, Capt. SEBRING, of the Ninth Precinct, aided by his officers, DAY and ACKERMAN, succeeded in effecting the arrest of AUGUSTUS L. SIMMS, who was implicated in the Coroner's verdict, rendered on Saturday night last, as being an accessory to the death of Miss CLEMENTINA ANDERSON. The arrest was made at the residence of his sister, No. 139 West Tenth-street. About 9 1/2 o'clock yesterday A.M., the following note, addressed to Officer SEBRING, and post-marked Albany, was received at the Station-house.

lead_paragraph: To-day, from 8 A.M. to 9 P.M., the Board of Registrars of the several Districts, set for the purpose of revising and correcting the list of voters for the coming election. Urge upon all voters, the importance of having their names registered in time, in order to avoid delay in voting on the day of election. Let every one see [???] his [???] registered. Don't rely on the fact that he voted at the last State election, or that he is an old resident, for it may be that his name has been omitted in the new register -- either intentionally or unintentionally. Such things have been done, and probably will be attempted again.

abstract: This morning at daylight a body of rebel cavalry, said to be sixty strong, entered Poolesville, seized Messrs. CHERRY AND SARGEANT, the Government telegraph operators stationed there, in bed, paroled them, and permitted them to telegraph their mishaps to Washington. This boldness of the rebels has caused much excitement in this neighborhood.

abstract: The Board of Supervisors met at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon--President PURDY in the Chair.  The Commissioners of Taxes and Assessments transmitted to the Board an order upon them from the Supreme Court to reduce the tax on the bank assets so far as to exempt the United States Bonds held by them. The order is in pursuance of the recent dedision of the Court, that these stocks are exempted from tax by law of Congress.

abstract: -- Among the passengers by the steamship Roanoke, from New-Orleans, arrived at this port last evening, is Brig.-Gen. ARNOLD, who is on his way home, in Boston, in a very critical condition from the effects of an apoplectic fit, causing a paralysis of his right side and tongue. Gen. ARNOLD has served twenty-five years in the regular army, having been brevetted several times for gallantry in the Mexican war. He was late in command of the United States forces in New-Orleans and Algiers.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- MYERBEER's new opera, "Dinorah," produced here on Monday, will be repeated to-night. The work is not altogether unknown in America. It was played in New-Orleans in 1860 -- the year of its production in Paris -- and the principal morceau, the "Shadow Song," has ever since been a favorite in the concert-room. Judging from the reception given to the first performance of the work, it seems probable that it will arrive at a fair and speedy popularity in New-York. In France, in Germany and in England, it was taken cum grane salis; here we have bolted it silently, but outright. Of the half-dozen works written by its illustrious composer, it is undoubtedly the one which enjoys the greatest popularity at the present moment, and which, from the interest of the story, as well as the intrinsic merit of the music, is likely to be most often played. It has certainly gained vastly in public consideration since the time of its production, and this is praise in itself of the highest kind.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- MYERBEER's new opera, "Dinorah," produced here on Monday, will be repeated to-night. The work is not altogether unknown in America. It was played in New-Orleans in 1860 -- the year of its production in Paris -- and the principal morceau, the "Shadow Song," has ever since been a favorite in the concert-room. Judging from the reception given to the first performance of the work, it seems probable that it will arrive at a fair and speedy popularity in New-York. In France, in Germany and in England, it was taken cum grane salis; here we have bolted it silently, but outright. Of the half-dozen works written by its illustrious composer, it is undoubtedly the one which enjoys the greatest popularity at the present moment, and which, from the interest of the story, as well as the intrinsic merit of the music, is likely to be most often played. It has certainly gained vastly in public consideration since the time of its production, and this is praise in itself of the highest kind.

abstract: Gen. PATRICK returned from Fredericksburgh at 7 o'clock last evening. He carried orders demanding the surrender of the place, and ordering that no more supplies should be sent out of town. The Mayor of the town was willing to accede to the request, but the military authorities refused to listen to the demands. Gen. PATRICK was contined all day in the guard-house which he himself constructed last Summer.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY, Nov. 22, 1862.

abstract: The inquest at Port Richmond, Staten Island, on the murder of ALABAMUS HARRISON, is yet in progress. From the testimony of Drs. EADIR and HARRISON, (the latter a brother of the victim,) it would seem that the murder was committed in doors, and the body left in the street afterward, as the underclothes were not at all wet, although a heavy rain fall during the night.
lead_paragraph: The inquest at Port Richmond, Staten Island, on the murder of ALABAMUS HARRISON, is yet in progress. From the testimony of Drs. EADIR and HARRISON, (the latter a brother of the victim,) it would seem that the murder was committed in doors, and the body left in the street afterward, as the underclothes were not at all wet, although a heavy rain fall during the night. From sickness in infancy the deceased was partially demented, and being incapable of following any kind of employment, he was supported by his relatives. His habits were irregular, but harmless. He frequented the liquor-saloons, and on the night of the murder visited two of the worst of the "lager-bier" saloons, which are resorted to by the abandoned of both sexes. Their vile character was never fully known till revealed by this inquest. The citizens are now highly incensed at finding that such places exist in the village, and threats are quite openly made of tearing down the buildings. JAMES MOORE, one of the parties under arrest on suspicion, is not an Irishman, as heretofore stated, but claims to be a native of Rochester.
headline: {'main': 'The Murder at Staten Island.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Murder at Staten Island.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The iron-clad battery Passaic left the Delamater Iron Works early yesterday forenoon, and arrived at the Navy-yard soon after. She was then turned over to the Government to whom she belongs henceforward. Her ensign had been hoisted, and her commission filed before.
lead_paragraph: The iron-clad battery Passaic left the Delamater Iron Works early yesterday forenoon, and arrived at the Navy-yard soon after. She was then turned over to the Government to whom she belongs henceforward. Her ensign had been hoisted, and her commission filed before. She was manned, and took on board all the necessaries for active service, having been ordered to go to sea with dispatch. At 4 o'clock last evening everything was nearly ready, and it was thought she would sail. To-day, however, she will be certain to go. The new arrangement for firing the gun inside the turret is most satisfactorily finished. The destination of the vessel is not known. We printed a list of her officers some days since.

abstract: editorial calls proposal blunder; editorial says Napoleon blundered by becoming involved in Roman question
snippet: editorial calls proposal blunder; editorial says Napoleon blundered by becoming involved in Roman question
lead_paragraph: That the Emperor of the French is a ruler of very large capacity will be generally admitted; but the most capable of men have often been known to overtask themselves, and break down from undertaking too much. The first NAPOLEON is a case in point. He was quite competent to handle Austria alone, or any single Power of Europe, besides keeping himself firmly on the usurped throne of France. But when it came to regulating all Europe combined, the undertaking proved too onerous, and the greatest ruler of his age was crushed on the field of Waterloo.

abstract: General GEORGE F. SHEPLEY, Military Governor of Louisiana, has issued a proclamation ordering an election in the First and Second Congressional Districts of that State, for Representatives in the present (twenty-seventh) Congress of the United States. At the time the present Congress was elected, Louisiana was in rebel bands and no members were chosen -- the last representative of that State being the gallant BOULIGNY, who refused to secede with the previous delegation. The State was, therefore, unrepresented last session, and will be be unrepresentated the ensuing session until about Christmas, when, the members to be chosen under Gen. SHEPLEY's proclamation may be expected to be present. The day fixed for the election is December 3.
lead_paragraph: General GEORGE F. SHEPLEY, Military Governor of Louisiana, has issued a proclamation ordering an election in the First and Second Congressional Districts of that State, for Representatives in the present (twenty-seventh) Congress of the United States. abstract: Do we mean to kill this rebellion or not? If we do, why this hacking at the extremities? Why this skin-deep scarifying of the sides? Why this mere pricking at the vitals? Why don't we drive our lance, with might and main, straight into the heart of the monster? Will it be said it has no heart? It has.
lead_paragraph: Do we mean to kill this rebellion or not? If we do, why this hacking at the extremities? Why this skin-deep scarifying of the sides? Why this mere pricking at the vitals? Why don't we drive our lance, with might and main, straight into the heart of the monster? Will it be said it has no heart? It has. A heart is an essential of all life, whether natural or civil. Every organization -- the body politic as well as any other -- must have its central seat of vitality and energy. Richmond is the heart of the Confederacy. Penetrate it, and he whole power of the rebellion reels and collapses. Will it be said we have not means strong enough? We have. With nearly a million of men now under arms, we can, if necessary, devote half of that force to this object. Such an army, if well directed, could overthrow any place on this Continent.

abstract: THE NORTH RIVER FERRIES.--The Jersey City Ferry Company gives gratifying evidence of public spirit, in furnishing fresh facilities to the traveling community. It recently established a new ferry, connecting with the foot of Desbrosses-street, thus enabling the railroad passengers to reach a point up town with the least possible delay.
lead_paragraph: THE NORTH RIVER FERRIES. -- The Jersey City Ferry Company gives gratifying evidence of public spirit, in furnishing fresh facilities to the traveling community. It recently established a new ferry, connecting with the foot of Desbrosses-street, thus enabling the railroad passengers to reach a point up town with the least possible delay. The new ferry however, deducted one from the number of slips on the New-Jersey side. The frequency of communication with Cortlandt-street was thus interrupted, and complaint was made of the consequent delay. The reconstruction of this slips on the New-York side added to the temporary inconvenience. All such difficulties are now obviated. A new slip has been arranged at the Jersey City end for the Desbrosses route, and the repairs at the foot of Cortlandt-street are completed, in a few weeks a new and splendid boat will be put in service. Then all possibility of complaint will be set at rest, and the ferry rank first among those leading from the City, in point of speed, promptness and convenience. The Company deserves credit for its enterprise.

abstract: On the 8th of the current month, in an article on "Our Friends in England," we gave some facts concerning the want and distress that prevails to such a fearful extent in the cotton manufacturing districts of England; and we suggested that it would be a humane...
lead_paragraph: On the 8th of the current month, in an article on "Our Friends in England," we gave some facts concerning the want and distress that prevails to such a fearful extent in the cotton manufacturing districts of England; and we suggested that it would be a humane and generous thing for the American people -- who, notwithstanding the fact that they are waging the greatest war of modern times, are yet blessed with overflowing garners and storehouses filled with plenty -- to send to their famishing brethren across the ocean a contribution from their abundance, as a proof and earnest of their sympathy with them in their day of misfortune. Whether it be a friend or a foe who is in distress, we are equally commanded by the Divine Word to go to his relief when it is in our power to do so; but we mentioned the noteworthy fact that about the only exhibitions of friendship for our Union and our cause which had come from Great Britain had been the utterances of these operatives and workingmen of Lancashire, now reduced to such terrible straits. If possible, this only made it the more imperative that we should signalize our appreciation of their fraternal feeling.

abstract: It would seem that desperation is seizing upon the soul of JEFF. DAVIS, and driving him to acts that can never be justified by the rules of war. Some mouths ago, the guerrillas of Marion County, Missouri -- (the scene, we may remark, of more bridge-burning and cold-blooded murdering than elsewhere occurred in blood-stained Missouri) -- kidnapped an estimable Union citizen of Palmyra, the county seat, and secreted him so that his friends could get no trace of him. It is believed he was murdered. Gen. MCNEIL, of the Missouri State Militia, commanding in the District, caught several of the guerrillas of the county, and held them as hostages for the safe return of the Union citizen, ordering that if the body of the latter were not produced within a given time, the guerrillas held as hostages should be shot. The kidnapped man was not restored, and the penalty was enforced.

abstract: The Mayor, &c., vs. John Kerr, et al. -- This case has been frequently reported in the TIMES. It is at last settled so far as the Courts of this District are concerned. abstract: A special dispatch to the American, from Harper's Ferry, states that Gen. KELLY yesterday sent out scouts from New-Creek, who captured a rebel cavalry picket of twelve men, with horses and accoutrements, within four miles of Winchester. The prisoners say that JACKSON has started with his whole force for Richmond, by way of Front Royal, leaving only a regiment of cavalry at Winchester, instructed to follow in a few days.

abstract: -- Messrs. E. & G.W. BLUNT have recently issued two contributions to hydrography, which will be as indispensable to the reader. as to the navigator. One is a chart or the "Bahama islands," giving full details of all the intricate windings of that archipelago; the soundings with the utmost minuteness, and all the data necessary to show the difficulties of checking rebel intercourse between Nassau and Charleston. The other is a map of "Charleston and its Vicinity," displaying all the water passages, inlets, islands and coast lines from the upper side of Bull Bay to Edisto Island. The topography is exceedingly full and accurate, extending almost to the centre of the State while everypeculiarity of the shore is conscientiously noted. The publications of the Messrs. BLUNT need no voucher for their excellence and fidelity.

abstract: DESTRUCTIVE FIRE--ONE MAN AND TWENTY HORSES BURNED TO DEATH.--Shortly after 9 o'clock last evening a fire broke out in the stables of the Knickerbocker Ice Company, in Furman-street near Fulton Ferry, and resulted in the destruction of the building and contents, together with twenty horses.
lead_paragraph: DESTRUCTIVE FIRE -- ONE MAN AND TWENTY HORSES BURNED TO DEATH. -- Shortly after 9 o'clock last evening a fire broke out in the stables of the Knickerbocker Ice Company, in Furman-street near Fulton Ferry, and resulted in the destruction of the building and contents, together with twenty horses. A hand in the employ of the Company was burned to death. His name is JAMES MCGUNNIGLE, who, it appears, was in the habit of lodging on the premises, and as supposed was asleep on some straw at the time the fire originated. There was considerable hay and straw in the stable, which burned with such rapidity that, the whole was enveloped before means could be taken to suppress the flames. Several persons broke open the doors, and succeeded in rescuing four horses at the peril of their lives, while twenty of the poor animals were left to be consumed. Mr. FREDERICK HAUGERZA, one of the principal men about the establishment, fearing that some persons were in the stable, made search, and found the dead body of MCGUNNIGLE. It was feared at the time that others were inside, but it was then impossible to make further examination. It is believed, however, that MCGUNNIGLE is the only one who did not succeed in making his escape from the premises. The stable was of frame 25 feet front by 50 feet deep, and valued at about $600. It was designed to build a brick structure this Fall. The value of each horse averaged $200, making a total loss, with harness, &c., about $6,000. The property is owned by the New-York Knickerbocker Ice Company, Mr. A. BARMORE, President. There were several wagons in the rear yard, and a vessel at the dock, but all were saved by the exertions of the firemen. The fire, it is supposed, originated by accident.

abstract: This little State has been much agitated and frightened latterly at reports of attempted filibuster invasions from Peru, and of contemplated revolutions and conspiracies against the authority of President MORENO and Gen. FLORES, his military chief. The Government at Quito had addressed notes to all the deplomatic representatives at the Capital, deploring any attempt at unlawful or irregular invasion of the country, to which they had replied in the same strain. I notice that official replies are published from both the representative of Gen. MOSQUERA and from the agent of the extinct government of New-Granada, from which it appears that Ecuador recognizes both our contending parties.
lead_paragraph: This little State has been much agitated and frightened latterly at reports of attempted filibuster invasions from Peru, and of contemplated revolutions and conspiracies against the authority of President MORENO and Gen. lead_paragraph: Samuel Engle and Another vs. John Yates. -- This case was stated in the TIMES of the 23d inst. The plaintiffs sought to recover $2,260, alleged to have been collected for them by the defendant, as their agent, and appropriated to his own use. The action was brought in the Supreme Court, and an order of arrest was obtained against the defendant, and he was arrested, but subsequently discharged on the ground that he was fraudulently induced within the district for the purpose of the arrest.

abstract: THANKSGIVING DAY. -- A glance at our adververtising columns will enable each reader of the TIMES to select the mode of spending this time-honored anniversary which shall be most agreeable to his inclinations or taste. The sermons of the morning are only equaled in variety by the entertainments of the evening, and between the two no one can fail to be delighted, for it is just at this interval that the dinner comes in. Appearances indicate that it will be one of the most jovially celebrated and highly enjoyed Thanksgivings that we have had for many a year, and so it ought, for are we not one year nearer the end of this infernal slaveholders' rebellion than ever we were before?

abstract: When a noted restaurateur changed his bsse to Fourteenth-street, it was generally thought that he had penetrated too far into the enemy's country; the supplies might be cut: it was a rash experiment, not warranted on sound military principles. His Summer campaign, however, has been a brilliant success, and what better proof could we demand of good generalship? ...
lead_paragraph: When a noted restaurateur changed his bsse to Fourteenth-street, it was generally thought that he had penetrated too far into the enemy's country; the supplies might be cut: it was a rash experiment, not warranted on sound military principles. His Summer campaign, however, has been a brilliant success, and what better proof could we demand of good generalship? WALLACK was the first among managers to perceive the advantage of an up-town stand. Three-fourths of those who patronize this class of theatre reside above Union-square. He has been amply rewarded for his sagacity and enterprise, as his houses night after night fully testify.

abstract: Thanksgiving--the day specially set apart for the manifestation of gratitude to Providence--has again dawned. It ought to be the day of all others for high impulses and noble deeds; for, most assuredly, there is no such  way of showing ourselves grateful as by being ourselves gracious, or of honoring the AllBountiful as by disposing freely of our bounty.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving -- the day specially set apart for the manifestation of gratitude to Providence -- has again dawned. It ought to be the day of all others for high impulses and noble deeds; for, most assuredly, there is no such way of showing ourselves grateful as by being ourselves gracious, or of honoring the AllBountiful as by disposing freely of our bounty. We cannot, then, let our issue this morning pass without once more invoking the friendly succor of the great-hearted Christian public for our -- shall we say, enemies? Thank Heaven, we are not obliged to use that word for our friends, the famishing operatives of England.

abstract: -- The Boston newspapers haveadvanced their price from two to three cents a copy. The New-York newspapers will do the same thing just as soon as they can make up their minds that the world is large enough for all of them. Up to the present time, each seems so fearful of losing its own position that they all prefer giving for two cents what costs them four or five, to running the risk of making any change.

abstract: From Rosario dates are up to Sept. 16. The Provinces are all quiet; but at Buenos Ayres the people were a good deal agitated about the question as to the place for the permanent location of the Capital. The local Legislature had rejected the bill for the federalization of the Province (?) of Buenos Ayres, or that for the municipal area of the city. The public mind was restless at the new turn of affairs.

He also dented that the Chilian Minister had been received uncourteously at the Court of St. James.

abstract: La Paz, the principal city of Bolivia, finally surrendered to Gen. ACHA, Provisional President, on the 16th of October, Gen. AGREDA, commanding there for the revolutionary leader PEREZ, retiring. For twenty days, previously, not a shop had been opened in the city, and the distress among many was getting to be very great.
lead_paragraph: La Paz, the principal city of Bolivia, finally surrendered to Gen. ACHA, Provisional President, on the 16th of October, Gen. AGREDA, commanding there for the revolutionary leader PEREZ, retiring. For twenty days, previously, not a shop had been opened in the city, and the distress among many was getting to be very great. Four or five mercantile houses only were sacked during the disturbances. PEREZ had fled, some say, to the Argentine Confederation, while others aver that he is still in the country, organizing for another attempt. At any rate, there is but little prospect for permanent rest, there are so many personal and political aspirations to satisfy in the country.
headline: {'main': 'BOLIVIA.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'BOLIVIA.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Public expectation is on tiptoe for the departure of the great expedition to be commanded by Major-Gen. N.P. BANKS. Meanwhile, as unostentatiously as the lion hunters will permit, the General is busy with his preparations. The troops and supplies are gathering at a convenient point, and any fine morning the public may be startled with the information that the great armada is afloat. Let us hope that it will prove invincible wherever it goes, and that it may reach the heart of the rebellion.
lead_paragraph: Public expectation is on tiptoe for the departure of the great expedition to be commanded by Major-Gen. N.P. BANKS. abstract: In the Matter of James Murphy, bail for Joseph E. Santos -- NELSON, C.J. -- This is an application to the Court to set aside the default and order to prosecute the recognizance of Murphy for the appearance of Santos on an indictment for fitting out a vessel with intent to employ her in the Slave-trade, and to abide the order of the Court. The prisoner appeared and answered to the indictment, but pending the trial and before it was concluded, he departed without leave of the Court. He was called and the recognizance duty estreated, but as the offence amounted to a misdemeanor only, the prosecution progressed, and the prisoner was acquitted by the Jury. The bail now applies for relief from the default and estreat of the recognizance.
lead_paragraph: In the Matter of James Murphy, bail for Joseph E. The prisoner appeared and answered to the indictment, but pending the trial and before it was concluded, he departed without leave of the Court. He was called and the recognizance duty estreated, but as the offence amounted to a misdemeanor only, the prosecution progressed, and the prisoner was acquitted by the Jury. The bail now applies for relief from the default and estreat of the recognizance.

abstract: RAILROAD COMMUNICATION WITH BLOOMFIELD, N.J.--The citizens of Bloomfield, and Montclair, N. .J., wearied with, and disgusted at, the constant delays to which they have been subjected at Newark, through the mismanagement of the Morris and Essex Railroad Company, held a meeting in the Bloomfield depot, on Tuesday evening, to take some action which ...
lead_paragraph: RAILROAD COMMUNICATION WITH BLOOMFIELD, N.J. -- The citizens of Bloomfield, and Montclair, N. .J., wearied with, and disgusted at, the constant delays to which they have been subjected at Newark, through the mismanagement of the Morris and Essex Railroad Company, held a meeting in the Bloomfield depot, on Tuesday evening, to take some action which should call attention to their grievances, and, if possible, secure them redress. Mr. WRIGHT F. CONGER called the meeting to order, and on his motion Mr. ROBERT M. HENING, of Montclair, was called to preside. After spirited speeches by Messrs. PRATT, HART, DODGE, M.W. DODD, and others, a series of resolutions was adopted declaring the delays a source of great inconvenience, and detrimental alike to the interests of the Newark and Bloomfield Railroad and to those of the community for whose accommodation it was built, asserting that the growing importance of the section of country represented in the meeting no only justified but demanded increased accommodation and more rapid communication with New-York, and urging direct communication without change of cars, as the proper remedy for existing difficulties. A committee of seven, consisting of Messrs. J.H. Pratt, Henry Nason, Wright F. Conger, H.J. Mills, C.D. Gibson, R.M. Hening, and James C. Beach, was then appointed to confer with the Directors of the Newark and Bloomfield Railroad Company, and to pledge them a hearty support in any liberal policy which would promote the interests of the road as well as those of the public. The meeting adjourned to meet at the call of the committee.

abstract: The announcement that Mr. MASON JONES would re-deliver his oration on "CURRAN and the Wits and Orators of the Irish Bar," drew a crowded and brilliant audience on Tuesday evening to the Academy of Music. Of course the night was wet. This was Mr. JONES' fourth appearance before a New-York ...
lead_paragraph: The announcement that Mr. MASON JONES would re-deliver his oration on "CURRAN and the Wits and Orators of the Irish Bar," drew a crowded and brilliant audience on Tuesday evening to the Academy of Music. Of course the night was wet. This was Mr. JONES' fourth appearance before a New-York audience, and on each occasion he has had miserable, wet evenings. Then, as if to add to his difficulties, his agent forgot to insert his advertisement in the morning journals, but in spite of all these drawbacks the Academy was crowded with a most critical and intelligent audience. The lecture was received with even greater favor than on the occasion of its first delivery in Irving Hall. All the points were taken; all the anecdotes well told, and at each successive withcism of CURRAN or some of his compeers, the house reechoed with shouts of laughter. The passage on "Universal Emancipation" which has provoked to much controversy was received with loud and repeated applause. On Wednesday last it was heartily hissed, on Tuesday evening to the applause with which it was greeted we did not hear one dissenting voice. The oration closed with a brilliant peroration on CURRAN's character and genius, and the services he rendered to the sacred cause of liberty, and after Mr. JONES had left the platform he was recalled by the tumultuous cheering of his admirers.

abstract: The steamship Africa arrived at Halifax yesterday, and in addition to the summary of her news telegraphed from Cape Race, we have now sent to us the full text of the dispatch of the French Minister of Foreign Affairs proposing mediation, together with the replies of the Russian and English Governments.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Africa arrived at Halifax yesterday, and in addition to the summary of her news telegraphed from Cape Race, we have now sent to us the full text of the dispatch of the French Minister of Foreign Affairs proposing mediation, together with the replies of the Russian and English Governments. Prince GORTSCHAKOFF, it will be seen, argues, like Earl RUSSELL, that the proper time for mediation has not arrived. If, however, France should persist in her intention, and Great Britain should acquiesce, instructions will be sent to Baron STOECKL at Washington to lend the French and English Ministers there, if not official aid, at least moral support.

abstract: Editorial on reasons to be grateful
snippet: Editorial on reasons to be grateful
lead_paragraph: The recurrence of that day of the year upon which so large a proportion of this people have united as a Day of Thanksgiving to the Almighty for his numberless and inestimable blessings, must ever excite the profound emotions of devout and affectionate natures. It is gratifying to know that the day is to be observed the present year with remarkable unanimity and heartiness, not abating one jot of earnest loyalty to an honored and venerated custom by reason of present national disturbances; but, indeed, gathering unction and fervor from the exercise of that sublime faith that looks through and beyond the perils and darkness of the hour to the bright and eternal day that is to crown the rest of all the children of God. The world was not made alone for what we now see of it. Men were not created alone for the fitful struggles of this short life, nor for the brief and bloody drama they are now performing, and that we from day to day take active part in. The time will come when the riddle of life and the problem of the world will be read aright by all -- when mortal foes shall lay aside the strife, in the spirit of which they thrust each other out of the world, and wonder that truth and freedom should need such sacrifices -- when perpetual peace shall succeed to the discords of war, and universal brotherhood fold the human race in unity and love.
headline: {'main': 'Thanksgiving Day.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Thanksgiving Day.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In an issue of the London Times for last December, there was an article written with considerable care, to enforce the theory of the English Press, that the affair of the Trent was but the last and most intolerable of a series of studied insults, offered by the United States to Great Britain.
lead_paragraph: In an issue of the London Times for last December, there was an article written with considerable care, to enforce the theory of the English Press, that the affair of the Trent was but the last and most intolerable of a series of studied insults, offered by the United States to Great Britain. That article served for some time as a kind of text-book for the public speakers in England, who, even after it was found that the Trent was detained without any instructions whatever on the part of the Government, and the amende honorable had been made, still followed up the unworthy attempt of inflaming the public mind of that country toward this, and provoking a war against us, in order to avenge, while our hands were tied, pretended affronts, to which, as they alleged, they had submitted while our hands were free. Among the items of insult and provocation set forth in that article is the following: "We were treated with much rudeness on the question of the Fisheries of Nova Scotia." BURKE speaks of the difficulty of framing an indocumentdictment "against a whole people," and if this is a fair specimen, it will be admitted that there is as much difficulty in pleading to such an indictment. On what occasion this "rude treatment" was committed is not set forth, and, as the accused party, we may well echo the words of BURKE, that we "do not know the method" of defending ourselves against such a charge.

abstract: From Lima we learn that Gen. SAN ROMAN was quietly installed as President of the Republic, on the 24th of October, in place of Gen. CASTILLA, the latter having served since he overthrew Gen. ECHENIQUE, in 1855. Gen. CASTILLA published patriotic addresses to the nation and to the navy when he retired, and President SAN ROMAN, in two addresses to the nation and the army, promises to govern strictly under the ...
lead_paragraph: From Lima we learn that Gen. SAN ROMAN was quietly installed as President of the Republic, on the 24th of October, in place of Gen. CASTILLA, the latter having served since he overthrew Gen. ECHENIQUE, in 1855. Gen. CASTILLA published patriotic addresses to the nation and to the navy when he retired, and President SAN ROMAN, in two addresses to the nation and the army, promises to govern strictly under the Constitution and laws, and to retrench the expenses of the Government. President SAN ROMAN called Gen. MANUEL MENDIBURU to take charge of the portfolios of the War and Navy Departments, charging him to organize the Cabinet as President of the Council of Ministers. This gentleman, however, finally threw up the attempt to form a Cabinet, for the reason that one of the persons whom he had proposed to associate with him declined the place assigned him. On the 26th, Don JOSE GREGORIO PAZ SOLDAN succeeded Gen. MENDIBURU, associating with himself as Minister of the Government, Don ANTONIO ARENAS; Minister of Finance, Don JOSE SANTOS CASTANEDA; Minister of Justice, Don MELCHOR VIDOURRE; Minister of War, Gen. ISIDRO FRISANCHO. The Government, after a great deal of public and private discussion, has finally accepted the $11,000,000 loan lately made in England, and which, after a portion of the money had arrived in Lima, Congress refused to sanction, on the ground that the loan and conversion of the old debt was made in London by the Peruvian Minister without due authority, and was an onerous one for the Government. Don PEDRO GALVEZ, Secretary of Hacienda, having refused to sign the decree accepting the loan, he resigned, and was succeeded by Senor MENDIBURU, Chief Comptroller of the Exchequer, who was more pliant. The usual scandal in such matters is circulated in Lima, that GALVEZ refused to approve the loan because he had his pet scheme by which he could better fill his own pockets, and that MENDIBURU did sign it because he got $200,000 for doing so. How this may be I know not, but I do know that in an $11,000,000 operation in Peru a good deal of the money is expected to stick to the palms of the Government officers. 900,000 of the money is deposited in Lima, awaiting the news of its acceptance to reach England.

abstract: -- This day promises to be generally celebrated throughout the city. Services will be held in the churches during the forenoon, and the war will, doubtless, be referred to by many of the pastors. The different charitable institutions and other associations have also made arrangements to observe the occasion in the usual manner, by furnishing those under their charge with the delicacies, of the season. Entertainments of various kinds are announced. Washington Skating Pond will be opened to subscribers of last year, and those wishing to join the club this year, in order to enable them to examine the movements which have recently been made, and are still in progress. A band of music will be in attendance during the afternoon. In former years the streets were alive with target companies, but from various causes there will be few excursions on this occasion, although several clubs and parties have made arrangements to enjoy the day at some of the numerous resorts beyond the City limits. Places of business will generally be closed, in compliance with the Governor's proclamation and the recommendation of the Mayor.

abstract: D.V. Freeman vs. Hiram Barney.--This was an action brought to recover an amount paid by the plaintiff as extra duties levied by the defendant. The penalty was levied on the ground that on appraisement the appraisers had advanced the value more than ten per cent.
lead_paragraph: D.V. Freeman vs. Hiram Barney. -- This was an action brought to recover an amount paid by the plaintiff as extra duties levied by the defendant. The penalty was levied on the ground that on appraisement the appraisers had advanced the value more than ten per cent. The evidence showed that the appraisers, in their calculation, wherever a number of cents occurred more than fifty, had called it a dollar, and whenever it was less than fifty cents, they had thrown it out entirely. On an accurate calculation, it appeared that the advance was less than ten per cent, on the value of the invoice by forty one-hundreths of a cent.

abstract: The United States vs. The Steamer Memphis and her Cargo.--This vessel was captured by the Magnolia, on July 31, 1862, off Charleston Harbor. On her being libeled, British subjects intervened as owners of vessel and cargo, and the evidence sustained their allegation that both were neutral property.
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Steamer Memphis and her Cargo. -- This vessel was captured by the Magnolia, on July 31, 1862, off Charleston Harbor. On her being libeled, British subjects intervened as owners of vessel and cargo, and the evidence sustained their allegation that both were neutral property. The evidence showed that the vessel had landed at Charleston a cargo consisting largely of contraband of war; that her master and owners knew that the port was blockaded, when the vessel was fitted out in England, and intended that her ingress and egress should be in violation of the blockade. The claimants in addition to the general points taken in these prize cases, claimed also that the capture was invalid, because it was not made by a vessel actually stationed at the blockaded port.

abstract: In this Court yesterday, DANIEL L. WELCH was placed on trial, under an indictment for obtaining money by false pretences. It appeared from the evidence adduced by the prosecution that the prisoner had been an employe of Mr. WEBB, the shipbuilder, and, in accordance with the usual custom of that establishment, presented himself on Saturday evening ...
lead_paragraph: In this Court yesterday, DANIEL L. WELCH was placed on trial, under an indictment for obtaining money by false pretences. It appeared from the evidence adduced by the prosecution that the prisoner had been an employe of Mr. WEBB, the shipbuilder, and, in accordance with the usual custom of that establishment, presented himself on Saturday evening at the office of the Cashier to receive his weekly wages. The number of days that each hand worked during the week. It seems, is left to his own statement, and the prisoner, on stepping up to the Cashier's office, merely uttered the words "five days," and was thereupon paid five days' wages by the Cashier. Immediately after making the payment, the Cashier said he suspected all was not right, and on inquiry at the yard, ascertained that the prisoner had not-worked at all that week. Mr. SPENCER, counsel for the prisoner, claimed that under the law, as laid down in the case of the People vs. Haynos, 14th Wendell, his client was entitled to an acquittal on the testimony of the Cashiers -- he having proved, by his own evidence, that he did not exercise that ordinary caution which the law requires of every business man. The Court took the same view of the case, and without proceeding any further in the trial instructed the jury to render a verdict of not guilty. This the jury refused to do, or at least two of their number declined to obey the instructions of the Court. Under these circumstances the Court informed them that they could retire and consult together, and intimated that they would be permitted to remain together until after Thanksgiving unless they could agree. This was not a very pleasing prospect to the refractory jurors, and after being out twenty minutes they compromised the matter by agreeing to the following verdict: "Not guilty, according to the instructions of the Court." The jury were then discharged for the term, and the Court adjourned to Friday morning at 11 o'clock.

abstract: THANKSGIVING IN NEWARK.--Thanksgiving Day in Newark passed off very pleasantly and quietly, the attractive weather causing an unusual throng of people in the streets, many of them being from the country, which on holidays always sends its quota to swell the crowd of passers-by. Business was entirely suspended, which gave the City the aspect of a Sabbath day.
lead_paragraph: THANKSGIVING IN NEWARK. -- Thanksgiving Day in Newark passed off very pleasantly and quietly, the attractive weather causing an unusual throng of people in the streets, many of them being from the country, which on holidays always sends its quota to swell the crowd of passers-by. Business was entirely suspended, which gave the City the aspect of a Sabbath day. The various churches ware all attended by large congregations, for Newark, be it known, is one of the most noted church-going places in the land. In fact, it is probable it is unsurpassed by any city in the country, not even by Brooklyn, the City of Churches, in the number and elegance of its places of worship. Yesterday the theme of discourse, in almost every instance, was the state of the country, many of the pastors taking occasion to express themselves very strongly upon the great questions at issue in the war.

abstract: A GANG OF JUVENILE PILFERERS DISPERSED -- ARREST OF AN ALLEGED RECEIVER. -- For some time past many of the down-town merchants have had considerable amounts of goods stolen from them, by an organized band of young thieves, most of whom live in the First Ward. On Wednesday, Officer Fincke, at the Twenty-seventh Precinct, made a raid on the young rascals and arrested six boys, ranging from 10 to 14 years of age, who gave their 'names as Wm. Gleason, Edward Ryan, Dennis McCarty, Philip McCall, Wm. Roscome, and John Fallon. Two of them had stolen each an odd boot from the store of JOHN MORTON, No. 122 Greenwich-street, and as the boy GLEASON alleges, sold them to Mrs. MART LOCKHEIMER, of Rector-street. GLEASON confessed to Capt. DECAMP, to selling the boots to Mrs. L. for $1 each, when, as he says, she induced him and his confederates to return to Mr. MORTON's store, and steal the boots to match those previously taken. By so doing, she would have two pairs of boots. GLEASON also stated that this gang of thieves have long been in the habit of selling stolen goods to Mrs. LOCKHEIMER, who even went so far as to indicate what articles she wanted them to steal. He says Mrs. LOCKHEIMER complained that they did not steal cloth enough, and wished them to bring her more dry goo is. On the testimony of the boys, Mrs. LOCKHEIMER was arrested, and the whole party were subsequently arraigned before Alderman HALL, who committed four of the boys and discharged the others (MCCARTY and McCALL.) Mrs. LOCKHEIMER, who claims to be a woman of the highest respectability, was also required to find ball in the sum of $1,000, to answer before the Court of General Sessions. The juvenile delinquents complained of are in the habit of sleeping in boxes, barrels, &c., when they can do no better. In one old rookery entered by the officer were found nearly a dozen boys, all asleep in one bed.

abstract: If the war has called into activity many of the most selfish and unscrupulous qualities of our people, it has also given occasion for the display of the most generous and lofty attributes of human nature.
lead_paragraph: If the war has called into activity many of the most selfish and unscrupulous qualities of our people, it has also given occasion for the display of the most generous and lofty attributes of human nature. The fact that thousands of dishonest speculators have seized upon the moment of their country's distress to glut their greed of gain, is well offset by the fact that other thousands, and vastly many more thousands, have willingly sacrificed time, comfort, property and life in the heroic duty of national defence, and in the more unobtrusive, but not less sublime work of relieving the poverty and healing the wounds that the war has produced. We need only refer to the Sanitary Commission in proof of our proposition -- an organization that, with no basis but the voluntary charity of the loyal millions, and no motive power but the self-sacrificing patriotism and benevolence of a few devoted men, has, nevertheless, erected a monument in good works honorable to our people, and more enduring than any granite shaft that shall commemorate battle-field or hero of the present to future ages. It will be well if some competent hand shall undertake to gather up in a suitable form for preservation the well-authenticated instances of private and public benevolence that have distinguished this remarkable war for the Union. It will be a matchless and triumphant answer now and for all time to maligners of our Government and people, who are already aiming to deceive history by charging the present struggle in good part to penuriousness and cupidity, so general as to amount to a national passion on the part of the North. It will present a record that the most elevated and liberal of Christian nationalities have never equaled.

abstract: The ship Granite State, from New-York, at Liverpool, reports that she saw the Alabama on Oct. [???], in lat. 40° 30', lon. 56°. She was lying to, hull down, to the westward, when first seen, and bore down to the Granite State. The ship was under single reefs, shook them out, and holsted maintopgallant sails. Toward dusk it came on very squally, and the Alabama took in her topsale and lay to under fore and aft sails.

abstract: editorials on proposal
snippet: editorials on proposal
lead_paragraph: The American Republic is engaged in a war against the rebel Confederacy, and the French Emperor has thought fit to propose a mediation between the belligerents, so that the war may be somehow or other brought to a close; or, to use his own words, he desires to "obtain an armistice for six months, during which every act of war, direct or indirect, should provisionally cease on sea as well as on land, and it might be, if necessary, ulteriorly prolonged." Now, it so happens that this same French Emperor is himself, at this moment, engaged in a war -- a war with the Government and people of Mexico -- which struggle has been raging more than a year upon the American Continent, and is watched by us with painful interest -- just as His Majesty watches ours. We have observed the most strict neutrality in the struggle. Even now the sentiments dictated to us have undergone no change but of a benevolent character. That neutrality ought to make us of service to the two parties, by helping them out of a position which seems to have no issue. After more than a year's efforts to subjugate Mexico, the French are now nearly in the same position as at first. They have, it is true, seized by their gunboats two or three towns on the coast, but they have not yet captured the Mexican Capital -- any more than our army has captured Richmond. Nothing authorises the presumption that more decisive military operations will shortly occur, according to the latest news received. The French and Mexican armies, on the contrary, were in a condition that would not allow either party to hope within a brief delay for any decided advantage to turn the balance and accelerate the conclusion of a peace.

abstract: THE GERMANS FOR HAWS FOR COMPTROLLER. --The adopted citizens of German birth very generally support HAWS for Comptroller. We are assured that a large German Democractic Club, in the Seventeenth Ward, went so far as to indorse HAWS as their candidate for Comptroller on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: THE GERMANS FOR HAWS FOR COMPTROLLER. -- The adopted citizens of German birth very generally support HAWS for Comptroller. We are assured that a large German Democractic Club, in the Seventeenth Ward, went so far as to indorse HAWS as their candidate for Comptroller on Wednesday night. In making a ticket to suit the Irish voters of the City, the Democratic leaders have made a double mistake, in the first place, the real representative Irishman, RICHARD O'GORMAN, Esq., was ignored; and in the second place, these gentlemen made the ticket a little too strong in that respect to suit the Germans and Americans, whose votes are necessary in the success of the candidates to be voted for on Tuesday next. If the Germans vote for HAWS in a mass, as is now among the probabilities of the times, he must be elected. This class of our citizens almost to a man voted for SEYMOUR at the late State election.

abstract: -- We are highly gratified to learn, from a gentleman who has the most intimate knowledge of the condition of the poor, and of the public charities of New-York, that the amount of want and the calls for charitable assistance in the City are less at this period than they have been at the opening of any recent Winter. There was a great diminution in poverty last Winter from previous years, and this Winter, it seems, we are to have very much less than we had even last year. No fact bearing upon our social condition can be more cheering to us all than this.

abstract: Major FREUDENBERG, of the Fifty-second NewYork Volunteers, (German,) has come to this city, by order of the War Department, to fill up the ranks of his regiment. This gallant and now war-worn body of men was organized in New-York, and left for Washington on the 11th of November, 1861.
lead_paragraph: Major FREUDENBERG, of the Fifty-second NewYork Volunteers, (German,) has come to this city, by order of the War Department, to fill up the ranks of his regiment. This gallant and now war-worn body of men was organized in New-York, and left for Washington on the 11th of November, 1861. It camped for a fortnight near Bladensburgh, and was then ordered to join the Brigade of Gen. FRENCH (now commanding a Division) in SUMNER's Division (now commanding a Grand Division) in "Camp California," near Alexandria. It marched at the head of the column to Manassas, and subsequently to Warrentown Junction. It went with MCCLELLAN to the Peninsula, and was present at the siege of Yorktown. It took part in the battle of Fair Oaks, when it was placed in the foremost line; and during the fight it was pitted against five rebel regiments, and lost one half of its men -- for its bravery and good behavior on which occasion it received the warm acknowledgments of Gens. FRENCH and SUMNER. It continued in the most active service during the entire period of the campaign before Richmond -- fighting heroically in the fierce contests at Savage Station, White Oak Swamp, and Malvern Hill. The regiment left the Peninsula, and went up to take part in POPE's campaign, on which occasion it covered, with SUMNER's corps, the retreat from Centerville. It accompanied MCCLELLAN from Washington into Maryland, and at the battle of Antietam (in RICHARDSON's Division,) it was in the advance. In this Maryland campaign it was under a rebel artillery fire for two days and nights, and faced the columns of rebel infantry on the two following days. It is now in the front line, opposite Fredericksburgh, on the banks of the Rappahannock. Such are some of the exploits of this renowned Teutonic regiment whose thinned ranks now require to be filled up. Major FREUDENBERG himself has been in the forefront of the regiment through all these battles, and a better and a braver soldier never wielded a blade in the cause of freedom.
headline: {'main': 'The Fifty-second New-York Regiment.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Fifty-second New-York Regiment.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- Our Democratic friends do not appear to be as confident of success at the municipal election as we had supposed they would be, after they succeeded in getting all the stump candidates to withdraw. They have evidently been looking over the figures of the election in 1858, which we must say has not a very encouraging look for their success on Tuesday next, especially when we take into consideration the fact that a large number of their best workers are disheartened and disgusted by the manner in which they have been sold out by the packed Committee, that arrogated to itself the duty of saying who should be the regular Democratic candidates for Comptroller and Counsel to the Corporation. The following are the figures as shown by the returns of the election in 1858:

abstract: There is no news of stirring importance from the Army of the Potomac this morning. Fredericksburgh, we learn, is not occupied by the rebels in force, merely a picket guard being there on duty. Business, however, is totally suspended, and the only flag visible is one of Great Britain, flying from a private residence. The President, on Wednesday, paid a visit to Gen. BURNSIDE, meeting him at Belleplaine. The interview is understood to have been an important one.

abstract: editorial lauds triumph of emancipation in elections; editorial lauds triumph of emancipation in elections
snippet: editorial lauds triumph of emancipation in elections; editorial lauds triumph of emancipation in elections
lead_paragraph: The late remarkable emancipation triumph in Missouri, all admit, was due not only to the great positive progress of Anti-Slavery sentiment, but in considerable measure to the absence from the polls of large numbers who were not willing to take the oath of allegiance, to which every man offering to vote was by law subjected, if challenged. Probably some twenty thousand thus disfranchised themselves. Whatever the figure, they were all reduced to an absolute cypher by this simple test.

abstract: Rev. Dr. POTTS preached, in the Presbyterian Church, corner of University-place and Tenth-street, an earnest and impressive discourse on the necessity of National Repentance, as the only means of securing a return of national peace and prosperity. He believed that we were undergoing a just punishment at the hands of the Almighty for our forgetfulness of Him, -- for our national pride, our self-reliance, and for the political and social corruptions which have grown out of this feeling. Even now, in the very crisis of our fate, we were relying, he said, far more on the skill of individual Generals, on our superior resources, and on the justice of our cause, far more than on the aid and support of God. We must seek that aid by prayer, by profound humiliation, and sincere repentance for our national and individual sins.

abstract: Yesterday a petition was presented to Judge MANIERRE setting forth that the son of the relator was restrained of his liberty by Brig.-Gen. TYLER, in Camp Douglas, under the pretence that he was an enlisted soldier of the United States; that he was under 18 years of age at the time of such pretended enlistment, and was never sworn into the service, and praying that a writ of habeas corpus might be issued for his discharge. The application was resisted, and by Col. COWEN, Provost-Marshal of Camp Douglas, on the ground that Gen. TYLER was not bound to obey it if issued, inasmuch as martial law had been proclaimed over the camp by the President.

abstract: The church of Rev. Dr. WM. ADAMS, corner of Madison-avenue and Twenty-fourth-street, was crowded to excess yesterday morning, and the exercises were unusually interesting. Dr. ADAMS was assisted in the preliminary services by Rev. Mr. FIELD; and the choir, comprising WM. H. PLATT, the leader, Dr. FLINT, organist, Mrs. TALLMAN, alto, Mr. FROST, basso, and an effective chorus, supplied some exquisite music. Major-Gen. and Mrs. MCCLELLAN were among the congregation, though unobserved, except in their immediate vicinity, until the close of the services.

abstract: Editorial cites instances of Confederate atrocities as means of retaliation
snippet: Editorial cites instances of Confederate atrocities as means of retaliation
lead_paragraph: A question has arisen in Missouri between a Union officer and the rebel Government, which demands the prompt attention of our authorities at Washington. We find in yesterday's Tribune a statement of the case. ANDREW ALLSMAN, an old resident of Palmyra, Mo., was a well known adherent of the Union cause, and had made himself especially valuable to our armies by his services as a guide. When the rebel Gen. PORTER descended upon Palmyra he took ALLSMAN prisoner. When Gen. MCNEIL, commanding the Union forces, returned to Palmyra, he heard of this capture and wrote to PORTER demanding his return, alive and unharmed, within ten days, and threatened, in case this demand was not complied with, to execute ten persons whom he held as rebel prisoners. So far as appears this demand was not delivered to PORTER, though the Tribune says that it was "widely published," and that " as PORTER was known to be in Northeast Missouri during the specified ten days, it is impossible but that he became apprised of Gen. MCNEIL's determination." At all events, no word came in reply, and accordingly on the 18th of October the following ten men held by Gen. MCNEIL as prisoners, were shot by his orders:

abstract: THANKSGIVING IN BROOKLYN.--This anniversary was observed in the usual manner. The city had the appearance of a Sunday. Business was suspended, with the exception of the liquor saloons.
lead_paragraph: THANKSGIVING IN BROOKLYN. -- This anniversary was observed in the usual manner. The city had the appearance of a Sunday. Business was suspended, with the exception of the liquor saloons. Still, there was no drunkenness observable about the streets. The only public demonstration was made by the firemen. Engines Nos. Three, Seven and Seventeen went to New-York to participate in a test of the capacity of the different machines at the pole corner of West Broadway and Franklin-street. Engine Company No. Nineteen brought home their new engine, built at New-Haven, and placed it in their house in Pacific-street. Engine Company No. Twenty-two received their renewed apparatus from New-York, and had an interesting time at their headquarters in Degraw-street in honor of the event. Independent of these matters, a general dullness prevailed.
