abstract: IRVING HALL.--Miss TERESA CARRENO'S debut, on Tuesday night, more than fulfilled the promise of her private performances, to which we have before referred. She deserves to be ranked, not as a child-wonder, who at the age of eight years has vanquished nearly all the technical difficulties of the piano, but as an artist of first-class sensibility.
lead_paragraph: IRVING HALL. -- Miss TERESA CARRENO's debut, on Tuesday night, more than fulfilled the promise of her private performances, to which we have before referred. She deserves to be ranked, not as a child-wonder, who at the age of eight years has vanquished nearly all the technical difficulties of the piano, but as an artist of first-class sensibility. Her perception of musical meaning; the clearness with which she sees, and the delicate skill with which she executes passages that are ornate or obscure, belong only to the better rank of performers, and are in fact characteristics that cannot be attained by study. It is not difficult to trace in the charming face and graceful figure of this beautiful child the indications of an extraordinary nature, and music -- as plainly -- is one of its healthiest and most genuine manifestations. She has an instinct for art which leads her to its beauties, and overcomes all obstacles in her search for them. Three pieces -- without counting the encores -- so different in style as those on Miss CORRENO's programme, would have taxed the powers of the best player. They were interpreted easily by the young lady -- with abundant technical skill, good force and quality of tone, and the nicest of expression. Her success was of course complete, but not more so than the admirable merit of the performance justified.

abstract: Observances, NYC churches
snippet: Observances, NYC churches
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was in reality, a day of thanksgiving and praise to the God of the Universe. On no similar occasion have we observed so general an attendance at the churches of all denominations, and at no time have we been called to chronicle a more hearty and all-pervading spirit of thankful recognition of the Divine mercy and goodness which have showered such plentiful blessings upon the nations making its path plain, its duties bearable, its energies competent for the assigned duty, and its prosperity so general.

abstract: This institution is under the care of a Board of Trustees, selected from four denominations of Christians, and was formerly superintended by Rev. Mr. PEASE, but is now in charge of Mr. BENJAMIN R. BARLOW and four assistants, and furnishes homes and clothing to destitute children round the Five Points.
lead_paragraph: This institution is under the care of a Board of Trustees, selected from four denominations of Christians, and was formerly superintended by Rev. Mr. PEASE, but is now in charge of Mr. BENJAMIN R. BARLOW and four assistants, and furnishes homes and clothing to destitute children round the Five Points. One hundred and thirty-five children live altogether in the house, and there is an average daily attendance at the school of 350. Eight hundred meals are also furnished daily to children round the Points. A most bountiful dinner was supplied to over 600 children yesterday, which was furnished by voluntary contribution from the various hotels, markets, groceries, bakers, &c., and from other generous sources.

abstract: Editorial says effective blockade of Charleston is hopeless
snippet: Editorial says effective blockade of Charleston is hopeless
lead_paragraph: ceived from Nassau (N.P.) last night, we learn that two rebel steamers from Charleston arrived at that port on the 20th instant-- Thursday of last week. There were two other steamers to the port of Charleston when these vessels left. It would thus seem that the trade of Charleston is still very brisk. Prior to the rebellion, it would have been thought a very wonderful thing to see four sea-going steamships in that harbor at one time; and such a thing as four steamships, or one steamship, engaged in foreign trade from Charleston would have raised the commercial prospects of the city to the highest pitch.

abstract: THE NEW-JERSEY LEGISLATURE.--The organization of the next Legislature is already engaging the attention of Democratic politicians. For the principal positions--the Clerkships of the House and Senate, there are a number of candidates. For Clerk of the House, Messrs. H.C. KELSEY, of the Sussex ...
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-JERSEY LEGISLATURE. -- The organization of the next Legislature is already engaging the attention of Democratic politicians. For the principal positions--the Clerkships of the House and Senate, there are a number of candidates. For Clerk of the House, Messrs. H.C. KELSEY, of the Sussex Herald; JOHN H. MEEKER, of Newark, and ALEX, M. JOHNSON, of Trenton, are principally named -- the chances being in favor of the former, who was promised the place last year. For Secretary of the Senate, MORRIS R. HAMILTON, of the Camden Democrat, has the inside track, having already served one session. It is now said that the Legislature will elect a United States Senator in place of Hon. R.S. FIELD (recently appointed by Gov. OLDEN, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Hon. J.R. THOMSON, whose term expired on the 4th of March,) immediately upon its organization -- the "party" being greatly incensed at Mr. FIELD's appointment, he being considered a "radical." As the Legislature meets on the 13th of January, any successor that body may appoint will have some seven or eight weeks to serve up to the 4th of March. It is now thought that Gen WM. COOK, who has intimate relations with the Camden and Amboy Railroad, will be appointed for this brief term -- a somewhat barren honor, we opine, and that Hon. WM. WRIGHT will be elected for the regular term of six years. Mr. WRIGHT is currently reported to be expending large sums of money from his liberal fortune, with a view to secure his election.

abstract: The organization of a regiment of black soldiers, under the direction of Brig.-Gen. SAXTON, I am told is progressing finely. I have often expressed my strong conviction that the negroes would show themselves courageous and worthy of their freedom ...
lead_paragraph: The organization of a regiment of black soldiers, under the direction of Brig.-Gen. SAXTON, I am told is progressing finely. I have often expressed my strong conviction that the negroes would show themselves courageous and worthy of their freedom, if ever the opportunity was offered them to fight, and recent events have fully justified this opinion. You have already received an account of a successful expedition of one of the tugboats with a company of armed blacks to Sapelo River and other places on the Georgia coast, where they were for the first time under fire, and acquitted themselves bravely in an engagement with their former masters, protecting the flight of a large number of their race who sought to escape the horrors of bondage. That success led to the projection of another enterprise, which, in brilliancy and practical value surpasses the first. Three companies of these South Carolina Volunteers, Capis. TROWBRIGDE, JANES and RANDOLPH's, under the command of Lieut.-Col. BEARD, Provost-Marshal under Gen. SAXTON, left Beaufort on the 13th inst., in the steamers Ben. Deford and Darlington, going to Doboy Sound, Georgia, and remaining there a week, returning with with two hundred thousand feet of the best Georgia pine lumber, sawed and ready for use. This was taken from HAWKINS's, TODD's and BLUE's mills on the mainland, directly in face of the rebels, who gave the black soldiers an opportunity to test their pluck on shord as they had previously on a tug-boat, where they fuoght with the advantage of a partial barricade. While most of the negroes were engaged in loading the steamers with lumber, the company of Capt. JANES advanced on a reconnoissance, and were opened upon with musketry by the rebels, from a position in ambush.

abstract: A DINNER FOR THE NEW-HAMPSHIRE SIXTEENTH.--There was considerable trouble at the encampment of the Sixteenth New-Hampshire at the Battery Barracks, on Thursday, owing to the fact that the meat served them for their rations was tainted-- some of it being almost putrid.
lead_paragraph: A DINNER FOR THE NEW-HAMPSHIRE SIXTEENTH. -- There was considerable trouble at the encampment of the Sixteenth New-Hampshire at the Battery Barracks, on Thursday, owing to the fact that the meat served them for their rations was tainted-- some of it being almost putrid. A large number of the men were marched to different eating-saloons, where they found some susceptible of being eaten without offering a direct insult to the palate. A meeting of a number of the Sons of New-Hampshire was held in parlor C of the Brandreth House, yesterday morning, for the purpose of making arrangements for furnishing the men with a good turkey dinner to-day. This would have been done Thursday, but it was impossible to make all the necessary preparations by that time. The regiment will therefore partake of its Thanksgiving dinner to-day.

abstract: editorial favors Mr. Haws for Comptroller
snippet: editorial favors Mr. Haws for Comptroller
lead_paragraph: We have very little to say about the election of Comptoller on Tuesday next. If the great body of the people of this City prefer to give control of their finances to a man whose only claim to their votes is that he has received a party nomination, rather than to reelect one who has proved himself in every respect competent and most admirably qualified for the place, they are at perfect liberty to do so. It is a free country, and every man has a right to select precisely such persons to manage his affairs as he thinks best.

abstract: BROOKLYN REGIMENTS.--Messrs. BOOTH and TUTTLE, the Committee of the Board of Supervisors, to whom was intrusted the money appropriated by the authorities for paying bounties to soldiers enlisted in Kings County, have concluded their labors.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN REGIMENTS. -- Messrs. BOOTH and TUTTLE, the Committee of the Board of Supervisors, to whom was intrusted the money appropriated by the authorities for paying bounties to soldiers enlisted in Kings County, have concluded their labors. These gentlemen have been constantly engaged in this business for the past three months, during which time they have disbursed several hundred thousand dollars. Yesterday they visited the camp of the One Hundred and Seventy-fifth Regiment at East New-York, and the Ironsides Regiment at Jamaica. Nearly $4,000 was distributed among the men. The latter had been provided on the day previous with three wagon loads of pumpkin pies and 150 turkeys, with which they were enabled to observe Thanksgiving in a becoming manner. The articles were furnished by the ladies of the village, to whom the soldiers return their sincere thanks. Some other regiments did not fare so well. There has of late been a great accumulation of soldiers at East New-York. Several New-York regiments, and all from the Eastern States, are emcamped between that point and Jamaica. The road is lined with tents the entire distance, presenting a scene well worth a visit. Yesterday the Twenty-eighth Maine Regiment was added to the number. They arrived in Brooklyn the night previous, and having no place to sleep, were generously provided with quarters by Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, who opened his church for their accommodation. Yesterday morning the regiment was taken to the Park Barracks, in New-York, and furnished with breakfast. After which they returned and marched to East New-York. The regiment numbers almost 1,000 men, under command of Col. WOODMAN. Last evening the Fifty-sixth Massachusetts Regiment returned to the City for the purpose of embarking for the seat of war. It is expected that all the regiments will take up their line of march on Monday next. Although it is understood that they will join the expedition under Gen. BANKS, nothing appears to be known as to their destination. The One Hundred and Fifty-ninth New-York Regiment is now on board the steamer Northern Light awaiting orders. The Colonel, Hon H.A. NELSON, having been elected to Congress, resigned his position, and the Lieutenant-Colonel, E.L. MOLINEUX, has been appointed to fill the vacancy. He received his commission from the Governor yesterday.

abstract: Danforth N. Barney vs. The President, Directors and Company of the Globe Bank of Boston.--This was was a motion on the part of the plaintiff to remand the cause to the Supreme Court of this State, where it was commenced. The plaintiff is a citizen of New-York, and the defendants are a Corporation, located in Massachusetts. The plaintiff sued as ...
lead_paragraph: Danforth N. Barney vs. The President, Directors and Company of the Globe Bank of Boston.--This was was a motion on the part of the plaintiff to remand the cause to the Supreme Court of this State, where it was commenced. The plaintiff is a citizen of New-York, and the defendants are a Corporation, located in Massachusetts. The plaintiff sued assignee of the Merchants' Bank or Cleveland, Ohio, to recover damages for the alleged neglect of the defendants to protest certain notes, &c., forwarded to them by the Merchants' Bank, as required by the course of business between the parties. The action was commenced by the publication of a summons under the provisions of the 135th section of the Code of Procedure; an attachment was subsequently issued, and property of the defendants attached. The defendants thereupon appealed in the action, and filed their petition under the 12th section of the Judiciary act for the removal of the cause to this Court. The order of removal was granted by the Supreme Court, and the action was entered in this Court. The plaintiff now moved to remand the case upon four grounds, to wit: 1. That this is not a "suit" within the meaning of that 12th section of the Judiciary act, but a mere special statutory proceeding in rem. 2. That no cases can be so removed except such as could have been originally brought in this Court, and that this case could not have been brought here, the defendants not being an inhabitant nor found in the State. 3. That the defendant is not a citizen within the meaning of that 12th section, and therefore cannot exercise the privilege of removal; and, 4. That the plaintiffs assignor could not bring this suit against the defendants in this District, and therefore the plaintiff cannot, and the jurisdiction fails.

abstract: Gets Democratic nomination for NYC Comptroller; Democratic ratification meeting held, Cooper Institute; nominates T Brennan for Comptroller; others on election ticket listed
snippet: Gets Democratic nomination for NYC Comptroller; Democratic ratification meeting held, Cooper Institute; nominates T Brennan for Comptroller; others on election ticket listed
lead_paragraph: Last evening, a Democratic meeting, slimly attended, was, held in Cooper Institute, in order to ratify the nomination of MATTHEW T. BRENNAN, as Comptroller, and JOHN E. DEVELIN, as Corporation Counsel. Until the arrival of ELIJAH F. PURDY, Hon. AUGUSTUS BELMONT was elected Chairman, who, upon taking the Chair, said that he considered that the coming municipal election would have a vast national importance. The voice of the Democratic Party had already spoken by the election of HORATIO SEYMOUR for Governor. [Cheers.] This election had already had its effect all over the Union, for, even in Connecticut, where, for the last twenty years, no Democratic majority had been given, now it was largely ahead. Abolitionism soon receive its death blow, and the Union would be restored as it was, and the Constitution as it is.

abstract: Feckheimer vs. Distz.--The defendant is the proprietor of the Prescott House in this City, and the plaintiff sues him to recover the value of a gold watch alleged to have been stolen from the plaintiff while a guest at defendant's hotel. It appears that the plaintiff, together with two friends, occupied adjoining rooms; one of his friends left the room about 6 o'clock ...
lead_paragraph: Feckheimer vs. Distz. -- The defendant is the proprietor of the Prescott House in this City, and the plaintiff sues him to recover the value of a gold watch alleged to have been stolen from the plaintiff while a guest at defendant's hotel. It appears that the plaintiff, together with two friends, occupied adjoining rooms; one of his friends left the room about 6 o'clock in the morning, and plaintiff omitted to lock the door after him, but went to sleep again. On rising, about 9 o'clock, he discovered that his watch was missing, having evidently been taken from his room by a thief. The defence set up, was the plaintiff's negligence in leaving his door unfastened, without which negligence on plaintiff's part the loss would not have occurred.

abstract: Brig.-Gen. WADSWORTH arrived at his home of Genesee on Monday. In reply to a speech of welcome from major HANDEL, the General made a few remarks alluding to the late canvass, and the many personal assaults made upon himself, but in no spirit of censure or recrimination.
lead_paragraph: Brig.-Gen. WADSWORTH arrived at his home of Genesee on Monday. In reply to a speech of welcome from major HANDEL, the General made a few remarks alluding to the late canvass, and the many personal assaults made upon himself, but in no spirit of censure or recrimination. He, however, wished to allude to one slander of the Press which had just come to his notice, and that was that he had at one time telegraphed DEAN RICHMOND regarding an opportunity to secure a "good thing" in a Government contract. This he denounced as a falsehood and forgery, as he had never had a penny's interest in such a contract -- nor desired to have -- or telegraphed anybody on the subject.

abstract: GERMAN OPERA.--LORTZING's comic opera, "Der Wildsehutz" (the Poacher,) was produced here lastnight with a degree of uproarious success that will justify its repetition on many succeeding evenings. It is a work peculiarly German in character, and depending largely on dialogue and jocularity of a provincial kind.
lead_paragraph: GERMAN OPERA. -- LORTZING's comic opera, "Der Wildsehutz" (the Poacher,) was produced here lastnight with a degree of uproarious success that will justify its repetition on many succeeding evenings. It is a work peculiarly German in character, and depending largely on dialogue and jocularity of a provincial kind. But to the American who understands a little German there is sufficient of broad, hearty humor to keep him in merriment from the opening scene to the final one. The music is in the happiest vein of the composer -- who, we may take this occasion to say, is not sufficiently known to our public. It is full of freshness and gaiety, and is amply filled with melodies, moreover, that are taking to the average ear. The performance last evening was extremely good. Herr GRAFF, who played the part of Baculus, the Schoolmaster, displayed an unctious vein of comicality which we hardly gave him credit for possessing. Without sacrificing the musical opportunities of his role he succeeded in keeping the house in a roar. Mme. JOHANSSEN was admirable also, as the Baroness Freimann, and a lady whose name we have not met before -- Mme. SCHAUMBERG -- made a favorable impression as Grettchen. The remaining characters were sustained with spirit and success by Messrs. WEINLICH, QUINT and KRONFELD. We have always to praise the orchestra and chorus at the German Theatre, and may unhesitatingly do so on the present occasion. Rarely have we sat out a performance that gave so much genuine satisfaction, or obtained so merited and unequivocal a success. "Der Wildschutz" will be repeated to-night (Saturday.)

abstract: editorial on public apathy over imminent battle
snippet: editorial on public apathy over imminent battle
lead_paragraph: There is an amazing degree of apathy on the part of they public in regard to the present face-to-face antagonism of the National and rebel armies, on the Rappahannock. We cannot account for it on the ground of unconsciousness of the position. Every citizen of the loyal North who reads knows that Gen. BURNSIDE has led his grand army, by a sudden oblique movement, from the line of the Blue Ridge toward Fredericksburgh, and that Gen. LEE, not at all blinded by the strategy, immediately began to concentrate his whole army at Fredericksburgh to oppose him. For ten days the two armies have been confronting each other in force, only a narrow stream dividing them, and the pickets indulging in colloquies, not unfrequently within fifty yards of each other.
headline: {'main': 'The Prelude of Battle.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Prelude of Battle.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial on relationship between a general's popularity and his political party

lead_paragraph: The Brookly Eagle gives the statement of Col. J.E. McLEAN, a native of Tennessee, but a son-inlaw of a well-known dentist in Brooklyn, who was captured by the rebels in September last as he was leaving Nashville for the North. Col. McLEAN has been a persistent Union man, and raised and organized the Second Tennessee loyal regiment. After his capture he was first taken to Chattanooga, thence to Richmond, and subsequently to Chattanooga again.

abstract: -- The Common Council of Newark are taking measures to disband a number of the hand-engine companies, and substitute steam fire engines and horse hose companies. There are already three steam fire engines in the Department, and it is contemplated to at once increase the umber to six. There is also one horse hose company in the Department. It is estimated that a saving of at least $12,000 per annum will be effected by the substitution of steamers for the present hand-engines.

abstract: A gentleman direct from Fort Henry, informs us that, at the time he left, the river was still too low for any but very light boats, with light loads, as far up as the mouth of Sandy, which is four miles above Fort Henry.
lead_paragraph: A gentleman direct from Fort Henry, informs us that, at the time he left, the river was still too low for any but very light boats, with light loads, as far up as the mouth of Sandy, which is four miles above Fort Henry. An empty steamer of the smallest size cannot pass the obstructions at and near Duck River Suck. The obstructions are of two kinds; one consists of bars and chains of rocks, the other of NAPPIER's regiment of guerrillas, with some artillery, located so as to command the river at the obstructed point. The artillery were taken off the boats burnt at this point, early last Summer, by these same rebels. A rise of water, and Col. LOWE's military operations will probably relieve the enemy of both between this and Christmas. Our informant has been among the people of that region considerably, and talked with them freely, and finds them sick of the war and anxious for peace, or a truce, or any arrangement that will stop the fighting even for a time, and he finds that they are determined to plant cotton and tobacco next year as early as possible. This year they were deterred from planting more than small patches, not the tenth part of the usual crops.

abstract: About 2 o'clock yesterday morning, an affray occurred among some noted politicians of the First Ward, during which THOMAS BYRNES was fatally shot in the abdomen with a pistol in the hands of DENNIS P. SULLIVAN.
lead_paragraph: About 2 o'clock yesterday morning, an affray occurred among some noted politicians of the First Ward, during which THOMAS BYRNES was fatally shot in the abdomen with a pistol in the hands of DENNIS P. SULLIVAN. The latter wasimmediately arrested and confined in the Tombs. BYRNES was taken to the New-York Hospital, and late in the afternoon Coroner COLLIN made an ante-mortem examination of the victim, who died shortly afterwards.

abstract: About thirty years ago, the classic land of Greece fell into trouble all about its Government, and, after a brief and very exciting struggle, the stronger Powers of Europe undertook, with characteristic parental solicitude, to provide the Greeks with a monarchy.
lead_paragraph: About thirty years ago, the classic land of Greece fell into trouble all about its Government, and, after a brief and very exciting struggle, the stronger Powers of Europe undertook, with characteristic parental solicitude, to provide the Greeks with a monarchy. They gave them OTHO, a young Prince of Bavaria, for King. At first the settlement seemed satisfactory. OTHO was a young man, of whom nothing was as yet known, and against whom, therefore, nothing ill could be said. It was easy to predict of him all that was valiant, able and true; and the Greeks, for whom he was imported, were ready to hope all things and believe all things, as they had so lately in their revolution been enduring all things.

abstract: All the ordinary pleas for non-intervention fail in this case. That we have the right to interfere is  amply established by the precedents of Greece and Belgium.
lead_paragraph: All the ordinary pleas for non-intervention fail in this case. That we have the right to interfere is amply established by the precedents of Greece and Belgium. That we should do any injustice by interfering is obviously false; interference is needed only to check a wanton aggression and to assist a brave, orderly, and unanimous people in rescuing their soil from the hordes of a barbarous invader. That we have no interest in interfering no honest man pretends to think, and became man dares to argue. Two years ago our chief manufacture was in a condition of especial prosperity now it is entirely suspended. Its raw material exists in plenty: it could be supplied in abundance for the future, if only we took means to secure its safe conveyance to this country. Until the war began the operatives of Lancashire were happy, contented, industrious, thriving. They had ample wages, cheerful homed, money laid by; they were learning to improve their condition and prospects by means of those cooperative states, with whose name and nature most of our readers are familiar. The blockade has ruined everything. It has closed the cooperative stores; it has emptied the savings banks; it has swept away the little provision which thrift and forethought had made for a time of pressure; it has turned happy homes into houses of mourning; it has extinguished the fires on cheerful hearths; it has taken the work from industrious hands and the bread from mouths unused to want; it has robbed half a million of people of the furniture, the clothing, the comforts they had acquired by a lifetime of honest and skillful labor; it has pauperized the most prosperous, proudest and most intelligent working population in the world. Ten years of war could not have done us half so much harm. And now, though these sufferers have a bare supply of food, and efforts are being made to give them fuel and clothing, we find that they are likely to perish by famine, if not of it. The diseases which famine breeds are making rapid progress among them; and there seems great reason to fear that, if the blockade lasts six months longer, the people of Lancashire will be decimated by a pestilence scarcely less deadly than the plague or the yellow fever -- a pestilence due to want alone -- to that want which has been created by the American blockade. And for the life of every man who dies by that pestilence her Majesty's Ministers are now solely and absolutely responsible. Whether their own consciences will ever forgive them we cannot pretend to say; their country never will.

abstract: After the sun had gone on the bloody field of Perry ville, and the gloom of evening overhung the scene of carnage and death, even then, at intervals, bodies of the two armies would occasionally come in collision.
lead_paragraph: After the sun had gone on the bloody field of Perry ville, and the gloom of evening overhung the scene of carnage and death, even then, at intervals, bodies of the two armies would occasionally come in collision. Brig.-Gen. CLAIBOURNE's command, with which was Gen. POLK, just at nightfall came upon an Indiana regiment. Gen. POLK was some distance in advance of our troops, and suddenly found himself in the very midst of the Indianians, who were firing briskly upon CLAIBOURNE's columns. Gen. POLK, seizing the Indiana Colonel by the shoulder, demanded, "Why he was firing upon his friends?" The Colonel said that he did not know that he was guilty of such a blunder, and asked, "Who are you?" "I'll show you who I am," said Gen. POLK, and then, raising in his stirrups, he gave the order to the Indianians to "Cease firing!" Saying to the Colonel, "You shall at once hear from me, sir," POLK rode quietly away, and as soon as he was out of sight, with accelerated velocity came dashing at headlong speed to the spot where Gen. CLAIBOURNE stood. Pointing to the Yankees, he exclaimed, "Let them have it, boys, they are Yankees; I've been there." Gen. POLK said afterward that he counted not less than fifteen balls as they penetrated his back while he rode away from the Indianians. We are happy to advise our readers that, on his arrival at this place Gen. POLK had entirely recovered from his imagined wounds; in fact, he wears a charmed life. He has never been wounded, neither at Belmont, Shiloh, Farmington, nor Perryville, at each of which places he exposed himself to needless dangers.

abstract: The English Ministers are far too practical and skilful politicians not to understand that the separation between the two factions of the American Republic is definitive, and that cannon balls are power...
lead_paragraph: The English Ministers are far too practical and skilful politicians not to understand that the separation between the two factions of the American Republic is definitive, and that cannon balls are poweress to patch up the dissevered Union. Several of the members of the Cabinet have already publicly expressed themselves on the subject in terms which allow no doubt to be entertained as to their convictions. To what, therefore, must their present dilatory system be ascribed. Hesitation would be conceivable if it were proposed to resort to a formed mediation or an effective intervention which might involve in mere active measures the powers which underlock it, but when it is only contemplated to recommended to the belligerents and [???] statistics, in order to enable diplomacy to seek out, and possibly to discover, association in conformity with the dignity and the interest of both parties, even with the certaintyof failure, hesitation is incomprehensible.Public opinion, unconvince by the [???] by England, will most certainly ascribe to otherreasons and to hidden motives her inexplicable [???]. Does she wish to behold the examination of both combatants, the miserable death in [???] of civil war of a rival the greatness of which has always caused her such great alarm?

abstract: -- It is certainly a most extraordinary thing that President LINCOLN should allow our Government to stand un-represented, at this all-important moment; at the Court of the Czar. We believe that Mr. CAMERON has not resigned his position as Minister, but has merely come back to this country to look after his private interests, and in case he should fail to be elected to the United States Senate by the Legislature of Pennsylvania -- which is not very likely -- he will return again, in his official capacity, to St. Petersburgh. But, really, it is impossible to conceive that the Government allows such considerations as this to enter into its calculations of duty. If Mr. CAMERON does not resign, he should at once be displaced; and if there be, anywhere, a man distinguished above all others for ability, honorable character, diplomatic skill, and pure loyalty, he should be sent to represent this nation before the Czar.

abstract: SON, at Lagrange, and Gen. HAMILTON, from Grand, Junction to Corinth. The widest gaps are between Memphis and Moscow, and for ten or fifteen miles west of Corinth, but the whole distance of those unoccupied spaces is scouted every day, and communication is open along the entire line from Memphis to Pittsburgh Landing, about a hundred and twenty miles. This is the front of the Army of Tennessee soon, it may be hopes, to be called the Army of Mississippi.

abstract: A correspondent of the Mobile Tribune states that there are now at the salt mines in Clark County, Ala., two or three regiments of conscripts, who, to avoid the draft, have taken themselves there.
lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the Mobile Tribune states that there are now at the salt mines in Clark County, Ala., two or three regiments of conscripts, who, to avoid the draft, have taken themselves there. Some of these shirkers of military duty are charging $75 a sack to the families of brave men who are in the army battling for their rights and property. Gov. SHORTER, or the Confederate authorities, ought to take the matter in hand. Men who can extort from the families of poor men who are in their country's service, are destitute of humanity and patriotism.

abstract: DR. BROWNE, THE ALLEGED ABORTIONIST, TO BE EXAMINED.--In the Court of General Sessions yesterday morning, Mr. SPENCER, counsel for Dr. BROWNE, sued out a writ of certiorari--a writ which takes the case to a higher tribunal.
lead_paragraph: DR. BROWNE, THE ALLEGED ABORTIONIST, TO BE EXAMINED.--In the Court of General Sessions yesterday morning, Mr. SPENCER, counsel for Dr. BROWNE, sued out a writ of certiorari--a writ which takes the case to a higher tribunal. Judge MCCUNN grantedthe writ -- the District-Attorney assenting; and itwas then agreed that the Doctor should be examinedbefore Judge MCCUNN on Wednesday next, at 2 B. M. Counsel visited Dr. BROWNE in the afternoon, and in reply to some question, the latter stated that he regarded his coviction as a foregone conclusion, and said. " They will send me up the river and place me in a hospital." An effort will be made by his counsel to exclude the testimony of AUGUSTUS L. SIMMS.

abstract: -- The Submissionists manifest a disposition to cavil at the summary proceedings of Gen. BUTLER in dealing with the rebels of the Lafourche District of Louisiana. They hold up their hands in horror at the proposed confiscation of the property of a rebel district, and aver that such proceedings must hasten that foreign intervention which they deem inevitable. But no one can peruse the order of Gen. BUTLER in the premises without a conviction of the masterly skill, as well as humane justice with which the rights of loyal citizens of the district in question are protected. The most scrupulous care is taken to guard the constitutional rights of all. In this respect BUTLER's order bears a striking resemblance to the President's Emancipation Proclamation. Both documents are directed in the most plain and unmistakable terms at the property of rebels, and of rebels alone. Those who would oppose the spirit of either, must of necessity place themselves in the attitude of defending the property of rebels. Such a position is quite untenable, since if we have the right to take the life of a rebel, there can be little doubt of our right to confiscate his property.
lead_paragraph: -- The Submissionists manifest a disposition to cavil at the summary proceedings of Gen. BUTLER in dealing with the rebels of the Lafourche District of Louisiana. abstract: Gen. JOHN H. MORGAN, a few days since came across a mail stage traveling the route between Bowling Green and Nashville. Of course, he quietly captured the affair, and became the possessor of a large quantity of Uncle Sam's postal matter. The most interesting correspondence was the letters of the various roporters for the Yankee Press -- the New-York Tribune, TIMES, &c. One of them describes the reception of ROSECRANS by the army at Bowling Green as exceedingly enthusiastic. The troops were generally distrusted with BUELL, and hailed the new chief as one certain to lead them to victory.
lead_paragraph: Gen. JOHN H. MORGAN, a few days since came across a mail stage traveling the route between Bowling Green and Nashville. Of course, he quietly captured the affair, and became the possessor of a large quantity of Uncle Sam's postal matter. The most interesting correspondence was the letters of the various roporters for the Yankee Press -- the New-York Tribune, TIMES, &c. One of them describes the reception of ROSECRANS by the army at Bowling Green as exceedingly enthusiastic. The troops were generally distrusted with BUELL, and hailed the new chief as one certain to lead them to victory.

abstract: Well may the President of the Federal Republic of North America express surprise and regret at the turn the elections have already taken in his own States.
lead_paragraph: Well may the President of the Federal Republic of North America express surprise and regret at the turn the elections have already taken in his own States. Every day renders it more evident that the people of those Northern States are discontented with the policy of Mr. LINCOLN, and are determined upon a change. There is a sort of electrical sympathy which courses through the population of this vast American nation. They act and think in masses, and they change in masses. For two years there has been one impulse which has swept all before it -- a racing tide which neither the counsels of wise men nor the lessons of misfortune could turn or stern. In mid-channel it runs as hard as ever, but it is ebbing at the shores. Everything is strange in American nomenclature. The faction who call themselves "Republicans" are those who care nothing for the Republic, but who are ready to sacrifice constitutional forms and individual liberty, civil rights, and the protection of law itself, to the one desire of vengeance. They are anything but Republicans. The only name which will describe them is that lately fixed upon them by their opponents and their victims, that of "Exterminators." They who call themselves "Democrats," on the contrary, are anything but Democrats. They are the Conservatives of this great Republic. They are for the Constitution according to WASHINGTON, for the law according to the Judges of the Supreme Court, and for the equal protection of the legal rights of all classes of the community. The Republicans are for absolute power, to be obtained by the sword, and to be exercised under the dictation of mobs led by a few frantic parsons and fanatical laymen. The Democrats are for limited power, to be exercised within the limits of the Constitution, and under the influence of the educated classes. The Republicans seem to have disgusted the unattached masses by their violence and their ill-success. The elections, thus far, are unmistakably going against them; and if the anticipations we publish to-day should be realized, and if it should turn out that New-York, New-Jersey and Massachusetts have followed the example of Pennsylvania, the first impulse will have been given to the change, and the Democrats will by peaceable or by forcible means once more obtain the direction of the policy of the Government.

lead_paragraph: Some days since the rebel Gen. PEMBERTON took the command of the Confederate forces at Jackson, Miss., in place of VAN DORN, who has, like BRAGG, been ordered to report at Richmond, to give an account of his stewardship. PEMBERTON is a Northern man by birth, and commanded at Charleston, S.C., till a short time since, when he was relieved by BEAUREGARD. We have learned by underground telegraph that PEMBERTON about a week since made an address at Brookhaven to a large number of troops assembled there. The substance of his remarks were:

abstract: The St. Louis Republican corrects the statement that Cornmodore FARRAGUT's fleet is below Vickshurgh, and that there are no other obstacles to the navigation of the river than those at that point.
lead_paragraph: The St. Louis Republican corrects the statement that Cornmodore FARRAGUT's fleet is below Vickshurgh, and that there are no other obstacles to the navigation of the river than those at that point. It says: This was the case a few months ago, but FARRAGUT, hearing that it was the intention of the rebels to erect strong batteries at Bayou Sara, above Baton Rouge, and fearing a blockade of his vessels, withdrew, and retired to New-Orleans. Since then, use has been found for the Southern fleet in the Gulf coast service, and the Confederates have been left to do pretty much as they wished on the Mississippi, between Vicksburgh and the Red River. The steamboats that ran up the latter stream and the Yazoo on the approach of our gunboats, have been brought out, and for months have been in the carrying trade from Baton Rouge to Tallalula, Miss., a distance of three hundred miles.

abstract: Editorials on work to be done by Congress when it reconvenes
snippet: Editorials on work to be done by Congress when it reconvenes
lead_paragraph: The attention of the country will now for some time to come be divided between the action of the army and the action of Congress. The military power, assembled on the banks of the Rappahannock, and the political power, which to-morrow will assemble in Washington, form the two great bodies to which are intrusted the life, the perpetuity, the honor and the glory of the nation. They are mutually dependent upon, and must mutually sustain each other. Both are the creation of the people, and both have been called into being, that they may execute the people's will.

abstract: For the neutrality of England we shall get no thanks from either North or South. By the former it will be ascribed to our fears for Canada and for our selves, by the latter to motives equally unworthy. No matter with what allies Great Britain might be associated in an offer of mediation, or in a proposal for peace, she alone would have been singled out for insult and contumely. It is almost to be regretted that France has not sought the cooperation of the other -- even the non-maritime -- powers of Europe, which would no doubt be given so far as an expression of opinion went, in her proposals for an armistice. If she did, the Americans would probably say that every nation in the world, except the British desired to see the end of this slaughter. It is certain now, that the French offer of me hat on has not been entertained at this time by Her Majesty's Government. The arguments used against cooperation with France, are, that the North would reject any armistice at a moment when their operations by sea and land are likely to be crowned with the success which, being deferred, has in its non-arrival neither sickened their heart nor paralyzed their arm. abstract: "Three cheers for ABRAHAM LINCOLN!" What do you think of that, distant reader? "Three cheers for ABRAHAM LINCOLN," called for and given by the Unionists of New-Orleans, as they marched in torchlight procession, last night. Well, the world is coming to an end -- or something. Perhaps it is the rebellion that is coming to a close. At any rate, President LINCOLN's friends spoke out last night. -- V.O. Delta.

abstract: The Sound steamboat lines between Boston and New-York (Fall River, Stonington, and Norwich) have agreed that freight shall be the same by each line, and that on and after the 25th instant four cents per foot for measurement goods be charged, and other goods as per their printed tariff. The public will, therefore, be equally treated try either line. These lines deserve well of the traveling public. Their accommodations are superb, their prices low, their rations equal to those of a first-class hotel, and no ocean steamer floats that can claim superiority to the Metropolis, of the Fall River Line, in any point whatever.

abstract: --Rev. Thomas K. Beecher, Chaplain of the regiment raised in the vicinity of Elmira, writes from near Warrenton: "I have been glad at heart to see our men in squads taking down a useless fence--by daylight--and putting the lumber to service.
lead_paragraph: -- Rev. Thomas K. Beecher, Chaplain of the regiment raised in the vicinity of Elmira, writes from near Warrenton: "I have been glad at heart to see our men in squads taking down a useless fence--by daylight--and putting the lumber to service. When they used to steal it bit by bit, the chaplain was grieved. But when the order came -- 'rise privates, take and build' -- then I felt like mixing dialects, and shouting Bully Hallelujah. We have worked on our huts two Sundays straight on. Men with axes on shoulder paraded in front of Adjutant's tent on Sunday -- the officers gave the order -- the Chaplain the justification -- "It is lawful on the Sabbath day to make a thousand men every whit whole." It is lawful to do good on the Sabbath day. If any of my brethren who dwell in parsonages and worship in sanctuaries, dissent from building log huts on Sunday, before I reason with them I shall insist that they just master the question, by taking one blanket and one ordinary sheet from their beds -- and going forth into an exposed meadow, snow three inches deep, and wind a blowing, to spend Saturday night. Next, let them be forbidden to enter any house, or take any hay, straw or shelter stuff. Compel them to hands off from all wood-piles. Somewhere about ten o'clock in the morning, Sunday, give the good man an axe and a Bible, and tell him to find his duty and do it, and, my word for it, he will build log shelters all day Sunday, quietly saying: "How much better is a man than a beast. It is lawful to do good on the Sabbath day. I will chop and build."
